webTitle: The best icecream scene:  American Psycho

fields.headline: The best icecream scene:  American Psycho
fields.trailText: Manhattan. Wall Street broker Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale) has taken his secretary Jean (Chloe Sevigny) back to his apartment after a meal out. She is obviously smitten.
fields.body:
Manhattan. Wall Street broker Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale) has taken his secretary Jean (Chloe Sevigny) back to his apartment after a meal out. She is obviously smitten.

He picks up a roll of duct tape while she sits on his couch eating ice cream.

"What's that?"

"Duct tape. I need it for... taping some things."

Jean looks pensive.

"Patrick, have you ever wanted to make someone happy?"

"What?"

Jean goes to put her tub of ice cream and spoon on Patrick's glass coffee table.

"NO!" Patrick bawls. "Put it in the carton!"

Jean is mortified.

"Sorry."

Bateman turns to address her previous question.

"Jean, what?"

"Um," she mumbles, "make someone happy. Have you ever wanted to?"

Bateman ponders the concept as he moves behind the sofa and silently holds a nail-gun to the back of Jean's head. She remains oblivious.

"I guess," he announces, "you could say I just want to have a meaningful relationship with someone special."

See also: Trees Lounge, Cheech And Chong's Nice Dreams, Comfort And Joy

Don't see also: Phantasm

Pointless trivia: Chloe Sevigny acted as costume designer on her then boyfriend Harmony Korine's Gummo (1997).

fields.headline: Anything you can do
fields.standfirst:
Thursday is Learning at Work Day and your chance to swap places with your boss. It may sound like a joke, but it has a serious purpose. Dolly Dhingra reports
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Think you could do your boss's job with your eyes closed and one hand tied behind your back? Perhaps you'd like her to come and sit in your chair for a day, to appreciate what it's like trying to deal with 101 emails while having to answer a constantly ringing phone.
fields.body:
Think you could do your boss's job with your eyes closed and one hand tied behind your back? Perhaps you'd like her to come and sit in your chair for a day, to appreciate what it's like trying to deal with 101 emails while having to answer a constantly ringing phone.

You might just get your chance. Thursday is Learning at Work Day, a national awareness campaign designed to emphasise the importance of workplace learning. Coordinated by the Campaign For Learning (CFL), it is being sponsored by the government and the University for Industry - and job swaps are one of the main activities being planned.

About 100,000 employees took part in the event last year, and the CFL is hoping to increase numbers this year by encouraging employers to adopt innovative learning methods for their staff. The AA motoring organisation has already signed up and has come up with the Learning Maze, an interactive exhibition exploring the various ways in which employees deal with customers.

But it is the job swaps that are likely to be the most illuminating - to senior management and support staff. Anyone can sign up for the scheme, so if you have been harbouring hostile feelings towards colleagues you think have a cushy time of it, the day of reckoning may well have arrived. Those taking part include Baroness Blackstone, the minister for education and employment, who is changing seats with the chief executive of Discovery Communications, Joyce Taylor. Steve Broomhead, chief executive of Warrington borough council, will be exchanging jobs with a canteen lady, while Dome chief executive Pierre-Yves Gerbeau will have the unenviable job of greeting punters at the attraction's Learning Zone. The National Grid is even planning to send its admin staff up pylons to open their eyes to the gravity-defying jobs done by engineers.

Michelle Wake of the CFL wants to encourage as many businesses as possible to get involved. "It's not just up to employers: we would like employees to take the initiative. If you want to swap jobs for the day, the best way is to approach your line manager. We have people at all levels taking part, including government ministers - and they are definitely not doing it for fun, but because they think they will learn something from it."

Caroline Howe, 27, project officer for the Association of Colleges, will be taking on the role of her chief executive, David Gibson. "An email was sent asking if anyone was interested, and as I was the first to respond I was selected. I'll be in meetings with senior officials of government departments. It will definitely show me what the role of a chief executive is and the skills needed to become one. I have ambitions to become all sorts of things; I'm certainly looking to climb the career ladder," she says.

All good fun, but how can swapping jobs for a day be a meaningful learning experience? "It's important to review the experience," says Wake. "If both sides want to do a follow-up, it's a way of consolidating learning. There might be a lot of different conclusions that you come to. There's no denying that many people are unhappy in their jobs, but a lot are unhappy because they don't understand the importance of their role in the organisation. Everyone wants to feel valued - from the cleaner up.

"The experience is also a way of clarifying your ambitions - finding out what you like and don't like about your job. Even if you conclude that you need a change of career, the experience will have had a positive outcome."

The CFL believes that traditional methods of learning, such as sending workers on courses, may soon seem dated. "There is so much learning and so many different kinds of learning to do in the workplace that what employers need to develop is a learning culture on a daily basis. Learning is a fragile thing and companies have to be aware that it needs continual boosting," says Wake.

To mark the campaign, an online learning network, learndirect, is being launched to make workplace learning easier and more accessible - business management skills are only a click of a mouse away. "It is important to understand that learning is something that makes us fulfil ourselves as humans on quite a deep level," says Wake. "And what we are trying to demonstrate is how people can have fun with learning."

fields.headline: Are they any good?
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Nokia 7110, £99 www.nokia.com
fields.body:
Nokia 7110, £99 www.nokia.com

What does it do? WAP phones offer the internet on a mobile phone (WAP stands for Wireless Application Protocol). Also acts as a PDA (personal digital assistant).

Easy to use? There's a gizmo that's a cross between a mouse and a wheel that can help you find your way around websites. You type in "sport" or "business news" and it finds the relevant info. But it is fiddly and expensive because you're online the whole time. What is great, though, is that you avoid sore fingers through typing because it is loaded with software that starts to recognise your abbreviations. And you can store bookmarks of your favourite sites.

Any good for secretaries? If you're not using it for surfing or downloading, forget it. The screen is bigger than a normal mobile, making the phone a bit chunkier. You'll be lucky to find one anyway. They're selling like hot cakes.

Palm IIIc, £349 www.palm.com

What does it do? Pretty much the same as the other Palms - that is schedules meetings, allows you to send emails and browse the net as well as acting as an alarm clock and contact list. Added extras include the colour screen and new Agenda view, letting you see all your appointments and outstanding to-do items on the same screen.

Easy to use? Learning the shorthand-style alphabet is fairly tedious but worth it. No excuse not to be organised again. May require an evening reading the handbook.

Any good for secretaries? You'll start making appointments just to use it. In any case, imagine the trauma of losing your address book. At least this one will always be backed up on your PC.

Psion 5MX, £429 www.psion.com

What does it do? This elegant little number is really a tiny PC: word processor, spreadsheet, and so on - and if that's not enough, it's capable of web browsing and sending emails as well as taking care of the mundane PDA chores of scheduling and contact lists. Easy to use? It is fast, and surprisingly easy to type on the minuscule keyboard. You can swap files with Office-type applications, and even hook it up to a Mac. Batteries seem to last forever. Requires at least an evening of studying the handbook, though - and "pocket-size" is a bit of an exaggeration.

Any good for secretaries? If you already have a laptop, ditch it for this. It's a truly mobile work tool. And it's sexier.

C-Pen 800, £292 www.cpen.com

What does it do? This chunky pen is really a handheld scanner that enables you to run it over any text, that is then downloaded once it is plugged back into your PC. It is also a personal information manager and email connection.

Easy to use? Yes, provided that you stay clear of unusual or coloured fonts. The C-Directory is a nifty extra (£30) that translates foreign languages that you scan with the C-Pen. Can be synchronised with Microsoft Outlook on your PC to carry your diary around.

Any good for secretaries? Only if you travel a lot or have to do on-the-spot research. Don't turn it down if your boss offers you one, though. They're great fun and wildly impressive.

Dragon Naturally Speaking Mobile Organiser, £249 www.dragonsystems.com

What does it do? Schedules meetings, creates emails, puts dates in your diary and new entries in your to-do list. But the juicy bit is its speech recognition software that you install on your PC. Basically, you talk into it wherever you are and once back at your desk, plug it into your computer and wait for it to communicate with your organiser and email software. The handset also works as general digital recorder which transcribes speech to text.

Easy to use? Not at first. The desktop software has to be trained to recognise speech from the handheld recor-der, for which you need several hours spare. In addition, you have to learn the lingo. Once it works, though, it's a beauty.

Any good for secretaries? A marvel if you're in a high-flying position, but a little threatening if not: this is the one that the magazines declare is "your very own electronic secretary".

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: •Sick of Work
fields.byline: Penny Cottee, Editor of Executive PA magazine
fields.body:
Sick of Work

Come on, come clean - have you ever pulled a "sickie" when you weren't really feeling that bad? According to the Institute of Personnel and Development, up to a third of sick days in the UK have nothing to do with genuine ill health. The IPD found that the most common reasons for staying at home were minor complaints such as colds and headaches - although non-manual workers most often stayed off with stress and back pain. The IPD report says sickness absence costs about £500 per employee per year, a total of £13bn annually.

 Congratulations

Congratulations to Anna March, 22, named international college-leaver of the year by secretarial recruiter Angela Mortimer at the company's 10th annual conference. March, who studied at Brookside secretarial college in Cambridge, will soon start work as a development assistant at Cambridge's Fitzwilliam college.

Brainwaves on the beach

New research has concluded that we are at our most creative when on vacation. Holiday firm Thomson has launched a competition to find the most creative "beach brainwaves", and one of its holidays is up for grabs. So if you have had any revelations while off work - such as deciding to write that novel, or set up in business on your own - describe them in 200 words, saying where and when you had the idea and how the holiday influenced you. Send your name, age, address and daytime number to Anna Shackleton, Thomson Beach Holiday Brainwaves, Band & Brown Communications, 57a Jamestown Road, Camden, London NW1 7DB, by June 20 2000.

 Join the dot.coms

What makes some dot.com companies so extraordinarily successful? E-Business Start-up, a new book from Kogan Page, aims to guide the way to your own e-commerce millions. Author Philip Treleaven, professor of computing at University College London, says anyone can become a hi-tech entrepreneur. All you need is a winning idea, total commitment and astute business sense. Copies cost £25 from Kogan Page, tel: 01903 828800.

Time is Money

Mixed news from employment services firm Reed. The continuing recruitment shortage, the company believes, is likely to see secretarial salaries rising more quickly than anticipated. But support staff are having to work ever longer hours to earn them. A Reed survey has found that more than 40% of secretaries work in excess of nine hours a day, while 7% of those in finance companies put in more than 11 hours. Fine if you get decent overtime, but only one in 15 firms offers overtime payments to all staff.

fields.headline: Clued-up accessibility
fields.standfirst:
Joshua Redman
Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
Joshua Redman
Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
Saxophonist Joshua Redman leaves precious little of the horn's sonic potential unblown. He delivers even the most labyrinthine improvisations with immense inner swing, even unaccompanied.

Redman sows a steady trail of clues through even the wildest of improvisations. This makes his performances highly accessible and the ingenuity of his solos seem all the more resourceful. The downside is a perceptible air of calculation. Coupled with a fondness for spectacular set-pieces and a repertoire of originals from his new album, Beyond, the mix can flag a little by the end of a 90-minute set.

Redman stayed close to the American postbop line, but exploited it with his customary energy, aided by a supporting trio that plays with the eager understanding that comes from high skill mixed with regular contact. The saxophonist opened with an unaccompa nied sermon-like exposition that burst into an up-tempo swinger, Leap of Faith, and followed it with the more oblique and exploratory Suspended Animations. Redman's sublime tenor tone and his uncanny multiphonic duetting with himself showed his class, but it was a standard, The Shadow of Your smile, and not his own repertoire that unfolded his most distinctive strengths.

At the Corn Exchange, Cambridge (01223 357851) tonight and De Montfort Hall, Leicester (0116 2333111) tomorrow.

fields.headline: Yes TV cancels flotation
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Yes TV
fields.trailText: Investors, still reeling from last week's battering of technology shares, suffered another blow over the weekend when video-on-demand provider Yes TV abandoned its planned stock market flotation, due this morning.
fields.body:
Investors, still reeling from last week's battering of technology shares, suffered another blow over the weekend when video-on-demand provider Yes TV abandoned its planned stock market flotation, due this morning.

Several would-be investors pulled their orders for shares on Friday as technology stocks went into freefall. The Techmark index suffered its biggest one-day fall, losing 8.7% of its value. With the planned £600m offer undersubscribed, Yes TV was forced to postpone its listing.

"We were selling into the teeth of a huge bear market," said Steve Garvey, head of marketing.

This is the second time Yes TV's chief executive, Thomas Kressner, has said no to floating the five-year-old company. Today's planned float price of 175 p per share was a substantial discount on the range of 225-275p set for April's abortive attempt.

The cancellation of Yes TV's float reinforces the view that the market is taking a more sceptical view of the value of hi-tech stocks after the collapse last week of online fashion retailer Boo.com. The Techmark, London's technology share index, stands almost 40% below its April peak.

Accountants PriceWaterhouseCoopers have warned that many loss-making internet start-ups are chewing through money at such a rate that one in four has less than six months of cash left. Separately, a survey by FT.com showed that the British public is turned off by the internet industries, with only 7% saying they would like to be involved in a dot.com and just 3% would give up their jobs if they had a good idea for an internet start-up.

Mr Garvey said the company had more than £40m in cash to tide it over while it sought investors to back its plans for aggressive roll-out of its video-on-demand service, a process which might take "weeks or months".

Yes TV's abandoned offering follows a string of bad news for the company, which provides movies and music on demand over cable and phone networks.

"With hindsight, we probably would have been better to wait until the autumn," Mr Garvey said, adding that would-be investors who had sent money would receive refunds as soon as was practicable.

There were reports yesterday that other flotations planned for this week could be at risk, including British-based internet firm TeleCity.

Analysts expect a nervous week in the markets as the threat of higher interest rates threatens to destabilise corporate profitability. Loss-making internet companies are particularly vulnerable to interest rates worries.

Some City analysts expect the European Central Bank to follow last week's move by the US Federal Reserve, ratcheting rates up at its meeting on Thursday.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: "Delegation is all about trust," says Monica Ross, head of buying for the womenswear and accessories departments at London department store Selfridges. "If you're relying on a team of people, you have to believe in them 150%, otherwise the whole system will collapse. I have 37 staff reporting to me, made up of buyers, merchandisers and administrators. They choose which lines to buy, which brands to introduce or terminate, and often they negotiate the deals. And I have to have complete faith in their ability."

I have 37 staff reporting to me, made up of buyers, merchandisers and administrators. They choose which lines to buy, which brands to introduce or terminate, and often they negotiate the deals. And I have to have complete faith in their ability."

Delegating tasks to other people is often the most difficult part of management; for Ross it's essential. "My job is mainly strategic, to plan the direction of womenswear in the store. I have a twice-yearly meeting where we discuss short and long-term strategy - how to make the departments more exciting, more accessible and more profitable. I then pass that information down to my buyers so that they are aware of the direction to head in."

According to Ross, there is a fine line between giving people autonomy and understanding the needs of the client. "We have regular meetings with clients to discuss new lines, to negotiate finance or staffing, and some I go to, some not. With a big client such as MaxMara, which has five sub-brands in the store, I would always go. With a smaller client, the buyer would do the meeting. With 2,000 brands, I couldn't possibly attend all the necessary meetings, and it's important for buyers to be able to stamp their own style on meetings."

Ross believes good delegation is a combination of giving both independence and support. "I don't stand over my buyers when they select merchandise from a brand. I trust their instincts and creativity. They have a budget, and how they spend it is up to them, but I do sign them off, so I keep tabs on what is going on. We also have strategy meetings that buyers and shopfloor managers attend and I try to ensure everyone has a voice. We discuss what's good, what isn't, and what's to be done."

Out of that meeting Ross forms an action plan and makes sure that everyone is clear on what points they have to action. "Clarity is essential. We also have weekly meetings when I communicate any action points that need seeing to, and when the buyers can bring up any concerns. It's hugely important to keep talking and to make sure that you are updated on anything that may become problematic, or simply any changes that are taking place. Although my buyers do work independently, at the end of the day I need to be aware of everything that is going on. And I have to trust that they are keeping me informed.

"I try to ensure my staff continually develop. Selfridges has an excellent training programme and if there are any aspects of the job that they're weak on, it's as much my responsibility as theirs to see that that is improved. I also take small groups out for coffee every so often, so we can have an informal chat. It's important to feel that you have a relationship with your team and that you understand them. After all, how can you have trust in someone who you don't really know?"

fields.headline: Roll out the biscuit barrel
fields.standfirst: ...or, what the free office snacks say about your place of work
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: Free office snacks say a lot about your place of work, says Judi James.
fields.body:
Self-employed people always are the fittest and finest employees in the land, which is less to do with the lifestyle and more with the fact that no-show means no-pay.

And no free croissants, either. If we want scram we have to fork out for it ourselves. In fact, the only two major perks of PAYE have always been paid hols and sickies and free grub at half time.

Which is where Greg Dyke met his possible Waterloo last week, in terms of employer-employee relations. Was it just an evil rumour put about by rival channels or did the man actually deprive workers of their birthright, ie free pastries at breakfast time? Could he really have been so woefully unaware of the motivational factors of the average British worker? Did the psychological impact of that little twist of high-fat, high-calorific continental bun really go over his head or was it all a bit of a lark?

Corporate snacks are of vital importance to the workforce. These little fellas say more about the real image of a company and how highly it values its staff than a thousand newspaper ads or mission statements. Forget what human resources tell you about their wonderful workforce during that recruitment interview and take a serious look at what's on offer on the plate next to the cup of stewed Assam.

The bagel boss
Working for a croissant company is different from being employed by a biscuit-based firm. Croissants, bagels and Danish pastries draw the fine dividing line between creative media person and office employee. They are a little bit 'whoa', a little bit 'wheey', a little bit Islington. They imply no paperwork to muss up with greasy digits. They say 'global' in a way that no plate of custard creams ever has. Working for the bagel-providing boss means being employed by a hedonist. To impress in this firm be an enthusiastic over-achiever. Avoid logic and detail and wear Armani. Use words like 'profoundly' 'cool' and 'passion' in liberal quantities.

The puritan
This boss will provide rich tea fingers, often on a paper doily. Forget the plate decoration, this company is practical, traditional and serious-minded. To impress here you will need to display loyalty and thoroughness. Wear anything in navy or grey, especially from M&S.

The status freak
Where you spot foil-wrapped or chocolate-coated you will know you are in the embrace of a status-conscious company. Indulge in massive name-dropping sessions on a regular basis and market yourself aggressively and unashamedly. Carry designer bags, preferably Prada.

Fruity-tootie
Fresh fruit on offer implies the health-conscious slave-master. Low-calorie snacks mean a leaner, meaner fighting workforce with no room for the lard-arsed work shy. This company is trendy and in-your-face. Be seen running up the stairs rather than using the lift, or removing cycle clips each morning in reception. Dress in Gap or Nike. Carry a bottle of designer water at all times.

Straight in the vein
Some companies bypass all social niceties when offering grub and proffer their biscuits straight from the packet they came in. There will be a strong element of comfort eating about this fare; choccie digestives or oatmeal creams will be favourite and there will often be outbreaks of minor scuffles among staff when the last one is consumed. This company is into instant gratification and is childlike in its pursuit of it. Comfort is the key theme here and any sense of style is almost totally absent. Converse in childlike tones, using phrases like 'ickle problem' and 'weeny spot of overtime'. Pin pics of pets around your PC. Wear cardigans and plaits.

fields.headline: From Russia with bravura
fields.standfirst:
BBCSO/Yakov Kreizberg
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
BBCSO/Yakov Kreizberg
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
With Diaghilev at the South Bank and Covent Garden, the imminent arrival of the Kirov, Mikhail Pletnev's Tchaikovsky marathon and Channel 4 turning Anna Karenina into a porn show, it seems that Slavonicism rules OK. Buried in all this, the BBC Symphony Orchestra and Yakov Kreizberg have been indulging in a two-part series entitled The Russians.

Rachmaninov's Paganini Rhapsody is twinned with Lutoslawski's Paganini Variations, both works for piano and orchestra. Rachmaninov's cantata Spring is coupled with Judith Bingham's The Temple at Karnak. It's a big, imposing piece full of relentless timpani beats and sepulchral tom-tom rolls suggestive of massive statuary.

Shostakovich was represented by two of his most undervalued symphonies, the Sixth and the Eleventh. Kreizberg refuses to see any hidden political agenda in the Sixth, presenting it as very much an abstract work. The result is beautiful, but a trifle cool. The politics of the Eleventh are hard to escape, however. Written in 1957, it is subtitled "The Year 1905", and depicts the abortive January revolution that year. Kreizberg, swivelling between desolation and ferocity, turns in a performance of such power that the symphony becomes a lament for the destructive forces unleashed by all violent revolutions. The real high point, however, was the pair of Paganini-inspired pieces. Peter Jablonski was the soloist. The finest of today's young pianists, he attacked Rachmaninov's Rhapsody with bravura, panache and mercurial wit.

fields.headline: Give us our daily gizmos
fields.standfirst:
Technological advances will revolutionise the job of support staff. Kate Hilpern wonders whether it is all a good thing. Below, we look at some of the gadgets on offer

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The year is 2005 and you're in the car on the way to work, stuck in a jam (some things never change, even in the future). But this is no problem to tomorrow's secretary. First you verbally instruct the car computer in your dashboard to deviate from the normal route, then you tell it to email your manager to tell her you'll be 10 minutes late.
fields.body:
The year is 2005 and you're in the car on the way to work, stuck in a jam (some things never change, even in the future). But this is no problem to tomorrow's secretary. First you verbally instruct the car computer in your dashboard to deviate from the normal route, then you tell it to email your manager to tell her you'll be 10 minutes late.

Meanwhile, at a red light, you pull out of your pocket your computerised pen. You've remembered that your boss asked you to order her a book, so you check a few sites to find the best price. Finally, as you're parking, you recall that you need to schedule a meeting with a stationary rep so you book it by the car email system and ask it to remind you nearer the time. By the time you undo your seatbelt, your hand-held computer has downloaded all your appointments for the day.

OK, OK, let's not get carried away. Not all this technology will be with us in five years. But it will be here soon, with a huge range of similar advances. And according to the Institute of Personnel and Development, it is the roles of secretarial and support staff that are likely to be most affected by technology's great leaps forward.

"Already, IT has changed the secretary's day-to-day life beyond recog nition," says Angela Baron, policy adviser to the IPD. Five years ago, she says, many a career secretary had no more computer skills than basic Word for Windows. Today, however, proficiency in Powerpoint, Excel and Access is a must. Often it's just a starting point.

According to recruitment consultants Office Angels, the biggest concern for today's PAs is just how much technological know-how is required in the millennial office. "It's a very grey area," admits director of corporate communications, Paul Jacobs. "Companies are upgrading their technology at hugely varying speeds. Some offer training and some don't. Some use around 2% of the potential of their software, others use more like 50%. Secretaries are, not surprisingly, in a state of confusion."

Wouldn't it would be nice to have a standard training programme and measurement of computer proficiency? Enter the European Computer Driving Licence (ECDL). This slick little "passport" - incorporating collectable stamps declaring your skills in a variety of technological competencies - is set to be the qualification for tomorrow's support staff, according to Pati Gram, training consultant at Kelly Training. "It's becoming so widely recognised in other countries that it is set to change its name to the International Computer Driving Licence," she says.

So how does it work? "It's administered in each country by the primary computer organisation for maintaining standards, and you have three years to complete it," says Gram, who believes it may take the place of the two main technological qualifications, Clait and NVQ. "It has seven main modules, which you can do separately either online or by tutorials at your own pace. Each has an exam and once you have passed them all, any re-cruiter will know you can deal with the future."

Sanne Bauer, a 20-year-old secretary at Kelly Services' East Grinstead branch, has just passed a module. "It's a myth that my generation is the computer generation," she laughs. "All the guys hogged the computers at school so I never had any IT training. A lot of employers know this is the case, and that when you say, 'I've got experience of computers,' that could mean anything. This qualification is the perfect solution."

If you want to be fully equipped for the technological revolution, however, recruitment consultancy Angela Mortimer plc argues you'll also need knowledge of mobile computers - notably "PDAs". Personal digital assistants are those sexy personal organisers that you see people showing off on the tube. While they can manage only a fraction of the things a desktop can do, they will still find you a phone number, book an appointment and give you a list of the day's jobs in an instant. They'll also send emails, allow you to download from the internet and set an alarm for that unmissable afternoon meeting. If there's another PDA owner at that meeting, you can beam them information using the infrared service (but beware of beaming abusive messages - the speaker may have a PDA of his own tucked in his pocket.)

"The important factor for secretaries is that you can synchronise all the information from the PDA directly onto the PC," explains Janet Alkama, Angela Mortimer's own personal PA. "That means that even if you don't have one, your boss's PDA will make a huge difference to your role. If, for instance, she makes any amendments to her diary or phone book, she simply hot-syncs it to my PC and so I have a constantly updated version of her movements and contacts." The good news is that PDAs are getting cheaper by the month; even better perhaps, formal training is unnecessary.

The next step up the technological ladder is the hand-held computer. Not so long ago, these were pocket devices with a keyboard so tiny a leprechaun would have trouble using it. Nowadays they are more like laptops, with many of the same programmes. You may also want to get your head round the WAP phone (a mobile phone with internet access), intranet systems (internal internet systems), digital dictation machines (you talk, they type), digital language converters, and on-line recruitment.

"Support staff have every reason to be excited," says Charles Walker of Blue Arrow recruitment services. "Their role is clearly set to overlap with that of IT staff. In a decade, they'll have an unrivalled range of transferable and up-to-the-minute skills. They'll also have an increasingly high chance of moving across into a purely IT role - something unheard of a couple of years ago."

But not everyone sees this as a good thing. "Particularly in smaller companies, there's a good chance that you'll be the only person in the office to have attended an IT course and you might wind up being the IT trouble-shooter without getting paid to be one," warns Angela Baron. "The line between IT staff and support staff may be getting blurred, but the difference in salary certainly isn't."

And some find the technological stampede itself a little worrying. Dr Mark Brosnan, principal lecturer in psychology at the University of Greenwich, believes that while technology was brought in to make our lives easier, the opposite is happening. "The job of the office worker who deals with technology is now proven to be one of the most stressful," he says. "There are more things to go wrong, there is more paper rather than less, there is more to do because everything works faster. It's a nightmare."

It's bad enough, he says, that most of us now have mini-offices at our homes, "but at least the journey home used to be sacred. Now, with mobile phones and hand held computers, even that time will be expected to be spent working."

"I wonder if the role of the secretary will disappear altogether," says Sue Andrews, an office administrator at Tesco. "All these new gadgets advertise themselves as taking over the jobs secretaries and PAs do - perhaps the human versions will become obsolete."

Certainly much of the new technology could make life easier for many PAs. But with technology magazines referring to the latest gadgets as "your very own electronic secretary which won't be grumpy on Monday mornings," perhaps support staff should be watching their backs - and remembering to smile.

fields.headline: Three-day deadline for Boo shutdown
fields.standfirst:
Liquidators will sell assets if no buyer is found by Wednesday

Boo.com
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Boo.com, the failed internet sports clothing retailer, will be closed if a purchaser for the business has not been found by Wednesday.
fields.body:
Boo.com, the failed internet sports clothing retailer, will be closed if a purchaser for the business has not been found by Wednesday.

A spokesman for the liquidators, KPMG, said talks with a handful of potential buyers took place yesterday at Boo's head office in Carnaby Street, London.

He said the liquidators wanted to be in a position to announce that the company had been saved today. But he warned that if a deal was not struck by Wednesday "the liquidation process will carry on and the assets will be sold off".

He said that Boo's 250 employees had not been paid for a month. Most of them had been sent home but had not yet been made redundant. Thirty people - including founders Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander - had been retained to demonstrate Boo's systems to possible buyers.

Mick McLoughlin and Shaun O' Callaghan of KPMG Corporate Recovery, the liquidators, are trying to sell the whole of the business as a going concern. But they are prepared to accept offers for parts of the business - essentially the sales and delivery systems.

Much of Boo's fulfilment capacity is contracted out to Deutsche Post in Europe and UPS in the United States.

Although 42 organisations expressed an interest in acquiring Boo, only a few were prepared to meet the liquidators' demand for a £1m returnable deposit to open the way to further negotiations.

Closure would raise relatively little for creditors since Boo has few physical assets for a company operating in 18 different countries.

The collapse will be a timely reminder to suppliers that they are unlikely to recover much from dot.com companies which go to the wall.

Most such businesses invest heavily in people and advertising. In the event of liquidation, their equipment and brand name is unlikely to raise much to repay creditors.

Boo's website gives no evidence of the company's troubles except for the bald statement that "Boo are not currently recruiting".

Its company history says the business is the first truly global internet retailer of fashion and sportswear.

It describes the company as "a team of dynamic individuals, handpicked from the worlds of fashion, new media, marketing, business, technology and finance" producing "an awesome virtual shopping experience".

The hype, however, failed to convince its financial backers, including French luxury goods tycoon Bernard Arnault and Italy's Benetton family, to invest more to bail the company out of its cash crisis.

Boo's failure will make it difficult for other dot.com companies to raise funds. For example, Net Imperative, an internet news and recruitment site, is in the middle of a crucial fundraising; Durlacher, the investment fund which is its major shareholder, has yet to decide whether to invest further in the company.

Durlacher, which has transformed itself from stockbroker to internet investment specialist, has seen its share price fall by more than 80% in the past three months as the market mood has swung against hi-tech stocks.

Boo's founders insisted at the weekend that the business was beginning to turn around and that it would have succeeded if it had secured the extra investment they wanted. But shareholders are unlikely to recover any of the $120m they sank into the company.

A spokesman for the liquidators, KPMG, said talks with a handful of potential buyers took place yesterday at Boo's head office in Carnaby Street, London. He said the liquidators wanted to be in a position to announce that the company had been saved today. But he warned that if a deal was not struck by Wednesday "the liquidation process will carry on and the assets will be sold off". He said that Boo's 250 employees had not been paid for a month. Most of them had been sent home but had not yet been made redundant. Thirty people - including founders Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander - had been retained to demonstrate Boo's systems to possible buyers. Mick McLoughlin and Shaun O' Callaghan of KPMG Corporate Recovery, the liquidators, are trying to sell the whole of the business as a going concern. But they are prepared to accept offers for parts of the business - essentially the sales and delivery systems. Much of Boo's fulfilment capacity is contracted out to Deutsche Post in Europe and UPS in the United States. Although 42 organisations expressed an interest in acquiring Boo, only a few were prepared to meet the liquidators' demand for a £1m returnable deposit to open the way to further negotiations. fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: A spirited study that amuses but ultimately lacks substance, plus Scar Culture, Everything you Need, A Fish Caught in Time and The Soldier's Return
fields.body:
Survival of the Prettiest: The Science of Beauty
Nancy Etcoff
Abacus £8.99 pp344
Buy it at BOL

Drawing on questionnaires - including one on the desirability of the unwashed male armpit to the female nose - and statistics, sprinkling quotes from Aristotle to Orwell, Nancy Etcoff (affiliated to Harvard Medical School) writes a spirited study of 'our passionate pursuit of beauty' that interests and amuses but ultimately lacks academic substance.

We may be grateful that the eighteenth-century belief that female adornment was tantamount to witchcraft persists no more, but the current vogue for cosmetic surgery at an increasingly young age seems a more depressing fact. On a lighter note, for the folically challenged, a useful recipe from 4000BC: rub head vigorously with dog paws, dates and asses' hooves that have been ground up and cooked in oil.

Scar Culture
Toni Davidson
Rebel Inc £6.99, pp247
Buy it at BOL

Toni Davidson's first novel is disturbingly mesmerising, complex in its construction and devastating in its subject of child abuse. Click, the child of deranged parents, chronicles his abuse with a camera; Pain, sodomised and abandoned, communicates via tape cassettes.

These fragmentary, abstracted autobiographical glimpses with which this unremittingly bleak novel commences are lent coherence when the two children come under the professional care of Dr Curtis Sad. A psychosexual researcher of inter-family sexuality, his own psyche scarred by the incestuous relations he forced with his sister, Sad is the most desperate of Davidson's wretched characters, manipulating his patients in a foolhardy experiment which ultimately backfires. The most chilling aspect of this exceptional fiction is that it could so easily be true.

Everything you Need
A.L. Kennedy
Vintage £6.99, pp567
Buy it at BOL

Morose Nathan Staples lives an ascetic life in a remote writers' retreat, tortured by memories of his estranged wife. He has not seen Mary, the daughter born of this union who believes her father dead, for years. But when Mary, by Nathan's contrivance, arrives at Foal Island, he becomes her teacher, struggling to confess his true identity. His attempts to do so spill over 500 pages of raw, emotive prose; his interior monologues, dark with self-loathing, are thrown into relief by joyful, beautiful Mary who comes to function as his muse and instrument of catharsis - in essence, his saviour.

A.L. Kennedy's talent is the erudite dissection of humankind to expose the minutiae of life; she may not always be kind, but her fiction is consistently honest and real and compulsively readable.

A Fish Caught in Time
Samantha Weinberg
Fourth Estate £7.99, pp241
Buy it at BOL

In 1938, Marjorie Courtenay-Latimer, curator of the east London museum, South Africa, discovered a fish long thought to be extinct. The coelacanth, aka 'Old Four Legs', was thought to be a missing link in the evolutionary chain. Courtenay-Latimer's infectious enthusiasm complements the sense of adventure aroused by research into the coelacanth, and Samantha Weinberg draws a sympathetic picture of this bizarre fish whose oil was believed by Chinese herbalists to have immortal properties, and whose balletic upside-down pirouette when troubled puzzled ichthyologists for decades.

It may be easier to raise money for the preservation of the 'soft and fluffies than for the wet and slimies', but this excellent book should persuade any reader that the wet, slimy and rather charming coelacanth should be treasured.

 Claudia-Pugh Thomas

The Soldier's Return
Melvyn Bragg
Sceptre £6.99, pp374
Buy it at BOL

Melvyn Bragg's haunting novel, recent winner of the WH Smith Literary Award, is set in his home town of Wigton, Cumbria, a place lovingly and convincingly evoked through the eyes of the small community in the years immediately following the end of the Second World War. Sam Richardson returns to Wigton after four years serving with the 'Forgotten Army' in Burma, during which time he saw friends and comrades butchered; images that torment him on his return to the sleepy, undisturbed town. But settling back into peace is painful and difficult - Sam struggles to regain his trust in his young wife, Ellen, and his son hardly knows him. Bragg creates an intimate and deeply-felt picture of the wounds that war inflicts on families and communities.

 Jane Perry

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: William Hootkins can barely conceal his disdain for the messy business of the whaling ship
fields.body:
In the Heart of the Sea
Nathaniel Philbrick

Read by William Hootkins
Running time 3 hours
HarperCollins £8.99
Buy it at BOL

Killing a whale is a gruesome and dangerous business. First, the whale is harpooned. Then the whalers in a frenzy of 'savagery, excitement and almost erotic blood lust' lever themselves nearer to the injured mammal. The executioner prepares himself with his 12ft killing lance, complete with petal-shaped blade, to inflict as much damage as possible.

Sometimes the whale is stabbed up to 15 times before the whaler hits his target - a main artery or a vital organ. Then the mammal begins to choke on its own blood which shoots through its spout, a geyser of gore. At this, the first mate shouts 'Chimneys afire!' and the whalers celebrate their kill, dragging the 'self-propelled tub of high-income lard' back to the mother ship where they continue with the 'blubber ripping' and decapitation until the deck of the ship resembles Dante's inferno - the blubber burning and crackling, the smell unbearable.

Nathaniel Philbrick's account of one of the most unusual disasters in nautical history is powerful and disturbing and translates beautifully into audiobook. Using data recorded by the survivors, he tells the story of the whaling ship, Essex, which in 1820, carrying 700 barrels of spermaceti, was attacked by an 85ft sperm whale.

William Hootkins can barely hide the disdain in his deep, throaty, American voice as he tells of the massacre. If you listen hard enough you can detect a hint of poetic justice as he relays the horrors of the survivors, found sucking the marrow from their dead shipmates' bones. Brilliant.

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Michael Frayn's ninth novel was the bookies' favourite to win the 1999 Booker Prize, and, despite being outrun at the last minute by J.M. Coetzee, it remains one of the most engaging novels to be published last year.
fields.body:
Headlong
Michael Frayn
Faber £6.99, pp394
Buy it at BOL

Michael Frayn's ninth novel was the bookies' favourite to win the 1999 Booker Prize, and, despite being outrun at the last minute by J.M. Coetzee, it remains one of the most engaging novels to be published last year. A complex historical detective story, Headlong is stamped with all the wit, scholarship and love of the farcical that you would expect from Frayn.

Martin Clay is a young philosopher who has already infuriated his wife, Kate, by deciding to abandon his career and retrain as an art historian. During the course of a dinner at the shambolic country house of their neighbours, Tony and Laura Churt, Martin becomes convinced that one of the Churts' paintings might just be a Brueghel, the missing link in his 'Seasons' series.

So begin Martin's fantastically elaborate machinations to get the painting away from Tony Churt without arousing his suspicions, in the course of which he ends up using all Kate's savings, stumbling into an affair with Tony's wife, and spending days submerged in painstaking research on Brueghel, which he shares with the reader at length.

Part of Frayn's joke is to weave fictional scholarship into the detailed historical background, with names and histories of invented painters rubbing shoulders with the real in a sly nod at the tricky business of establishing authenticity. Whether or not the painting is a genuine Brueghel almost becomes of secondary importance; the unspoken question is whether - even if it is - it will have been worth everything Martin, in his Fawltyesque scheming, has risked for it.

fields.headline: Only connect
fields.standfirst: If you want to sell something, it's not enough merely to advertise as Malcolm Galdwell explains in The Tipping Point
fields.trailText: If you want to sell something, it's not enough merely to advertise as Malcolm Galdwell explains in The Tipping Point
fields.body:
The Tipping Point: How Little Things Can Make a Big Distance
Malcolm Gladwell
Little Brown £14.99, pp279
Buy it at BOL

Read an extract

The vagaries of human preference preoccupy lofty aestheticians (who agonise about notions of good and bad taste) and down-and-dirty marketeers (who use focus groups to determine whether Northumbrians prefer pet food in blisterpacks, sachets or tins). Anticipating consumer choice is the philosopher's stone of modern business. Get it right and you can turn a base product not exactly into gold, but into a market-leader which is, of course, in the end much the same thing. It is a compelling subject.

Malcolm Gladwell's visual metaphor of tipping summons up images of the quantitative graphics used on flipcharts in dire marketing seminars with striplights and plastic cups. It describes that moment in the life of a product, a fashion or an opinion when it ceases to be a minority taste or an unappreciated commercial novelty and, to borrow an expression from an earlier phase of business history, acquires enough critical mass to interest, persuade or infect the majority.

'Infect' is not inappropriate: epidemiology, or the study of how diseases spread, has a surprising amount in common with, say, colour forecasting, record-plugging and product planning.

If you can understand the dynamics of, say, sexually transmitted diseases (and Gladwell includes a chapter which, perhaps, tells us more than we actually want to know about syphilis in Baltimore), then you have a mathematical and behavioural model about how the activities of a minority can soon influence the rest of us. That is the demand side. From the supply side, the question of anticipating popular desire was handled differently by Harley Earl, chief wizard in the den of kitsch that was General Motors in the Fifties: he told his designers to go as far as they could, then pull back some. That way you lead the public, but not by too much. So we got the two-tone paint and the tail-fin.

No one seems certain if the consumer is innately conservative or adventurous. Using material and methods from diffusion studies, Gladwell soon fascinates the reader. Word-of-mouth seems to be the way it always starts: that was how the Volkswagen Beetle, greeted derisively by the US auto industry, took off with the American public in the Fifties.

It was the same with an all but dead brand called Hush Puppies in the Nineties. Taken up by a vocal and visible clique (called 'connectors' by Gladwell) a moribund brand became a must-have. Skoda is going through the same process right now.

The psychologist Stanley Milgram attempted to understand these mechanisms. In the late Sixties he asked people in Omaha, Nebraska, to send a package to a stockbroker in Sharon, Massachusetts, via the closest intermediary they knew. When the results came through, there were usually no more than seven steps involved in a transcontinental journey from hayseed to preppy.

This research gave rise to the expression six degrees of separation which is about as close as most people are. The Tipping Point is full of such interesting stuff. For instance, recent research shows that in the networking cauldron of Hollywood, Elliott Gould was the most connected actor, being only 2.63681 removes from almost anyone else. If you want a market-leading product, get Elliott Gould to endorse your dog food or pantyliner.

The locus classicus of how ideas develop in the group mind was Bruce Ryan's and Neal Gross's study of the distribution of hybrid seed corn in Greene County, Iowa, in 1928. This gave us the memorable expression 'early adopters'. The Tipping Point, one senses, is also seeking a methodology and vocabulary that will stick, thus it has some irritating tics, including constant repetition of the tipping or tipped coinage. Gladwell is intelligent, articulate, well-informed and thought-provoking, but in fact and spirit The Tipping Point is really only a long article (which is exactly as it first appeared in the New Yorker). As journalism in hard covers, this book has an ephemeral feel and I doubt it will become a classic, although it's noteworthy that 'tipping point' is already appearing in US newspaper headlines.

In the end, it seems persuasion is an art not a science, rather like taste itself. Nietzsche said all life is a question of taste and life is ultimately humane and anarchic: no amount of computer-modelled diffusion studies could have predicted the astonishing ironic revival of, say, Kangol headgear. While it is true that all global phenomena begin with the approval of an enthusiastic minority, it is equally true that there are very many enthusiastic minorities who are still mumbling to themselves.

fields.headline: We're all doomed...
fields.standfirst: ...except for middle aged French philosophers. Andrew Marr on Michel Houellebecq's Atomised
fields.trailText: ...except for middle aged French philosophers. Andrew Marr on Michel Houellebecq's Atomised
fields.body:
Atomised
Michel Houellebecq
translated by Frank Wynne
Heinemann £12.99, pp379
Buy it at BOL

How do you write engagingly about what is boring, disgusting, pointless? How do you keep a reader gripped by the description of a society which has fallen apart and for which you feel no affection or respect? It is an old problem, never satisfactorily resolved by Camus, nor by the 'new wave' of French novelists of the Seventies - nor in this book by a man hailed across the Continent as a new Camus.

Atomised is, however, that rare thing, a novel of ideas which comes close to working. It is destined to be a cult book, a reactionary blast at the permissive society and bogus spirituality, US consumerism and the break-up of the family. Houellebecq, an Irish-based Frenchman with an uncanny resemblance to A. N. Wilson, tells the story of two half-brothers, a molecular biologist called Michel and a sex-crazed bore, Bruno, as they struggle for meaning in the last years of the twentieth century.

On the page, this often means long and arid tracts of anti-erotic pornography - descriptions of relentless, joyless, pointless sex which are a real grind to read. Anyone who thinks book-reviewing is an easy trade should try getting through a hundred pages or so about unattractive middle-aged Frenchmen getting blow-jobs. Mingled with this is an almost equal quantity of philosophising, based on a good understanding of recent mathematical and physical science and a strong dose of anti-liberal, anti-enlightenment politics. By now it sounds, no doubt, like a book from hell, a practical joke created by a few bored ex-Pythons on holiday to satirise the state of the French novel.

But Atomised is far better than that. For a start, it has integrity. Houellebecq's disgust and horror is not feigned. He is making serious points about the grimmer outcomes of the sexual revolution, the despair of the first sexual revolutionaries as their bodies age and they find they have failed to invest in companionship, family and the dense web of non-sexual connections that keep us fully alive. And his denouement, in which Michel lays the foundations for a wave-theory based scientific breakthrough which destroys human individualism, indeed humanity, and replaces us with a new order of being - a more social species who have set aside the 'monstrous egoism, cruelty and anger' of humans - is a genuine page-turner. It is not unlike the best of Aldous Huxley, whom Houellebecq clearly admires.

Beyond that, however, there is a poised, sometimes very funny and self-confident tone: 'In earlier times, when bears were more common, perhaps masculinity served a particular function, but for centuries now men clearly served no useful purpose. For the most part, they assuaged their boredom playing squash, which was a lesser evil...' Though this is Michel thinking, Houellebecq's conceit is that the whole novel is produced by post-humans in tribute to our vanished species; presumably this sweepingly confident tone is theirs as well. So that's it: humanity is to disappear and will be replaced by cloned asexuals who sound exactly like a Parisian brasserie philosopher of pronounced conservative opinion. Don't say you haven't been warned.

Wilson, tells the story of two half-brothers, a molecular biologist called Michel and a sex-crazed bore, Bruno, as they struggle for meaning in the last years of the twentieth century. On the page, this often means long and arid tracts of anti-erotic pornography - descriptions of relentless, joyless, pointless sex which are a real grind to read. Anyone who thinks book-reviewing is an easy trade should try getting through a hundred pages or so about unattractive middle-aged Frenchmen getting blow-jobs. Mingled with this is an almost equal quantity of philosophising, based on a good understanding of recent mathematical and physical science and a strong dose of anti-liberal, anti-enlightenment politics. By now it sounds, no doubt, like a book from hell, a practical joke created by a few bored ex-Pythons on holiday to satirise the state of the French novel. But Atomised is far better than that. For a start, it has integrity. Houellebecq's disgust and horror is not feigned. He is making serious points about the grimmer outcomes of the sexual revolution, the despair of the first sexual revolutionaries as their bodies age and they find they have failed to invest in companionship, family and the dense web of non-sexual connections that keep us fully alive. And his denouement, in which Michel lays the foundations for a wave-theory based scientific breakthrough which destroys human individualism, indeed humanity, and replaces us with a new order of being - a more social species who have set aside the 'monstrous egoism, cruelty and anger' of humans - is a genuine page-turner. It is not unlike the best of Aldous Huxley, whom Houellebecq clearly admires. Beyond that, however, there is a poised, sometimes very funny and self-confident tone: 'In earlier times, when bears were more common, perhaps masculinity served a particular function, but for centuries now men clearly served no useful purpose. For the most part, they assuaged their boredom playing squash, which was a lesser evil...' Though this is Michel thinking, Houellebecq's conceit is that the whole novel is produced by post-humans in tribute to our vanished species; presumably this sweepingly confident tone is theirs as well. So that's it: humanity is to disappear and will be replaced by cloned asexuals who sound exactly like a Parisian brasserie philosopher of pronounced conservative opinion. Don't say you haven't been warned.

fields.headline: The making of Tate Modern
fields.standfirst: Karl Sabbagh tells the inside story of the conversion of the Tate Modern in Power into Art
fields.trailText: Karl Sabbagh tells the inside story of the conversion of the Tate Modern in Power into Art
fields.body:
Power into Art
Karl Sabbagh
Allen Lane £20, pp352
Buy it at BOL

This book about Tate Modern is only the second work I have ever reviewed about the construction of a building, rather than a building itself. The first was Richard Goy's meticulous account of the creation of the Ca' d'Oro in Venice. Nearly 600 years separate the birth of that sumptuous palace on the Grand Canal from the conversion into an art gallery of a disused power station beside the Thames, but although the one was a work of domestic ambition and the other an institutional enterprise, to the lay person the two projects seem to have had a surprising amount in common.

The palace made much use of material salvaged from a twelfth-century predecessor on the site. The gallery was inserted into Giles Gilbert Scott's Bankside power station, completed in 1963. The making of the Ca' d'Oro was muddled by the obsessive interference of its owner, the tycoon Marino Contarini. The Tate Modern project was obfuscated by frequent differences of opinion and style between patrons, architects and builders.

And just as the story of the opulent Ca' d'Oro encapsulates the condition of Venice in the fifteenth century, so the saga of Tate Modern properly symbolises the conversion of late twentieth-century Britain from splendid insular complacency to aspirant multiculturalism. Karl Sabbagh, who is primarily a television director, has been associated with the project since 1994 and he describes it with an exhausting kind of pride. Well he might, for it is an exhausting history.

From start to finish, nothing was easy, hardly anything unanimous. There were objections to the very idea of converting a power station into a gallery of modern art, instead of building a new one. There were criticisms of the choice of architects, the then little-known Swiss firm Herzog and de Meuron. There were the usual environmental concerns, the inevitable tussles of personality, the perennial worries about raising money or satisfying benefactors, arguments about colour, materials, the shape of doors or the size of staircases. Sabbagh ably tells it all, barring no holds and occasionally taking a chance, I nervously thought, on libel.

The work took six years. Many of its activists came and went in the course of it, and that handy old American acronym - snafu - constantly entered my mind as I read the book. Now they find unacceptable levels of asbestos in the original structure. Now a supply factory burns to the ground. A hoist fails to work, a lift door won't open. Steel comes late. A pump doesn't turn up. A crane breaks down. The approach to the connecting bridge over the river clashes with plans for the landscaping of the museum.

Harry Gugger, one of the architectural partners, complains about the 'terrible' quality of the workmanship, and says it would all be different in Switzerland. Somebody from the Tate talks about 'an incredible sense of a "wow" factor'. Someone from a construction company remarks coolly of his clients that 'they come from this arts background'.

But all comes more or less right in the end. This is called 'muddling through', as poor Gugger doubtless came to realise. The building was even finished on time and would have made a better millennial monument, to my mind, than the tiresome Dome downstream. Concerned though the Tate people sometimes seem to be, like our political leaders, with the dismissal of everything old, familiar or traditional, the new building is an honourable blend of past and future, industrial and artistic, the powerful and the sensitive, symbolically more proper than any new building Rogers or Foster might have proposed.

The hero of the epic is the Tate itself, its staff and, above all, its director, Sir Nicholas Serota. Through thick and thin, they backed their visionary architects against all querulous complaint, defying that awful old English mantra: 'It can't be done', and even holding relatively aloof to political correctness.

I have had my own doubts about Serota ever since that famous pile of bricks by Carl Andre at the old Tate, which I still consider an indefensible error of judgment, but reading about him here has quite won me over. Trying to assess contemporary art clearly involves risk - even an 'expert' can be made a fool of - but Serota has always been prepared to take a plunge, just as he was ready from the start to defy all philistine opinion, all trendy preference, in pushing through this brave and sensible project. I think he, his colleagues and his architects from Basel have done Britain proud, and that when we are long gone people will still be getting as much pleasure from Tate Modern as they do from the Ca' d'Oro, itself, by the way, now an art museum.

fields.headline: From local rags to riches
fields.standfirst: Monster or genius? J Lee Thompson sees Lord Northcliffe as a bit of both
fields.trailText: Monster or genius? J Lee Thompson sees Lord Northcliffe as a bit of both
fields.body:
Northcliffe: Press Baron in Politics
J Lee Thompson
John Murray £28, pp368
Buy it at BOL

Monster or a genius? Lord Northcliffe's biographers have always invited us to choose. The virtue of J. Lee Thompson's studious contribution to Harmsworthiana is that, at least implicitly, he recognises that there are no simple choices. The first great press baron of the modern age may have been gripped by monstrous delusions as his life ended in madness, but he was also a newspaper genius.

The facts tell their own cool story. Here's Alfred Harmsworth, first son of an affably unsuccessful barrister, looking for a career. He leaves school at 16 and scratches a freelance living from the Hampstead and Highgate Express. No silver spoons. At 20 (in 1885), he's editor of Bicycling News. Two years on, he's invented his first mass market magazine, Answers, and the road to glory opens before him. A magazine empire floated at 28; the London Evening News bought at 29; the founding of the Daily Mail and Daily Mirror; the purchase of The Observer and the Times; the youngest peer ever created, at 40. He had a blinding talent for innovation. Essentially, he invented our national press.

When he went to New York in 1901, Joseph Pulitzer of the World (and the prize) challenged him to produce the 'newspaper of the future'. He did it alone in a handful of days; a tabloid offering of 'All the News in 60 Seconds', which brilliantly encapsulated all the trends of the century to come. Genius.

Where, though, is the man who Hugh Cudlipp once described as the desecrator of good journalism in 'his pursuit of political power unguided by political prescience?' He is here, too; Thompson portrays him whole - not as some Citizen Kane, but as a thoughtful stripling whose philosophy 'combined Tory populism, Disraelian imperialism and a firm belief in the "Anglo-Saxon future",' which is a pretty fair take on even today's Daily Mail.

Politics intrigued him, to be sure, yet he also, at least in the beginning, knew where the lines of freedom and influence should be drawn. He appointed Garvin to The Observer and when, at last, the two fell out over imperial preference, he sold the paper on to Waldorf Astor, rather than sack his editor. His guarantees of independence for the Times lasted longer than many expected and fractured, at the close, as much on its dozy lack of new editorial thinking as any single issue of politics.

Northcliffe, to be fair, was originally no manic seeker of power. Rather, the politicians, seeing the influence his papers had begun to wield, crawled to him, just as their ancestors flock to pay court to Rupert Murdoch. And he was by no means always wrong. He was right to see the dangers of war with Germany and right again to flay the inert prosecution of that dreadful conflict once it came. His sense of country and service to it was strong.

He was also, in his way, a casualty of war. We all know - from the Falklands to the Gulf - how battlefields tear up the rulebooks of decent journalism, how Whitehall twists in the 'national interest'; by that time, Northcliffe was an insider as well as an outsider. His own rulebooks went missing in action. But he was never an armchair critic. Sickly, exhausted, he'd still go to the fronts of France to see and learn for himself. The dementia at the close was a cruel line drawn under this life.

Lee Thompson's account is by no means all-embracing. He leaves out the private Northcliffe (and tiptoes away from the family moralist who fathered three kids by a mistress). There's no clue (the Times aside) how Northcliffe picked the teams of editors and reporters who made his papers. Too many chapters consist of little more than history lessons with quotes from Mail leaders as commentaries. (What did Northcliffe write himself? How did his empire survive his interminable holidays of recuperation?) Nevertheless, the bones for judgment are here, and, with them, one inexorable conundrum: how do we want our newspapers owned? What are proprietors supposed to do?

There's no single answer to that, but it's necessary to say that without Harmsworth, many newspapers of today would never have existed. He knew instinctively where the readers of the twentieth century were. He reached out to them, included them in the debate. Was he supposed, after that, to sit vapidly to one side? Human impossibility. You bought the whole package, and you did, in your millions, buy.

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: James Thurber created a genre and was a master of it... what exactly that genre is is more difficult to say
fields.body:
The Secret Life of Walter Mitty
James Thurber
Penguin Classics £8.99, pp404
Buy it at BOL

When James Thurber died in 1961, The Observer wrote: 'He somehow gave us a sense of revelation... he created a genre and was a giant in it.' What, exactly, that genre was is very hard to define, but one thing is certain - without the New Yorker it might have never gained international recognition.

So it's appropriate that this reissue of Walter Mitty should carry an affectionate dedication to Harold Ross, the one-man disaster zone who conceived and edited the magazine during its golden years.

Among the many pleasures of this reissue ('All Right, Have It Your Way - You Heard a Seal Bark'), it's a relief to discover that the title story does not fail to hit the spot or that, after more than 50 years, Thurber's peculiar blend of precision and fantasy is as joyously entertaining as when it first appeared.

Perhaps Penguin can now be persuaded to reissue The Years With Ross, Thurber's classic memoir of his tempestuous time at the New Yorker.

fields.headline: Three sides to the story
fields.standfirst: Caryl Phillips unearths the legacy of slavery in the US, Ghana and Britain in The Atlantic Sound
fields.trailText: Caryl Phillips unearths the legacy of slavery in the US, Ghana and Britain in The Atlantic Sound
fields.body:
The Atlantic Sound
Caryl Philips
Faber & Faber £16.99, pp352

You start this book and by page six you want to get off. You are exhausted; ennui has settled inside your brain and drained you of all energy. You force yourself to read on. You long to go to sleep so you will not have to sit with the characters another minute, yet you know there is no easy let-off. You wish you had never started what appears, even by the middle of the prologue, to be an interminable book and you pray for the end.

Which is exactly the point of course. We are on a ship with Caryl Phillips, a 'banana' boat carrying cargo to the white cliffs of Dover. It is a functional vessel with none of the frills of proper passenger liners. Like Jonathan Raban and the early V.S. Naipaul, Phillips can do truly live reportage. You don't sit back and merely empathise with what is going on. The honesty and detail forces you to experience what the writer is going through. You feel his depressions, the tedium, his forbearance as he lives through each day encountering exploited Burmese workers and fellow passengers, mostly people of small spirits and even smaller, meaner lives.

Phillips decided to make the Atlantic crossing from the Caribbean to Britain just like his parents and other West Indian immigrants had done in the Fifties and Sixties. They had undertaken that 'long, arduous journey which had brought them from one world and placed them in the heart of another'. They hoped that 'both worlds would belong to them, the old and the new'. There has been much written and spoken by the Windrush generation about how these hopes turned to ash. But here you feel the cold loneliness and fear of these pioneers as Phillips reflects on how they did not know what lay ahead whereas he arrives with a sense of 'knowledge and propriety'.

Ever since his first novel, The Middle Passage, Phillips has been obsessed with crossings, dispossession and with that place called home which is forever elusive for so many of us. We go on heartbreaking journeys to Africa, to India and Pakistan to make sense of who we are. We walk in English graveyards and pore over old books seeking lost stories. We are all struggling with the pain of doctored narratives, ancestral links, of ownership and rights and of living in a country which remains determined not to know the grim realities of its murky history.

Phillips is one of the most tenacious of these excavators and in this book his intense focus is on the Atlantic slave trade. The three main sections of the book are based in Liverpool, Elmina in Ghana and Charleston, US - three cities which were central to this horrendous trade. Fact is fleshed out with the fictional imagination; today calls out insistently to yesterday; everyday observations shed light on stories of heroism and betrayal.

First we get the story of a Christian African, John Emmanual Ocansey who comes over to Liverpool in 1881, looking for the white English gentleman who cheated his family of money under the pretence of fair trade. He heads back home with tears in his eyes. Centuries on, Phillips arrives looking for truth and is as disappointed. Waiting at Liverpool station, he observes: 'A train pulls in and I can hear the uncivilised braying of football fans readying themselves for a Saturday afternoon of revelry. I am glad I am leaving. It's disquieting to be in a place where history is so physically present, yet so glaringly absent from people's consciousness.'

Ghana, too, is exposed to these ruthless eyes which refuse to look away. Phillips wants to know if Africans teach their children that some of their own were implicated in the slave trade. A Ghanaian professor warns him: 'You must not be too romantic about slavery. It was a terrible thing, but I still maintain that many of the Africans who left here were not good people... in some respects they got what they deserved.'

My problem with Phillips is that he is always too controlled. Maybe it is a male thing. But this can be his greatest strength too. Whether he is writing fiction or non-fiction, he seems to hone every thought and word before he allows it to leave his head. I cannot imagine a chatty hour over coffee with him. There would be too many disconcerting silences and I would end up filling the spaces with shallow babble from which he would not rescue me. That stillness beneath his words is what makes Caryl Phillips such an exceptional writer and this book so compelling.

webTitle: Precious little mettle in the Iron Lady's soul

fields.headline: Precious little mettle in the Iron Lady's soul
fields.standfirst: The first volume of John Campbell's biography of Margaret Thatcher is essential reading for anyone intrigued by the manufacture of political legends
fields.trailText: The first volume of John Campbell's biography of Margaret Thatcher is essential reading for anyone intrigued by the manufacture of political legends
fields.body:
Margaret Thatcher Volume One: The Grocer's Daughter
John Campbell
Jonathan Cape £25, pp512
Buy it at BOL

More than a decade since her red-eyed defenestration from No 10, the memory of Margaret Thatcher continues to exercise an extraordinary grip over our politicians. William Hague's steady lurch rightwards is impelled by the Conservatives' hunger to return to her thrice election-winning certainties. Tony Blair and the non-ideologues of New Labour, embarrassed to be seen as the incremental reformists that they are, dress their managerial politics in the metallic-cladding of Thatcheresque resolve and purpose.

This fascinating account of the creation of Thatcher is essential reading for Blair, Hague, and anyone intrigued by the manufacture of political legends. As with Thatcher's memoirs, Campbell has sawn the Lady in two. His first volume, like hers, takes us from birth to assumption of power. That is the end of the similarities. She called the first half of her life The Path to Power, suggesting a pre-destination to Downing Street. The Grocer's Daughter explores the under-appreciated role played by chance. The book's even greater service is to unpick the embroidery of the Thatcher myth.

The foundation stone of her iconography is that the Victorian verities of thrift, temperance, self-reliance, patriotism and duty that she brought to government were learnt in Grantham in Alfred Roberts's corner shop on the Great North Road. Campbell detonates that myth by demonstrating that her canonisation of the Methodist father was retrospective and much of it was the product of what we would now call spin-doctory. Hard work and a respect for profit, the grocer certainly taught his daughter that. Some of the outlines of what she was to become are to be detected in the young Thatcher. Oxford contemporaries remember the same hard-driving, scarily intense, humourless, lonely girl at Somerville. The snobbish, leftish dons of the college who patronised her have much to answer for by firing her with hatred against what she would later eviscerate as the liberal Establishment.

An essential feature of the Thatcher myth is that all her progress was the reward of virtuous application. Luck: that could not possibly have come into it. The future Queen Bee was certainly a worker ant. It took creditable determination for a woman to break through the thick upper crust of Tory public schoolboy prejudice and win herself a parliamentary seat.

And yet she would not have risen to the top without the kindly smile of good fortune. Time and chance were handmaidens to her career. It was not her father, but her husband who was the most important man in her making. The prayer of St Francis that she delivered on the steps of No 10 was doubly fake. It was a nineteenth-century invention which would prove to be a wildly inaccurate guide to Thatcher in power.
