fields.headline: Death and the maidens
fields.standfirst: Life's no picnic in Sofia Coppola's elliptical directorial debut. You won't understand it, but you should see it
fields.trailText: Peter Preston: Sofia Coppola, writing and directing, captured all the elliptical complexity of Jeffrey Eugenides's cult novel and added something haunting of her own
fields.body:
The Virgin Suicides is a film apart. It hovers on the edge of genre familiarity - high-school romance, American Beauty 2, horror whydunit - and yet it is none of these things. Sofia Coppola, writing and directing, captured all the elliptical complexity of Jeffrey Eugenides's cult novel and added something haunting of her own. You'll love it or hate it. I thought it was terrific.

We're in a leafy Michigan suburb 25 years ago and the Lisbons live across the street. Dad Lisbon (James Woods), a downtrodden maths teacher; Mom Lisbon (Kathleen Turner), a dumpy Bible basher; and their five lissom, golden-haired daughters. The spotty boys of the neighbourhood look on and lust inchoately. But this isn't adolescent paradise. Thirteen-year-old Cecilia (Hanna Hall, with the blank eyes of a young Uma Thurman) inexplicably slits her wrists. The local psychiatrist recommends a little male company. Mom throws an awful, awkward party. Cecilia impales herself on a railing.

The four who remain, led by Lux (Kirsten Dunst), persuade Mom to let them go to the school prom. Lux finds splendour in the grass with the local hunk (Josh Hartnett), who loves her and leaves her. Turner locks up her daughters. Dunst goes wanton. The denouement of the title begins to brew. Yet the plot is merely a smidgen of the full story. We never discover why what happens is allowed to happen. Our lack of understanding is echoed by the boys, now grown, looking back on events that shaped the rest of their lives. There is, in one sense, no reality, because the precision of defined personality is washed away. The girls are seen as unknowable symbols in a fairy tale; the themes of longings and incomprehensions across the sexual divide are universal.

Does that make it sound forbidding? It isn't at all. The playing is spot on - Woods and Turner, both shrewdly cast against type (where have you gone, Mrs Robinson?). Danny De Vito's bemused psychiatrist. The languor of the golden girls and the gaucheness of the unlikely lads. Dunst is radiant and wildly mysterious.

There's acute social comedy and a moody, drifting score from the French group Air. It is lovely to look at and unsettling to know, a transference of pain. As you sit there, your own memories come flooding back. I remembered the girl called Jacqueline of long ago who died, trapped in her bedroom, when the house caught fire, and I remembered how I felt. I was meant to remember, invited to look back in melancholy. That, in the fullness of its sorrow and pity and awakening, is the power of The Virgin Suicides. The questions it asks are the questions you must ask for yourself, and you will only fail to respond if those questions are foreign to you.

Sofia Coppola has carried a grinding weight of expectation into her debut. How could it be otherwise for the 28-year-old daughter of Francis Ford Coppola and wife of Spike Jonze (who was shooting Being John Malkovich at the same time)? Those kind of connections spell inflated expectation. But this is a subtle triumph, a film that owes nothing to father or husband. Here's another rare talent to cherish.

webTitle: Julia Roberts's Latin lover, Benjamin Bratt

fields.headline: Julia Roberts's Latin lover, Benjamin Bratt
fields.trailText: Benjamin Bratt is a famous actor. He really is. He must be because he is a fixture in gossip columns, a prime paparazzi target and the kind of A-list guest party planners want sipping Chardonnay and popping nibbles at their fancy bashes. But that's only if he is with his girlfriend. You have probably heard of her: she is Julia Roberts.
fields.body:
Benjamin Bratt is a famous actor. He really is. He must be because he is a fixture in gossip columns, a prime paparazzi target and the kind of A-list guest party planners want sipping Chardonnay and popping nibbles at their fancy bashes. But that's only if he is with his girlfriend. You have probably heard of her: she is Julia Roberts.

Forget Brad and Jennifer (too anodyne) or Puff and Jennifer (too volatile), Ben and Julia are the hot showbiz couple. They manage to appear sexy, affable and affectionate although reports of backstage tantrums have, of course, surfaced. They met three years ago when, in an LA restaurant, the actress looked at the Peruvian-American actor for the first time and 'it was like something hit me over the head with a bat'. About their relationship, Bratt says: 'We're in it as deep as it gets.' That's pretty deep. The first book he ever bought her was Henry Miller's Tropic of Cancer.

Since Bratt - or Mr Roberts as the US tabloids occasionally call him - began going out with the world's most famous actress, his career has enjoyed a predictable upsurge. Not that he was doing badly before. He was the straight arrow star of television cop series Law & Order; a well regarded show with modest viewing figures.

As a 'Latin heart throb' he was frequently described as a junior Jimmy Smits, the star of NYPD Blue, a rival and more successful cop show. Like Smits he left television to pursue a movie career. Unlike Smits, he has been successful. He left Law & Order last year claiming that he wanted to move into producing and starring in indie movies. Instead, he has wrapped big budget movies opposite Sandra Bullock, Val Kilmer and Madonna. Box-office security is not guaranteed but a decent paparazzi turnout at the premiere is.

In his upcoming release The Next Best Thing, he is Madonna's squeeze. The film focuses on the deteriorating relationship between a gay Rupert Everett and Madonna after they have a child. Bratt is the suave businessman who sweeps the Material Girl off her pumps. It's a half-baked issue film, but Bratt emerges relatively unscathed. It's art imitating life to the delight of stargazers. Apart from the screen re-creation of Everett and Madonna's best buddies act, Hollywood trophy boyfriend Bratt is the male eye candy.

The Bratt/Roberts relationship has intrigued and beguiled America in the same way the high profile, mixed- race relationship between Jennifer Lopez and Puff Daddy did. The cosmetic appeal of the couple, who naturally boast matching cheekbones, is obvious.

After a string of romantic near misses for America's sweetheart (one failed marriage, one failure to appear at the altar), the media desire for a resolution as neat as the ending to one of her films is strong. Bratt could be The One.

Of course, a boy needs to think about his career too. Bratt's looks healthy enough but the $20 million paycheques the missus brings home are a long way off. In life as on the screen, Bratt seems destined for a supporting role.

 The Next Best Thing opens on 23 June

Five things you should know about Benjamin Bratt

1 His mother, a Peruvian Indian from Lima, moved to the US when she was 14.

2 According to Bratt, Julia Roberts is 'simple in the most beautiful ways: generous, soulful, giving, humorous, loving - all those things that are important to me'.

3 He got his first break on a short-lived crime series called Nasty Boys.

4 In 1999 he was voted one of People's 50 Most Beautiful People

5 His production company is Chacras Filmworks (Chacras means 'fertile soil' in the Quechua dialect indigenous to Peru)

fields.headline: One-touch perfectionist
fields.standfirst: Fernando Redondo hasn't always fitted in with wishes of his managers but he is the heartbeat of Real Madrid. On his day, and Wednesday could be one of them, he can humiliate the opposition.
fields.trailText: Fernando Redondo hasn't always fitted in with wishes of his managers but he is the heartbeat of Real Madrid. On his day, and Wednesday could be one of them, he can humiliate the opposition.
fields.body:
On a university campus just outside Boston, on a summer's day six years ago, the Argentine players were getting ready for the World Cup by playing a scratch game among themselves. So good was the mood that Diego Maradona stopped giving interviews and joined in. Every goal at either end was cheered by hundreds of rich Argentines studying in Boston.

Yet it was quiet enough to hear the players shouting. And the word they shouted most often was 'Flaco!'

None of the Argentine players was named Flaco, but in Latin America you only become a real person once you acquire a nickname, and 'Flaco' - 'Thin One' - was the sobriquet of Fernando Redondo.

The reason everyone kept screaming it was that Redondo always seemed to have the ball. In this brilliant team, which but for a cocktail of ephedrine would have won the World Cup, all attacks ran through the long-haired, hippie-like figure at the back of midfield. So they do at Real Madrid, the team that on Wednesday night plays Valencia for the Champions League.

Real's chances depend largely on El Flaco (or The Prince, or The White Machine). At his best he can destroy Manchester United. At his worst, he infuriates Johan Cruyff. And whether Redondo will be at his best depends largely on his team. Real Madrid have just overcome United and Bayern Munich, but a year ago, with much the same team, in the Spanish Cup semi-finals, they lost 6-0 to Valencia. 'San Marino, you are like San Marino,' sang the Valencia fans. So which Flaco and which Real will we get?

Redondo was born 30 years ago in Adrogué in Buenos Aires. It is common to say of any Latin American footballer that the game helped him escape from the slums. This is not true of Redondo. A middle-class boy, he was studying law when Carlos Bilardo, then the Argentine manager, called him up for some friendlies before the World Cup of 1990.

Redondo turned him down, saying he had to sit exams. The truth is more complex. There are two basic types of Argentine coaches: those such as Bilardo and Daniel Passarella, who think football is about breaking legs, diving for penalties and punching goals, and those such as Jorge Valdano, Cesar Luis Menotti and the current Argentine manager, Marcelo Bielsa, who think there is more to it. The latter tend to be educated men who compare football with poetry, music and countless other art forms.

The Bilardistas are generally on the political right: Passarella captained the Argentine side that won the 1978 World Cup under the military regime. The Menottistas are mostly left-wingers.

Redondo, an educated man of the left, is with the Menottistas. This is more than a matter of academic interest: it has shaped his career, and explains why he is at Real. After rejecting Bilardo, he moved to Europe to play for Tenerife, where his manager was Valdano. It was Valdano who brought him to Real Madrid in 1994, and it was Bielsa who recalled him to the Argentine side.

Before the last World Cup Passarella had kicked Redondo out of the Argentine team. Famously, Redondo had ignored Passarella's edict to cut his hair. In fact, the hair was merely the excuse. The dispute went deeper: Passarella wanted Redondo to consider himself a soldier in his army. Redondo would not.

Passarella ended up looking silly. Argentina went out of the World Cup in the quarter-finals, weeks after Redondo had helped Real Madrid win the Champions League.

At Real, Redondo has won everything: two league titles and the World Club Cup, as well as the 'septima', the club's seventh European Cup. Yet it would be wrong to say that he has had six glorious years. Real are a crazy club, led by a president with a three-second attention-span, and Redondo has often been dragged down with the rest.

This year Real have climbed out of the bottom half of the Spanish league but never got a whiff of the title. Their home defat on Friday means they have finished fifth and must win on Wednesday to return to next season's Champions League. 'Real Madrid have been playing fairly badly to very badly all year,' said Johan Cruyff in March. 'I don't think there is a team in the world where the midfield loses so many balls. You can't count how many Redondo loses.'

Redondo is often called the master of the one-touch. 'Tactically perfect,' said his former coach Fabio Capello. But when his team-mates are not moving, he can appear helpless. He lacks acceleration, is often carrying injuries, and sometimes seems not to care. Then he becomes the master of the two or three-touch, passing needlessly to defenders, slowing the game down.

Real have continued to falter, but this spring they have at least played well in the big games. A month ago they saved their season by beating Manchester United 3-2 at Old Trafford, chiefly thanks to Redondo. Playing further forward than usual, he also produced the moment of this year's Champions League.

First, it must be said that humiliating United's Henning Berg is a realistic proposition. It has been done before, usually by Berg himself. But Redondo defined the art. Sprinting with Berg to the goalline, he back-heeled the ball through the Norwegian's legs, collected it and passed to Raúl who scored Real's third goal. Later Rinus Michels, the authoritarian former manager of Holland, was asked about that back-heel. Surely he would never have tolerated it? 'That boy,' said Michels, 'would never have heard anything about it from me.'

Alex Ferguson noted that all loose balls that night had seemed to fall to Redondo. 'What does this player have in his boots?' Ferguson asked. 'A magnet?' Redondo is indeed more than a playmaker - at his best, he hoovers the midfield.

United escaped lightly. In the semi-finals Redondo and Raúl deliberately humiliated Bayern Munich. At times the two had fun simply passing to each other, making jokes about Carsten Jancker as the huge striker lumbered after the ball. More than once Redondo showed the ball to Bayern's Stefan Effenberg, waited for Effenberg to pounce, and then rolled it to a team-mate.

The Germans also sulked about a particularly frivolous bicycle-kick by Roberto Carlos. This, they felt, was bad manners.

In this Real side, Redondo and Raúl - perhaps the two key players - are best mates. Both like their peace before games. In the next few days, while his colleague Steve McManaman whiles away the time watching films and Nicolas Anelka and Geremi are busy on their Playstations, Redondo and Raúl will be reading bound volumes of paper known as books. The Thin One enjoys Jorge Luis Borges, Gabriel García Márquez and Italian fashion magazines.

Wednesday could be Redondo's day: Anelka, Raúl and Fernando Morientes are exactly the quick forwards he needs. Alternatively, Valencia could win 6-0 again.

Yet it would be wrong to say that he has had six glorious years. Real are a crazy club, led by a president with a three-second attention-span, and Redondo has often been dragged down with the rest. This year Real have climbed out of the bottom half of the Spanish league but never got a whiff of the title. Their home defat on Friday means they have finished fifth and must win on Wednesday to return to next season's Champions League. 'Real Madrid have been playing fairly badly to very badly all year,' said Johan Cruyff in March. 'I don't think there is a team in the world where the midfield loses so many balls. You can't count how many Redondo loses.' Redondo is often called the master of the one-touch. 'Tactically perfect,' said his former coach Fabio Capello. But when his team-mates are not moving, he can appear helpless. He lacks acceleration, is often carrying injuries, and sometimes seems not to care. Then he becomes the master of the two or three-touch, passing needlessly to defenders, slowing the game down. Real have continued to falter, but this spring they have at least played well in the big games. A month ago they saved their season by beating Manchester United 3-2 at Old Trafford, chiefly thanks to Redondo. Playing further forward than usual, he also produced the moment of this year's Champions League. First, it must be said that humiliating United's Henning Berg is a realistic proposition. It has been done before, usually by Berg himself. But Redondo defined the art. Sprinting with Berg to the goalline, he back-heeled the ball through the Norwegian's legs, collected it and passed to Raúl who scored Real's third goal. Later Rinus Michels, the authoritarian former manager of Holland, was asked about that back-heel. Surely he would never have tolerated it? 'That boy,' said Michels, 'would never have heard anything about it from me.' Alex Ferguson noted that all loose balls that night had seemed to fall to Redondo. 'What does this player have in his boots?' Ferguson asked. 'A magnet?' Redondo is indeed more than a playmaker - at his best, he hoovers the midfield. United escaped lightly. In the semi-finals Redondo and Raúl deliberately humiliated Bayern Munich. At times the two had fun simply passing to each other, making jokes about Carsten Jancker as the huge striker lumbered after the ball. More than once Redondo showed the ball to Bayern's Stefan Effenberg, waited for Effenberg to pounce, and then rolled it to a team-mate. The Germans also sulked about a particularly frivolous bicycle-kick by Roberto Carlos. This, they felt, was bad manners. In this Real side, Redondo and Raúl - perhaps the two key players - are best mates. Both like their peace before games. In the next few days, while his colleague Steve McManaman whiles away the time watching films and Nicolas Anelka and Geremi are busy on their Playstations, Redondo and Raúl will be reading bound volumes of paper known as books. The Thin One enjoys Jorge Luis Borges, Gabriel García Márquez and Italian fashion magazines. Wednesday could be Redondo's day: Anelka, Raúl and Fernando Morientes are exactly the quick forwards he needs. Alternatively, Valencia could win 6-0 again.

webTitle: Stewart stands firm to prove point despite criticism

fields.headline: Stewart stands firm to prove point despite criticism
fields.trailText: The former England captain has answered the doubters this week with a strong display of batting in the one-sided first Test at Lord's.
fields.body:
'A great day for. A great day for Darren [Gough]. A great day for England. And a great day for Chelsea.' So said a happy Alec Stewart after this monumentally one-sided day of Test cricket.

Other than that, England's most durable batsman was happy to let all talk focus on the fast bowler who had bowled, he said, 'as quick as I've ever seen'.

Asked if he knew what speed he had registered, a smiling Gough replied: 'About 90 today. And about 93.7 in the first innings.'

It was Stewart who pointed out that Gough's most dangerous deliveries were those that dismissed the left-handers, and the bowler confirmed that swinging the ball back into these batsmen - 'up the slope' - had been gratifying. 'When you get a great rhythm and it's coming out well it will go like that.'

Rather obscured in this euphoria was the performance of the leading batsman of the Nineties. We are not talking here about Sachin Tendulkar or Brian Lara, or either of the Waugh twins. On runs scored, the honour falls to Alec Stewart, with 6407 at 40.80. And that average has since risen.

And yet the cry from the bar-room has been for the removal of Stewart, now 37, in favour of younger players. It is an argument in which logic has been twisted by Stewart's dual role as wicketkeeper-batsman, the false assumption being that he is a makeshift keeper.

David Lloyd, in his just-published Anything But Murder, describes the dropping of Stewart, in 1996, for the first Test of Lloyd's reign as coach. Manager Ray Illingworth is implicated, though Lloyd stops short of saying that he disagreed.

Indeed, he seems to be admitting something as he says: 'To my great and lasting regret [Stewart's] most effective role in the side has never been satisfactorily resolved. The saga of what to do with Stewart has been a running sore at selection meetings for much of the past decade.'

Stewart has not since been omitted on form, and now he seems to be benefiting from a permanent placement at No 5. One almost forgets that he also keeps wicket as, upright and positive, he takes command in the middle of the innings.

Sometimes it seems he is not so much about the receive the ball as to hold court. He prepares with familiar mannerisms: the backward dragging of the bat to brush away offending debris, the trademark twirling of the vertical bat.

Tennis also came to mind with a shot midway through the morning that was trademark Stewart. It was a pull to midwicket off the slow-medium Paul Strang in which the arms stayed long, the head still, the body tall, and it was as dismissive as any forehand, crosscourt winner on Centre Court.

There were also a couple of alarms in mid-morning. Against the occasionally dangerous Neil Johnson, Stewart pulled at successive leg-side balls that were not quite the right line or length.

He survived narrowly, the second time thanks only to umpiring doubt as wicketkeeper Flower scooped up the under-edge. That apart, Stewart's morning progress to 59 was sedate, setting up the charge to 100 which he reached within an hour of the lunch break.

There was certainty as the front foot went to the ball, precision in the straight descent of the bat, harmony in the timing as the ball fled through the field. Three fours in successive balls from Heath Streak - two square drives and a pull to wide long-on - were gloriously emphatic.

As for Graham Hick, it is worth noting that he is now a much more orthodox, as well as relaxed, batsman. Mike Atherton and Mark Ramprakash, too, are models of orthodoxy.

Suddenly, Australians no longer seem to be playing a different game as they stand upright and calm at the crease and play either forward or back.

Yes, England yesterday were lording it over modest opponents. But it does seem that they have at last got their best batsmen together, and it could just be that these fellows can do the business on the world stage.

fields.headline: Lloyd's bark not so terrible
fields.trailText: Vic Marks: The publication of David Lloyd's book Anything But Murder follows a well-worn path. Predictably there are one or two spicy bits that attract attention.
fields.body:
The publication of David Lloyd's book Anything But Murder follows a well-worn path. Lloyd, like his predecessor Raymond Illingworth, moved seamlessly from the commentary box to the role of England coach. Inevitably as soon as possible after he had relinquished his England duties he delivered his book just as Illingworth did when he published One Man Committee written in conjunction with Jack Bannister. Then he resumed his slot in front of a microphone. At least, unlike Glenn Hoddle, he had stopped coaching the national team before telling us the 'inside story'.

Predictably there are one or two spicy bits that attract attention. In Illingworth's book the focus was often Devon Malcolm; in Lloyd's we learn that Graham Thorpe was 'surly', and Andrew Caddick was regarded as a 'nerd' - assessments that may provoke some new nicknames in the England dressing room. This creates the odd headline; sales increase while Lloyd protests in countless interviews that these observations are taken out of context; for a week or so one or two players are miffed and then life goes on.

In fact Lloyd's book is rather more balanced than the headlines suggest. Thorpe may be surly but is also 'one of our box-office players'. Caddick, we finally learn, is 'a grand lad; we get along great, but he does put his big, clumsy foot in it now and again' - titbits that don't make great headlines. Lloyd's strongest criticisms are aimed not at the players but at the ECB and in particular Tim Lamb, with whom he clearly had a frosty relationship. Lloyd is forever summoned to his study, feeling like a naughty schoolboy.

'They seemed to want a paperwork mountain and a nanny state,' says Lloyd about the ECB. This is a valid warning signal. The ECB has mushroomed in size in recent years, employing almost as many people as all the other cricketing boards put together. Centralisation of everything seems to be the goal and it is always worth asking whether this is: a) necessary, and b) affordable.

Lloyd also recalls England's infamous little tour to Zimbabwe, a trip that soon established that 'my honeymoon in the job was well and truly over... to my detractors Zimbabwe will always be a rope to hang me with'. This may explain why he devotes so much space to that tour, detailing the poor accommodation, sub-standard practice facilities and the lack of cooperation from the hosts. All these protestations seem a little hollow at the moment.

Here in England we have the Zimbabwean cricket team; back home their country is in disarray so that the players must be constantly anxious about the welfare of their families. Their cricketers are being rewarded with the princely sum of £3,000 for their three-month trip to England and since inflation is so rampant in Zimbabwe that figure might be reduced, in real terms, by 15 per cent by the time they return. And key players are absent through injury. Yet we have not heard one jot of self-pity from their squad, who are determinedly soldiering on when everything - including the toss - is against them. In this context the protestations about all the hardships that had to be endured in Zimbabwe three years ago still seem insufficient to justify the surly demeanour and the poor performances of that England touring team.

Lloyd, for all his virtues - his boundless enthusiasm and his determination to give his players every possible prop, whether they be psychologists, bowling coaches or bonding weekends halfway up a Welsh mountain - occasionally lost his sense of perspective. His successor, the measured Duncan Fletcher, is unlikely to fall into the same trap. If the rain intervenes today and tomorrow leaving Zimbabwe with nine wickets down at the conclusion of this Test match, don't anticipate a 'We flipping murdered 'em' from him.

fields.headline: Lehmann's point
fields.trailText: Just a glimmer of Darren Lehmann is normally enough to set the pulse racing and the diehards scattered around the County Ground on an increasingly wind-chilled final day were grateful for that as the match meandered to an indeterminate conclusion.
fields.body:
Just a glimmer of Darren Lehmann is normally enough to set the pulse racing and the diehards scattered around the County Ground on an increasingly wind-chilled final day were grateful for that as the match meandered to an indeterminate conclusion.

The South Australian lefthander has warmed to the task in his last two championship outings, and a reliable batting track offered all the encouragement needed after 115.3 overs were lost to rain in the first three days.

He grew in confidence through the first session then launched into a round of robust strokeplay for his first hundred of the season as the break beckoned.

Derbyshire, 46 in arrears when Yorkshire were dismissed for 349, tucked into a depleted attack and soon erased the deficit with Stephen Stubbings's first half-century in the championship. Matthew Dowman drove Jamie Middlebrook to cover, but Michael Di Venuto looked in ominous form, undefeated on 42, when the hosts took tea boasting a lead of 92.

The Tasmanian finished on 81 not out, made off only 76 balls, while Stubbings cruised to a career-best, unbeaten 84 before the weather had the last word with 21 overs remaining.

Yorkshire were looking to maintain a slender lead over arch rivals Lancashire at the head of the championship and were in no mood to dispense favours at the outset. David Byas, the captain, defied what some saw as convention on a bright morning and batted on, still 87 behind Derbyshire's 303 with three wickets in hand.

Reducing the points for victory this season from 16 to 12 has made the acquisition of batting points and a draw a more attractive proposition in certain instances, and the Scarborough farmer evidently deemed this the furrow to plough. An extra point was always well within their reach, of course, and Lehmann's eighth century for Yorkshire, his forty-fifth overall, ensured they eventually gained another.

Byas was no doubt mindful of not granting the opposition undue leeway in a nine-team Division One competition, and his team's bowling attack have been ravaged on all fronts, with Craig White keeping Darren Gough company at Lord's, and Chris Silverwood and Ryan Sidebottom, withdrawn late here, laid low by heel and groin injuries respectively.

Middlebrook is not renowned for his batting, but Lehmann was grateful for some support as the cloud cover thickened and the youngster unfurled a couple of expansive cover drives worthy of the Australian himself on the way to a career-best 45.

Karl Krikken missed stumping him off Simon Lacey then Lehmann was dropped at midwicket off Matt Cassar before the pair posted an eighth-wicket record of 114 for Yorkshire in matches against Derbyshire.

Colin Wells, the Derbyshire cricket manager, had earlier assured any who cared to listen that Tim Munton would be ready to bowl after a nasty accident in practice on Thursday, but 40 stitches in a gashed eyebrow prompted a rethink. Rob Bailey's apologetic off-spin eventually did for Middlebrook, then Matthew Hoggard was clean bowled by Cassar as Yorkshire strove for a seventh bonus point.

Lehmann, after previous championship scores of 95 (against Derbyshire at Headingley) and 85, was determined to crack on after reaching his hundred, and took the long handle to anything over-pitched before levering a catch to Dominic Cork at leg gully for 113 immediately after lunch.

His five-hour innings included 14 fours off 234 balls, an effort of enough poise and vibrancy to stir even the hardiest of Peakites. Cassar's devotion to a rigorous fitness campaign after two years of injury problems earned a career best six for 76.

fields.headline: Joy of starring with 'Pfeiffer'
fields.trailText: Ed Giddins reflects on a remarkable performance for England with the ball.
fields.body:
Five for 15 in a Test at Lord's is more than I could have hoped for, particularly as my selection wasn't confirmed until the morning of the game.

Since spending the winter at Lilleshall, I have woken up at six o'clock sharp whether I like it or not. That was the time of my early morning run, but on Thursday it was a case of checking for cloud cover. There wasn't a cloud to be seen.

I felt there was a chance that I wouldn't be picked, but still had to prepare myself for five to eleven as though I was definitely in the team. My routine involves visualising what I intend doing: fluent run-up, pitch it on leg and hit the top of off with a good follow-through. Simple, really.

The clouds duly arrived and at 9.38am I was told I was in, which was a great moment.

At the Oval last year, I was far more nervous than I thought I would be, and I think that adversely affected my performance. This time around I was extremely calm and confident. I keep harping on about the mental side of the game, but it is incredibly important. I have not spoken to any of the other guys about nerves, but feel I've conquered that little problem.

It has to be said that Nasser Hussain is a top tosser. He has won seven out of nine as captain of England and we were all delighted to put the Zimbabweans in. Andy Caddick got us off to a great start with those three quick wickets bowling into the wind, and then I took over from him.

Andy Flower edged my fourth ball to Michael Atherton at slip and I was off and running. Whittall played on, Streak got an edge, Ramps took a sharp catch to get rid of Strang and, finally, Johnson skied one to Darren Gough, who had a little juggle before giving me my fifth wicket.

In the England dressing room is an honours board with the names of all those who have taken a 'Pfeiffer' - five for, geddit? - for England in a Lord's Test. I'm thrilled that my name is going to be up there with the greats of the past 120 years. In fact, 'ESH Giddins 5-15' is up there already, courtesy of Alec Stewart, some tape and his daughter's stencil.

The back-slapping started almost immediately. The team have been great and I got some good-natured ribbing from the other bowlers. Duncan Fletcher has been fantastic, and I got a message along the lines 'Well bowled, you creep' from Bob Woolmer. The Warwickshire boys have all left messages on my phone, most of which have been incredibly rude. There is another reason for their enthusiasm. I think they feel that my performance may keep me away from Warwickshire for a while.

My family were there as well, which was special, and I think they have been in the pub for the past couple of days as they tend to get a little overexcited.

One bloke who really deserves my thanks is Matt Asquith. He was my personal instructor at Lilleshall over the winter and he kept me going. At six o'clock on a freezing December morning, it is very tempting to turn up the radiator and go back to sleep, but Matt always coaxed me out of bed for a run. He was always encouraging during the tough times - and there were several - and has become a good friend.

It's difficult to know how I feel about what has happened. I haven't looked at the papers yet, although I gather a fair bit has been written. It seems strange, but I can't get too excited. I'm very aware that the next time I get the ball in my hand I might go wicketless and get carted for 150, and everything would be forgotten.

This game has seen me achieve my highest score in a Test with the bat - a sparkling five-ball seven. Goughie did a great job yesterday evening and now we want to get the job finished as quickly as possible.

I've always had huge self-belief and I'm more determined than ever to go out there and do it again.

fields.headline: House bailed out
fields.trailText: A dismissal in a million, England collapses frustrate an artist, and cameras, cameras everywhere.
fields.body:
It was bizarre. In fact it sounds just like one of those hypothetical little teasers dreamt up for an umpiring quiz night. But it actually happened last Wednesday night at Hove.

As Sussex's Will House was playing at a Glenn McGrath delivery, the leg bail, unnoticed, was dislodged by the strong wind. A split second later the off bail went in conventional fashion as the ball hit that stump, and House departed bowled.

It was only later that TV replays revealed the strange sequence. Seeing that on their dressing-room screen, Sussex wondered if their man had perhaps been hard done by.

Not so. Even if the umpires had realised what had occurred they were unlikely to have recalled the batsman, for the laws state: 'If one bail is off, it shall be sufficient... to remove the remaining bail.' This may have been framed to cater for run-outs when the wicket has already been broken, but the wording would also have covered the Hove episode.

House can at least be con soled that his was a one-in-a-million dismissal, maybe even one in several billion.

All power to the woman in the white hat. Jocelyn Galsworthy has now painted about 90 cricket grounds, many of them featuring in her just-published White Hats and Cricket Bats (Swan Hill Press, £25). They are grounds on which the sun is always shining. But the cricket executives who so gallantly find a special place for the artist and her easel, and murmur appreciatively at the result, may be unaware of dark thoughts beneath the brush strokes.

Galsworthy has been tormented by England collapses, starting with the two-and-a-half-day Test at Edgbaston in 1995. 'I could see what was going to happen but couldn't react in time,' she recalls. 'Now I know you can't rely on them, and I've got to make sure I get in all the essentials pretty quickly.'

She complains that when England wickets fall no one stops the rot. 'I've been so ashamed all over the world, not only with the way they've played but the way they've behaved. They've got no discipline, no self-control. And the practising has been so unprofessional it's looked childish. It changed a lot last winter, thank goodness.'

Though her love for the 'intelligent' game of cricket is undiminished, and her career is now entirely focused on painting grounds, Galsworthy also has a poor opinion of the county game. 'As a member, I shudder at the state of Hampshire. They thought Shane Warne would change it, but it doesn't work like that. County cricket is an appallingly low standard. Players shouldn't be paid for it - only Test players should have contracts - and county second elevens should be scrapped.'

But the World Cup was a revelation to her. 'It was the first coloured clothing I had painted, and often it enhanced a vivid scene on small county grounds. It's a pity we can't have more music and flags in our cricket. And more international cricket brought to the counties.'

While the lights flicker on and off at Hove, up at Edgbaston they're pressing their bid to be the first English Test ground with permanent lighting. Warwickshire have appealed against a local decision to refuse the installation, and now rely on a public inquiry next month.

Should they succeed, they ought to try to learn from Hove. Sussex, the flag-bearers in floodlights, are worried at the level of back-up for their permanent lights.

They urgently need to fix 'something that is shorting in one pylon, tripping a generator'. The resulting 20-minute delay in the day-night match last week proved critical, as Sussex were just short of their target when the rain came.

The challenge of Channel 4's coverage seems to have stimulated further innovation from rivals Sky. New this season is a 'rail camera' just outside the boundary, shuttling back and forth between extra cover and point (and the leg-side equivalent).

The aim is to put the viewer in the boots of the sprinting 'sweeper' trying to head off boundaries. Likewise, a special camera lined up behind backward point gives the viewer a feel of dynamic catches and stops in the position made famous by Jonty Rhodes. Short of wearing 3-D glasses, is there anything more the viewer can have to get right into the game? Actually there is. Sky are experimenting with putting a camera in the wicketkeeper's floppy hat.

fields.headline: Gough shatters Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst: Tourists collapse in the face of a hopeless task as Hick and Stewart put England out of reach
fields.trailText: Tourists collapse in the face of a hopeless task as Hick and Stewart put England out of reach.
fields.body:
A fearsome late-evening burst from Darren Gough, the least likely of the English bowlers in the first innings, multiplied the torment of the Zimbabweans on their nightmarish first appearance in a Test match at Lord's. Hurtling in from the Pavilion End, he overwhelmed four Zimbabwean batsmen, through pace and devilish swing, leaving the tourists in an utterly hopeless position unless there are now two days of uninterrupted rain. Faced with a first innings deficit of 332, Zimbabwe are 39 for five.

Unlike Thursday, when Gough was the sole wayward English bowler, he was bang on target from the start. And he was fast. After each delivery he glanced not so surreptitiously at the 'speedster' on the boundary's edge. It always registered between 87 and 90 mph - too fast for the tourists' upper order. For an hour, Lord's was the Yorkshire imp's playground and the Zimbabweans were out of their depth.

Grant Flower was stuck on the crease and palpably lbw in Gough's first over. Then Trevor Gripper edged to Nick Knight at third slip, and the validity of the catch was referred to the third umpire just as it had been in the morning when Stewart gloved the ball to Andy Flower. Gripper, unlike Alec Stewart, was greeted with the red light.

Soon to follow him was Alistair Campbell, hapless and helpless against a fast inswinger. Plumb lbw. Andrew Caddick, lacklustre by comparison from the Nursery End, now intervened. Murray Goodwin, who ended up in a postion that only French cricketers could justifiably employ, was struck on the pads. Plumb lbw.

Gough had not finished yet. Brian Murphy, the nightwatchman, foolishly took a single to expose his besieged captain and Zimbabwe's best batsman, Andy Flower. Again Gough produced a wonderful delivery to the left-hander: fast, yet swinging into him. Plumb lbw. These were not difficult decisions for the umpires. A trickier one now had to be addressed. At 36 for five, Nasser Hussain had the temerity to ask for the extra half-hour. Remarkably this request was granted, but the bad light prevented it being used to the full.

The Zimbabweans had been blown away, utterly outclassed, yet it's still tricky to assess how much progress this represents for the English side. They have been clinically ruthless throughout, but there is this considerable proviso: they are playing against a poor side playing badly.

If Gough was the central figure of the final session; the first belonged to Graeme Hick, the second to Alec Stewart. Both of these hit centuries, but Hick's may be the most significant. His celebrations were modest by modern standards, just a raised bat to the crowd, a firm handshake with his partner, Stewart, and a relieved smile.

Again the temptation for hyperbole should be resisted. Hick had played well, occasionally dismissing the ball to midwicket with the disdain he showed in the Eighties. He looked uncommonly relaxed, but let's not talk of 'the dawn of a new era' just yet. Hick himself certainly won't. 'Yes, I enjoyed myself out there, but let's just see if I can get through the whole summer in the England team; that would be a first,' he said afterwards.

On a rare dry morning, Hick seemed more likely to be dismissed run out by Stewart than by the Zimbabwean bowlers. He waited for the ball expertly, and against some of Zimbabwean seamers you have to wait a long time. Stewart was less at ease; he scratched around for three-quarters of an hour for his first 10 runs, whereupon the Zimbabweans thought they had him. Facing Neil Johnson, Stewart attempted a pull but only managed to glove the ball down the legside. Flower, plunging forward, claimed the catch and Stewart stood his ground.

Umpire Peter Willey was in no doubt that the ball had flicked the glove, but was unsure whether it had carried; so was umpire David Orchard at square leg. So the matter was referred to the third umpire. In another era, Flower would have nodded to Stewart, who would have marched off. Typical of the Zimbabweans' luck on this tour: Stewart could stay, but later on Gripper had to go. Heath Streak subsequently reported that these decisions would be 'queried' by the Zimbabwean management

The taking of the second new ball at 246 for three was inevitable but welcomed by Stewart, who enjoys the hard ball. Immediately he dispatched Bryan Strang for two boundaries and England were serenely on their way. The tension returned briefly when Hick was on 99. Streak kept him stranded there for 26 minutes and 14 deliveries, several of which passed the outside edge. But eventually Hick eased the ball through the leg side and the modest celebra tions began. They did not last long. Streak's next delivery kept low and darted down the slope and Hick was lbw.

Knight supported Stewart without alarms throughout the afternoon, though he was almost run out when Stewart, in pursuit of his hundred, called for an unlikely second run. Applause for the century had to be delayed until it was confirmed that Knight had scrambled home. However, to the last ball before tea, Knight cut carelessly at Guy Whittall and was caught in the gully.

The English innings now disintegrated slowly. The lower order from Andy Flintoff downwards never settled and Stewart - inexplicably - could muster only nine runs in the hour after tea, when England would have been better off bowling. Whittall may have been flattered by his figures of three for 27, Streak (six for 87) most certainly wasn't.

fields.headline: Player of the week
fields.trailText: Plus all this today's fixtures and tables.
fields.body:
Tables

Glenn McGrath, Worcestershire
Glenn McGrath has been living up to his reputation: mean, dangerous and sometimes explosive. His figures in one early B&H match, 9-6-9-4, may not be bettered in any one-day match this season. At Hove in the floodlit game last Wednesday his three wickets for 19 surely won it for Worcestershire; and he followed it with five wickets for 54 in the championship match. But in the night match there was a tantrum. On being no-balled he argued at length with umpire Bob White. Jamie Carpenter then lashed the free-hit ball to the cover boundary. The young batsman got some terrible verbal for that. Finally, McGrath grabbed his jersey so hard that it drew a protest from the half-choked umpire. Afterwards, grinning Glenn was his other self as he talked cheerfully of getting 'a little bit too fired up... if I can work on that I'll be fine.' But is he working on it? Alternatively, is it the key to his success? These are key questions for a great fast bowler who is now likely to be closely monitored.

fields.headline: House us, save your city
fields.standfirst: Key staff are being driven out of London. Will Labour help them, asks  Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: Key staff are being driven out of London. Will Labour help them, asks Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
Simon Craske used to advise Ministers at the Department of Trade and Industry on the minutiae of trade policy. But, convinced he had something more to offer society, Craske gave up his high-powered civil service job three years ago to retrain as a psychiatric nurse. Next September he will qualify.

Craske, 34, is determined to live and work as a nurse in London, but he doesn't think his fellow students will be able to do the same. Most will leave the capital, he said.

'On our salaries there's no way we can afford a home. We're in an area of health which isn't sexy. I don't think I'll ever be able to buy a house near my work.'

Craske's gloomy prognosis is part of a wider malaise which is gathering momentum. All over London and the South-east, nurses, teachers, policemen and other essential workers are simply priced out of the property market. Their answer is to up sticks and leave the South-east behind.

No conclusive research has so far been commissioned detailing the region's recruitment shortages in vital services, but anecdotal evidence paints a grim picture.

A Police Federation spokeswoman said that following the abolition of officers' housing allowances in 1994, the forces in and around London have 'real difficulties' filling the ranks.

'For every three people who leave the Met, only two are recruited. We can't recruit older, maturer people with more life experience. There are officers in the South-east living on family credit and taking second jobs,' she said.

A National Union of Teachers' spokeswoman remarked last week: 'Newly qualified teachers earn £16,050 a year. On that salary, you'd be lucky to afford a semi-detached toilet in London.'

Health campaigners say there are 5,000 nursing vacancies in the capital. This cannot be unconnected to the fact that medical staff are increasingly forced to find homes in the expensive private rental sector, rather than have the NHS supply digs.

The reason is that often hospitals funded by the Private Finance Initiative or run by trusts have to raise money by selling off to developers land and homes previously earmarked for staff.

Greenwich Healthcare Trust used to supply 387 homes for staff at Greenwich District General in South-east London. Next year, it is moving into an old military hospital in nearby Woolwich. The trust says it can only supply its minimum statutory requirement: just 97 homes, with 70 reserved for doctors.

Key workers were to be have been found homes through an arrangement with a housing association. This deal fell through. Now the trust is relying on its local borough and the private rented sector to take them in.

In five years, the average price of an inner London house has almost doubled from £72,582 to £140,148, according to Nationwide Building Society figures. But the provision of social - now rebranded as 'affordable' - housing, has dwindled.

In 1985, before council house tenants had the right to buy their homes, Britain had six million council and housing association homes. Today, according to the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions, there are only 3.5 million.

Council house sales in 15 years have totalled 1.5 million. Recently, says DETR, there has been a flurry of sales, as tenants take advantage of generous sales discounts at a time when the housing market is frothing.

The Government is concerned about the growing crisis affecting key workers. Last month Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott, who runs the DETR, published the first Housing Green Paper in 23 years.

Its wide-ranging proposals could mark the biggest change in affordable housing for 40 years. They include transferring council houses to new social companies which, unlike local authorities, will be able to borrow money on the open market, using tenants' rents as secu rity for loans. The move will free up the councils to take a more strategic view of housing and regneration.

For key workers, Prescott wants to set up a Starter Home Initiative, which would subsidise the purchase of homes by those living in areas where 'house price affordability is a significant problem'.

At this stage, the DETR admits that the plan is sketchy. It is inviting mortgage providers and housing associations to come up with funding models. Plans being discussed include interest-free mortgage loans and 70 per cent mortages with loans covering the rest of the house price, redeemable once a property has been sold on.

For the Starter Home Initiative to have a real impact, mortgage providers and housing experts say the subsidies would have to be huge. 'Someone is going to have to foot the bill for higher costs in the South-east,' said one lender. There are no definitions of who exactly is a key worker. Are hospital porters, firemen and catering staff going to get assistance?'

But Alan Cherry, chairman of housebuilding firm Countryside Properties and a member of Lord Rogers' Urban Task Force, said: 'You have to recognise that at least 25 per cent of us cannot afford to buy their own house after so many years of house price growth. When I think back, I was heavily subsidised when I bought homes. Mortgage Interest Tax Relief [now abolished] was a device to get people to buy property. No one complained too much then.'

In early July, Chancellor Gordon Brown will unveil his first Comprehensive Spending Review free of the strictures of the last Conservative government's spending plans. It will be the first indication of whether Prescott's lobbying of the Treasury has borne fruit.

Last week, Prescott went public in his battle to release more money for his 'super Ministry'. He made it clear that he wants the Treasury to stump up £19bn over five years to pay for the backlog of council estate repairs.

To be fair to the Chancellor, this financial year will see the first increase in public subsidy for affordable homes since 1997. Planned spending will go up by £900m on last year's total, to £6.7bn.

But Shelter, the charity for the homeless, wants that subsidy to double. In a report published last week, it warned that 'if these pressures are not tackled, more people will live in overcrowded, miserable homes.'

It is likely that some money will be found for a Starter Home Initiative. But it is expected to be limited.

Meanwhile, housing experts believe the British obsession with home ownership should be tempered. A recent survey said 68 per cent of Britons own their homes, and 90 per cent aspire to do so.

These days, there is a discernible energy emanating from housing associations and registered social landlords. Many are developing schemes which bring together private sector tenants and those needing well-built, harmonious estates.

In Hackney, east London, the once-notorious Holly Street estate, home to more than 3,000 people, has been transformed from an unforbidding series of 'snake and tower' blocks into a mixed- tenure neighbourhood where parents are not afraid to let their children play outside.

It is the result of a public-private partnership between the local council, the Housing Corporation and private finance from Laing Homes. There, you can enter into share ownership contracts or buy a home outright. But 66 per cent of the dwellings are reserved for rent, either through the council or housing associations.

For key workers to benefit from similar initiatives, council lists will have to be reorganised. Again, measures are in place to do this which will finally sound the death knell for the 'sink estate' syndrome.

But for a new age of affordable housing to begin, the Chancellor will have to show a willingness to release more cash in July.

The midwife
Penny Bart, 27, is a language graduate now training to become a midwife at Greenwich District General, London. Brought up in West Sussex, she likes her department because it is open to modern midwifery techniques and she deals with mums-to-be from different ethnic backgrounds.

But she admits that if she decides to start a family, she will be forced to leave London. 'If I wanted to have a baby, I don't know if I'd settle the way things are now.' Bart is moving out of her flat at Greenwich Hospital which is to close. The trust is, she says, making a fortune from selling prime real estate. She is now moving to a less safe area of South-east London.

The nurse
Matthew Stonebrdge is a 34-year-old social policy graduate who spent two years as a care assistant and is now a nurse at St Barts in the City of London. He supplements his nursing wage with an evening bar job in Islington.

Stonebridge spends £100 on rent each week and says he is in debt 'before he walks out of the door'. He is considering two career options. One is to jack in nursing altogether with the aim of finding a career offering a better wage.

What is more likely, Stonebridge says, is that he will eventually become a nursing lecturer away from the South-east, which will be less stressful work with better pay.

fields.headline: Caddick completes the rout
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe 83 and 123
England 415
England won by an innings and 209 runs
fields.trailText: In a result as predictable as that of the election for mayor of London, England won the first test of the summer against Zimbabwe shortly before four o'clock yesterday afternoon.
fields.body:
In a result as predictable as that of the election for mayor of London, England won the first test of the summer against Zimbabwe shortly before four o'clock yesterday afternoon.

After rain destroyed much of the first two days, Saturday's decisive play, in which England gained a first-innings lead of 332 and then, in the gloaming, Zimbabwe were reduced to a shambolic 39 for five, ensured that the game was up for the visitors provided the weather held out.

Rain kept the players from the field until 2.10 yesterday afternoon but less than two hours later Andy Caddick and Ed Giddins between them had taken the wickets that remained after Darren Gough had sliced through the top order the previous evening.

The final wicket, that of Pommie Mbangwa, who headed a bouncer on to his middle stump as precisely as if he had nodded the winning goal in the African Nations Cup, gave Caddick match figures of seven for 66 to go with Gough's six for 93 and Giddins' seven for 42 which earned him, in his second test, the man of the match award.

Apart from Andy Flintoff briefly in the first innings, no one else bowled for England in the match, certainly not the young wrist-spinner Chris Schofield who, as he made a second-ball duck on Saturday, enjoyed the most earthshattering debut since that of Gavin Hamilton at the Wanderers last winter. Unlike Hamilton, however, Schofield finished on the winning side and his time will come.

The winning margin, an innings and 209 runs, would have been wider still had not some vigorous hitting from Bryan Strang, who made 37 from as many balls largely at the expense of Gough, flogged the score into three figures.

England have now won 77 matches by an innings and, at 92 for nine and only Mbangwa to come, it seemed that the impending defeat for Zimbabwe would be the third heaviest ever inflicted by England. The last-wicket stand of 31 was the highest of the innings, though, and Nasser Hussain and his side must settle for eighth place.

Rather than let the players drift off home, Hussain insisted that they dined as a unit last night, part in celebration but also for a first debrief. In offering congratulations on a job well done, he and the coach Duncan Fletcher will none the less have tethered the side to this planet.

There was much to admire in the overall performance, not least the bowling, with Caddick's irresistible display on the first morning setting the agenda, Giddins justifying his selection ahead of Steve Harmison with some clever manipulation of the ball at a lively pace, and Gough, stung by the success of others in the first innings, roaring in on Saturday evening and claiming four wickets through sheer pace and swing.

The dismissals of the left-handers Alistair Campbell and Andy Flower, both lbw to fast deliveries which swung in late, will have raised a few eyebrows in the Caribbean, where the West Indies batting order is loaded with left-handers.

The bowlers were backed up by first-rate close catching and there was also the sight of an England team reaching 415 and so taking a first-innings lead for only the second time in 20 matches.

Against a Zimbabwean side who lacked teeth, with the exception of Heath Streak who took six for 87, runs were at less of a premium than they will be in the coming months against stronger attacks. But Graeme Hick's 101 represented an ominous return in his ninth incarnation as a test cricketer and his extreme discomfort when on 99, given that he had passed that milestone on 109 previous occasions, shows how much he needed three figures. Alec Stewart's unbeaten 124 reaffirmed his comfort down the order, even if he was most telling against the hardness of the second new ball.

It was, for the most part, a classy effort. However, the management team will not have lost sight of the fact that for all their failures over the past few years it was back in 1995, when West Indies beat them, that England last lost the first match of the summer. In three of four opening matches since then India, Australia and New Zealand were all trounced, and a probable win over South Africa was spoiled by the weather.

There is much room for improvement, in particular the manner in which the England innings was allowed to stagnate in its later stages. In normal circumstances, with weather set fair, there would be no imperative other than to score as many runs as possible. But this match was going to involve dodging the showers and an Australian side, say, would have pushed ahead on Saturday afternoon. Losing their last six wickets for 39 and scoring at only three runs an over while doing so - Stewart took almost two hours to score 24 after he had completed his century - represented time wasted.

What England lacked on Saturday was the ability to take the game by the throat, something that may come with practice as it has with the Australians, and the courage to decide that, having bowled the opposition out cheaply first time around, they had the bowlers to do it a second time.

webTitle: The Brazilians are coming... to Wales and England

fields.headline: The Brazilians are coming... to Wales and England
fields.standfirst:
Wales v Brazil (Millennium Stadium, Tuesday 7.30pm)
England v Brazil (Wembley, Saturday 3pm)
fields.trailText: A Who's Who of the Brazil squad to face England and Wales.
fields.body:
Goalkeepers
Dida (Corinthians) Age 26, 28 caps
Now the regular first choice and the successor to Taffarel, he has an excellent record at saving penalties and a very poor record at being caught off his line.
Carlos Germano (Santos) Age 29, 9 caps
Third reserve goalkeeper in France and always consistent at club level, all his caps have come in friendlies. The last was in the surreal World Cup warm-up against Andorra, played in a third division Parisian stadium, two years ago. He kept a clean sheet.

Defenders
Antonio Carlos (AS Roma) Age 31, 28 caps
Forms the central defensive partnership with Aldair but is an unpopular choice with Brazilian critics and has a violent streak, best demonstrated when he was once sent off for kicking the doctor of an opposing team who was on the pitch to treat a player.
Aldair (AS Roma) Age 34, 76 caps
Veteran of the past two World Cups whose experience is seen by Luxemburgo as crucial in the volatile world of South American qualifying matches but whose slowing legs give Brazilians the jitters.
Cafu (AS Roma) Age 29, 87 caps
The third of the AS Roma trio, he has been the only real candidate for the position since taking over from Jorginho early in the 1994 World Cup final.
Evanilson (Borussia Dortmund) Age 24, 9 caps
Cafu's understudy, he has reached the national side without ever making much impression in Brazilian domestic football.
Roberto Carlos (Real Madrid) Age 27, 70 caps
The left-back's boomerang-like shot seems to be hitting defensive walls with worrying frequency these days but he still has no real challengers.
Silvinho (Arsenal) Age 26, 0 caps
His inclusion was greeted with surprise as Brazilians have almost no idea how he has been playing at Arsenal. Strangely, he was never in the national team reckoning when he was playing in his own country.
Emerson (Portuguesa) Age 25, 0 caps
he latest uncapped central defender to be picked as Luxemburgo continues his search to end Brazil's vulnerability in this position.

Midfielders
Cesar Sampaio (Palmeiras) Age 32, 40 caps
Ever present in the World Cup two years ago, he was left in the lurch by Luxemburgo until being picked to face Ecuador last month.
Flavio Conceicao (Deportivo La Coruna) Age 25, 37 caps
Defensive midfielder with a powerful shot, his efforts in the Spanish league have been rewarded with only his second recall since injury cost him a place in the World Cup two years ago.
Emerson (Bayer Leverkusen) Age 24, 26 caps
Dunga's successor is seen by his club coach as the perfect example of a modern player. Brazilian critics are less convinced and see him as something of an uncultured hatchet man. He is certainly never afraid to foul the opposition but he also has a good goalscoring record at international level.
Ze Roberto (Bayer Leverkusen) Age 25, 35 caps
Has kept his place in the squad despite criticism of his performances in Brazil's two World Cup qualifiers. Nippy and skillful but not really effective at international level. Like Rivaldo and Roberto Carlos, he loathes to even touch the ball with his right foot.
Rivaldo (Barcelona) Age 28, 39 caps
The world's number one saved Brazil from humiliation last month when he scored a quick equaliser after they had fallen behind to Ecuador in a World Cup qualifier. He has the full confidence of Luxemburgo, his mentor when the pair were at Palmeiras in the mid-Nineties.

Forwards
Amoroso (Parma) Age 24, 12 caps.
One of Luxemburgo's preferred strikers, though injury has hampered his career throughout. He gives plenty of support to those who see South Americans as born divers.
Elber (Bayern Munich) Age 27, 11 caps
His exploits for the Bavarian club seem to weigh more heavily than his performances for his country when Luxemburgo picks his squad. Elber has rarely impressed at international level and certainly lacks the spark of players such as Romario and Edmundo.
Franca (Sao Paulo) Age 24, 0 caps
Has earned what many, including himself, see as a belated call up after some prolific scoring for his club.
Romario (Vasco) Age 34, 62 caps
Has looked as sharp as ever this year, yet has still to play a full international under Luxemburgo. He was excluded from last year's Copa America squad for declaring: 'I want to win another title.' Luxemburgo's reply was: 'A player who conjugates a verb in the first person singular cannot be part of the squad. He has to conjugate the verb in the first person plural. We. We want to conquer. We are going to conquer...'

fields.headline: Di Matteo does it again
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 0 - 1 Chelsea
fields.body:
They gave the old thing a decent send-off, but not even fireworks and about a thousand Tannoy mentions of the Twin Towers' impending doom could conceal the fact that the last FA Cup final before Wembley is pulled down was about as threadbare as the Venue of Legends itself.

The only goal was scored by Roberto Di Matteo, who owns the record for fastest FA Cup final strike with his 43-second rocket against Middlesbrough three years ago. This one took 72 minutes longer to arrive, but was no less welcome. Another half-hour would have tried everybody's patience, and the prospect of another penalty shoot-out between an English side and a foreign one was too awful to contemplate.

The result was a fair one, too. Aston Villa managed to contain Chelsea's illustrious attack for half the game, but hardly threatened going forward. John Gregory's players had gone into a huddle before kick-off, perhaps for a discussion about where their goals might come from, for though David James is sure to take some blame for his part in the goal, the bluntness of Villa's attack was just as big a factor in the final outcome. 'We didn't do enough in the final third, but that's been the story of our season,' Gregory said.

Villa actually enjoyed the better of one of Wembley's more mundane opening half-hours, managing to keep Chelsea pinned back in their own half even if the sum total of their early pressure amounted to a couple of well-flighted free-kicks and an optimistic shot over the bar from Paul Merson.

Dennis Wise brought the first save of the game when he volleyed straight at James from the edge of the area in the ninth minute, but though George Weah showed a couple of clever touches, he and the equally isolated Gianfranco Zola were mere spectators to most of the first-half action. Gianluca Vialli had preferred Zola to Tore Andre Flo, and after paying £10m for Chris Sutton at the start of the season Vialli couldn't even find a place for him on the bench.

It was one of those games that needed something unexpected to liven it up, yet nothing short of a bomb or the early arrival of Wembley's demolition men appeared likely to shake the players out of their torpor. Even the bookings were niggly non-events. Gareth Barry and Mario Melchiot, a late replacement for the injured Albert Ferrer, collected cautions after tit-for-tat fouls on each other midway through the first half, and Wise in one of his more mischievous moods was correctly pulled up by referee Graham Poll for a sneaky attack on George Boateng's ankles.

The first half's most entertaining event, by far, came right at the end, when Dion Dublin, perhaps frustrated by winning so many aerial challenges and seeing so little come from the knock-downs, hurled Frank Leboeuf to the ground by the scruff of the neck as he shepherded the ball in his own area. Surprisingly, neither the referee nor his linesman saw anything wrong with the blatant shove, and somewhat less surprisingly, there was little sympathy from the crowd when the Frenchman stayed on the ground theatrically clutching a hamstring.

Leboeuf reappeared for the second half, which, by the time it was 10 minutes old, had provided more incident and entertainment than the entire first half. First Gareth Southgate headed over from Merson's cross, then Zola found Weah at the other end for the Liberian to produce a shot on the turn that flew a foot wide of the right post.

Neither goalkeeper had had much to do by this stage, but James had showed signs of nerves when spilling a first-half cross, and looked uncomfortable again in the 53rd minute when saving from Di Matteo but making a present of the ball to Wise. The Chelsea captain accepted the gift gratefully, but his side's celebrations were cut short by an offside flag raised against Weah.

After Gus Poyet had become the second Chelsea player cautioned for a foul on Boateng, Weah had the chance to make amends on the hour when a teasing Zola cross eluded Poyet and Villa's defensive cover at the near post, and ran through to Weah at the rear. Completely on his own, the former World Player of the Year struck early but wastefully wide.

At least Chelsea had managed to make an impression on the game and a goal looked much more likely. Di Matteo finally broke the deadlock after Melchiot had decided he could do more than just keep an eye on the disappointing Benito Carbone, and set off on a run that saw him swap wings and interchange passes with Celestine Babayaro before Ian Taylor brought him down near the goal-line just outside the Villa area. Zola arrowed his free-kick predictably into the danger zone, James came for a punch but only ended up knocking the ball against Southgate, and in a crowded penalty area Di Matteo was on hand to sweep the rebound high into the net. It was hardly a classic Wembley winner, not a patch on his sweet strike from outside the area three years ago, but it was always likely to be enough.

'We can only get stronger from this,' a dejected James said. 'Individual mistakes cost us the game, and mine was one of them, but we are a group of friends and we will overcome it.'

Villa brought on Julian Joachim and Steve Stone for the final 12 minutes, to little avail. Weah and Chelsea continued to have the better chances, with James continuing to have nervous moments, although shortly after the goal Leboeuf was obliged to clear off the line after De Goey had come out and missed a Merson free-kick.

Ugo Ehiogu headed Villa's last chance over the bar, and having gone up the field for a last free-kick James was spared further embarrassment by the final whistle when Chelsea won the ball.

Though this was in some ways a hollow victory, Vialli must have enjoyed his first FA Cup final as manager, with the fans singing his name at the end, more than his debut as a player. 'It's like sex, the first time is always the one you remember,' Leboeuf had said before the game. Vialli would disagree, and so would Villa's FA Cup virgins.
