Villa actually enjoyed the better of one of Wembley's more mundane opening half-hours, managing to keep Chelsea pinned back in their own half even if the sum total of their early pressure amounted to a couple of well-flighted free-kicks and an optimistic shot over the bar from Paul Merson. Dennis Wise brought the first save of the game when he volleyed straight at James from the edge of the area in the ninth minute, but though George Weah showed a couple of clever touches, he and the equally isolated Gianfranco Zola were mere spectators to most of the first-half action. Gianluca Vialli had preferred Zola to Tore Andre Flo, and after paying £10m for Chris Sutton at the start of the season Vialli couldn't even find a place for him on the bench. It was one of those games that needed something unexpected to liven it up, yet nothing short of a bomb or the early arrival of Wembley's demolition men appeared likely to shake the players out of their torpor. Even the bookings were niggly non-events. Gareth Barry and Mario Melchiot, a late replacement for the injured Albert Ferrer, collected cautions after tit-for-tat fouls on each other midway through the first half, and Wise in one of his more mischievous moods was correctly pulled up by referee Graham Poll for a sneaky attack on George Boateng's ankles. The first half's most entertaining event, by far, came right at the end, when Dion Dublin, perhaps frustrated by winning so many aerial challenges and seeing so little come from the knock-downs, hurled Frank Leboeuf to the ground by the scruff of the neck as he shepherded the ball in his own area. Surprisingly, neither the referee nor his linesman saw anything wrong with the blatant shove, and somewhat less surprisingly, there was little sympathy from the crowd when the Frenchman stayed on the ground theatrically clutching a hamstring. Leboeuf reappeared for the second half, which, by the time it was 10 minutes old, had provided more incident and entertainment than the entire first half. First Gareth Southgate headed over from Merson's cross, then Zola found Weah at the other end for the Liberian to produce a shot on the turn that flew a foot wide of the right post. Neither goalkeeper had had much to do by this stage, but James had showed signs of nerves when spilling a first-half cross, and looked uncomfortable again in the 53rd minute when saving from Di Matteo but making a present of the ball to Wise. The Chelsea captain accepted the gift gratefully, but his side's celebrations were cut short by an offside flag raised against Weah. After Gus Poyet had become the second Chelsea player cautioned for a foul on Boateng, Weah had the chance to make amends on the hour when a teasing Zola cross eluded Poyet and Villa's defensive cover at the near post, and ran through to Weah at the rear. Completely on his own, the former World Player of the Year struck early but wastefully wide. At least Chelsea had managed to make an impression on the game and a goal looked much more likely. Di Matteo finally broke the deadlock after Melchiot had decided he could do more than just keep an eye on the disappointing Benito Carbone, and set off on a run that saw him swap wings and interchange passes with Celestine Babayaro before Ian Taylor brought him down near the goal-line just outside the Villa area. Zola arrowed his free-kick predictably into the danger zone, James came for a punch but only ended up knocking the ball against Southgate, and in a crowded penalty area Di Matteo was on hand to sweep the rebound high into the net. It was hardly a classic Wembley winner, not a patch on his sweet strike from outside the area three years ago, but it was always likely to be enough. 'We can only get stronger from this,' a dejected James said. 'Individual mistakes cost us the game, and mine was one of them, but we are a group of friends and we will overcome it.' Villa brought on Julian Joachim and Steve Stone for the final 12 minutes, to little avail. Weah and Chelsea continued to have the better chances, with James continuing to have nervous moments, although shortly after the goal Leboeuf was obliged to clear off the line after De Goey had come out and missed a Merson free-kick. Ugo Ehiogu headed Villa's last chance over the bar, and having gone up the field for a last free-kick James was spared further embarrassment by the final whistle when Chelsea won the ball. Though this was in some ways a hollow victory, Vialli must have enjoyed his first FA Cup final as manager, with the fans singing his name at the end, more than his debut as a player. 'It's like sex, the first time is always the one you remember,' Leboeuf had said before the game. Vialli would disagree, and so would Villa's FA Cup virgins.

fields.headline: Villa's Jamesian comedy
fields.standfirst: After a season of rehabilitation goalkeeper is undone by one mad moment
fields.trailText: Ian Ridley witnesses a season of rehabilitation for the Villa goalkeeper undone by one moment.
fields.body:
IF YOU KEEP a clean sheet, it matters not when the winning goal comes, 43 seconds or 72 minutes. Roberto Di Matteo set Chelsea on the way to victory over Middlesbrough in the FA Cup final three years ago with that early 25-yard bolt from the Blue; yesterday he put their ribbons on it again with an equally significant one from 2.5 yards.

Poor David James. A season of tender rehabilitation at Villa after the 'Calamity James' era at Anfield, ushering him back into England's 28, was undermined in one flapping moment. In added time he desperately threw himself forward into Chelsea's penalty area in search of an equaliser from Paul Merson's free-kick that would avoid a repetition of his fate when Eric Cantona's late goal for Manchester United saw off Liverpool in '96. To no avail.

At the whistle, seconds later, he fell to the ground near the centre circle, his efforts to get back to his goal redundant. Merson lifted him to his feet but the game was up. As Dennis Wise lifted his baby son Henry (Dennis is the one on the right) and the Cup, James pulled his goalkeeper's jersey over his head in his anger and his shame. 'It went in,' he later said when asked for his take on the goal, before bravely adding: 'I took my eye off the ball. It was a silly mistake.'

At Villa's team meeting earlier in the week, the manager John Gregory wrote a sentence on the board: 'History is in your hands.' How cruelly ironic it was to prove for James, if not as cruel as the spread-betting firm who were offering odds in the morning papers on his mistakes and erstwhile nickname being resurrected. When it was all added up, a quid invested would have apparently, astonishingly, yielded £200. Venue of legends? For James and Villa it was a venue of dog ends.

They pushed the boat out at Wembley in the last final before the old pile and its faded grandeur fall victim to the wrecking ball, to be replaced by a more appropri ate modern upstart. As many former captains of winning teams since the inaugural White Horse final of 1923 as are still available were invited to the celebrations, and with special gusto the Doncaster belle Lesley Garrett belted out Abide With Me - the only part of the day your bored, put-upon mum used to enjoy.

It was difficult, as a neutral, not to feel this was a less-anticipated, less-climactic finale to an English season than usual, however. The FA have presided over a diluted sideshow of a competition this year, with Manchester United opting out, re-arranged dates that have disdained tradition, replays foregone in the latest rounds, wildcards and TV- timed games that coincide with the next round's draw.

Belatedly, the FA have recognised their mistakes in the dash for cash that is the modern game - yesterday's historic programme cost an outrageous £10 - and they are at last polishing and restoring their jewel. Next season, they say, there will be no exemptions, no wildcards and they are talking with police to have replays sanctioned again for a few days later. The next-round draws will take place on a Monday night.

Part of the event's fall from grace may have something to do with some overseas players viewing it with the mere resigned professionalism with which their own domestic cups are regarded. It was amusing to witness the players during what used to be the lump-in-throat moments of the national anthem. Only one Chelsea player, Dennis Wise, knew the words and was singing. Eight of Villa's sang and savoured the experience. Just before kick-off, they enveloped themselves in a bonding huddle.

Fired up, and unused as they are to such big occasions, Villa initially relished it the more. Dion Dublin won the first header and George Boateng snapped into the tackle against Wise, for which he later received in return a late lunge by the Chelsea captain. Managers like early intent; it can set a tone.

Indeed, Chelsea struggled to find any rhythm to their passing game after their inconsistent end to the season. How hard it is to turn on and off the flamboyance. Perhaps there was no flow because there was no Flo, Tore Andre having unluckily been left on the bench. Chelsea lack pace up front and Gianluca Vialli clearly decided that George Weah's was superior.

The Chelsea manager also deployed Gustavo Poyet wide on the right and the Wright, looking to use his phenomenal heading ability against the diminutive Alan. After 28 minutes, the Uruguayan switched flanks with Roberto Di Matteo, however. Sometimes it is not the size of the dog in the fight but the size of the fight in the dog that counts.

Not that Villa had any more joy. The idea was that Dublin would exploit Frank Leboeuf's contempt for the high ball but Villa, tentative with so much at stake, were slow to deliver and support. All game, only Merson's dead-ball skills and eye for an opening threatened to undo Chelsea.

In hindsight, a tight contest was always likely with neither side being prolific goalscorers but both adept in defence, unless they are playing Barcelona, that is. Would one inspired moment or poignant error decide? The reprieve was only temporary when an assistant referee's flag deemed Weah to have been actively involved as Wise stabbed home Di Matteo's spilled shot. Again James gave Chelsea the drop. This time it was decisive.

Now the time hurtled by, the scoreboard at each end now screaming at James, in contrast to the slow minutes before. For a long while it had looked as if we would be given another chance to see whether an English team could finally win a penalty shoot-out. On the bench, Vialli knew that Italians have had trouble with these, too, and, under pressure for his first trophy after Chelsea's Champions League exit, he will remain forever grateful to his compatriot Di Matteo.

webTitle: Soccer thugs get cash for video nasties

fields.headline: Soccer thugs get cash for video nasties
fields.standfirst: Britain powerless to halt US hooligan film
fields.trailText: British hooligans are being offered substantial cash rewards for footage of their violent exploits by film-makers who are planning to release a compilation of 'hardcore soccer violence' in time for Euro 2000.
fields.byline: Jason Burke, Denis Campbell and Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.body:
British hooligans are being offered substantial cash rewards for footage of their violent exploits by film-makers in California who are planning to release a compilation of 'hardcore soccer violence' in time for next month's European championships.

Authorities are concerned that the film, which is to include footage of attacks on police and innocent bystanders as well as pitched battles between rival gangs, will incite hooligans to further exploits.

Lord Bassam, the Home Office Minister responsible for Euro 2000, last night condemned the film as 'a perverse and appalling reaction to something that brings shame to the national game and misery to those that get caught up in it.'

He pledged that ministers and the police would investigate the possibility of banning the video, called Hooligan - No one likes us and we don't care.

Police say that the cash offer will encourage thugs. 'This means that if you go out and have a ruck and film it, you get paid. It's basically an incitement to fight', said one senior policeman involved in monitoring hooligans.

Ken Chapman, a former Metropolitan Police chief superintendent who is now Millwall's security adviser, said he was saddened that 'people want to glorify hooliganism and make a profit from it.' He said: 'The timing of it is obviously in bad taste, after Copenhagen and with Euro 2000 coming up. Sadly, though, there will be a market for this sort of thing.'

The film is being advertised through British hooligan websites with promises that buyers will get 45 minutes of 'classic scenes' of violence from soccer's history. There will be footage dating back to the Sixties as well as from clashes at the World Cup in France two years ago.

Producers of the film also hope to include footage of the violence which erupted between fans of Leeds United and Galatasary in Istanbul last month - leaving two Leeds supporters dead - and scenes from Arsenal-Galatasary in Copenhagen last week.

They expect Steve Jones, a former member of the Sex Pistols, to narrate a commentary for the film which the advertising describes as 'no interviews, just action-packed.'

Last week an Observer journalist posing as a hooligan e-mailed Stanley Video offering amateur footage of last week's fighting in Copenhagen. A swift response asked: 'What have you got and how much do you want for it?'

The Observer, in collaboration with the Europe-wide soccer news website onefootball.com has now traced the man responsible for producing the film.

He is Leslie Thompson, an English electrical contractor based in West Hollywood. Thompson originally came from Newcastle, and moved to the Los Angeles area about 20 years ago. He has a home in West Hollywood and keeps a sailing boat at Marina del Rey, near Venice Beach.

Confronted at the postal box service on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles which he uses as his business address, Thompson said: 'Obviously we're trying to make some money so it is a bit sensationalist.'

He claimed that the film did not endorse hooliganism, but 'we are showing that it's often not the fans' fault,' he said.

'Often the foreign police don't go about controlling it correctly and go over the top. The quality of policing is often not what it should be. We're just showing it more from the fans' point of view.'

Thompson said that he had received footage from all over the world. 'The video will feature hooligans of all nationalities and include some pitched battles between German and Belgian and German and Dutch fans,' he said.

As well as the Steve Jones voiceover, Thompson said the video would feature a thumping dance music soundtrack 'to heighten the atmosphere'. Asked if he anticipated criticism in Britain, Thompson said the film was 'definitely not glorifying hooliganism.'

Steve Jones's agent in Los Angeles did not respond to calls about her client's role in the video. It could be difficult to prevent distribution of the video in the UK. Since it will be bought from overseas - probably over the Internet - the regulatory authorities have limited powers to prevent its import.

The British Board of Film Classification - which regulates both films and videos - said that they would not be able to stop the hooligan video's sale.

fields.headline: Merson shown the door
fields.trailText: Exclusive: Yesterday's Cup Final could well have been Paul Merson's last game for Aston Villa. The club's player of the year has been told by the Villa manager John Gregory that he is planning to let him go this summer.
fields.body:
Yesterday's FA Cup Final could well have been Paul Merson's last game for Aston Villa. The club's player of the year, elected by both fans and his fellow players, has been told by the Villa manager John Gregory that he is planning to let him go this summer.

Merson has met Gregory twice over the past few weeks seeking a one-year extension to the two years he has left on his current contract, adding that he was willing to take a pay cut from his current basic of around £20,000 a week to stay on. He was shocked to discover that Gregory was instead willing to transfer him.

'I want to stay at Aston Villa,' says Merson, 32. 'If I could get another year, I would finish my career there but after my discussions with the manager I can't see that happening. I would say it looks 90 per cent certain that I won't be there next season.'

Merson was hoping to talk to the Villa chairman Doug Ellis at last night's post-Final party at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London, to see if there was a way of resolving the issue. But he concedes it is likely the chairman will back his manager if Gregory decides to go ahead with the sale.

Gregory last week described Merson as a 'high-maintenance' player who requires frequent reassurance and confidence-boosting as part of his recovery from addiction to gambling, alcohol and drugs. Merson in turn simply states: 'If my head is right, then my game is right.'

He has not had a bet or a drink for more than a year now and his head has been right this season. After a poor start, when he was mostly omitted, Merson returned to the team in January for the FA Cup third-round tie against Darlington and has been a regular, and an inspirational creative figure, ever since.

It could be that Gregory, having signed Luc Nilis from PSV Eindhoven and opened negotiations to keep Benito Carbone, deems Merson as surplus to requirements. In addition, he could now get a fee for him whereas in three years it is likely that Merson will have no resale value.

A fee of around £2.5 million could secure Merson, and a host of clubs are likely to be alerted by Gregory's willingness to deal. Charlton Athletic are thought to be interested, but would have to show their seriousness about the Premiership by breaking new ground in their wage structure.

Keeping Charlton in the top flight is the sort of challenge that would stimulate Merson. He moved to Middlesbrough from Arsenal and enjoyed the role of playmaker as the club won promotion. Equally, he would relish repeating his Middlesbrough role with an ambitious First Division club who could afford him.

After the break-up of his marriage, Merson has enjoyed settling into a new home at Sutton Coldfield and has built up a network of fellow recovering addicts who help each other. His willingness to stay in the area could alert Birmingham City. That, not to mention Gregory's intentions, will shock the Villa fans who voted him their player of the season and cheered their cult hero at Wembley yesterday, blissfully unaware of the doubts over his future.

fields.headline: Dons' mission impossible
fields.standfirst: They may have beaten Rangers once this season, but recent Aberdeen performances suggest the Scottish Cup is Ibrox-bound
fields.trailText: They may have beaten Rangers once this season, but recent Aberdeen performances suggest the Scottish Cup is Ibrox-bound.
fields.body:
As imbalanced contests go, Saturday's Tennents Scottish Cup final between Aberdeen and Rangers seems as grotesque a mismatch as an unarmed man fighting a lion. Having missed only two of these occasions since 1954, I find it impossible to recall one in which two teams from the same division have appeared so far apart.

Yet those supporters who arrive at Hampden park wearing the red-and-white favours will not only treat hopelessness like a leper, but will show due cause. It is a curious fact that Aberdeen's feebleness throughout this tormented season has been relieved only by two seemingly impossible results against Rangers (as well as, certainly, a performance against Hibs in the semi-final of this competition that made their place in the season's climactic showdown entirely deserved).

The Pittodrie side's extra-time victory over the league champions in the CIS Insurance Cup last autumn and their 1-1 draw in a home Premier League match on 1 April has given the club's connections enough nourishment to sustain the belief that they have a more reasonable chance of success next weekend than is widely thought, and it has certainly deepened the conviction that their prospects of landing the old trophy would be even dimmer were Celtic the opposition.

While the other three league matches against Rangers this season each ended in defeat and produced an aggregate deficit of 13-1, this seems like a minor triumph when set beside their record of 23 goals conceded and one scored in four outings against the Parkhead side.

Even Ebbe Skovdahl, the Dane who has overseen the club's fall to the bottom of the league, admitted after the last outing to Celtic Park - Aberdeen having finally scored at 5-0 down - that his players seem better able to cope with Rangers.

Skovdahl was not so rash as to offer an explanation for this curio, but drew some satisfaction from the thought that they have at least scored three times and avoided defeat twice in their five collisions with the Ibrox side.

None of this, however, can erase from the neutral observer's mind the memory of Aberdeen's lamentable performance against Celtic in the final of the CIS Cup or the thought that a similar display at the end of this week will see them eaten alive. The narrowness of the scoreline that day in March, when Celtic won 2-0, seemed to interfere with the critical faculties of some professional commentators who promoted the idea that Aberdeen had somehow 'regained their pride'.

The actual truth of the matter is that, were it possible to establish figures, the final could go down in history as the only one in which a team managed not to contrive a solitary shot on target throughout the 90 minutes. Aberdeen were fortunate, too, in meeting a Parkhead side whose own fragile confidence following the Scottish Cup débcle against Inverness Caledonian Thistle had made them more careful than usual.

In fact, careful was all Celtic had to be to win. Even so, they still hit the crossbar and squandered enough scoring opportunities in the later stages of the match to prompt the unarguable claim that they should once again have won by a handful.

In Rangers, however, Aberdeen will not be meeting opponents who have trouble with their self-belief. Having ruthlessly swatted everything in sight - only one defeat as they go into their final league match of the season at Motherwell this afternoon - Rangers are entitled to the kind of swagger that would make Mussolini look like a Franciscan.

Dick Advocaat and his players have been making unsurprising noises about the dangers of complacency and the need not to underestimate their opponents, but these smack simply of a becoming politeness on the part of the long odds-on favourites.

Managers never have far to look in the search for what they believe to be appropriate analogies in these circumstances and Advocaat duly found one in the recent French Cup final, when Nantes of the First Division were considered very fortunate to beat the amateurs of Calais 2-1.

'What happened in France should tell anybody all they need to know about the danger of complacency,' said Advocaat. But, even from this side of the Channel, it seemed clear that Calais, thanks to their performances in eliminating other top league sides such as Bordeaux on their incredible expedition through to the final, had established credentials that made them far more fancied and likelier to create an upset than Aberdeen.

Rangers' overall strength appears insurmountable for a Pittodrie team whose weakness in midfield and defence has led to their present status as officially the worst team in the Premier League.

Rangers supporters, on the other hand, have cause to be more worried about the future of the coach they have come to revere. Advocaat is under contract to the club only until the summer of 2002 and he hinted the other day that he is unlikely to stay beyond that, despite being courted by the Ibrox chairman, David Murray, with a view to enticing him into signing an extension to his existing agreement.

'David Murray is trying to keep me beyond 2002,' he said, 'but I have to think about that and discuss it with my family. I have to consider this club and the football side of this club before I can make a decision.'

This seems to be a clear indication of Advocaat's growing conviction that there is a clearly delineated limit to how far Rangers can go in European football. He has said with complete candour often enough that a certain calibre of player will simply not come to Glasgow, no matter how much money is on the table. A fact confirmed by a number of players with big reputations who have rejected the advances of both Old Firm partners in favour of a more celebrated league, such as in England, Spain or Italy.

But even if Advocaat believes he may not be able to make Rangers a great deal more formidable than they already are, they are still good enough to dispose of Aberdeen - and with plenty to spare.

Having missed only two of these occasions since 1954, I find it impossible to recall one in which two teams from the same division have appeared so far apart. Yet those supporters who arrive at Hampden park wearing the red-and-white favours will not only treat hopelessness like a leper, but will show due cause. webTitle: 'I haven't cried like that in 15 years'

fields.headline: 'I haven't cried like that in 15 years'
fields.standfirst: What they said
fields.trailText: The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr George Carey: 'It was dull, really. The game needed an early goal.' All the quotes that matter.
fields.body:
Aston Villa goalkeeper David James immediately owned up to the blunder that led to the single goal which decided the final, and admitted that he had burst into tears at the end as the magnitude of his mis take sank in: 'I think I took my eyes off the ball and it cost us the final. I have to put my hands up.'

At the final whistle, James cut a distraught figure as he lay on the Wembley turf, with his shirt pulled up above his eyes, as if trying to hide from the world. He admitted that he was in tears after the game 'for the first time in about 15 years'.

Team-mate Paul Merson rallied to James's defence, saying: 'I don't blame him for the goal. He's been in a different class all season. People make mistakes. But if it wasn't for him, we wouldn't be where we are.'

Villa captain Gareth Southgate said that Villa had given everything all afternoon 'but it wasn't quite good enough'.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr George Carey, agreed, saying: 'It was dull, really. The game needed an early goal.'

Chelsea's Italian forward Gianfranco Zola said: 'After what we produced in the game, I think we deserved it. Villa were very honourable opponents but in the end we deserved to win.'

Frank Leboeuf said Chelsea's persistence paid off: 'In the first half we didn't play very well and didn't find each other properly. But in the second half we did what we had to do: we created chances.'

Chelsea captain Dennis Wise laughed off the apparent breach of FA etiquette by some Chelsea players in bringing their children on to the pitch amid the post-match celebrations. 'I may never get the chance to do that again,' he said. 'When he gets older, he will have something to remember.'

fields.headline: Vialli vindicated with consolation prize
fields.standfirst: The Chelsea manager has saved his season but he will have to do better next year
fields.trailText: The Chelsea manager has saved his season but he will have to do better next year, says Paul Wilson.
fields.body:
Wednesday's UEFA Cup final was not a particularly good advertisement for the tournament. Arsenal were disappointing in the game, but had disappointed long before kick-off, a sobering reflection on the high stakes now being played for at the top of the Premiership and one which puts Chelsea's victory at Wembley into perspective.

Gianluca Villa was desperate to win the FA Cup because he felt his credibility needed a boost. Ending the season with a trophy always beats entering the InterToto, and few would begrudge the likeable Vialli his moment in the sun after entertaining campaigns both at home and in Europe.

Yet, with the possible exception of Aston Villa, no one regards the FA Cup as the measure of a successful season any more, and as Arsenal can testify, qualification for the Uefa Cup does not compensate for missing out on the Champions League.

Uefa have unintentionally downgraded the tournament which bears their name, despite allowing it to take over the old Cup Winners Cup, by admitting first-round losers from the Champions League. David O'Leary had a point worth considering when he described the arrival of new entrants halfway through the competition as a joke.

Had Leeds United managed to win this season's Uefa Cup the club and their fans would have rightly regarded it as a magnificent achievement. Leeds are not Champions League material yet, but having done well with such a young side to qualify for the lesser tournament through league placing, would have welcomed Uefa Cup success as evidence of continuing improvement and a mark of future ambition.

Arsenal, by virtue of the manner in which they entered the competition, are simply not entitled to view the Uefa Cup in the same light. If you set out for the Champions League and fail, everything else becomes tainted, so that while only a few years ago Arsenal would have been thrilled to be in any European final, now they are choosy about which one.

Exactly the same thing could happen to Chelsea. The club need to be in Europe, and have at least managed that, but if Marcel Desailly and Co found it hard to keep their concentration for the lesser games in the domestic programme last season they are unlikely to appreciate the delights of Thursday night football.

Sir Alex Ferguson once bought himself time at Manchester United by winning an FA Cup after four trophy-free seasons, but that was 10 years ago in the age of comparative innocence that existed pre-Premiership, pre-Champions League and pre-Bosman.

Nowadays, when United cannot even be relied upon to enter the FA Cup, a club with a salary bill the size of Chelsea's know they have to do more than bring home an FA or even a Uefa Cup every now and then.

Vialli, in common with the managers of Arsenal, Liverpool and Manchester United, can only expect to be judged on Champions League performance, both in terms of getting into the competition and prospering once there.

As Chelsea went further than Arsenal this season and departed at the same stage as United, Vialli can hardly be counted a European failure and deserves at least another season.

But, because Arsenal and United will be playing Champions League football next season and Chelsea will not, Vialli is in exactly the same position as Gérard Houllier at Liverpool. Both managers had Champions League places within their grasp, only to lose ground through inexplicable lapses of concentration against lesser teams, and both are keenly aware there will be zero tolerance in their respective boardrooms for any more of the same.

But at least Chelsea won the Cup, which is a more uplifting conclusion to the season than the one Liverpool came up with, and Vialli has a couple of weeks in peace before pondering next season's dilemma. Viz, what to do about Leeds United.

At the start of last season there were only four teams gearing up for Champions League challenges, and with only three places on offer it was obvious that either Arsenal, Chelsea or Liverpool would lose out, since no one could imagine Manchester United doing so.

Leeds came from nowhere to upset all the calculations, and, though their eventual third place owed much to Liverpudlian generosity, they are now spending the sort of money that suggests they expect to be in the top three by right next year.

Five into three doesn't go, of course, and it would take a brave man to put money on Vialli's Chelsea not finishing fifth again. It isn't just the fabled inconsistency or the foreign policy. Just look at the average ages of the five teams involved.

fields.headline: Cradle of the titans
fields.standfirst: With  Gladiator taking the critics by storm,  Angela Clarence set off across the Libyan desert to visit Leptis Magna, the ancient city which kept Rome supplied with slaves for the arena
fields.trailText: With Gladiator taking the critics by storm, Angela Clarence set off across the Libyan desert to visit Leptis Magna, the ancient city which kept Rome supplied with slaves for the arena
fields.body:
Relations between Libya and the UK are thawing. A new embassy in Knightsbridge is dispensing visas. British Airways and Libyan Airlines are carrying oil workers and businessmen to Tripoli several times a week. So it is 'all clear' for UK travellers to trade political preconceptions and strong drink (Libya is 'dry') and enjoy this fascinating North African country.

Lunching under an acacia tree in Wadi Mathhendusc, a dry riverbed dissecting the Messak plateau of the south-west Libyan desert - the Fezzan - I discovered a Stone Age cutting tool lying at my feet. Not an unusual occurrence, for millions of prehistoric relics - spearheads, arrowheads, crushing and cutting tools, shards of pottery and ostrich eggshells - litter the plateau, the high dunes, the dry wadi beds and the verdant oases of the Fezzan.

Around 12000 BC, the people who roamed the once lush savannah, hunted elephant, giraffe, rhino, ostrich and crocodile. They were also talented artists who engraved their observations in the rocky cliffs above the many rivers with a purity of line of which Picasso would have been envious. They depicted the gentle movements of giraffes, the lumbering bulk of rhino, the last moments of a dying elephant and the lassooing of a group of ostriches. In fact, 12,000 years of civilisation can be charted through the engravings and delicate rock paintings of the area: the slow march of climate change, the shift from hunting to pastoral pursuits, tribal differences, mysterious religious ceremonies, the introduction of the horse and finally, as the desert encroached, the camel.

The water still runs deep below the surface of the wadis that criss-cross the Fezzan and it is here that scrubby trees, bushes and scratchy grass support myriad animal life. The evidence is in the sand. The droppings of camel, goat, gazelle and ibex. The spoor of a fox poised above a gerbil burrow, a bird picking off a dying lizard, the antics of kangaroo mice (who hop on hind legs only) and the scurrying scarab beetle. But to catch sight of a fox you must sleep out under the starry desert sky and I had chosen a more luxurious option.

With more than 30 years' desert experience, Italians Sergio Scarpa Falce and his wife Adrianna have fulfilled a long-cherished dream of organising a fixed camp deep in the Sahara from which to inculcate tourists in the beauty and diversity of the desert. Deep in the Acacus mountains in a stunning amphitheatre topped with rock sculptures whittled by the wind, they have created Camp Auis. The 20 double tents have wooden floors, comfortable beds, feather duvets and pillows and electric light from 7am to 10.30pm. Hot water is brought to your tent in the morning for a splash wash at your basin, as well as hot, sweet tea. Each tent is assigned its own private lavatory and shower in a separate block. Showers are taken in the late afternoon after the water has had time to heat up, but plans are under way for guaranteeing hot water via solar power by next year. The dining room is well-supplied by excellent local produce, supplemented by shipments of food from Italy, Egypt and Tunisia. A well is mooted for the camp and the village; in the meantime, water is brought in by tankers, siphoned from the desert aquifers in part of Libyan leader Colonel Muammar Gadaffi's great 'man-made river' project.

I spent four days and nights at the camp and each was filled with new surprises. In the ever-changing landscape of the desert we met one of the seven remaining nomadic families in Libya; we saw a camel giving birth; we wandered through wadis accompanied by chirping mulla mulla birds; we raced across the desert plains in four-wheel-drive Toyotas at 60 miles an hour, our Tuareg drivers vying with each other to get there first (wherever 'there' was); we leapt over impossible, impassable dunes, whipped into geometric knife-edges by the ever-present desert wind; we came across cracked, salt lakes where strange, bulbous trees live and die; snowy white patches of gypsum; swathes of green plants with pale purple flowers, a consequence of three days' rain two months before; and, unforgettably, the great blue-green slashes of still water, fringed with succulent date palms and stands of pampas grass, that comprise the beautiful oases of Um El Maa, Mandara, Mafu and Gabraoun, where turtle doves flutter through the air, tiny pink shrimps swirl in the water and, on that occasion, a solitary white camel was tethered on the shady bank.

White camels are highly prized and our Targi driver, Barka, told me that his family had won races across the Arab world with his 15-strong herd. In high summer he will leave his village and go with his family and his camels into the desert. When I explained that England has no desert, he exclaimed sadly: 'Then there is no yellow'.

The Tuareg are not of Libya, Algeria, Niger, or Mali, they are the people of the Sahara. Their native tongue, Tamashek, uses neither Arabic nor Roman script. But they have had to adapt, taking Libyan nationality, settling in villages and learning Arabic, and French, or Italian and English. Proud, honest and exceedingly generous, they are a joy to be around. They acted as drivers, guides and cooks, regaling us with traditional songs, dispensing chilled water from goatskin bags, and, on one occasion, picking herbs from a desert bush to alleviate constipation. Every day after lunch they brewed Tuareg cham pagne - strong green tea boiled over a driftwood fire, poured from a height to make cappuccino-like foam, then reheated and poured into small glasses with plenty of sugar.

The Tuareg were a thorn in the side of ancient Rome, plundering the trade routes from Africa to the port of Leptis Magna (one hour east of Tripoli). Eventually the Romans were forced to make peace, safeguarding the vital shipments of ivory, slaves and wild animals sent to Rome for gladiatorial displays. These are graphically shown in Ridley Scott' s new film Gladiator which is set in the reign of the decadent Emperor Commodus (son of Marcus Aurelius). His lust for bloody displays in the arena helped make Leptis rich and made one of its citizens, Septimus Severius, a Libyan, Emperor of Rome. The remains of the city of Leptis with its theatre, temples, courts of justice, market, saunas, latrines, lighthouse and an intact amphitheatre are in an excellent state of repair. As is the Roman city of Sabratha (half an hour west of Tripoli) and the Greek cities of Apollonia and Cyrenica near Benghazi.

There is little crime or unemployment in Libya and tourists are not pestered for baksheesh. Libyan women wear simple headscarves with their modern clothes, can venture out alone and are allowed to drive. The hotels and restaurants in Tripoli are excellent. The roads are good and fuel costs only 7p a litre. The historical monuments are more than worth a three-and-a-half hour flight, not to mention the romance of the desert.

Libya facts

Best time to travel: October to April

Travel Tips: Take a warm jacket for nights in the desert. It is not advisable to talk politics and inadmissible to pack a penknife or take in alcohol

Reading: Libya: The Lost Cities of the Roman Empire A colourful coffee table guide to the archaeological sites. (£9.99, Könemann) The Secret of the Desert Easy-to-read explanation of pre-historic rock art with more than 200 colour pictures. Around £33 including postage direct from authors Rudiger and Gabriele Lutz in Austria (tel 00 43 512 34 14 24) Leptis Magna and Sabratha Paperback guides to these important sites in English translations from Italian publisher Polaris ( guides to Cyrenica and Apollonia are to published in September) . Available from Daunt Bookshop for Travellers, 83 Marylebone High Street, London W1 (020 7224 2295). T he Green Book The personal philosophy of Col Muammar Gadaffi

Getting there: Angela Clarence travelled with Cox and Kings (0207 873 5000 or www.coxandkings.co.uk) which offers group and tailor-made itineraries to Libya. A 13-day Sahara and Roman Africa itinerary costs £1,695 per person (based on two sharing).The tour includes British Airways flights, transfers, full board, with four nights at Auis camp and visits to Leptis Magna and Sabratha

Websites: www.alnpete.co.uk/lepcis; www.libyana.org

In the ever-changing landscape of the desert we met one of the seven remaining nomadic families in Libya; we saw a camel giving birth; we wandered through wadis accompanied by chirping mulla mulla birds; we raced across the desert plains in four-wheel-drive Toyotas at 60 miles an hour, our Tuareg drivers vying with each other to get there first (wherever 'there' was); we leapt over impossible, impassable dunes, whipped into geometric knife-edges by the ever-present desert wind; we came across cracked, salt lakes where strange, bulbous trees live and die; snowy white patches of gypsum; swathes of green plants with pale purple flowers, a consequence of three days' rain two months before; and, unforgettably, the great blue-green slashes of still water, fringed with succulent date palms and stands of pampas grass, that comprise the beautiful oases of Um El Maa, Mandara, Mafu and Gabraoun, where turtle doves flutter through the air, tiny pink shrimps swirl in the water and, on that occasion, a solitary white camel was tethered on the shady bank. White camels are highly prized and our Targi driver, Barka, told me that his family had won races across the Arab world with his 15-strong herd. In high summer he will leave his village and go with his family and his camels into the desert. When I explained that England has no desert, he exclaimed sadly: 'Then there is no yellow'. The Tuareg are not of Libya, Algeria, Niger, or Mali, they are the people of the Sahara. Their native tongue, Tamashek, uses neither Arabic nor Roman script. But they have had to adapt, taking Libyan nationality, settling in villages and learning Arabic, and French, or Italian and English. Proud, honest and exceedingly generous, they are a joy to be around. They acted as drivers, guides and cooks, regaling us with traditional songs, dispensing chilled water from goatskin bags, and, on one occasion, picking herbs from a desert bush to alleviate constipation. Every day after lunch they brewed Tuareg cham pagne - strong green tea boiled over a driftwood fire, poured from a height to make cappuccino-like foam, then reheated and poured into small glasses with plenty of sugar. The Tuareg were a thorn in the side of ancient Rome, plundering the trade routes from Africa to the port of Leptis Magna (one hour east of Tripoli). Eventually the Romans were forced to make peace, safeguarding the vital shipments of ivory, slaves and wild animals sent to Rome for gladiatorial displays. These are graphically shown in Ridley Scott' s new film Gladiator which is set in the reign of the decadent Emperor Commodus (son of Marcus Aurelius). His lust for bloody displays in the arena helped make Leptis rich and made one of its citizens, Septimus Severius, a Libyan, Emperor of Rome. The remains of the city of Leptis with its theatre, temples, courts of justice, market, saunas, latrines, lighthouse and an intact amphitheatre are in an excellent state of repair. As is the Roman city of Sabratha (half an hour west of Tripoli) and the Greek cities of Apollonia and Cyrenica near Benghazi. There is little crime or unemployment in Libya and tourists are not pestered for baksheesh. Libyan women wear simple headscarves with their modern clothes, can venture out alone and are allowed to drive. The hotels and restaurants in Tripoli are excellent. The roads are good and fuel costs only 7p a litre. The historical monuments are more than worth a three-and-a-half hour flight, not to mention the romance of the desert. Libya facts Best time to travel: October to April Travel Tips: Take a warm jacket for nights in the desert. It is not advisable to talk politics and inadmissible to pack a penknife or take in alcohol Reading: Libya: The Lost Cities of the Roman Empire A colourful coffee table guide to the archaeological sites. (£9.99, Könemann) The Secret of the Desert Easy-to-read explanation of pre-historic rock art with more than 200 colour pictures. Around £33 including postage direct from authors Rudiger and Gabriele Lutz in Austria (tel 00 43 512 34 14 24) Leptis Magna and Sabratha Paperback guides to these important sites in English translations from Italian publisher Polaris ( guides to Cyrenica and Apollonia are to published in September) . Available from Daunt Bookshop for Travellers, 83 Marylebone High Street, London W1 (020 7224 2295). T he Green Book The personal philosophy of Col Muammar Gadaffi Getting there: Angela Clarence travelled with Cox and Kings (0207 873 5000 or www.coxandkings.co.uk) which offers group and tailor-made itineraries to Libya. A 13-day Sahara and Roman Africa itinerary costs £1,695 per person (based on two sharing).The tour includes British Airways flights, transfers, full board, with four nights at Auis camp and visits to Leptis Magna and Sabratha Websites: www.alnpete.co.uk/lepcis; www.libyana.org

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: Discovering whales
fields.body:
Discovering whales

If you want to get back to nature without making the commitment of a safari or trekking holiday, Discover the World has a four-day whale watching tour in Husavik, whale-watching capital of Iceland. The tour is based at Lake Myvtan which also offers excellent birdwatching opportunities and almost continuous daylight. Iceland's other natural spectacles can be viewed from a sightseeing flight taking in an active volcano, bubbling mud pools and steam vents. Departures start on 1 June and continue until the end of September. The tour costs £670 per person, including return flights from Glasgow or London, internal flights in Iceland, half-board hotel accommodation and the expertise of professional whale-watchers. Phone 01737 218 800 or visit www.arctic-discover.co.uk

Mongolian trek

KE Travel offers a trek through a really remote part of the world on an expedition to Mongolia. The trek starts 1,200 miles east of Ulaanbaatar on the western edge of the Mongolia steppes, where the group's baggage is taken to the remote base camp by camel. From there, travellers will take part in daily ascents of the three highest peaks in Mongolia, including Mount Khuiten. The expedition is led by experienced western guides, and a crew of six at the base camp will take care of the cooking. After flying back to Ulaanbaatar, there are visits to nomadic herdsmen in their camps outside the city with a chance to try their traditional wrestling and horse-riding. Potential trekkers should be reasonably fit, preferably with some winter mountaineering experience. The trip starts at £1,995 including flights. Details from 017687 73966.

Cuba libre

Create your own package holiday to Cuba with a new brochure from Voyager Cuba (01580 766 222). The renovated Hotel Sevilla, made famous by Graham Greene is among the wide range of Havana hotels featured. Further afield, the brochure includes accommodation in the UNESCO World Heritage town of Trinidad, the beach resort of Varadero and the all-inclusive resort island of Cayo Largo. While it is possible to stay in just one of these destinations, Voyager Cuba specialises in customising packages to travellers' specifications and encourages a combination of locations. Prices start at £457 for seven nights bed and breakfast in Havana including flights, tax and Tourist Card.

Designs on your kitchen

Ballymaloe Cookery School has joined with kitchen designer Johnny Grey to create a two-day course aimed at anyone thinking of re-vamping their kitchen. Participants are asked to bring a blank plan of their own kitchen, which Johnny Grey will use in his tuition, helping them to understand the role of furniture, the 'unfitted kitchen', design ergonomics, lighting and colour. There will be tips on how to make the best use of the room and on how to avoid expensive mistakes. The cookery school is near beaches and cliffs and guests can use the farmland gardens and tennis courts. The course runs for two days at the beginning of June and costs IR£350 (£270) per person including lunch and dinner. Self-catering accommodation is also available at IR£15.50 (£12) per night per person sharing. Details from Johnny Grey & Co on 01730 821 424 or Ballymaloe Cookery School on 00 353 21 646 785.

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst:
47 Park Street Hotel, London
Peter Barwick, head concierge
fields.trailText: Any famous guests?
fields.body:
Any famous guests?

Our clients are mainly American. We get a number of very famous people - worldwide names in art and music - who choose the hotel because it is small and discreet. From the outside it looks more like a house, although the suites inside are very large. I have to keep their names secret otherwise we would be overrun with autograph-hunters!

Any unusual requests?

The strangest requests are when guests call me from the States and ask if I can find a particular sort of puppy and fly it to them because there aren't any in America. It is like an elaborate shopping service because we have to find the right dog, buy a cage for the flight and send enough food and water with it. They specify the pedigree and the colouring. I've sent Labradors to Paris and Cocker Spaniels to America - it's ridiculous. It's the same with cars. I have had guests asking for rare 1930s sportscars and parts for vintage Bentleys which are only available in Britain. One guest even wanted a left-hand drive Morris Traveller sent to Germany: we are quite happy to do anything.

What about a night out?

Our own restaurant, Le Gavroche, is one of the best in London, and Albert Roux is our Managing Director. But I also like to send guests to the Waterside Inn at Bray - they all love Diego, the maitre d'. It is such a fantastic experience and we can always get guests a reservation. In London I recommend restaurants that have the same sort of high standard as The Square in Bruton Street. The Ivy and Teatro are popular with theatre-goers. The main problem in London is that pubs close at a stupidly early time. All that is changing, which is great news.

What about a day out?

I really like the Cotswolds, so we book guests into the Manoir Aux Quat' Saisons for lunch and they can have a day out in the country. They find it very relaxing: seven years ago I moved out to Buckinghamshire and life in the villages is at a much slower pace.There are endless sight-seeing options inside London, and I always run through what's on in the theatres and galleries with guests. I'm not overly keen on the Dome, which feels a bit temporary, but I am selling hundreds of tickets for the London Eye. The Tower and Westminster Abbey are also much more popular. However, there are also lots of secret gems in London, such as the Wallace Collection, which none of the guide books ever mention.

47 Park Street: 0207 491 7282

The Waterside Inn: 01628 620 691

The Square: 0207 495 7100

The Ivy: 0207 836 4751

Teatro: 0207 494 3040

The London Eye: 0870 500 0600

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Barry Hearn loses it on Radio 5, Fiorentina fans lose it in Florence, and Italy's Des Lynam finds a new partner. Plus all the tales from the tabloids.
fields.body:
Hearn: it's OK, he's one of us

Kosovan refugee Naim Uka, interviewed in The Observer last week, made a strong impression on his Leyton Orient debut, starring in the inaugural Bobby Moore Cup against West Ham. But how his new two-year contract rests with the political stance chairman Barry Hearn adopted on national radio last month is unclear.

Hearn told Nicky Campbell on BBC Five Live: 'I think it's disgraceful we let all these people into the country. It's about time we started looking after ourselves. I wouldn't have one of them in'. Presumabaly Uka - who arrived in the country in the back of a lorry after his parents disappeared, his home was blown up and his neighbours murdered - falls into Hearn's 'one of us' category. A few black and black-ish boxers could remain in the country, Hearn said, 'because they could make me a fortune'.

Batigol: 'please don't go' riots commence

Fiorentina fans have reacted furiously to news that icon Gabriel Batistuta plans to leave Italy for England this summer. After the striker confirmed 'I have asked Fiorentina to let me go', three Molotov cocktails were thrown at the office of club president Vittorio Cecchi Gori, 500 fans held a vigil outside the stadium, and others threatened to boycott next season's games.

Fifty fans also spent a night outside Batistuta's villa with a banner declaring 'Florence loves you. You love Florence. So why leave?' Money, it seems, has nothing to do with it. 'I will probably earn something extra wherever I go,' he said last week, 'but that won't change my life.'

Italian Des: let's make it a threesome

Italy's Des Lynam - Alessia Merz - has spoken for the first time of the depth of her passion for football. Merz - the country's most popular football presenter and former fiancee of ex-Milan midfielder Giampiero Maini - told the Italian press last week of her plans to find a new on-screen partner.

'Tacchinardi would be first up; hes a good-looking lad, but then Pippo Inzaghi could join in and thats not a bad couple! Montero also seems pretty nice as well. It would be interesting and a lot of fun.' Rival presenter Sabrina Ferilli subsequently promised a public strip-tease if Roma won the Scudetto - something Merz refused to stoop to, despite her 'glamour model' past. So where will the race for self-promotion through sex go next? Not, we hope, to Richard Keys.

Tales from the tabs

CHELSEA IN £17M SALAS SWOOP Gianluca Vialli plans to smash the British transfer record with a £17m move for Lazio star Marcelo Salas. The deal would mean the end for Chris Sutton.

KOP TO KAL THE £6M SHOTS Liverpool have finally moved to sign long-time midfield target Kakha Kalhadze. The Dynamo Kiev midfielder should join in a £6m deal this month.

AND THE REST_

Valencia and Lazio are battling Leeds and Middlesbrough for Atletico Madrid's Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink: Valencia president Pedro Cortes says he'll match any offer made from England; Arsenal have captured Cameroon midfielder Lauren Bisan-Etame Mayer for £7m from Real Mallorca - Arsene Wenger also wants Roda centre-back Joos Valgaeren;Robbie Fowler has rejected an approach from Chelsea : 'I've always said that I'm well happy at Liverpool - Gerard Houllier has been unbelievable with me'; Wolves are chasing Coventry defenders David Burrows and Paul Williams; Wimbledon's Kenny Cunningham could be first out of Selhurst Park: Everton are in the hunt - team-mate Neil Sullivan is also wanted by Arsenal and Spurs ; Liverpool's Rigobert Song could be sold to finance a deal for Newcastle's Didier Domi - Newcastle need the cash to fund a bid for Feyenoord's Paul Bosvelt; Middlesbrough are scouting Lens strikers Pascal Nouma and Joseph Desire-Job; Fulham are chasing Metz star Louis Saha and West Ham midfielder Marc Keller; Sheffield Wednesday striker Gilles de Bilde says he wants to stay at Hillsborough: 'I hope I can'; Sunderland could re-sign Kevin Ball from Fulham as a coach; and Graham Taylor has denied that Charlie Miller is set to leave Watford.

Said & Done: david.hills@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Inside sport
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke wins the league, the old ways are the best, and what's in a name?
fields.body:
Watchdog wait

Moves to create a groundbreaking football regulator have reached 'the difficult phase', according to insiders involved in the discussions. There is a dispute over what the new watchdog should be called.

The football authorities had suggested the Independent Scrutiny Panel, but it may actually emerge next month with a different title. Inside Sport also understands that there is growing opposition to Dr Jack Cunningham, the ex-Cabinet minister, chairing the new body. 'His links to Sir John Hall, the rest of the Hall family and Newcastle United in general mean he wouldn't be seen as truly independent,' said one source. 'Some people think he'd be a soft touch for the Premier League.'

Controversy also surrounds the possible appointment of Sir Roland Smith, the chairman of Manchester United's plc arm. However, his obvious financial interest in the game may render him unsuitable. Someone who may well be one of the panel's five or six members is the black Tory peer Lord Taylor of Warwick, a Villa fan who is greatly concerned about the activities of agents selling young African players to European clubs.

A person with a background in a football supporters organisation will also be on. And so, too, may Sir John Smith, the ex-policeman who produced an excellent report on rooting out corruption in football. With more money than ever circulating in the game, his expertise may be very useful.

Old grey whistlers welcome

Veteran referees will be drafted into the Premiership in a desperate bid to curb indiscipline on the pitch and, with luck, eliminate the controversial decisions that have enraged so many players recently.

Until now, only officials young enough to subsequently qualify for international duty - age limit 45 - have been introduced to the Premiership ranks each year, effectively ruling out anyone over 40. But next season the 'elite' group will be scrapped with all 74 referees on the same national list.

Most of the present top-flight refs will continue to handle the top games in the opening weeks. But there will also be a review every two months with promotion from the Nationwide Leagues based purely on current performance, irrespective of age.

Premiership bigwigs believe older whistlers, seasoned by the hurly-burly of the lower divisions, will avoid many of the controversial incidents that soured relations between players and officials last season.

Leboeuf collared

Frank Leboeuf been accused of having a bad temper, finding the Premiership too tough and fancying himself as a bit of an intellectual. But at least he's loyal, unlike other foreign legionnaires.

During the Frenchman's unveiling last week as a celebrity contributor to sports internet site Sportal, his son Hugo sat quietly nearby minding the Leboeuf family dog. After the World Cup winner had answered predictable questions with varying degrees of honesty ('Yes, England have a good chance of winning Euro 2000'; 'No, I'm not worried about Emerson Thome stealing my place'; 'Yes I will see out the last two years of my contract'), he cradled the Maltese Bichon terrier on his knee and revealed that the white fluffy creature is actually called Chelsea. All together now: aahhh. Presumably Leboeuf will soon have to enlarge the mutt's nametag to accommodate the words Olympique Lyonnais. Who mentioned loyalty?

Dyke shows a deft touch

BBC Director General Greg Dyke may not have been able to show Grandstand yesterday because of an embarrassing shortage of events, but he has just recorded an auspicious sporting triumph.

He has won the manager of the month award in the Beeb's fantasy football league. Dyke, a Manchester United fan, confided: 'The key moment was selling Andy Cole and buying Thierry Henry.'

Greg's Eleven were struggling in 198th place in the 216-team BBC league but, under the DG's stewardship, have climbed 140 places to fifty-eighth. John Motson duly presented his boss with his award last Friday night, and even brought a copy of his commentary notes from yesterday's FA Cup Final for Dyke's son Joe.

Greg's Eleven are: Westerveld (Liverpool), Hyypia (Liverpool), Silvinho (Arsenal), Andersen (Wimbledon), Silvestre (Man Utd), Beckham (Man Utd), Merson (Aston Villa), Giggs (Man Utd), Di Canio (West ham), Phillips (Sunderland) and Henry (Arsenal).

Inside Sport: denis.campbell@observer.co.uk

webTitle: On the trail of the divine

fields.headline: On the trail of the divine
fields.standfirst: Fear of theft has kept many church doors locked, but  Stephen Pritchard found a different trend in Lincolnshire, where tourism is making churches more accessible - and safer
fields.trailText: Fear of theft has kept many church doors locked, but Stephen Pritchard found a different trend in Lincolnshire, where tourism is making churches more accessible - and safer.
fields.body:
Tradition has it that the church is as important to village life as the pub and post office, but just as the pub is probably owned by a chain and the post office under threat of closure, so the church is under siege - from public indifference.

Making churches more accessible is one way of raising awareness, but fear of thieves keeps many fine buildings shut. However, recent figures suggest that a locked church is six times more likely to be robbed than one that stays open.

The Lincoln diocese is among the first to spot the opportunities in keeping churches open and its Church Tourism Network has devised what it calls Divine Tranquillity trails.

Last week I asked Rosemary Watts, Britain's first full-time lay church tourism officer, if there was an uneasy relationship between individual churches and tourism in Lincolnshire. 'Some are not keen to open up, but most can see the benefits,' she said. 'More people in churches at unpredictable times means less chance of theft and more visitors means a boost for local shops, pubs and restaurants.'

And, most important, those visitors make fascinating discoveries. During a short tour I found Viking graffiti scratched into ancient stonework, a memorial to death by smallpox, stunning medieval wood carving, William Morris glass... and a digital musical box that can accompany hymns at any pitch and any speed.

A tour starts at the site of the dawn of Christianity in Lincolnshire. St Paulinus baptised Saxons in the River Trent in 627AD and, as the excellent laminated cards that accompany a tour tell you, the church of St Margaret at Marton nearby has the distinctive herringbone masonry of a pre-Norman Conquest building. Inside, nineteenth-century builders discovered an exquisite crucifix among rubble used to block an arch. The crucifix depicts Christ's legs as separate, not nailed to the cross with one nail as was the custom in medieval art, which suggests that it dates from the building's Saxon origins.

The stonework at St Mary's, Stow, is more ornate, as is fitting for a former minster. In the tenth century this area was in the see of the Bishop of Dorchester-on-Thames and Stow was a 'mother church' for far-off Lincolnshire. The original burnt down, but Lady Godiva, that devotee of nude equestrianism, rode to the rescue with money to enrich a new church. Even so, in 1070 Bishop Remigius began to build his cathedral in Lincoln, and Stow minster became a very grand parish church. A sensitive nineteenth-century restoration by J. L. Pearson, architect of Truro Cathedral, kept many fine features, including a rough scratching of an oared sailing vessel, the earliest known representation of a Viking ship in England. It could be the work of a Scandinavian marauder, who had sailed up the Trent.

Just up the road at Coates, surrounded by massive fields under a sky peppered with larks, stands the little church of St Edith. Its remoteness may have helped save some of its interior from religious reformers. Inside is a complete medieval rood screen and loft (into which you can climb via a tiny ancient staircase). The rood, or crucifix, has gone, but traces of a painting of Mary can still be seen. There is a special sense of history in this gem, a tangible awareness of the generations that would have sat underneath the lovely barn-like timbers of its ancient roof.

The Victorian sprawl of Gainsborough wraps around the church of All Saints, which is a real oddity. A Classical nave was welded on to a medieval tower in the eighteenth century and the result makes you feel a little seasick, so it is not surprising to find a gravestone to a crew member of Captain Cook's second global voyage. The architect Francis Smith had worked on St Martin's-in-the-Fields, London, and externally the similarities are striking. In 1903 another architect, G.F. Bodley, described the glass as 'atrocious' and proceeded to design a window for a side chapel that has no apparent merit over those he dismissed.

Real craftsmanship can be found at St Paul's, Morton, which is justly famous for its astonishing collection of Edward Burne-Jones windows. They were made in William Morris's workshops and commissioned by the church's builder, Sir Hickman Bacon, of Thurrock Hall nearby, a keen patron of the arts. Much Victorian church design is second-rate, but this is a jewel, full of curiosities. The Frosterley marble font is embedded with hundreds of fossils and its cover shows figures from the Old Testament, including Moses with horns on his head. This is because of a medieval mistranslation of the Hebrew 'queren' which can mean horns... or rays of light.

Modern glass craftsmanship is the crowning glory of the last church on the trail, St John the Baptist, which serves the Ermine housing estate in Lincoln. Designed in 1962 by local architect Sam Scorer, this stunning hexagonal building has an aluminium hyperbolic paraboloid roof which sweeps to the ground. It follows in the great Anglo-Catholic tradition of building places of wonder in deprived areas of Britain's towns and cities. Dominating the east end is an enormous window by Keith New, a bravura display of crimsons, blues and greens that stops you dead in your tracks. Sadly, this inspirational building can find no organist, so the ever-resourceful incumbent has found a digital machine to accompany the singing. Let's hope an organist will soon beat a path to his door. This church cries out for real music.

 Divine Tranquillity tour guides, which include maps, opening times and details of each church, are available at £3.95. Three-night holidays with church tours and concerts range from £138 to £217 per person. Contact Rosemary Watts, Church Tourism Network, Church House, The Old Palace, Lincoln LN2 1PU Tel: 01522 529241; Fax: 01522 512717; e-mail: lincolndio@claranet.co.uk

fields.headline: Keegan summons Alf for inspiration
fields.standfirst: With three games left before the start of Euro 2000 the battle begins for squad places and a system
fields.trailText: With three games left before the start of Euro 2000 the battle begins for squad places and a system.
fields.body:
For someone who was only 15 at the time, Kevin Keegan spends a lot of time talking about England's one and only World Cup win.

In the course of a 40-minute press briefing last week, Keegan mentioned 1966 and all that on three separate occasions, which practically puts him in the Alan Ball bracket. And at least Ball played in the World Cup final.

Perhaps the meeting with Germany in Charleroi on 17 June is playing on Keegan's mind. Either that, or through spending too much time worrying about his lack of wingers he has developed an instinctive empathy with the late Sir Alf Ramsey, to whom he refers familiarly as 'Alf'.

'I can't see the point of putting someone in just because he's got a left foot,' Keegan said, talking about the shortage of left-sided full-backs in his squad but probably making Jason Wilcox's ears prick up. 'We'll have to move people around at times, we might have to play a wing-back if we get an injury, but I think we have enough options within the squad to cover most eventualities. I know the balance could be better, but most of the other coaches are in the same boat. Even Alf had that criticism when he named his squad in 1966, but the shape of the team emerged as the tournament progressed. What Alf was thinking six months before the World Cup was different to what he did in the tournament.'

What Alf famously did in 1966 was drop Jimmy Greaves and play without wingers. As long as Alan Shearer remains captain and David Beckham's crossing ability is required, there seems little chance of Keegan doing anything quite so drastic, but he may go half way to winglessness. Steve McManaman's form for Real Madrid appears to have edged him ahead of Wilcox, the Leeds United winger who is in the 28-man squad basically for his left-footedness. McManaman has a Champions League final on Wednesday, and will not join up with England in time for Saturday's friendly against Brazil, but previous disappointments in an England shirt appear likely to be forgotten if the former Liverpool player has another outstanding game in Paris.

'Steve has earned the right to be reconsidered by forcing people to change their minds and yes, I can see a way to harness him, maybe playing left side,' Keegan said. 'In the past it has been a bit of a mish-mash with people playing out of position on the left, but a Steve McManaman in form for Real Madrid is different from a Steve McManaman having a bit of a struggle at Liverpool. He's playing with confidence now, and confidence is everything.'

So it is, though while most people would agree that McManaman at his best is a more versatile and creative player than Wilcox, it should be remembered that the two are not necessarily interchangeable. With Beckham, Paul Ince and Paul Scholes more or less assured of midfield places, left wing seems the only available spot for McManaman to occupy, but to get the most from him England need to allow him a measure of freedom and preferably support his ability to hold the ball with intelligent movement to create passing options. They need to play more like Real Madrid, in other words. If they intend to carry on playing like England, with wingers attempting to reach the by-line and put crosses in for Shearer, Wilcox remains the best option.

The other area of doubt for Keegan to work on in the next three games is who plays support striker to Shearer. Michael Owen is the favourite at the moment, with Emile Heskey as reserve, and Robbie Fowler, Andy Cole and Kevin Phillips contesting the final two squad places. Since the last three are more prolific scorers than the first two Keegan knows he will attract criticism whichever way he jumps, but insists he has an open mind at this stage. 'I've been quoted as saying I don't want to take Andy Cole, but I've never said that,' he said.

'You can't find any quotes from me that say Andy Cole is in doubt for Euro 2000. I bought and sold Andy Cole, and I only sold him to take Newcastle on. None of the others except Shearer have scored goals at this level, and that includes Cole, but in seven games he's only had two starts, so he deserves a chance. So does Fowler, who is fit, but needs matches. It might be a slight gamble if we take Robbie, but in a 22-man squad you can take one gamble.'

Just one last time for the record, England will not be gambling on penalty shoot-outs. 'We will practise penal ties,' Keegan said. 'Teams will go through on penalty shoot-outs, you can be sure. I still stick with what I said earlier though. You can practise all you want, but you can never replicate the shoot-out situation.'

True, but a few practise shots in training might have stood David Batty in better stead two years ago. 'Glenn Hoddle probably wouldn't have had David Batty practising penalties anyway,' Keegan said. 'He couldn't possi bly have known he would have one man sent off, one with cramp, and have to play 70 minutes with 10 men.'

Batty's penalty was the beginning of the end for Hoddle, as Keegan knows. 'The flak will fly if it doesn't go well, but I'm quite happy to be judged by results,' he said. 'It's my job to be positive, and I've got the chance to do something no England manager has ever done before, to win a tournament away from home.'

fields.headline: How they rated...
fields.trailText: Points mean prizes. Amy Lawrence with player performance ratings from Wembley.
fields.body:
ASTON VILLA

DAVID JAMES 5

For 71 minutes, it was an impressive performance from the goalkeeper formerly known as Calamity - an important early gather from Wise's drive and an improvised fling-of-the-hand to thwart Weah. Then came the calamity, an agonising spill that led to Chelsea's goal.

MARK DELANEY 7

Willing to gallop up the right flank, he caused Chelsea some uncomfortable moments.

UGO EHIOGU 7

Strong and forceful at the back, fluffed a free header in stoppage time.

GARETH SOUTHGATE 6

Dependable as ever... until Zola's free-kick brushed against his upper arm and fell to Di Matteo. One nil to Chelsea.

ALAN WRIGHT 6

Kevin Keegan looked at him for Euro 2000 but he wasn't quite convinced. As usual, Wright was reliable, but he's not world class. Replaced by Lee Hendrie.

GARETH BARRY 6

Early caution for hacking down Melchiot mid-surge. The youngster was edgy and let the occasion get to him.

PAUL MERSON 7

Tried manfully to prise open a suffocating game. Always a danger with those delicately floated crosses. Came close with an opportunistic volley.

IAN TAYLOR 6

Such a potent scorer earlier in the season for Villa, he might have done better with a header on the edge of the six-yard box. Substituted for Steve Stone.

GEORGE BOATENG 6

Combative. Tangled with Wise after only three minutes, which set the tone. He allowed himself to get wound up regularly.

BENITO CARBONE 5

Anonymous. This was one of his more enigmatic days. Just when Villa were desperately in need of some trickery to find a way into the box, he glued himself to the touchline. Trouble finding a way through the tall blue line underpinning Chelsea. One chance, one scuff. On came Julian Joachim in his place.

DION DUBLIN 6

Scarcely a touch in the first half, apart from a kick up the backside delivered to Leboeuf. Scant opportunities fell the big man's way.

CHELSEA

ED DE GOEY 6

Easy money if this passes for work... barely called upon to make an interception worthy of the word save.

MARIO MELCHIOT 7

Still adjusting to the English game, the Dutchman slotted in comfortably enough at right back.

MARCEL DESAILLY 7

Known as 'the rock', he has not always been quite so solid in the blue of Chelsea, but he was a formidable barrier.

FRANK LEBOEUF 7

The sight of him rolling on the turf clutching his buttock fits the critics' stereotype of the Frenchman. His fans prefer another image: secure and elegant at the back.

CELESTINE BABAYARO 7

The Nigerian was assured on the left flank. For Villa's gameplan to work they needed the wing-backs to make an impression - they couldn't.

GUSTAVO POYET 6

Never at his happiest playing wide, one of his most telling contributions almost created a goal. But unfortunately for Chelsea, when Wise poked in the Uruguayan's cross, Weah was caught offside.

DENNIS WISE 7

Had the first shot of the game thumped in from long range. Should have had first goal of the game, until celebrations for his tap-in were cut short by an offside flag. Booked for hacking at Boateng.

DIDIER DESCHAMPS 6

Did some of his traditional water carrying and not much else.

ROBERTO DI MATTEO 8

Switched from time to time with Poyet, and was the most effective supporter of the front line from midfield. Rewarded on 72 minutes when, as a player who surely loves the FA Cup final, he lashed home.

GIANFRANCO ZOLA 7

Rather like his season as a whole, the Italian's skills only shone in flashes. At the heart of the one good move of the first half, but like all the other attackers on the field he cried out for some decent service. Instead, he selflessly provided it for others, conjuring a devastating, whirling cross for the goal. Withdrawn in stoppage time to give Jody Morris a few Wembley seconds to savour.

GEORGE WEAH 6

So many memories from a majestic career, he will want to forget his moment of glorious opportunity on the hour when he blazed horribly over. Prior to that he was put through and fizzed a low volley narrowly wide. Sadly, the former World Player of the Year looked past his prime. Eventually made way for Tore Andre Flo.
