fields.headline: We test the budget carriers
fields.standfirst: No-frills airlines have changed the face of British travel.  Joanna Walters  explains the phenomenon while, overleaf, we send  four travellers to test the new high flyers on a fare budget of £100 each
fields.trailText: No-frills airlines have changed the face of British travel. Joanna Walters explains the phenomenon while, overleaf, we send four travellers to test the new high flyers on a fare budget of £100 each.
fields.body:
They said it would never take off in Britain but they were wrong. The low-cost, no-frills airlines are a huge success and have changed the face of air travel in Europe for ever.
They have exploded onto the scene during the past five years offering safe, comfortable air travel at a fraction of the cost big airlines traditionally charged. The weekend break or family visit has become a commodity, with tickets for a tenner not unheard of.
New cities on the Continent are being linked up and direct booking via the Internet has caught the public's imagination.
Simon Evans, industry affairs adviser at the official UK watchdog the Air Transport Users' Council (AUC), said : 'Airlines have shown that if you get the price right people will travel. We are generally impressed with the quality of the low-cost airlines.'
There has been a knock-on effect across the rest of the market, too. The low-cost airlines have seduced people into taking breaks - and business trips - more often and stolen passengers from the big national carriers.
But it is more than this. The competition has put intense pressure on the large scheduled airlines to lower their prices. It has also prompted charter airlines to sell cheap, individual seats for short breaks. So the whole UK air travel market has grown, and continues to grow, by more than six per cent a year.
Industry observers throw in two notes of caution. First, not all the low-cost airlines will necessarily survive in the long term. Debonair collapsed last year and it may only be a matter of time before another follows.
Second, consumers should still shop around for air fares as, despite the hype, the low-cost airlines are not always the cheapest. Prices vary according to airlines, routes and dates. The advice is book early.

There is a note of regret that the south-east has seen most of the low-cost action. EasyJet has a limited network from Liverpool and there are plenty of low-cost flights between London and Scotland. But on the whole the regions lose out, with London Luton and Stansted bursting with no-frills services now. This is unlikely to be remedied in the short-term because while the millions of people who live nearer other city airports such as Cardiff, Manchester, and Birmingham, may be keen to travel to Europe, the Continentals tend to flock to London, making it the most commercially viable base.
The no-frills idea came from the United States. Ryanair, based in Dublin, pioneered the market in the UK in the early Nineties, followed by easyJet in 1996, which grabbed attention with flights between Luton and Glasgow for £29 - 'the price of a pair of jeans'.
The British Airways offshoot Go followed and earlier this year Air UK, owned by Dutch national airline KLM, reinvented itself as Buzz. Virgin Express, a subsidiary of Sir Richard Branson's empire, is also low-cost but with only one route between Heathrow and Brussels.
They take a simple formula: buy lots of the same aircraft, fly as often as possible to popular cities, hire young staff on low pay, and offer eye-catching fares and no frills such as free meals.
In the US, one in every four passengers travels on a low-cost airline. In Europe that figure is one in 20 and passenger numbers are predicted to rise to 15 million by 2002 from just five million two years ago.
Keiron Brennan, vice president of management consultants Gemini Consulting, said: 'In the domestic market in the UK, the rail network is quite weak and that is a recipe for success in the low-cost airline business. They have created a new market.'
Simon Evans of the AUC advises travellers to shop around. Try bonded consolidators such as Trailfinders or Flightbookers, high street travel agents, Internet sites (such as www.lastminute.com or www.cheapflights.com), or phone the airline. Bargains are waiting to be discovered.

webTitle: Gunners give the Beeb a boost

fields.headline: Gunners give the Beeb a boost
fields.trailText: Jon Henderson: You almost certainly regretted it afterwards, but a huge number of you watched the Uefa Cup final on television last Wednesday evening.
fields.body:
You almost certainly regretted it afterwards, but a huge number of you watched the Uefa Cup final on television last Wednesday evening. So many, in fact, that the match is currently in the bronze-medal position for the most-watched games of the season (the figures for yesterday's FA Cup final, which will provide an intriguing indicator of the competition's continuing popularity, are not included in our list).

The high viewing figure for the Uefa Cup decider in Copenhagen between Arsenal and Galatasaray completed what was an unexpectedly successful season for the BBC considering they had just a handful of live games. Four of them ended up in the top 10, including their 'as live' - that is, slightly delayed but shown in full - coverage of the Scotland-England Euro 2000 qualifier from Hampden Park. The 9.4 million viewers they got for this game confirmed the lasting popularity of the traditional free-to-air broadcasters. The actual live coverage on Sky drew an audience of 2.07 million, while the second leg at Wembley - shown live on both ITV and Sky - produced the season's table-topping viewing figure of 14.6 million for ITV while just over a million chose satellite.

Once again Manchester United dominated the top 10 with seven entries, although, perhaps significantly, none of their Champions League matches made it into the top three. Is Uefa's decision to allow so many non-champions into their Champions League having an effect?

One advantage - and it is a sizeable one - that clubs relegated from the Premiership have over the teams they join in the First Division is the television money they take down with them. Wimbledon, for example, are already guaranteed a parting gift of £4.3 million made up of a merit award of nearly £700,000 and an equal share of the Sky TV money, which this time around works out at £3.65 million per club.

In all they are likely to collect close to £6 million by the time the fees for their TV appearances last season - live on Sky and on the BBC's Match of the Day - are paid. In addition they will get a so-called parachute payment - 50 per cent of the equal share - for the next two seasons.

Meanwhile, teams coming up from the First Division to the Premiership have to make do with the far sparser television rewards paid to Football League clubs as they seek to make their squads strong enough to survive in the top flight. All of which almost certainly accounts for the fact that clubs trying to go straight back up from the First Division tend to be more successful than the new arrivals in the Premiership are at fighting off relegation. Perhaps some thought should be given to redressing this. Top 10 football matches 1999-2000

1. England v Scotland Euro 2000 qualifier (ITV) 14.6m

2. Manchester United v Necaxa World club championship (BBC1) 10.2m

3. Arsenal v Galatasaray Uefa Cup final (BBC1) 10m

4. Manchester United v Fiorentina Champions League (ITV) 9.9m

5. Manchester United v Real Madrid Champions League (ITV) 9.8m

6. Manchester United v Marseille Champions League (ITV) 9.7m

7= Scotland v England Euro 2000 qualifier (as live) (BBC1) 9.4m

7= Manchester United v Valencia Champions League (ITV) 9.4m

9. Manchester United v Vasco de Gama World club championship (BBC1) 9.2m

10. Sturm Graz v Manchester United Champions League (ITV) 8.8m

webTitle: Good guy Mendieta a wanted man

fields.headline: Good guy Mendieta a wanted man
fields.standfirst: But Valencia's conscientious objector and star schemer has no intention of walking away
fields.trailText: Alex Simpson on Valencia's conscientious objector and star schemer, who has no intention of walking away.
fields.body:
Guus Hiddink, the former Holland national coach, went for an interview recently and it probably went something like this: 'Well Guus, your career appears to have been on the slide a bit recently, so why should we give you the job?' 'Well I was the one who discovered Gaizka Mendieta.' 'That's fine Guus, when can you start?' replied the Celtic directors in unison.

Blond Valencia midfielder Mendieta might not be a household name, but he unites opinion in everyone who witnesses his delightful football. If ever a player were available who could justify the kind of exorbitant fees commanded by players such as Inter's Christian Vieri, then it would be Mendieta.

But then the Basque-born Gaizka (pronounced: guyshka) is unlikely to be ever available, one of the old school, a player who would rather not complicate his professional life and see out his time with just one club - a rarity in modern football. Mendieta, much to the chagrin of Spanish coaches - who this week voted him along with Real Madrid's Raúl as the best national player - will be sticking with Valencia.

'Mendieta is the type of player every team would love to have,' said the Rangers coach Dick Advocaat after his side faced Valencia in the first group stage. 'Not just skilful, but with imagination, and full of running and working for his team.' 'Dick was just drooling about him after going out to watch his team in Spain,' said John Greig, Rangers' former captain and manager.

Anyone who sees Valencia play generally fixes on the skilful, bustling, hard-working midfielder and the speed and effectiveness of Claudio Lopez up front. Fans love the tireless and tough Mendieta on the right, one minute back in defence helping out, moments later up the other end feeding another ball into the channel for Lopez to seize on, and every now and again getting into the box himself. In short, the sort of player everyone wants in their team. The Spanish national coach, José-Antonio Camacho, describes him as the all-round player personified.

And then there are the goals: not just the quantity you expect from an all-round player, but beauties, goals that, if compiled on an agent's videotape and sent to the moneybags chairmen of the very richest clubs, would solicit a 'sign that player' response.

The moment when everyone sat up and took notice came in last year's Spanish Cup final, when the Valencia captain gave as complete and dominant a performance as one could wish to see. Totally dominating his side of the pitch, and blunting the effectiveness of the Atletico Madrid midfield, he set up a goal for Lopez and capped his one-man show with a goal that will remain forever in the memories of Spanish fans. With his back to goal, Mendieta turned, flicked the ball over his marker's head, controlled it in the area and evaded the tackle of another opponent before scoring. The word from the Nou Camp, Santiago Bernabeu, San Siro et al after that goal was: Sign up Mendieta. The mobile phone of Mendieta's agent, he later revealed, never stopped ringing; doubtless the line at the Mestalla club offices fairly hummed too.

The Valencia board got to work. Mendieta's contract was due to expire in 2000, he could have seen it out, or just taken one of the offers from the team's then guaranteeing Champions League football the following season.

Valencia are not a powerhouse, and the club has had cash-flow problems. 'Mendieta is an emblem of the club,' declared Valencia president Pedro Cortes, and the cup winners promptly handed their captain a new eight-year deal that doubled his earnings... netting him about £1.25 million.

'Everything I ever wanted as a footballer I've achieved in 1999, given that apart from winning the cup, I was called up by Spain and extended my contract with Valencia,' he said, newly rich and newly capped. The cup-final goal was compared in Spain to one scored by Pele in the World Cup finals in 1958. Mendieta, who admitted that he was proud to be compared to the great Brazilian, showed an extremely rare lapse of his accustomed modesty when he said he thought his goal was better.

It's not the first time his goals - 18 this season - have earned such comparisons. Following one mazy run away at Athletic Bilbao, former coach Claudio Ranieri said 'I can only compare that goal to Maradona.' Viewers in the UK may have seen Mendieta's Nou Camp goal from last year's cup run, when he volleyed a corner from outside the area which rocketed into the top corner. It was unstoppable.

Mendieta is not a typical football star. Quiet and unassuming, shy, quite different from his appearance on the pitch. He was a conscientious objector and refused to do his military service; consequently he was required to work for the social services instead, and and didn't use his professional football to get out of it.

In his formative years, he alternated between right-back and holding and organising midfielder, but says that his preferred position is what is known in Spain as the 'pivot' - in front of the back-line, and not just responsible for destruction, but also creation of play.

'At this moment I'm not thinking of changing team. I've got a long contract,' he said. He differs from most of today's mercenaries in that he means it.

fields.headline: Dennis loses his menace
fields.standfirst: Arsène Wenger faces a tough decision on precious striker Bergkamp, who no longer conjures the magic to turn big games
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger faces a tough decision on precious striker Bergkamp, who no longer conjures the magic to turn big games.
fields.body:
Happy Birthday Dennis Bergkamp? Turning 31 last Thursday won't go down as one of his most convivial celebrations.

A lonely schlep down the motorways of northern Europe with a head full of frustration and failure is no recipe for a swinging party. All those hours in the car staring out of the window with nothing to do but think probably didn't help him to digest another large dose of disappointment. Why is it that showpiece games keep dragging him down? Copenhagen 2000 was not the first time the media has built him up as a potential matchwinner only to cackle in his face. In the end his performance was so indifferent he was hauled off before he had the chance to miss a penalty.

The onus is always on the extraordinary player to make the difference and he is always expected to be the star, the catalyst. Arriving in Denmark last week he knew it was about time he enjoyed his moment on the major stage again. After a series of downers, he felt good before the game. Sharp, strong, excited even. But he didn't produce. He flickered, but never quite sparked to life. The fact is that big games no longer elicit the best of Bergkamp.

What to do with his enigmatic Dutchman is the single biggest question facing Arsène Wenger over the summer. Yes, he has to ensure the futures of Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit, and entice a new striker, central midfield back-up and perhaps a centre-half among others. Bergkamp, though, is key. He has a year left on his contract and reportedly wants an extension. So far, in his five seasons at Highbury he has been guaranteed his place if fit.

But this season's statistics make you wonder how long that faith can continue: he lasted 90 minutes only eight times all season in the Premiership. He scored only six league goals. Of course there is more to him than goalscoring, but he would be the first to admit this has been a largely disappointing campaign. Wenger has to decide to what extent Arsenal can afford to carry someone who plays in such a critical position as Bergkamp when the striker's in one of his depressed moods.

Too often he reacts to close marking as if it's an insulting invasion of space and becomes ratty instead of rising above it to teach some stopper a lesson. High on intelligence and fiercely private, Bergkamp has always come across as slightly intense, but sometimes these days he's so unrelaxed he can't play his normal game - especially in Europe, where he puts himself under extra pressure because of his travel arrangements (he won't fly). It's interesting to recall how Manchester United only clicked for real in Europe when their own icon, Eric Cantona, was out of the equation.

Wenger has always found Bergkamp fascinating. He studies his precious No 10 in the same way a trainer tries to understand the idiosyncrasies of a brilliant racehorse, where so many complexities and delicate details have to be right to ensure peak performance.

But now he must ask himself whether his playmaker has simply had a desperate run of poor luck or, more worryingly, if he just doesn't have the head for high-tension games anymore. Frank Rijkaard, Bergkamp's national coach, is probably pondering the same thing. His Holland berth for Euro 2000 was under considerable threat until something snapped in Ruud van Nistelrooy's knee.

Nobody is asking for 90 minutes of unadulterated genius, but just a few telling moments capable of changing a game would do. Consider the last time Bergkamp reigned supreme over a grand occasion. It was nearly two years ago - two years ago! - when Holland stunned Argentina in the dying embers of a fiery tussle in the World Cup quarter-finals. He had been subdued for most of the game and suddenly scored the most beautiful and technically accomplished goal of the tournament. Then it all went wrong. There was no repeat in the semi-final against Brazil and Holland went out via the agony of the penalty shoot-out. Bergkamp scored his (as the iceman always used to do), but others weren't so lucky.

Penalties. Damn penalties. Bergkamp has never been the same since he had the chance to fulfil a long-standing FA Cup Final dream with a last-minute spot-kick against Manchester United in 1999's epic semi-final replay. He rates Peter Schmeichel's save as one of his most heartbreaking moments in football. His hatred of the penalty has spread like a virus through the ranks of Highbury. Nine Arsenal players were cursed from 12 yards this season.

It can't only be ill fortune. If losing one penalty shoot-out is unlucky and two is plain careless, three is a major psychological barrier. For all the multitude of positives Wenger has brought to Arsenal, they have lost some of their mental toughness. They never gave the impression of being fully motivated for the Uefa Cup Final. The manager aknowledged afterwards that Galatasaray were more 'up for it' - a reflection of Wenger's biggest weakness. Sometimes players need a whip to be cracked or a carrot dangled but he doesn't like raised voices in the dressing room, and expects the individuals in his team to be rounded enough to raise themselves. The price you pay for bringing in foreign quality is an eroding sense of closeness and comradeship. Today's multicultural squads are made up of fellow professionals, not mates.

As Galatasaray bounded on to their bus with the trophy, their bond of friendship was there for all to see. They bellowed their victory songs and hammered the windows, danced in the aisles and jumped on the seats. You couldn't imagine Arsenal would have been half as expressive even if they had emerged triumphant.

Leaving the Parken behind in a manner so different to last time around in 1994, Tony Adams tried to be philosophical, saying that what matters is how you get up from a fall. He believes you learn more from defeats than from victories. Food for thought for the one man who wasn't on the bus to the airport, Dennis Bergkamp.

But now he must ask himself whether his playmaker has simply had a desperate run of poor luck or, more worryingly, if he just doesn't have the head for high-tension games anymore. Frank Rijkaard, Bergkamp's national coach, is probably pondering the same thing. His Holland berth for Euro 2000 was under considerable threat until something snapped in Ruud van Nistelrooy's knee. Nobody is asking for 90 minutes of unadulterated genius, but just a few telling moments capable of changing a game would do. Consider the last time Bergkamp reigned supreme over a grand occasion. It was nearly two years ago - two years ago! - when Holland stunned Argentina in the dying embers of a fiery tussle in the World Cup quarter-finals. He had been subdued for most of the game and suddenly scored the most beautiful and technically accomplished goal of the tournament. Then it all went wrong. There was no repeat in the semi-final against Brazil and Holland went out via the agony of the penalty shoot-out. Bergkamp scored his (as the iceman always used to do), but others weren't so lucky. Penalties. Damn penalties. Bergkamp has never been the same since he had the chance to fulfil a long-standing FA Cup Final dream with a last-minute spot-kick against Manchester United in 1999's epic semi-final replay. He rates Peter Schmeichel's save as one of his most heartbreaking moments in football. His hatred of the penalty has spread like a virus through the ranks of Highbury. Nine Arsenal players were cursed from 12 yards this season. It can't only be ill fortune. If losing one penalty shoot-out is unlucky and two is plain careless, three is a major psychological barrier. For all the multitude of positives Wenger has brought to Arsenal, they have lost some of their mental toughness. They never gave the impression of being fully motivated for the Uefa Cup Final. The manager aknowledged afterwards that Galatasaray were more 'up for it' - a reflection of Wenger's biggest weakness. Sometimes players need a whip to be cracked or a carrot dangled but he doesn't like raised voices in the dressing room, and expects the individuals in his team to be rounded enough to raise themselves. The price you pay for bringing in foreign quality is an eroding sense of closeness and comradeship. Today's multicultural squads are made up of fellow professionals, not mates. As Galatasaray bounded on to their bus with the trophy, their bond of friendship was there for all to see. They bellowed their victory songs and hammered the windows, danced in the aisles and jumped on the seats. You couldn't imagine Arsenal would have been half as expressive even if they had emerged triumphant. Leaving the Parken behind in a manner so different to last time around in 1994, Tony Adams tried to be philosophical, saying that what matters is how you get up from a fall. He believes you learn more from defeats than from victories. Food for thought for the one man who wasn't on the bus to the airport, Dennis Bergkamp.

fields.headline: Road threat to masterpiece
fields.trailText: Travel news.
fields.body:
British art experts are dismayed by an Italian motorway project which threatens a major site on the 'Piero trail' on the Tuscan/Umbrian border.

Ten years ago Piero della Francesca's Madonna del parto fresco was painstakingly removed from a tiny chapel near Monterchi, for display in a specially prepared building on the edge of the ancient village. Now road planners want to build a motorway within feet of the permanent exhibition.

The highway will be raised on stilts, destroying the view of the village from the surrounding plains.

'This is sacrilege,' said Royal Academician Sir Frederick Gore, who has painted several views of the village. 'The Piero was moved to its present site at great risk. It is now properly displayed in what is something like a shrine to his work.'

The road starts in Arezzo, where Piero's work in the church of San Francesco (featured in Escape 's Italy Special on 7 May) has only recently opened to view after years of restoration. Monterchi is included with Arezzo and Sansepolcro on a trail taken by many art lovers to see the Renaissance master's work.

Dr Patricia Rubin, Renaissance specialist at London's Courtauld Institute of Art, is not surprised by the plans. 'The Italians have always been quite irresponsible about their landscape, and developments to facilitate the motor car are completely uncontrolled. I am sure there are any number of political and economic factors involved because people make a lot of money from building roads.

'I am very distressed about the effect this highway would have on the landscape,' she added. 'Although I am critical of the fresco's present setting, it is very tied to the town's identity. It is an unexpected and grandiose image in such a remote region.' British protesters are invited to write to Signor Antonio Rolle of the Committee for the Protection of Monterchi, Il Palasetto, Borgecciano, Monterchi, Italy.

More visitors to Northern Ireland

Despite the stuttering progress of the peace talks, Northern Ireland is reaping a 'peace dividend', reporting a record number of visitors in 1999.

For the first time ever more than a million British visitors crossed the Irish Sea last year. Crucially, 100,000 of these visitors travelled on holiday, up 23 per cent on 1998.

David McAuley, acting chief executive of the Northern Ireland Tourist Board, said: 'This growth is a reflection of the real progress which has been made in the last two years both politically with the peace process and economically with the investment of our public and private industry part ners.' The Republic of Ireland is the biggest market for tourism to the north, with 104,000 holiday visitors crossing the border - a rise of 16 per cent.

 A strike by French security guards has sparked a cash crisis. Up to 60 per cent of automatic teller machines were reported out of action last week as guards refuse to ship cash to them. Anthony Totten, of Lloyds TSB cards service, advised visitors to France to expect to use credit cards. He said retailers were lowering limits to as little as 10 francs for purchases. Foreign currency travellers' cheques are safer than carrying excessive cash, he said.

fields.headline: Why Ulster should be independent
fields.trailText:
Yet another week of crisis looms for
                                                                  Northern Ireland, with no certainty that
                                                                  David Trimble can persuade his party to
                                                                  accept the latest deal. Behind this lies a
                                                                  truth as curious as it is unnoticed. If its
                                                                  implication are worked out logically, it
                                                                  leads to the one outcome no one as yet
                                                                  publicly advocates...an independent
                                                                  Ulster.
fields.body:
Yet another week of crisis looms for Northern Ireland, with no certainty that David Trimble can persuade his party to accept the latest deal. Behind this lies a truth as curious as it is unnoticed. If its implication are worked out logically, it leads to the one outcome no one as yet publicly advocates...an independent Ulster.

On the face of it, we have here a familiar territorial dispute... the United Kingdom and Irish Republic competing over a province which they both cherish, while nationalists wanting a united Ireland are confronted by unionists who want to remain in the United Kingdom. None of this corresponds to reality.

Plainly the British Government is trying to disengage from Northern Ireland. The negotiations of the past few years, including the latest cosmetic deal with the IRA, might have been inspired by the advice an American gave his country over Vietnam 30 years ago: declare a victory and get out. It might well be the wish of the British people.

The British - 'English' would be more accurate - have no great emotional affinity, or love, for the Ulster Protestants. When Harold Wilson attacked the Loyalist strikers as 'spongers' in 1974 he was echoing, less eloquently, what John Milton said more than 300 years earlier - and what many Englishmen vaguely feel to this day. The Ulster settlers were Scotch 'thieves and red-shanks', Milton said, who had been 'neighbourly admitted ... by the courtesy of England, to hold possessions in our province, a country better than their own', and in return had 'with worse faith than the heathen, proved ungrateful and treacherous guests to their best friends'.

It doesn't seem far from there to the Downing Street Declaration of 1994, which said, truthfully enough, that the British had no selfish strategic or economic interest in Northern Ireland, which begged to be completed with 'so please let us find a way of getting out'.

At much the same time Sir Patrick Mayhew told Die Zeit that the British would leave Ulster 'mit dem Handkuss' - with pleasure - if they could. This is one truth that David Trimble has grasped. Any unionist argument from history is certainly poor: the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland didn't exist 200 years ago, and in its full form lasted for no more than 120 years. The only thing feebler is the historical argument for a United Ireland, given that no independent Irish state ever existed before 1922, and that Ireland has never been politically united in its history, except under the English Crown.

Maybe the southern Irish dimly recognise that. For generations the Irish state made an irredentist claim on Northern Ireland, embodied in Articles 2 and 3 of the constitution. In reality, 'the national question' played a most distinctive role in Irish political life: reunification was a goal which must always be pursued, but must never be achieved.

Not least, the Irish knew that partition had been highly convenient for them. By exporting sectarian conflict to the North, it was the essential factor which made possible the creation of a stable and peaceful Irish state. It isn't really surprising to anyone who knows Ireland that in a poll not long ago, a mere 21 per cent of Irish said they were 'very interested' in reunifcation. And seven years ago a still more pointed question was asked: in order to achieve a united Ireland, would they would be prepared to pay any more taxes? All of 19 per cent of Irish polled said they were.

Is this, as Borges's said, two bald men fighting over a comb? The truth is, no one wants Northern Ireland. With all their noisy violence, republican and loyalist zealots are hooligans at a match neither side wants to win.

Least understood is the position of the Ulster Protestants. Occasionally someone asks why we call them loyalists 'when they don't seem very loyal'. The answer is that not only is 'loyalist' a misnomer, so is 'unionist'. Partition and the Stormont statelet was not a 'unionist' outcome for Northern Ireland: the only part of Ireland which hadn't wanted home rule was the only part to get it. But before long the Ulstermen had come to like Stormont too well, and by the late Thirties, 'Back to Westminster' - the dream of integration which beguiled many, was rejected by the Ulster Unionist Council.

The real nature of 'unionism' was shown by one of the least known, and most extraordinary, episodes in Ulster history. In the spring of 1945, Sir Basil Brooke's unionist junta at Stormont called an early Northern Ireland general election. No sooner had the unionists won a landslide than the Stormont cabinet discussed whether the time was ripe to demand Dominion status from Westminster. When one Minister reminded his colleagues of the huge subsidies Northern Ireland enjoyed from the British Treasury, they backtracked.

What this says is riveting. Had Northern Ireland become a Dominion, Brooke could have still have used the 'British' rhetoric of Crown and Empire. But he would have been governing a country as effectively independent as Canada and Australia, not to say as De Valera's Ireland. In other words, what was unionism was really Ulster nationalism - and so it remains. Henry McDonald's biography of David Trimble is revealing in this respect. In 1974 Trimble was arguing that 'independence may be the only alternative to a united Ireland', and he continued to advocate Dominion status until the late Eighties.

Maybe Trimble is right. If the British don't want Northern Ireland, and the Irish don't want it either, then logic points to a separate Northern Ireland. A sovereign Ulster would be quite as large in area and population as - and much larger in domestic product than - many United Nations member states. It would have to find a way for its two communities to live together, and it would have to stand on its own feet economically. For years, we have been told that there is no alternative to the Belfast Agreement, there is no 'plan B'. Perhaps we should start looking for plan C.

fields.headline: Changing the culture of defeat
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain is not a man drawn to hyperbole. There were no "we flippin' murdered 'ems" from him as he collected his winner's cheque on the balcony. He chose, instead, to describe England's demolition of Zimbabwe as "almost a complete performance".
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain is not a man drawn to hyperbole. There were no "we flippin' murdered 'ems" from him as he collected his winner's cheque on the balcony. He chose, instead, to describe England's demolition of Zimbabwe as "almost a complete performance".

But let's be a bit more upbeat than that - after all England won at Lord's, their nemesis, and with a day to spare. At five to four this afternoon they beat the weather, history, public indifference and an ego-denting innings from Bryan Strang at the death to complete their first innings victory at home since they trolloped New Zealand at Trent Bridge in 1994.

England looked cohesive thoughout the match. They supported each other in the field, caught like champion anglers and looked pleased to be there (Chris Scofield even handed Ed Giddins a stump at the end in a gesture of new-boy solidarity). Two of the contracted 12 got centuries and the fast bowlers complemented each other well - Gough's bounce was back and Giddins won the Man of the Match award in his second Test. The selectors can be well pleased.

Of course, not everything dovetailed perfectly. Schofield did a Hamilton - no runs or wickets - on debut (but without having a chance to bowl), Ramprakash had another unfulfilled trip to Lord's, and there was the usual collapse by the tail. But - hallelujah - England have now won two Tests on the trot (however controversial the circumstances at Centurion) - just nine more and they too will be challenging the record of Clive LloydÕs West Indians. So Schofield's first outing in Test cricket comes in a winning team and Giddins experiences a victory in only his second Test: invaluable if Duncan Fletcher and Hussain are to change the culture of defeat.

The Zimbabweans on the other hand, Heath Streak's bowling and Strang's swashbuckling apart, offered the sort of resistance that England have specialised in at Lord's over the last decade. In other words, none. They might have tried to take their minds off the defeat this afternoon by watching Cinderella on BBC1. But unless Zimbabwe can pull themselves out of the slump and refocus their minds, they won't be going to any balls this summer.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Advisers who'll never say 'boo' to a dot.com

fields.headline: Advisers who'll never say 'boo' to a dot.com
fields.trailText: A model and a former poetry critic raise £80 million to start an online retail company which purveys only 'urban sportswear'. What could possibly go wrong?
fields.body:
A model and a former poetry critic raise £80 million to start an online retail company which purveys only 'urban sportswear'. What could possibly go wrong?

Plenty. The designer can of worms that is boo.com is only just beginning to emerge. And my guess is that we will see a dribble of increasingly ear-bleeding testimony about just how the company managed to burn £100m in a year.

The story pushes all the wrong buttons in terms of knee-jerk prejudices: who could resist laughing at the predicament of the smug and silly man in his square specs or the woman who is so beautiful that it is a wonder anyone ever bothered to photograph of Martha Lane Fox?

But if I was one of the many investors and employees of boo.com, I would reserve my wrath for the 'advisers', JP Morgan. The fact that the bank resigned its role in February, having taken a stake in the company, does not disguise the fact that controls within boo.com for the preceding nine months were lamentably absent.

Investment banks, which charge a nonsensical rate for their highly skilled services, often give the impression that when dot.com dobbin roams into view the last thing they do is ask him to open wide while they inspect his gums.

The result of this incautious approach to investment management is bound to be more boos in the pipeline. JP Morgan no doubt acted in good faith at the time and did its best possible work, but it is informative to cast the mind back a year and remember that all boo had going for it was rarity value. Then, there were only a handful of potential Internet initial public offerings and boo.com was one. But rarity value is not enough to justify sanctioning a business - putting money into boo was after all tantamount to taking out a put option on dodo egg futures.

No one will spill too many tears for Bernard Arnault and his handbag empire. He and the other investors took on the role of pioneering venture capitalists. They must have known there was a strong chance of them never seeing a return on investment. But among the 400 employees who lost their jobs, there must be a strong sense that they were let down by management within and outside the company.

It is breathtaking that no one called time on expansion months before they did, and a relief that the firm collapsed long before small investors got the chance to lose their shirts in a disastrous IPO.

Granada's announcement last week that it was taking over caterer Compass and proceeding swiftly to the flotation of its media businesses and a full demerger of the company happened more quickly than most imagined. It can hardly have been a sur prise, however. The market has been baying for a Granada demerger for three years, but that has not helped the company's lamentable share price.

Even a promise from the golden couple of British management, Gerry Robinson and Charles Allen, that they expect to deliver better shareholder value and double-digit growth in the coming year has not lifted the scepticism, which in some quarters has spilled into an open knocking of their recent record. Yet the company's results have continued to be as solid as ever.

The doubts are firstly over whether Compass's £5bn merger with Granada's leisure and hotels business will slow the caterer by opening it up to the cyclical hotels business.

The doubts about that deal will make a demerger heavy going if it continues to depress the share price. This is a shame because Granada's media intentions are clear: to retain a majority in ITV, whether that means taking over United News and Media or Carlton, and to expand with further acquisitions.

The basic problem for the City appears to be a serious failure of belief in the powers of Robinson and Allen to deliver. There is no real evidence, for instance, that Compass will be held back by losing its catering focus, so long as the leisure business's integration is handled with care.

Similarly, the criticism that Granada has not been a visionary risk-taker in television does not detract from its pole management positions in the hugely successful ITV network and a play, albeit a weak one, through OnDigital, in multi-channel pay-TV.

Given the famine of decent managerial records in the FTSE, it seems premature to label the deal a dead loss, but the sceptics will give Robinson his last big challenge before he goes. If he can beat that, he can beat anything.

The designer can of worms that is boo.com is only just beginning to emerge. And my guess is that we will see a dribble of increasingly ear-bleeding testimony about just how the company managed to burn £100m in a year. The story pushes all the wrong buttons in terms of knee-jerk prejudices: who could resist laughing at the predicament of the smug and silly man in his square specs or the woman who is so beautiful that it is a wonder anyone ever bothered to photograph of Martha Lane Fox? webTitle: Greg Dyke was right to snub the Queen Mother

fields.headline: Greg Dyke was right to snub the Queen Mother
fields.trailText: Where will you be on 19 July? If you haven't made plans, then here are a few ideas: wrap yourself in the flag of St George and quaff a flagon of mead, hold a street party complete with bunting and Union Jack hats, or invite yourself round to Paul Dacre's house (he's the editor of the Daily Mail) and settle down in front of ITV with a six-pack.
fields.body:
Where will you be on 19 July? If you haven't made plans, then here are a few ideas: wrap yourself in the flag of St George and quaff a flagon of mead, hold a street party complete with bunting and Union Jack hats, or invite yourself round to Paul Dacre's house (he's the editor of the Daily Mail) and settle down in front of ITV with a six-pack.

Because 19 July, you may be surprised to learn, is the Queen Mother's hundredth birthday. Actually, it isn't. But it is her pre-hundredth birthday pageant, the event which the BBC said it had no plans to televise live and thus scandalised the Daily Mail. From the furious response, one would have thought Mr Dyke had defecated through the letter box of Clarence House, rather than made a sound judgment on something which promises to be as thrilling as Trooping the Colour. The Mail, in turn, made hay with a campaign it could not lose - to shame broadcasters into allowing the nation to see this extravaganza. BBC director-general Greg Dyke, to his great credit, stood firm, allowing ITV, which had shown, it had to be said, no prior interest in this national day of celebration, to step into the breach.

Worse was to come for Dyke. The Telegraph devoted a leader in Friday's paper to a small item entitled 'Show Dyke the Door', claiming that there were acute similarities between Bob Ayling's decision to take the union jack from the tailfin of British Airways' planes and Greg's decision to keep the Queen Mum's tattoo off the BBC. For the feeble minded, this might seem 'strikingly similar' but Ayling's eventual demise was because his errors were entirely a commercial misjudgement. If on 19 July the country grinds to a standstill and workers pack living rooms, church halls and pubs to watch the parade that Dyke passed up, then clearly he should be sacked..

Somewhere in the hysteria, it has already been forgotten that the BBC is already spending a million pounds of licence payers money on special Queen Mother programming.

The disgrace of an untelevised pageant for the Queen Mum fell in the same week as other issues about the role of television grumbled on elsewhere in the press: the suitability of Andrew Marr to be the new BBC political editor, the disappearance of Grandstand on Cup Final day and the continuing furore over News at Ten .

The fact that the media seem hypnotised by their own navels is an unfortunate fact of life. For television scheduling to be used as a soapbox issue for politicians and tabloid editors is inevitable. Dangerous broadcasters are like dangerous dogs - they generate a high-profile debate which involves no financial commitment but gives the entirely false impression that policy makers are actually doing something in the interest of the public.

Television - in an age when one in three have some form of multichannel TV - is no longer as 'special' as it once was in having a scheduling duty to the public, and is getting less special by the day.

But the BBC is special, because we pay for it, whether we like it or not; if you have a television, you are taxed via the licence fee. Therefore, it is right and proper that licence-fee payers should be allowed to whinge about coverage or lack of it whenever they want to.

Which to my mind makes Greg Dyke's stoicism in the face of outrage utterly laudable. If the BBC was a state broadcaster rather than a public service broadcaster, it would be compulsory for it to show every bum-numbing occasion featuring non-elected dignitaries, but thankfully our television service is more evolved that those of North Korea and Albania.

No one would wish the Queen Mother anything but goodwill on her hundredth birthday, but to expect a TV company which can no longer afford to bring us the Cup Final to spend millions on the outside broadcast of birthday celebrations for someone who is neither the monarch nor the head of state is as preposterous as it is arcane.

fields.headline: Shame about the Net
fields.standfirst: Luton to Amsterdam
fields.trailText: Luton to Amsterdam.
fields.body:
Booking

EasyJet sells 67 per cent of its seats on the Net. I had never entrusted my credit card number to the Internet, but chose to go with the flow. The easyJet website is clear, listing available fares for each flight. Amsterdam ranged from £22.50 to £97.50. I chose a flight out for £37.50 and back for £47.50 (total, £97.30 with taxes). I entered my payment details and four minutes passed before I read: 'Sorry, there has been a problem with the database. Please come back and try later.' I clicked on the 'Back' button. 'Your browser just lost all the data pertaining to this reservation. It's a common problem with MS Explorer 3.' This seemed bad news. I phoned reservations and was assured my booking had been received. I asked if this had happened before. 'It's actually very common,' he replied, but couldn't tell me if my card number was now available to hackers worldwide.

Tickets

EasyJet is a ticketless airline: my confirmation number was e-mailed to me.

Check-in

I checked in an hour before take-off. Luton is a refreshing (and well-signposted) change from the disorientating expanses of Heathrow. Staff were courteous and efficient.

Boarding

Outbound: Screens announced that my flight was delayed from 12.45 to 13.20, due to a late departure from Amsterdam. I asked the easyJet helpdesk for information; it was not even aware that the flight was late. At 13.30 we began boarding. EasyJet does not allocate seats. Numbered boarding passes are issued according to the time you check in: early birds get the pick of the seats.

Inbound: the flight departed punctually at 11.50.

Take-off

No problem, on either leg.

Ambience/decor

Orange! Cabin staff were young and cheerful.

Catering

No hot meals on the one-hour flights. Sandwiches (from £2.50) and drinks (coffee £1.10, fruit juice 60p).

Service

Attentive and discreet service meant that when I fell asleep (thanks to the surprising leg-room), I wasn't disturbed.

Arrival

My baggage arrived promptly. Trains leave Schiphol for Amsterdam's Central Station every 15 minutes. Single tickets for the 20-minute journey cost 6.50 guilders (£2).

Verdict

The price I paid was reasonable for such friendly departure times. As for the Internet: once bitten, twice shy.

Rating out of 10

Service 8
Value 7

No-frills Amsterdam

Cheap eat

D'Theeboom (Singel 210: 00 31 20 623 8420) serves three courses for 47 guilders (about £13).

Cheap sleep

I found a short-let canal-side apartment (from Amsterdam Apartments 00 31 20 62 65 930), which, at £50 a night for two, was comparable to a medium-priced hotel.

Typical thing to do

I preferred the engaging Stedelijk Museum of Modern Art to both the Van Gogh and Rembrandt museums.

Less typical

Beyond the Botanical Gardens is the Tropenmuseum, a collection of anthropological artifacts from around the world.

Traveller's tip

Hire a bicycle to explore the canal paths. There is one overwhelming reason why Amsterdam feels safe, quiet and clean: there are fewer cars than in British cities.

fields.headline: Let's begin at the beginnings...
fields.standfirst: The Anthology of Prefaces that Alasdair Gray has been promising for so long is a joy
fields.trailText: The Anthology of Prefaces that Alasdair Gray has been promising for so long is a joy
fields.body:
The Anthology of Prefaces
Alasdair Gray
Bloomsbury
Buy it at BOL

This anthology of prefaces has been announced so many times in previous Alasdair Gray blurbs as to seem like a joke, though one that has taken on a phantom life of its own in booksellers' catalogues (valued at £20 in a 1993 guide, for instance, seven years before publication). The double or triple bluff is a favourite Gray device and shapes one of his blurbs here: 'Do not let smart children handle this book. It will help them pass examinations without reading anything else', a delicious truth disguised as an empty boast, disguised in turn as a sober warning.

It was William Smellie, chief compiler of the first Encyclopaedia Britannica, who gave Gray the idea for what has been 16 years' labour by observing in his introduction to The Philosophy of Natural History (1790) that 'a collection of prefaces would have exhibited a short, but curious and useful history both of literature and authors' - would have, if only writers had responsibly set out their motives and plans for what was to follow.

Many authors have, in fact, done so and their prefaces make up precisely the survey that Smellie imagined. Gray's selections start from the seventh century and go on till the early twentieth. He grazes over the common pasture of the ages, until he comes up against the baleful enclosure of copyright. A narrow definition of what constitutes a preface would insist on a difference of register from the bulk of the book and so would exclude, for instance, the General Prologue to The Canterbury Tales. Narrowness is not Gray's way and he cheerfully violates his own editorial principles. If he wants to include a book in his survey, then the absence of a suitable preface is not enough to disqualify them.

The commentaries, or 'glosses', appear as columns of small red print bordering the texts, giving the look of an old bible. Most such matter is by Gray, but he has subcontracted 30 or so other writers to finish the business. He admits to having tampered with the contributions of others, but not to having contradicted their opinions. He has exercised that prerogative, quite properly, in his own sections. So Roger Scruton's admiring gloss on Burke as a critic of the French Revolution is reproved in advance by the editor's remark that the revolution killings 'sprang from a great effort at social betterment, so are still used as a warning by writers who find deaths caused by well-established governments [even death through famine and poverty] natural and lawful'.

He sees culture as necessarily bound to economics, but not in a reductive way. Free speech became established early in Scotland, as he explains it, not because of the abstract vigour of the people but because of the sparseness of the population and the poverty of the soil: landowners could not afford to dismiss labourers, however stroppy. This is a characteristic Alasdair Gravian analysis - an absolute good becoming a reality in relatively few circumstances. From his point of view, the real casualties of the dissolution of the monasteries were the poor, since 'church social welfare' ended and a hundred hospitals were closed in a single year. In his postscript he describes his (Old) Labour roots, and the coincidence of his childhood with a patch of that scant 40 years in which education was emancipated from parental ability to pay.

But this is anything but a dour book, being multiply suffused with love and humour. Gray responds to fancy effects without wholly respecting them, and his loyalty is all to robustness and clarity, to writing with a connection to ordinary talk. He remarks about Burton's rhymed preface to The Anatomy of Melancholy (1621) that 'speech was then so healthy that even an Oxford tutor could make good plain poetry'.

Gray loves not just language but the book. He has considered every aspect of its presentation, but The Book of Prefaces also bears witness to many makers - to production assistants, typists, typesetters, all of whom have their portraits included. From copies of Gray's early book, Unlikely Stories Mostly, tumbled an erratum slip bearing the message: 'This slip has been inserted by mistake.' The slip tucked into Prefaces is more functional, but the editor's playfulness shines through it too: 'When this book had been printed and bound/22 errors were found...' In a book so extensive and so intricately laid out, it's hardly surprising that there are at least as many more undetected - but no such flaws can take away its integrity and the vitality of this achievement.

fields.headline: Labour is condemned as racist
fields.trailText: One of Britain's most prominent black politicians has launched a withering broadside against the Government and the Labour Party for being guilty of erecting 'institutional barriers' against black and Asian people.
fields.body:
One of Britain's most prominent black politicians has launched a withering broadside against the Government and the Labour Party for being guilty of erecting 'institutional barriers' against black and Asian people.

In an attack that echoes the 'institutional racism' phrase in the Macpherson report, Trevor Phillips, the Labour Party's candidate for deputy mayor of London and now Labour chair of the Greater London Assembly, said that the party had to take a deep look into its soul if it was to regain the trust of its huge black and Asian support.

Writing in The Observer, Phillips said many of Britain's democratic bodies looked as if they had been 'ethnically cleansed' of black people.

The attack will shake the Government and the Labour Party, coming a month after a similar attack by the union leader, Bill Morris. Phillips is a New Labour loyalist and a close friend of the Northern Ireland Secretary, Peter Mandelson.

He said that black and Asian Labour supporters 'wanted someone, anyone, to bid for the top table - not least to counter the drum beat of anti-asylum-seeker sentiment from our own Government'.

'New Labour's failure to elevate more black and Asian people to its upper ranks carries such a sting for these communities. This is not, as some suppose, a lack of political will at the top; it is worse than that. The problem lies in the nature of the party itself.

'There clearly are institutional barriers to black participation at the highest level.'

Phillips said it was 'a disgrace' that just one in 10 assembly members was black or Asian when the ratio among Londoners was one in three.

fields.body:
I tried to be diplomatic, as befitted an historic occasion. Having won the privilege of making the first speech to London's new Assembly as its first Chair, I felt that I had to live up to the occasion. A colleague later accused me of being 'urbane', for which read 'smooth bastard'. On reflection, I should have been direct. Instead of saying: 'We have some way to go to represent the diversity of London with just two black members', I should have said to the Assembly: 'In a city where at least one in three of us is black or brown, the fact that fewer than one in 10 of us around this table fits that description is a disgrace.'

Of course, you shouldn't judge a book by its cover. There are, apparently, no Asian members of the capital's new assembly. In fact, two of my Labour colleagues are descended in part from Anglo-Asians. In many senses, they represent the ethnic diversity of modern London better than those of us from particular communities. But even if we include them, the shameful fact is that in the four devolved assemblies - Scotland, Wales Northern Ireland, and London - our newest democratic institutions are virtually whites-only areas.

Our new democracy is ethnically-cleansed. Swathes of the British people have become disappeared persons. But if political parties fail to put a range of candidates before the people, the outcome is hardly surprising. No party, other than Labour, put a single black or Asian candidate in a winnable constituency.

The smaller parties could, I suppose, claim that they have so few seats that it's hard for them to represent the spread of the population. But the two largest parties have no excuse. William Hague's problem is that his party's rank and file manifestly does not want to be represented by black or Asian people.

Labour's high command has no such constraints. The leadership of the party is desperate to put competent, non-white people into office, and has discreetly tried to use the Millbank machine to widen its range of candidates. For example, the vetting panel which grilled Ken Livingstone also put forward more black, Asian and Chinese candidates than any similar process in the party's history. Yet despite all this effort, we have little to show by way of success.

The price of our failure is greater by far than that of the other parties. Leading Labour figures have been debating the party's appeal to its so-called 'core vote'. Some talk as though this 'core' consists entirely of the old, blue-collar vote, the traditional, white working classes. The London elections starkly demonstrated that this is no longer the truth. Our core vote may well be working class, but it is also black and Asian. These voters are just as concerned about crime, transport and jobs as anyone else. Labour is their natural home. Nine out of 10 African-Caribbeans and two out of three Asian voters back Labour. Even though Frank Dobson's share of the vote in the election fell to depths previously unthinkable for a Labour candidate in a Labour-voting city, the evidence is that those who stayed loyal to Labour were disproportionately Asian and African.

But unlike other voters, at the top of their political agenda is a deep frustration that they are voting for a political leadership that excludes them. Again and again on the doorstep, I found that black and Asian voters did not want to talk about policy, but took me to task for not running as Mayor. The questions of whether I could have won or not, or whether Dobson would have been a better Mayor (he would), were irrelevant to them. They wanted someone, anyone, to bid for the top table, not least to counter the drum beat of anti-asylum-seeker sentiment from our own government.

Even the Left fails to grasp what is taking place here. An associate of Ken Livingstone's told The Observer last week that black people did not want to be represented by the black middle classes. He could not be more wrong. Go to any Indian community, any African-Caribbean church or any mosque and the desire to 'get on' is palpable. The talk is of 'role models' and success. That's why New Labour's failure to elevate more black and Asian people to its upper ranks carries such a sting for these communities - they want to see their own people climbing the ladder of success.

This week, attention will be focused on the race to succeed Bernie Grant as Labour's candidate for Tottenham. There should be no assumption that this is a 'black' seat. Colour-coding parliamentary seats will only force excellent black candidates into being forced to compete with each other for the few seats where there are large numbers of black people. All four of those short-listed would make first-rate MPs.

But several well-known black candidates were judged to be not up to the mark for a tough by-election. I doubt that there was a Blairite plot to impose a Millbank candidate. And a short list with just one white person on it could hardly be accused of being the result of racial bias. This is not, as some suppose, a lack of political will at the top. It is worse than that. The problem lies in the nature of the party itself, and we need to take a hard look at why we are failing our most committed members.

Clearly, there are institutional barriers to black participation at the highest level. Paradoxically, improvements in the selection process may be raising the hurdles still higher for young and minority aspirants. The professionalisation of selection, with high-powered interviews and presentations, though improving the calibre of candidates, requires a kind of life experience denied to many from the minority communities. Would the young Bernie Grant have made it through the current process? Possibly not. Not because his views were too left-wing, but because his plain-spokenness would have been deemed too much of a risk with a hostile media pack.

One member, one vote is right, but it puts a premium on having been around for long enough for local party members to know you. And the membership proved remarkably conservative in its choices. Remember, it was not the party hierarchy which knocked out so many black and Asian GLA candidates - it was the membership which voted for names with which they were familiar.

I do not believe we should turn back the reforms, but I do believe that we can cope with them better. First, we can prepare people for the rigours of the political process. A new organisation, called EQ, is to be launched this week by leading Labour women and minority politicians. It will offer training and mentoring, even small grants to give them time off work, if needed. Second, the few black and Asian politicians who are there need to back each other up, rather than sniping at each other. Personally, I would never have made it through electoral maze without the support of Paul Boateng, Keith Vaz and Bernie Grant.

Third, the party needs to set itself a public target. This will be hard, because it implies that some aspirants who are not black or Asian will need to put their ambitions on hold. But this is the test. Do we mean it when we say we want to be representative or not? If we do, then given that some 40-50 per cent of our vote in London is black or Asian, among our London MPs, there should be at least 25 who are not white.

There is one constituency which recently mislaid its Labour MP - Brent East. Time to show the way.

webTitle: 'Judas' of the eco-warriors spreads his gospel of doubt

fields.headline: 'Judas' of the eco-warriors spreads his gospel of doubt
fields.standfirst: Anthony Browne reports on the Greenpeace founder who now denounces 'extremism'
fields.trailText: Anthony Browne reports on the Greenpeace founder who now denounces 'extremism'.
fields.body:
He helped found Greenpeace, and was a director of it for 15 years. He took part in direct action against whaling and nuclear testing, was arrested for protecting a seal pup from being clubbed to death, and was on board the Rainbow Warrior the day it was blown up by French spies in Auckland harbour.

But now Dr Patrick Moore is seen by environmentalists as a traitor to the cause.

In his latest broadside against the green movement, Moore last week denounced the charity to which he devoted so much in the Seventies and early Eighties as an enemy of the environment, declaring its policies 'irrational' and 'damaging'. The Canadian author - who is now employed by the timber industry as its spokesman - also condemned much of the rest of the mainstream environment movement for scaremongering and peddling 'phoney baloney'.

He criticised a range of other green charities, including the World Wide Fund for Nature and the Rainforest Foundation, and ridiculed celebrities such as Sting and Leonardo DiCaprio, who he believes have jumped on the green bandwagon. 'I doubt Leonardo DiCaprio has a deep knowledge of molecular biology,' he said.

In an atmosphere of bitter recrimination, the environmentalists are hitting back hard. Greenpeace has declared that he has 'gone off the rails'. The Forest Action Network has even dedicated a website to proving that 'Patrick Moore is a big fat liar' featuring pictures of him with a Pinocchio nose. 'Judas Is-cariot had the decency to hang himself after betraying Jesus,' one item reads. 'Moore ... can't even be persuaded to shut his mouth'.

Indeed, he cannot. Moore, 52, regularly takes to the airwaves and publishes essays in North America to denounce environmental 'extremism'.

And the greens do not like it one bit. 'He gets far more press than is scientifically justifiable. It's one individual who is trading on his past credentials to try and discredit everything that everyone else is working for,' said Tamara Stark of Greenpeace Canada. 'There is a sense of betrayal. There is great frustration and some level of anger.'

Chris Genovali, of Western Canada Wilderness Committee, said: 'Each time I read something by this megalomaniacal crackpot, I get the urge to hurl.'

Moore insists he is still an environmentalist. He voices concern about global warming and deforestation in the tropics, and still has some warm words for the charity he helped to found.

'Greenpeace is still doing some great things, but most of the really serious issues have been dealt with. The fact is that there are an awful lot of positive trends. We're improving air quality and water quality. Population growth is slowing. In the developed world, forests are increasing; the bald eagle has been taken off the endangered list.'

These developments, he insists, came about because the activists of the Seventies and Eighties pushed green issues to the top of the political agenda. 'At the beginning, the environmental movement had reason to say that the end of the world is nigh,' said Moore. But public opinion was swayed, politicians listened and action was taken. Moore says that, after 15 years of being 'against three or four things a day' in Greenpeace, he left the charity in order to be for something. Greenpeace says he left after losing a power struggle.

But according to Moore, most eco-activists just wanted continued confrontation. 'When society adopted the more reasonable items, the only way to maintain a confrontation was to adopt a more extreme stance that most people just don't agree with,' Moore said. 'Greenpeace isn't interest in solutions - only conflicts and bad guys.'

Today's environmentalists, he insists, are against science, business, civilisation and even humans; and the net result is that they are anti-environment. 'It comes to the point of dogma. There is no longer any room for intelligent discourse.'

Nuclear testing in the Pacific has finished, nuclear waste is no longer dumped at sea, whales are no longer in danger of extinction, and elephants are being culled because their numbers are too high.

'It's almost as though the movement has to invent doom-and-gloom scenarios,' Moore says. Mass extinctions are repeatedly predicted but do not happen, he says, adding that the Amazon rainforest would have been destroyed 50 times over if more outlandish claims had been believed.

Top of his charge sheet is the 'invisible poisons', such as pesticide residues and GM foods. 'The environment movement has been very clever at inventing campaigns to make us scared of our food. They conjure up invisible poisons that will give us cancer, birth defects, mutations and otherwise kill us in our sleep,' says Moore, who asks why greens concerned about cancer do not do more to tackle the tobacco industry and poor diet.

Moore provokes most green ire with his promotion of forestry and the mass felling of trees in Canada. He is spokesman for the Forest Alliance of British Columbia, an industry body. 'He is nothing more than an apologist for the timber industry,' said Gavin Edwards of Forest Action Network.

But Moore insists that - with replanting - forestry could act as a renewable source of fuel for power stations, replacing fossil fuels, and is a far more sustainable building material than steel and concrete. He says that, by attacking the forestry industry, environmentalists are attacking a truly green future. 'We should be moving to an economy that is based on renewables, and they're stopping that,' said Moore.

But Stark of Greenpeace said: 'He is very isolated. You would not find one environmentalist in Canada who would support his position.'

Warning signs

Greens say: The Earth is in the middle of the biggest mass extinction since the dinosaurs.

Moore says: No families of beetles, birds, amphibians or mammals have become extinct. There have been very few extinctions in tropical rainforests, and the few extinctions that have happened have been limited to islands.

Oil rigs

Greens say: Rigs such as Brent Spar shouldn't be sunk at sea, even if they do not contain toxic chemicals.

Moore says: Rigs sunk at sea will create artificial reefs, producing a breeding area for fish and other marine life. Greenpeace towed the refloated Rainbow Warrior to a marine park and purposely sank it just for that reason.

Farming

Greens say: We should move to organic farming and not use artificial fertilisers or pesticides.

Moore says: If we converted everything to organic farming, productivity would be so low we would have to cut down the world's forests and convert them to agricultural use.

Pesticides

Greens say: Using pesticides on food is dangerous for humans and can cause cancer.

Moore says: Scientific studies have shown no connection between pesticides and cancer.

Deforestation

Greens say: It is massive in industrialised countries.

Moore says: The area of forest in industrialised countries is growing by 0.2 per cent each year.

webTitle: An exuberant desire to land smoothly

fields.headline: An exuberant desire to land smoothly
fields.standfirst: There are signs that the Fed's Alan Greenspan is too confident about the US miracle, reports  William Keegan
fields.trailText: There are signs that the Fed's Alan Greenspan is too confident about the US miracle, reports William Keegan
fields.body:
It is three-and-a-half years since Alan Greenspan issued his warning about 'irrational exuberance' in the financial markets, but it is now a commonplace that the US boom has gone on, and on, and on.

Last week's half percentage point rise in the key Federal funds rate (to 6.5 per cent) was anticipated in market rates. In what deserves to go down as a classic exercise in hedging bets, one lone Wall Street analyst was quoted before the event as saying: 'I expect it to be 25 [basis points] but I fully expect to be wrong.'

It was the sixth rate rise since last June, and the first time in this phase of its attempts to cool the economy that the Fed has upped the stakes from a series of gentle quarter-point rises. The Fed Open Market Committee's (FOMC) minutes for last June indicated that it expected 'an appreciable moderation in the trend' of economic growth during the second half of 1999. In fact growth (measured as the percentage change on a year earlier) rose from 3.8 per cent in the second quarter of 1999 to 4.3 per cent in the third and 4.6 per cent in the fourth.

During that fourth quarter growth was at a staggering annualised rate of 7.3 per cent (all these figures are inflation-adjusted); and it was still 5.4 per cent (annualised) in the first quarter of this year. Such rates are significantly higher than the 3.6 per cent that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development estimates to be the rate of growth of the US economy's productive potential. And the latter figure, which takes account of productivity gains associated with the US lead in information technology, compares with the 2.5 per cent which was reckoned to be the long-run growth rate before all the talk of a 'new paradigm' or 'new economy'.

Although Wall Street is now somewhat below earlier peaks, the Dow is still more than 50 per cent above where it stood when Greenspan issued his warning. He must often have rued the day he gave it.

His failure to calm market exuberance has done nothing to puncture belief in his mystical powers. If anything, he has proceeded through a process of beatification to canonisation. And in the course of both 1997 and 1998 he counteracted his own efforts to dampen exuberance by relaxing monetary policy first in reaction to the Asian financial crisis and then a year later.

Throughout this period since 1996 the revered chairman of the US Federal Reserve has been thinking aloud in speeches and Congressional testimony about the 'new economy' and the impact of technology on America's productivity and capacity for the sustained higher economic growth that our own Gordon Brown dreams about. At first he was sceptical. Then he began to think there was something in it. But when he gave an early indication of his possible conversion, an old friend of his who telephoned to ask for the Fed data was told 'Oh, it's just hunch.'

The hunch began to be reflected in the statistics. Productivity has improved from the low levels of recent decades. As the OECD, which acknowledges the improvement in economic performance, puts it: 'The US economy... has now been expanding continuously for longer, albeit not more rapidly, than at any time in modern history.'

One retired international financial official who has watched Greenspan comments: 'He has been erring on the relaxed side, and mostly he's been right. The US did get handsome productivity gains. Giving growth a chance paid off very well. But you reach a point where you can't keep doing it, and I think they've reached it.'

Unemployment in the US, at 3.9 per cent, is now below the level that many economists regard as 'full employment'. Wolf has been cried many times about the degree to which financial market valuations have parted company with the reality of even an improved US economic performance; but in the fairy tale the wolf did eventually turn up.

And that prospect is being increasingly discussed. Both the International Monetary Fund in its recent World Economic Outlook , and the OECD in a largely favourable assessment of the US economy, have recently sounded warnings. 'New economy' or no, the problem is that some rather old fashioned imbalances have been building up, with demand in the US economy continuing to run way ahead of supply, credit being stacked up, private savings run down, and a sensational balance of payments deficit running at over 4 per cent of gross domestic product; in effect American consumers are borrowing more than $1bn a day from the rest of the world to finance their amazing appetite for imports.

All historical experience suggests that the US cannot go on like this, yet the Fed's efforts to cool things have so far been patently ineffectual. The IMF warns that 'the process by which this widening of internal and external balances will ultimately be reversed is one of the major uncertainties facing the world economy'. The OECD says 'financial markets have anticipated future income gains and capitalised them to a very full extent', adding 'there must be some doubt whether the real net worth per share of the non-financial corporate sector can continue sufficiently rapidly to boost real earnings by around 8 per cent a year when the annual potential growth rate of the economy is only around 3.5 per cent.'

The IMF has urged that the reversal of the US economic imbalances should be made in an orderly manner - the so-called 'soft landing'. John Llewellyn, global chief economist at Lehman Brothers, says that 'investors are currently more risk averse than at any time over the past decade' and that, in discussions, this 'fear of a hard landing of the US economy generally figures prominently'.

Bill Martin of Phillips & Drew warns: 'The larger the imbalances become, the lower the chances that policymakers will be able to steer the economy successfully.'

A veteran Fed watcher said that, in the excessively gentle approach, Greenspan might be suffering from a little too much exuberance himself about the US economic miracle. Other members of the FOMC are said to have insisted last week on saying 'the committee is concerned that this disparity in the growth of demand and potential supply will continue, which could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's outstanding performance.'

The next two FOMC meetings are on 27-28 June and 22 August. By August the US will be well into the electoral convention season, and after that the Fed faces the diplomatic difficulties of the run-up to the Presidential election itself in November.

Greenspan himself has taken to talking about the need for 'a smooth landing'. Bill Martin, noting the reaction to the Lawson boom in the UK and the Japanese bubble of the1980s, warns that 'he would be jolly lucky to secure even a soft landing'.
