Last week's half percentage point rise in the key Federal funds rate (to 6.5 per cent) was anticipated in market rates. In what deserves to go down as a classic exercise in hedging bets, one lone Wall Street analyst was quoted before the event as saying: 'I expect it to be 25 [basis points] but I fully expect to be wrong.' It was the sixth rate rise since last June, and the first time in this phase of its attempts to cool the economy that the Fed has upped the stakes from a series of gentle quarter-point rises. The Fed Open Market Committee's (FOMC) minutes for last June indicated that it expected 'an appreciable moderation in the trend' of economic growth during the second half of 1999. In fact growth (measured as the percentage change on a year earlier) rose from 3.8 per cent in the second quarter of 1999 to 4.3 per cent in the third and 4.6 per cent in the fourth. During that fourth quarter growth was at a staggering annualised rate of 7.3 per cent (all these figures are inflation-adjusted); and it was still 5.4 per cent (annualised) in the first quarter of this year. Such rates are significantly higher than the 3.6 per cent that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development estimates to be the rate of growth of the US economy's productive potential. And the latter figure, which takes account of productivity gains associated with the US lead in information technology, compares with the 2.5 per cent which was reckoned to be the long-run growth rate before all the talk of a 'new paradigm' or 'new economy'. Although Wall Street is now somewhat below earlier peaks, the Dow is still more than 50 per cent above where it stood when Greenspan issued his warning. He must often have rued the day he gave it. His failure to calm market exuberance has done nothing to puncture belief in his mystical powers. If anything, he has proceeded through a process of beatification to canonisation. And in the course of both 1997 and 1998 he counteracted his own efforts to dampen exuberance by relaxing monetary policy first in reaction to the Asian financial crisis and then a year later. Throughout this period since 1996 the revered chairman of the US Federal Reserve has been thinking aloud in speeches and Congressional testimony about the 'new economy' and the impact of technology on America's productivity and capacity for the sustained higher economic growth that our own Gordon Brown dreams about. At first he was sceptical. Then he began to think there was something in it. But when he gave an early indication of his possible conversion, an old friend of his who telephoned to ask for the Fed data was told 'Oh, it's just hunch.' The hunch began to be reflected in the statistics. Productivity has improved from the low levels of recent decades. As the OECD, which acknowledges the improvement in economic performance, puts it: 'The US economy... has now been expanding continuously for longer, albeit not more rapidly, than at any time in modern history.' One retired international financial official who has watched Greenspan comments: 'He has been erring on the relaxed side, and mostly he's been right. The US did get handsome productivity gains. Giving growth a chance paid off very well. But you reach a point where you can't keep doing it, and I think they've reached it.' Unemployment in the US, at 3.9 per cent, is now below the level that many economists regard as 'full employment'. Wolf has been cried many times about the degree to which financial market valuations have parted company with the reality of even an improved US economic performance; but in the fairy tale the wolf did eventually turn up. And that prospect is being increasingly discussed. Both the International Monetary Fund in its recent World Economic Outlook , and the OECD in a largely favourable assessment of the US economy, have recently sounded warnings. 'New economy' or no, the problem is that some rather old fashioned imbalances have been building up, with demand in the US economy continuing to run way ahead of supply, credit being stacked up, private savings run down, and a sensational balance of payments deficit running at over 4 per cent of gross domestic product; in effect American consumers are borrowing more than $1bn a day from the rest of the world to finance their amazing appetite for imports. All historical experience suggests that the US cannot go on like this, yet the Fed's efforts to cool things have so far been patently ineffectual. The IMF warns that 'the process by which this widening of internal and external balances will ultimately be reversed is one of the major uncertainties facing the world economy'. The OECD says 'financial markets have anticipated future income gains and capitalised them to a very full extent', adding 'there must be some doubt whether the real net worth per share of the non-financial corporate sector can continue sufficiently rapidly to boost real earnings by around 8 per cent a year when the annual potential growth rate of the economy is only around 3.5 per cent.' The IMF has urged that the reversal of the US economic imbalances should be made in an orderly manner - the so-called 'soft landing'. John Llewellyn, global chief economist at Lehman Brothers, says that 'investors are currently more risk averse than at any time over the past decade' and that, in discussions, this 'fear of a hard landing of the US economy generally figures prominently'. Bill Martin of Phillips & Drew warns: 'The larger the imbalances become, the lower the chances that policymakers will be able to steer the economy successfully.' A veteran Fed watcher said that, in the excessively gentle approach, Greenspan might be suffering from a little too much exuberance himself about the US economic miracle. Other members of the FOMC are said to have insisted last week on saying 'the committee is concerned that this disparity in the growth of demand and potential supply will continue, which could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's outstanding performance.' The next two FOMC meetings are on 27-28 June and 22 August. By August the US will be well into the electoral convention season, and after that the Fed faces the diplomatic difficulties of the run-up to the Presidential election itself in November. Greenspan himself has taken to talking about the need for 'a smooth landing'. Bill Martin, noting the reaction to the Lawson boom in the UK and the Japanese bubble of the1980s, warns that 'he would be jolly lucky to secure even a soft landing'.

webTitle: Ailing M&S cuts dividend in half

fields.headline: Ailing M&S cuts dividend in half
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer will this week stun the City by cutting its dividend as part of a deck-clearing exercise by the new chairman.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer will this week stun the City by cutting its dividend as part of a deck-clearing exercise by the new chairman.

The cut, which is expected to leave the pay-out at half last year's 14.4p, underlines the extent of M&S's fall from grace. It will be confirmed at a board meeting tomorrow, and will be accompanied by gloomy news on current sales of clothing ranges.

Luc Vandevelde, who took over as chairman of the group three months ago, will use his first results presentation to set out his strategy for returning M&S to its pre-eminent position on the high street.

He has said that he supports many of the measures introduced by chief executive Peter Salsbury, but he is likely to promise even greater emphasis on merchandising and price as ways to win back customers.

Analysts believe sales from M&S food halls have continued to perform reasonably well: they are expected to be up around 4 per cent since its March year-end. Clothing sales, however, have been sluggish, and most analysts expect M&S to report a slight improvement in total sales but a slight decline if new store openings are included. That is despite the success of its Autograph range for women, which has been well received.

The dividend cut will reflect a sharp drop in profit before tax, from last year's £656 million to about £475m - less than half the level achieved in 1998. That would produce earnings of 11.5p, too low to cover a maintained divided.

More seriously from Vandevelde's point of view, ana lysts think that profits in the year to next March will recover only slightly, to around £530m, which would still leave a maintained dividend uncovered. By cutting the dividend now, Vandevelde can start to increase it again next year, albeit from a lower base.

'It has to be the last chance for the existing management,' said Paul Smiddy of Credit Lyonnais. 'They will throw the kitchen sink into these numbers and start afresh. If they do not do it now, they never will.'

Most analysts are expecting the final dividend to be halved from last year's 10.7p to about 4p which, with the 3.7p paid at the interim, would give a total for the year of 7.7p. M&S shares have collapsed from more than 650p to just 231.5p in two years.

webTitle: Leaking pipes row threatens roads gridlock

fields.headline: Leaking pipes row threatens roads gridlock
fields.trailText: The traffic chaos of London is poised to worsen dramatically as a single company prepares to dig 3,000 holes a week in the roads over the next year.
fields.body:
The traffic chaos of London is poised to worsen dramatically as a single company prepares to dig 3,000 holes a week in the roads over the next year.

The already jam-packed central area will bear the brunt, warns the firm, Thames Water. It is telling the Government that massive disruption will be unavoidable if it has to meet cuts in leakage rates set out by the industry regulator.

Tony Blair will need little reminding of the misery the drilling will cause. Hours after he and his wife Cherie returned from hospital with the new-born Leo, contractors for Thames Water began digging up Downing Street to mend a leaky hydrant.

The AA and the RAC reacted angrily, saying drivers would bear the pain for a stand-off between the firm and the water watchdog.

The disruption will be acutely sensitive following the London Mayoral election campaign, which focused on gridlock as a key concern of residents. Mayor Ken Livingstone has pledged to cut traffic by 15 per cent by 2010.

The capital's motorists, cyclists and pedestrians have suffered increasing frustration as streets have been clogged by cable and utility companies laying and repairing pipes and wires. The roadworks are now so bad that councils have drawn up a voluntary code to try to co-ordinate digging by utilities. Last month the Government announced plans to fine firms up to £500 a day for unnecessarily delaying repairs.

However, the firms are able to dig almost at will because of wide powers given to them under the 1991 New Roads and Street Works Act.

Thames wrote last week to Ian Byatt, head of the regulator Ofwat, requesting an urgent meeting, and it is intending to raise the issue with Livingstone.

The company says it met a two-year programme of leakage reductions demanded in 1997 by Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott to prevent a widespread wastage of water. But the new demand for cuts of at least 10 per cent a year is unreasonable and will cost £20 million this year alone, it says. This bill cannot be passed on to consumers.

One company source said: 'We have calculated that we are going to have to make 3,000 street openings [holes] a week to meet these targets.

'What is the benefit to the environment, consumers and shareholders compared with the chaos? We are not threatening anyone, but this disruption will be a consequence of the regulator's demands.'

AA spokesman Michael Johnson said: 'This is an awful lot of holes. Motorists are trapped between the regulator and the company.'

The RAC's Edmund King said drivers faced 'a bleak future of misery. Utilities must be forced to co-ordinate their digging.'

fields.headline: Don't club this culture
fields.standfirst: Steven Barnett on Broadcast
fields.trailText: Steven Barnett on Broadcast
fields.body:
It is still not clear who 'leaked' the story claiming the Government was including the privatisation of Channel 4 in its next manifesto. In the game of smoke and mirrors which these days passes for political communication, suggested culprits include: the Treasury looking for the next item of family silver to flog; Downing Street think-tankers indulging in a bit of kite-flying; the Department of Trade and Industry sending a salvo across the bows of the Department of Culture, Media and Sport; and Channel 4 executives who got wind of some 'preliminary thinking' and wanted to a) nip it in the bud or b) promote it to make their fortunes in share options.

The idea, of course, is preposterous. If it happened, it would within three years destroy one of the most ingenious cultural creations of twentieth-century Britain. For those Thatcherite philistines who still don't appreciate the consequences, here is a rebuttal to the arguments for privatising Channel 4.

 It makes pots of money and can survive perfectly well in the marketplace .

There is a profound difference between making money which can be reinvested in programmes and making money as dividends for shareholders. The former allows for innovation, diversity and programming for minorities. The latter means pressure to maximise revenue from every programming slot.

If it was run wholly for profit, the public service framework which governs Channel 4's output would become a tedious millstone to be observed in the letter but not the spirit. In its current incarnation, the commissioning editors and programme-makers feel free - within certain limits - to follow their creative instincts.

 But it spends its money on US imports such as 'Friends' and 'ER' - that's hardly public service .

A comparatively small proportion of the budget goes on programmes that draw audiences in and create an ambience for the channel - just as it did under Michael Grade and Jeremy Isaacs. The cost is small beer compared with the peak-time scheduling of factual programmes such as Dispatches and Equinox , highly original drama such as Longitude , innovative comedy like Smack the Pony and minority programming such as Queer as Folk - all of which benefit from audiences passed on by high-rating imported programmes. There is nothing like the same diversity on ITV or Channel 5 because the drive for profits means you have to aim for the largest possible audience at every opportunity.

 But being part of the market ensures a proper responsiveness to audiences.

Commercial broadcasters do not sell programmes to audiences; they sell audiences to advertisers. Because Channel 4 does not have to make every programme advertiser-friendly, it can afford to experiment and sometimes fail. Its chief executive Michael Jackson put it well in his Fleming lecture to the Royal Television Society last week: 'New thinking has to be about valleys as well as peaks, places where ideas can be incubated.' There's not much room for incubation where every programme is driven by the need for guaranteed ratings success.

 We've got the BBC to experiment. We don't need two public service broadcasters.

There are certain things - best summarised as sex and politics - on which the BBC is institutionally cautious because of its funding. Channel 4's freedom from public funding combined with its remit to innovate gives it the kind of licence Auntie cannot exercise. As Jackson reminded us, the BBC turned away Brass Eye while Channel 4 showed it (just about). Whatever you thought of the programme, it added to the diversity available to viewers.

 It's gone downmarket. Look at the Wednesday night schedule: 'ER' followed by 'Sex and the City'.

Yes, and look at Thursday night's schedule: an archaeology programme followed by a historical series on Elizabeth I. Show me a commercial broadcaster anywhere in the world which schedules a serious one-hour news bulletin every weekday at 7pm, a critical time for building audiences. Any shift downmarket is a regulatory problem, and can be dealt with as such if it happens.

In his unequivocal statement of opposition to privatisation, Michael Jackson bravely rejected his lucrative share options and reminded us how the creative character and distinctiveness of Channel 4 will evaporate if it is sold off. It has taken nearly 20 years to construct a channel which, because of its unique funding and structure, can be a cutting-edge creative and democratic force which is neither beholden to the government nor tyrannised by advertisers. To abandon that legacy to the marketplace in order to raise one-tenth of the revenue the Treasury prised out of mobile phone operators would be an act of unforgivable cultural vandalism. Expect the announcement any day now.

 Steven Barnett is senior lecturer in communications at the University of Westminster.
S.Barnett@wmin.ac.uk

webTitle: Protecting planet Earth - from your cradle to your grave

fields.headline: Protecting planet Earth - from your cradle to your grave
fields.standfirst: Andrew Bibby finds that leading a greener lifestyle is a matter of life and death and - with planning - it's not difficult
fields.trailText: Disposable nappies have changed the mucky job of wrestling with nappy pins, terry nappies (and unhappy babies) into something half-way acceptable. But unfortunately, disposables have an after-life.
fields.body:
Babies in the house

Disposable nappies have changed the mucky job of wrestling with nappy pins, terry nappies (and unhappy babies) into something half-way acceptable. But unfortunately, disposables have an after-life.

According to the Real Nappy Association, disposables now make up 4 per cent of household waste, with the vast majority festering for decades in landfill tips. For parents in need of serious guilt-tripping, the RNA has plenty of other statistics on offer: disposables use more than three times the energy used to produce and clean modern cloth nappies, and account for eight times more non-renewable resources.

The RNA, linked to the Women's Environmental Network, argues that cloth nappies are not only greener, they're cheaper too. Sensing a PR opportunity, the Association recently delivered a selection of nappies to 10 Downing Street, and has called on the Blairs to ensure that their new baby's bottom is clad in only environment- friendly nappies.

There's a wide range of washables now available, ranging from shaped terries held in place with Velcro fastenings to all-in-one versions. Companies offering mail order include Green Baby (www.greenbabyco.com) and Little Green Earthlets (www.earthlets.co.uk). The RNA itself provides a comprehensive list of stockists.

A network of professional nappy cleaning services has also developed in recent years, delivering clean nappies and removing dirty ones. Information is available from the National Association of Nappy Services (NANS) on 0121 693 4949. The RNA's fact pack (large envelope plus two stamps) is available from PO Box 3704, London SE26 4RX). The RNA also has a useful web site at www.realnappy.com.

Motoring on

There are 24 million cars in Britain (though reportedly only 23 million of these are on the M25 at any one time). Congestion means frustration, time wasted and a greater risk of road rage. But car use also has major environmental implications: as Friends of the Earth points out, cars take energy and materials to produce, consume energy and emit pollutants when they are driven. They also pose a tricky problem of disposal at the end of their lives. But even the most enthusiastic campaigners for traffic reduction accept that vehicle numbers are unlikely to fall very much. The problem is we like our cars too much.

The green-minded motorist will opt for a less high performance car which guzzles less petrol. There are now tax advantages to this: owners with cars up to 1100cc (1200cc next year) pay £55 a year less in road tax. From next April the road tax arrangements for brand new cars will be based on four tax bands, so that vehicles with the lowest rates of carbon dioxide emissions are taxed the least. There will also be a £10 discount for cars using cleaner fuels (such as dual fuels) and a surcharge on cars running on diesel. But is this enough?

One possibility, which is very popular in Germany and north America, is to develop the idea of car sharing and car pools. Currently a number of pilot car sharing schemes are running in the UK: they include the CampusCar scheme at Cranfield University, where staff and students can book cars over the university website; and Smart Moves in the Earlsdon area of Coventry, which is intended as a community car-sharing club. A slightly different idea is lift-sharing. National CarShare(www.nationalcarshare.co. uk) is an organisation which attempts a life-matching service.

The food we eat

Organically produced food, once typified by a battered box of curiously shaped carrots in the local wholefood shop, is now widely available in supermarkets, though the price premium means it remains a luxury purchase.

Friends of the Earth has suggestions for ways to avoid the weekly trip to the supermarket by car. It urges consumers to shop close to home, looking for locally grown seasonal fruit, vegetables and products, especially those from organic farms. This sounds like a tall order, though the growing number of farmers' markets makes the idea more feasible than in the past.

Farmers' markets (street markets where growers sell direct) may be a feature of life elsewhere in Europe, but in Britain it has taken strong encouragement from the Soil Association for the idea to develop. The latest list from the Soil Association gives details of about 150 farmers' markets, ranging from high-profile venues such as Victoria Square, Birmingham, to small towns.

Another possibility is the organic food box scheme, which has also been strongly supported by the Soil Association. The principle here is that a farmer or wholesaler delivers a box of organic produce to each subscribing household, typically every week.

Some box schemes go further and effectively turn organic farms into community-supported co-operatives, where subscribers are also involved in financing and managing the farming ventures.

The Soil Association produces a Directory of Where to Buy Organic Food (£3 including p&p) and can also supply the newly published Organic Directory (£7.95 plus postage). Details from 0117 914 2446 or www.soilassociation.org

When it's time to go

Death has long been an environmental issue. In Victorian times, when vast necropolises were spreading out from cities, the Cremation Society of England campaigned for an alternative way to go, against the wishes of the Church (which preferred the slower way of returning to dust and ashes).

Nowadays, environmentalists raise other concerns, such as the chemicals used in embalming and the use of potentially harmful materials in veneer coffins. A desire for secular and more natural funerals has also brought back the idea of burial, this time in non-consecrated ground such as woodland. Some local authorities and private landowners offer this facility.

For a compendium of everything you would want to know (and probably plenty you wouldn't) about alternative funerals, the place to turn is The Dead Good Funerals Book by Sue Gill and John Fox. This book includes, among much else, suppliers of cardboard coffins, coffins made from recycled wood and helpful instructions on making do-it-yourself shrouds. There are also suggestions for non-religious ceremonies.

The Dead Good Funerals Book can be obtained from distributor Edge of Time, which also produce other guides to aspects of alternative living.

One possibility, which is very popular in Germany and north America, is to develop the idea of car sharing and car pools. Currently a number of pilot car sharing schemes are running in the UK: they include the CampusCar scheme at Cranfield University, where staff and students can book cars over the university website; and Smart Moves in the Earlsdon area of Coventry, which is intended as a community car-sharing club. A slightly different idea is lift-sharing. National CarShare(www.nationalcarshare.co. uk) is an organisation which attempts a life-matching service. The food we eat Organically produced food, once typified by a battered box of curiously shaped carrots in the local wholefood shop, is now widely available in supermarkets, though the price premium means it remains a luxury purchase. Friends of the Earth has suggestions for ways to avoid the weekly trip to the supermarket by car. It urges consumers to shop close to home, looking for locally grown seasonal fruit, vegetables and products, especially those from organic farms. This sounds like a tall order, though the growing number of farmers' markets makes the idea more feasible than in the past. Farmers' markets (street markets where growers sell direct) may be a feature of life elsewhere in Europe, but in Britain it has taken strong encouragement from the Soil Association for the idea to develop. The latest list from the Soil Association gives details of about 150 farmers' markets, ranging from high-profile venues such as Victoria Square, Birmingham, to small towns. Another possibility is the organic food box scheme, which has also been strongly supported by the Soil Association. The principle here is that a farmer or wholesaler delivers a box of organic produce to each subscribing household, typically every week. Some box schemes go further and effectively turn organic farms into community-supported co-operatives, where subscribers are also involved in financing and managing the farming ventures. The Soil Association produces a Directory of Where to Buy Organic Food (£3 including p&p) and can also supply the newly published Organic Directory (£7.95 plus postage). Details from 0117 914 2446 or www.soilassociation.org When it's time to go Death has long been an environmental issue. In Victorian times, when vast necropolises were spreading out from cities, the Cremation Society of England campaigned for an alternative way to go, against the wishes of the Church (which preferred the slower way of returning to dust and ashes). Nowadays, environmentalists raise other concerns, such as the chemicals used in embalming and the use of potentially harmful materials in veneer coffins. A desire for secular and more natural funerals has also brought back the idea of burial, this time in non-consecrated ground such as woodland. Some local authorities and private landowners offer this facility. For a compendium of everything you would want to know (and probably plenty you wouldn't) about alternative funerals, the place to turn is The Dead Good Funerals Book by Sue Gill and John Fox. This book includes, among much else, suppliers of cardboard coffins, coffins made from recycled wood and helpful instructions on making do-it-yourself shrouds. There are also suggestions for non-religious ceremonies. The Dead Good Funerals Book can be obtained from distributor Edge of Time, which also produce other guides to aspects of alternative living.

fields.headline: Roe rage as piracy rules
fields.standfirst: Illegal overfishing has pushed sturgeon stocks dangerously low - and the price of caviar dangerously high, reports  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Illegal overfishing has pushed sturgeon stocks dangerously low - and the price of caviar dangerously high, reports Jamie Doward
fields.body:
It appears paradoxical to assert that uncaught fish, for instance, are a means of production in the fishing industry. But hitherto no one has discussed the art of catching fish in waters that sustain none. - Karl Marx

Unfettered gangster capitalism following the end of the Cold War and the disintegration of the Soviet union has reached as far as the shores of the Caspian Sea, the world's largest inland body of water. It has intensified competition among the region's fishermen and dramatically accelerated the harvest of the sea's highly prized fish, the sturgeon.

The roe of this fish, salted, is sold as caviar. 'Serve simply with toast and lemon wedges, garnished with sour cream, minced onion and hard-cooked egg whites,' say the gastronomic bibles.

Little more than 10 years ago, fishing rights across the Caspian's 371,000 square kilometres were rigorously enforced by both Iranian and Soviet governments, and the sturgeon population was kept in healthy equilibrium.

Pollution caused by the increase in oil and mineral excavation in the region forced the Soviet authorities temporarily to restrict the fishing of sturgeon in 1989, a move which prompted a hefty hike in the price of caviar.

The increase was felt acutely in the US, which had imposed sanctions against Iran in 1987, so saw its supply severely limited.

But a large-scale clean-up of the Caspian saw caviar prices return to a more realistic level by the early Nineties, where they remained for the following five years.

However, in the middle of that decade things started to change. The dismantling of centralised control across the Caspian's Soviet states - Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Russia and Turkmenistan - meant that protecting the sea's fish stocks in the Caspian's northern waters became increasingly difficult. As the former Soviet economy collapsed, racketeers, many with links to the Russian mafia, took advantage of the chaos and started fishing the Caspian illegally, earning the epithet 'caviar pirates'.

Today the sturgeon population in the Caspian, which provides 90 per cent of the world's caviar, has been exhausted by overfishing and the price of the roe in the West is, according to experts, close to unpayable - despite the fact that the US recently lifted sanctions against Iran. the Gulf state last year exported 90 tonnes of caviar, reducing the country's balance of payments deficit by more than £20 million.

The overfishing has in recent years prompted drastic cuts in exports to the West, in an attempt to replenish the Caspian's sturgeon stocks. Russia's Fisheries Committee announced last month that it was to cut exports of black caviar by a third this year, to around 60 tonnes. Ten days ago Iran raised the price of caviar by 40 per cent and said it would look to cut production to safeguard sturgeon stocks. In a bid to handle demand, the country's system of negotiating with caviar customers has been replaced by an auction, a move that guarantees further price hikes.

But even the Russian and Iranian governments' predictions for caviar production seem optimistic to some observers. John Stas is managing director of WG White, one of the UK's largest caviar importers: 'This year it's likely there will be less than 100 tonnes of caviar coming out of the Caspian. Ten years ago it was something like 1,000 tonnes. Even two years ago it was producing 300 to 350 tonnes.'

In 1999 WG White imported 10 tonnes of caviar, largely from Iran, but Stas admits his company will be lucky if it manages to bring in as much this year.

Even if it does, it is questionable whether UK consumers will pay the prices caviar is now fetching. Traditionally the price has increased by around 5 per cent a year; but recently the industry has seen hyperinflation.

A year ago, a kilo of beluga caviar - said by connoisseurs to be the best, and the type hardest hit by overfishing - would have cost UK gourmets £1,400. Today it is a minimum £2,000. Some brands fetch considerably more. Within two years, say the experts, beluga caviar will command £3,000 a kilo in the UK. 'It will make the product very difficult to sell,' says Stas. 'The public will accept certain prices but we've reached the ceiling.'

What the caviar industry refers to as the 'giveaway' sector, has collapsed. The casinos, airlines and cruise ships which traditionally offered caviar free to clients, have now balked at inflated costs.

Environmentalists say that while the Iranian caviar 'pirates' fish from boats, many of those from the former Soviet republics use deep nets stretched across the Caspian's river deltas, a technique that greatly exacerbates depletion of sturgeon stocks.

Jonathan Miller, provisions buyer at Fortnum & Mason, says: 'Since the break up of the USSR there's been something of a free-for-all. In the old communist bloc, fishing was strictly policed, but the Russian ports aren't.'

Iran, angry at the way it feels its Caspian neighbours have presided over the mismanagement of fishing stocks, is attempting to replenish the sturgeon population. But the migratory nature of sturgeon means this is not without problems.

Stas says: 'There's so much illegal fishing going on in the northern part of the Caspian. The sturgeon are being caught too young. The Iranians are putting between 20 million and 30 million sturgeon back into the sea - fish that are going to be caught by the Russian fishermen.'

Theoretically, sturgeon stocks are protected by the Geneva-based pan-national environmental agency Cites - the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. But there is only so much that Cites can do. Exporters and importers of caviar need to hold licences before they can trade, but the explosion in the trade of caviar on Eastern Europe's black market means regulation of the industry is now practically impossible.

As caviar sells in Russia for something like a quarter of what it costs in the West, the rewards for smuggling sturgeon roe through Eastern Europe's porous border controls are huge. Each week the likes of Fortnum & Mason reject several kilos of caviar from dubious sources with links to the black market.

In a bid to compensate for the depleted Caspian stocks, France and the US have attempted to enter caviar production. Caviar from French sturgeon is, although farmed, of very good quality, but it is often even more expensive than that from its wild cousins in the East. By contrast US caviar is deemed to be far inferior to its Caspian rivals, and has struggled to attract customers outside its domestic market.

Ironically the worldwide shortage of caviar comes as the roe, once deemed the 'food of kings' - its arrival at ancient Greek banquets was heralded by trumpets - has started to throw off its aristocratic mantle and attract a wider following. Marks & Spencer now stocks it.

Stas says: 'Maybe they should stop fishing in the Caspian for 10 years and then things could get going again. But by then caviar may have been forgotten.'

That seems unlikely; but it is clear something must be done, and soon. Otherwise a food synonymous with luxury and decadence will be killed by the rampant capitalism which made it so popular in the first place. Marx wouldn't have been surprised.

webTitle: Gay brother 'is key to Lolita author'

fields.headline: Gay brother 'is key to Lolita author'
fields.standfirst: Nabokov family rejects claims that Vladimir's dark novels were inspired by his homophobia and uneasy relationship with playboy sibling Sergei
fields.trailText: The family of Vladimir Nabokov, author of  Lolita, poured scorn this weekend on a claim that an intense relationship with his homosexual brother was the key to his dark and lurid work.
fields.body:
The family of Vladimir Nabokov, author of Lolita, poured scorn this weekend on a claim that an intense relationship with his homosexual brother was the key to his dark and lurid work.

They were responding for the first time to new evidence about the origins of Nabokov's notorious homophobia. Speculation about the Russian emigré brothers, Vladimir and Sergei, has intensified among American scholars this month in the wake of Stacy Schiff's acclaimed biography of Vladimir's wife, Vera, which five weeks ago won a Pulitzer Prize.

Homosexuality was not a guilty secret in the family, the brothers' cousin, Marina Ledkovsky, 76, stressed. Speaking exclusively to The Observer, she said: 'Sergei was a talented, noble and kind man in his own right and something of a war hero.'

Ledkovsky, who knew both men well - Sergei was best man at her wedding - does not believe the brothers had an unusually damaging effect on each other.

An article published in internet magazine Salon.com last week suggests that the two Nabokovs, who were very close in age, operated a kind of dual identity. It also emphasises the influence that two elder gay relatives may have had on the brothers. The author, Lev Grossman, argues that Vladimir's well-chronicled hatred of homosexuality and his obsession with questions of identity stemmed from his fear that his own personality was not distinct enough from his brother's.

They lived oddly parallel lives - both studying the same subject at Cambridge and taking a first job in a bank - until Vladimir married. In their late twenties, Vladimir threw himself into marriage and work, while Sergei became a playboy, mixing with the stars of the Parisian avant-garde - Jean Cocteau, Diaghilev and the writers Alice B. Toklas and Gertrude Stein.

The short story The Real Life of Sebastian Knight, which deals with the shifting sense of self and of right and wrong, is actually about Sergei, according to Grossman. The constant return to the idea of a double existence and the importance of mirrors in all Nabokov's work is part of the same pathology, the argument goes.

'This may be the case,' admits Ledkovsky, now a retired professor living in America. 'But it was not something that I felt when I read The Real Life of Sebastian Knight . My uncles were alike in their wonderful voices and in the way they read poetry. It is wrong of Grossman to imply that they were the opposite of each other in every way.'

The great novelist's son, Dmitri, feels the same way, she said. He wants the lives of the two brothers to be allowed to stand separately.

Nabokov, best known for his fictional portrayal of the paedophile love of the middle-aged Humbert Humbert for the 12-year-old schoolgirl Lolita, often wrote with public disgust about homosexuality. In private he also wrote of his disdain for his brother's sexual persuasion or 'certain oddities of behaviour'. Ledkovsky said her family knew Sergei was homosexual yet adopted a surprisingly tolerant attitude for the time.

'I asked my father if Sergei was homosexual and he told me I was right, but said the important thing was that he was a good man.'

Ledkovsky does give credence, though, to another of Grossman's theories.

While most of the Nabokov family escaped from Germany, Sergei is known to have died at the hands of the Nazis in 1945. He was first arrested for being homosexual and then, after being released from prison, spent his time denouncing the Nazi regime.

'Within the family we were told that he was finally arrested because he challenged someone at a party who argued that the German culture was the greatest in world history,' said Ledkovsky.

Grossman's article suggests an even more dramatic and heroic end to Sergei's life. Princess Zinaida Shachovskaya, a relative of the Nabokovs by marriage, believes he was caught trying to help a British airman, who was a former Cambridge friend, escape from Germany after he had been shot down.

'This is quite possible,' said Ledkovsky. 'He was a brave man with many English friends and it is the sort of thing he would do. The Princess is still alive in a Paris nursing home and she may well know the truth of this matter.'

Read the Salon article

webTitle: Free from hassle and good value

fields.headline: Free from hassle and good value
fields.standfirst: Stansted to Helsinki
fields.trailText: Stansted to Helsinki.
fields.body:
Rating out of 10:
Service 7
Value 7

Booking

The website was good but I booked by telephone - quicker to discuss prices and dates. Buzz offers Done Deal (advance purchase, must stay two nights and travel on agreed flights, no refund) or Open Deals (flexible, refundable, with optional extras such as access to airport business lounge). I booked a Done Deal for £90 including taxes using Barclaycard. Took five minutes.

Tickets

Buzz does not issue tickets but sent a letter with confirmation, receipt and reference number. The airline changed departure from 6.40am to 7.15am and called to warn me.

Check-in

Outbound: Turned up just before flight closed 30 minutes before departure and was last to check-in. Flight number on screen and buzz desks clearly marked. Staff friendly and efficient, told me to run. Frustrating queue at baggage X-ray, but handy set of toilets right next to departure gate.

Inbound: After outbound mistake, turned up early and was almost first to check-in. No queues. Great shops.

Boarding

Outbound: No seat allocation; plastic boarding card issued. Walked across airport apron to aircraft and up boarding steps. Flight only 70 per cent full so choice of seats at the back.

Inbound: Similar arrangements. No hassle.

Take Off

Outbound: On time (7.15am). On-board announcements, including safety demonstration, in rapid English (no Finnish translation). Arrived 10 minutes early.

Inbound: On time at 7.30pm.

Decor/ambience

Boeing 737, fun yellow exterior with blue flower; interior, plain, clean and bright. Purple seats with average economy-class legroom and width, negligible recline. Toilets, clean with paper and soap. Steward in dapper yellow shirt and tie with route-map design. Stewardesses in embarrassing school pinafores. Seat pocket contains useful Rough Guide destination information.

Catering

No free refreshments. Menu changes bi-monthly. Breakfast £5.50: choice of two. Snacks: £4.50 (eg BLT ciabatta roll). Sandwiches from £2.50. Children's snack pack £3.50. Pringles, muffins or flapjacks £1.

Lunch/dinner £7: choice of two. Free drink up to £1.50 with meal.

Mini-champagne £5, spirits £2-£2.50, coffee/hot chocolate £1.50, decaff coffee/tea £1, soft drinks 50p.

We had coffee, flapjack and water, which were fine.

Service

Cabin crew were polite and friendly.

Arrival

Outbound: buzz flies into the main Helsinki airport. Only had carry-on luggage so through small airport without delay. No special offers on transport. Public bus to city cen tre (railway station) departs from right outside terminal and costs markka 11 (£1.10) and takes 20 to 30 minutes. Walking distance from hotel.

Inbound: Arrived on schedule at 8.25pm. Stansted very quiet. Made it through airport and collected car within 10 minutes.

Verdict

You can get better offers with buzz than £90 - Paris for £50, Berlin or Lyon £60. Helsinki is currently offered at £80. But just getting to Scandinavia for less than £100 return feels like a miracle.

Buzz was good value, friendly and efficient. They don't treat you like cheapskates and the journey was very pleasant.

Rating out of 10:

Service 7

Value 7

No-frills Helsinki

Cheap eat

Café Engel bears the name of the architect who created much of 'old town' Helsinki. Opens mid-morning until midnight. Cosy; friendly staff. Huge hot chicken, lamb, turkey, goat's cheese or cold smoked salmon salads for £6. Large glass of wine £3.20. Large pastry counter with homemade cakes, pies, quiche. Address: Alexandersgatan. Tel: 00 358 965 2776.

Cheap sleep

Hotel Helka. Easy walking distance from central train/bus station. Quiet, private, clean, friendly, comfortable. Spacious double room, bright and modern, en suite £52 including breakfast buffet.

Typical thing to do

Go to Kotiharju, Helsinki's only surviving wood-fired, public sauna. Just renovated to coincide with City of Culture 2000. Men and women separate. Steam until prawn-like then get an attendant to scrub you down for £3.50. Towels provided. 1 Harjutorinkatu, Kallio district (10 mins out of centre by tube or tram).

Less typical

Visit the Museum of Art and Design in the old town. Exhibitions change. Small and manageable, within walking distance of centre. Café, shop. Entry £4 for adults. 23 Hogbergsgatan. Tel: 00358 9622 0540.

Traveller's tip

Book accommodation via the official Helsinki Booking Centre. Helpful assistants provide lists of hotels in your chosen price range/location/taste, marking which have breakfast and sauna.They will book it free.

Tel: 00 358 9 2288 1400.

www.helsinkiexpert.fi

webTitle: Endowments 'still mis-sold on a huge scale'

fields.headline: Endowments 'still mis-sold on a huge scale'
fields.trailText: Endowment mortgages are still being mis-sold on a massive scale, a TV documentary will reveal tomorrow.
fields.body:
Endowment mortgages are still being mis-sold on a massive scale, a TV documentary will reveal tomorrow.

Two thirds of companies in this business are mis-selling the products, according to the BBC's Panorama. Its makers say a senior figure at the Financial Services Authority told them the regulator thinks only a third are giving proper advice. He says this is a 'poor picture'.

The FSA says most current endowment policyholders - 3 million households - may end up with a too little from the insurers to pay off what they owe on their homes.

Michael Folger, director of investment business at the FSA, is said to have told Panorama: 'In only about a third of the cases could we be confident that the right advice has been given. We've made it clear that firms have got to get their act together through this year.'

In the Eighties as many as 80 per cent of home loans were sold with endowments, insurance policies intended to repay the loans on maturity. In recent years the figure has fallen to a third or less.

Panorama secretly filmed an agent representing insurer Allied Dunbar who was apparently promoting endowment policies as superior to repayment mortgages. This contravenes the new mortgage code of conduct.

Allied Dunbar said it was unable to comment fully on the allegations because it had not seen a transcript of the programme, but it believed it has taken a 'partial view' of what the salesman said.

A member of an FSA advisory panel tells the programme that the Government seems frightened of the financial services industry.

The FSA said it was preparing to take disciplinary action against some firms for failures leading to mis-selling. The regulator has also told insurers to warn policyholders in writing if their policies are not on course to yield enough to repay their loans.

fields.headline: The direct approach
fields.standfirst: From mail order to online shopping, flying winemakers to garage wines, there's nothing obvious about Tony Laithwaite
fields.trailText: From mail order to online shopping, flying winemakers to garage wines, there's nothing obvious about Tony Laithwaite.
fields.body:
Tony Laithwaite doesn't look like one of Britain's richest men. Away from his desk, he may well travel around in a chauffeur-driven limo with a TL1 number plate, leopard-skin seats and a minibar stocked with Dom Pérignon, but somehow I doubt it. Ostentation isn't Mr Laithwaite's thing. He greets visitors to Bordeaux Direct's offices in Reading in a black T-shirt and jeans; his desk is squashed into a corridor beside the company's tasting room.

But very wealthy he most certainly is. 'I'm not sure what the business is worth, to be honest with you,' he says, with genuine nonchalance. 'Some people say £100m, some four times that, but it doesn't really matter because I'm not planning to sell it.' Whatever the true figure, Bordeaux Direct is an amazing success, one of the most profitable wine businesses in the world, with 500 employees and a turnover of £137m. Mail-order sales of 2.3m cases make it the sixth biggest retailer in the country.

Laithwaite started the company in 1969 with a geography degree, a van and a £700 loan from his gran in Bolton. After university, he'd worked a harvest at a co-operative near St Emilion and was encouraged by the director to sell a few cases in the UK. Laithwaite shipped 100 cases of 1966 claret and sold them to family friends at 13 shillings and sixpence a bottle; he was 23 years old.

It seems obvious now, when one-man-and-a-van wine companies are everywhere, but in those days they were unusual, not to say revolutionary. After six months, Laithwaite began to ship wines from other regions, starting with Bergerac, then moving outside France. 'Because we're called Bordeaux Direct, some people think we only sell Bordeaux wines, but that's never been so. At the end of the 1970s, half of our business was Bulgarian. Nowadays, we sell more Aussie wine than we do Bordeaux.'

Laithwaite was original in another sense, too. He was the man who invented flying winemakers - southern hemisphere oenologists working in the northern hemisphere during their winter. Since 1987, these airborne Aussies, Kiwis and South Africans have had a dramatic impact on the quality of the wine we drink.

'I like Aussies and I always have,' says Laithwaite. 'Their approach is: "What style of wine do you want?" not "This is the way it is and stuff you."' There's still plenty of scope for flying winemakers, according to Laithwaite. 'France is littered with unambitious co-operatives; put the right sort of Aussie in there, and they soon perk up.'

The desire to innovate still motivates Laithwaite. He and his team are now making what he calls 'garage wines', small batches from different parts of France, blended with little regard for the appellation laws.

'Our customers trust me,' Laithwaite says, 'so if a wine is good enough they don't mind if it's a vin de table and doesn't have a vintage on the label.'

Last year saw the launch of the company's website. 'For once,' he admits, 'we were slow off the mark, but we wanted to get it right.' Eight months after the launch, Bordeaux Direct is the biggest online retailer in Britain. Laithwaite is unimpressed by most wine e-tailers. 'They're run by the sort of people who call customers "punters" and see wine as a quick way to make loads of dosh. It doesn't work like that. In this business, you have to have the wine thing in you. I could have retired to the south of France years ago, but I'm a wine freak. That's why I'm still here.' *

fields.headline: @large
fields.trailText: Expertgardener.com | Petsathome.com
fields.body:
The gush feature

It was all so tragically inevitable. Given the plethora of online gardening sites springing up of late, it was only a matter of time before Charlie Dimmock and Alan Titchmarsh launched a website - www.expertgardener.com. The site attempts to bring gardening enthusiasts together by allowing them to 'swap tips and ideas in an online chat room'. 'The community element of the site is really important,' Charlie gushes. As will be some form of webcam, presumably.

Pet mates

Never let it be said that dot.com companies don't know how to plumb the deepest depths of gimmickry. Petsathome.com, the online 'portal' for, yes, pets, is to launch a pets' dating agency! (The exclamation mark is all their own work!!). Sadly, the site isn't nearly as interesting as it sounds. Our requests to take a hamster out on a blind date were thwarted at the first hurdle. The service is merely for soppy pet owners to post pictures of their loved ones on the Web. Someone call the Advertising Standards Agency pronto.

Blind dates
Red faces at Yahoo! Its popular calendar service, which allows users to turn their computer screens into online Filofaxes, has been suffering a technical glitch. Around 10 per cent of users have been sent reminders from other people's diaries. The rumour is that some Yahoo! users even turned up at other people's events.

webTitle: Boo.com sale hopes suffer early blow

fields.headline: Boo.com sale hopes suffer early blow
fields.trailText: Efforts to secure a buyer for the remnants of boo.com have been dealt a blow by reports that its much-praised 'business-to-business' fulfilment capability is run by two external companies. The news came as liquidator KPMG held negotiations with a handful of companies hoping to realise value from boo's intangible assets.
fields.body:
Efforts to secure a buyer for the remnants of boo.com have been dealt a blow by reports that its much-praised 'business-to-business' fulfilment capability is run by two external companies. The news came as liquidator KPMG held negotiations with a handful of companies hoping to realise value from boo's intangible assets.

KPMG made much of boo's 'huge capacity' infrastructure - customers can order goods in 18 countries and have them delivered to their door. 'This represents a real point of interest for potential buyers,' said Mick McLoughlin of KPMG Corporate Recovery.

Boo's system was also independently praised in a report from analysts at CSFB earlier this year.

But boo's international fulfilment function, based in Munich and Kentucky, is outsourced to Deutsche Post in Europe and UPS in the US. A UPS spokesman confirmed that the company carries out boo's US fulfilment, and that its main cargo centre is in Kentucky.

Deutsche Post and UPS are among creditors owed a total of $25 million for their services.

Boo has no assets other than its tarnished brand, intellectual property, and the website, which has been kept running as a showpiece for potential buyers.

KPMG warned that the business faced closure by Wednesday if it was unable to strike a deal this weekend. It received 42 expressions of interest in all following boo.com's spectacular crash last Tuesday. However, that has dropped to just a handful after KPMG asked would-be buyers to lodge a £1m deposit by Friday's deadline.

Last week French entre preneur Bernard Arnault's private firm, Markas Holdings, which pumped in some £7m, was the final investor to pull the plug. And despite speculation that he was looking to pick up boo.com from the liquidator on the cheap, Arnault has also now finally walked away. 'We have no interest. It was a small financial investment for us. It turned out to be a turkey,' one source close to Arnault said.

Other mooted buyers shunning the auction include UK Internet provider Freeserve, German sportswear group Adidas and Italy's Benetton - another main boo.com investor. Boo's collapse followed 15 months of free spending by its Swedish founders.

fields.headline: Over the rainbow
fields.standfirst: It may often be flabby and farmed, but a judicious use of spice and seasoning can make trout a tasty fish supper
fields.trailText: It may often be flabby and farmed, but a judicious use of spice and seasoning can make trout a tasty fish supper
fields.body:
It is all very well for us cookery writers, chefs and other professional piggies to say that if a vegetable, a fruit or a piece of meat is not perfect, then do not buy it, but the truth is that sometimes we must buy the best we can. I mean, have you actually tried to buy a wild, straight-from-the-rod rainbow trout recently? If you have succeeded, then I am deeply envious. Famous fisherfolk such as Diana Rigg, Jeremy Paxman and, I suppose, JR Hartley, are lucky to have a fish at the end of their line, though I must say I will not be joining them. The only time I ever went fishing, I prayed I wouldn't catch anything - the thought of having to finish off a flapping, gasping trout would have been a trauma too terrible to bear. For squeamish, urban cooks like me, the choice is simple. It is farmed trout or no trout at all.

I am not sure the trout I eat now has much to do with the rainbow-tinted ones my father used to bring home in a smelly bag from his fishing trips to Much Wenlock. (At least he said he was going fishing, although I always suspected his weekends involved something far more sinister, ending with a quick trip to MacFisheries on the way home.) His fish were wild, beautiful and had spent their life in a lake. Mine are invariably from a farm, for which read underwater factory. His trout had at least put up a bit of fight, flaying around helplessly at the end of his rod, whereas mine have probably spent their lives milling around aimlessly, wondering what to do till feeding time.

I cannot say I do much to my trout when I get it home from the fishmonger. (The poor things are obviously destined to live a life of no excitement even to the very end.) If they are lucky, they will end their days buttered and grilled with a wedge of lemon, or perhaps sitting in a thin, sharp sauce of capers and lime. I am not being unimaginative here: trout is something that doesn't need much of a sendoff - just a hot pan and something tart to make its pink flesh sing.

Wild trout is the fish you want. One that has had an adventure or two. But for most of us, it is the farmed fish variety, the couch potato of the fish world, or nothing. This is bland fish, make no mistake - complain all you like that trout doesn't taste like it used to, but it will get you nowhere. I am already bracing myself for a ticking off from the Trout Council or whatever body the trout farmers employ to see that we cookery writers do as we are told. But I have never had much truck with the food world's PR merchants.

I have had some pleasing suppers this week, however, and four of them involved a trout. There was a baked fish, naked except for a tuft or two of tarragon and a shake of tarragon vinegar. Then there was a salad for which I fried the fish and marinated it with coriander and vinegar; a couple of fillets grilled with lime and scattered with capers, and then a whole fish cooked in its own steam with lemon grass. Do you see a pattern here? You need a snap of piquancy. Throw the cream out of the window and you will eat well enough. Lime, capers, vinegar, lemon grass all have some sort of acidity that, like passion fruit with lacklustre strawberries, breathe life into the dish.

On the positive side, trout is high in the omega 3 fatty acids that are so important for guarding against heart disease, it is easily available - with even the simplest supermarket running to a pre-packed version - and it is almost the cheapest fish you can buy. The trout is as happy steamed as baked, and is generally juicy. It smokes delectably and can be used in any of the thousands of recipes you can find for salmon. On the downside, they can taste like mud. Much will depend on the farm your fish has come from, on what it has been fed and how fresh it is. Look for something that is stiff and shimmering, with red gills and twinkling eyes. But it is unlikely to sport the exquisite blue, brown, grey and pink colouring we associate with the wild fish.

It wasn't so long ago that the most famous fish dish, trout with almonds, was a luxury. Then again, so were grapes, Camembert and After Eight mints. But that expensive fish with its gilding of thinly sliced nuts was more often than not straight from the deep freeze. I know this much because I spent most of my teenage years fishing bistro classics out of freezers to put on restaurant plates. I do think this is a recipe worth doing, though, especially if you take the trouble (and it is trouble) to skin and slice the almonds yourself and use the sweetest, freshest butter.

No matter how much olive oil has taken over from dairy produce in the modern kitchen, it doesn't do much for salmon and trout. Those who seek to impose olive oil on the oilier fish (ie, almost every restaurant in town) seem to have misunderstood that its flesh is already awash with oil - which is why trout tastes so much better when sizzled in a pan with butter till it turns nutty-smelling and brown and, I imagine, even better if that pan is perched on a camping stove by the side of a lake.

Warm marinated trout with butter sauce

The idea of marinating the trout is both to flavour it and keep it juicy. The marinade is then boiled down and finished with butter. This is not a dish that will hold and wait, as the sauce will split. Do it when there are just two of you and you are ready to eat. Some new potatoes, scrubbed and buttered would be nice here. Serves 2.

2 trout, filleted

150ml white wine vinegar

4 tbsps mild olive oil

1 small onion, peeled and very thinly sliced

1 dried chilli, roughly crushed

1 tsp of coriander seeds, lightly crushed

a bay leaf or two

a thick slice of butter for frying the fish

to finish the sauce

50g cold butter, cut into small chunks

Pour the vinegar into a shallow glass, china or stainless-steel dish, add the olive oil, the onion, the chilli and the coriander seeds. Crumble the bay leaves into the dish.

Rinse the trout and dry it on kitchen paper, then lay it, skin-side up, in the dish. If the marinade doesn't quite cover the fish, add more vinegar and oil. Roughly crush a few peppercorns and scatter them over, then cover with clingfilm or a plate and set aside somewhere cool for at least an hour.

Melt the butter in a shallow pan and when it starts to froth, slide in the trout fillets, skin-side up. After a minute or two, carefully turn the fillets, cover the pan with a lid and continue cooking until the flesh is tinged with golden brown - a matter of three or four minutes.

Lift the fish out and keep warm in a low oven. Pour off most of the butter left in the pan, then add the marinade, holding back the onions and chilli with a draining spoon. Let it bubble over a very high heat until it has reduced to a few spoonfuls, now beat in the second lot of butter with a whisk until the sauce is glossy, then spoon it over the fish (there won't be much), and serve.

Trout with prosciutto and sage

I suspect it is more than my life is worth to give you a veal recipe, so here is Veal Saltimbocca made with trout. It tastes much better than it sounds because of the trout's curious affinity with bacon. Serves 2.

75g cold butter

4 large slices of Parma ham

2 large trout, filleted

4 large sage leaves

a little plain flour

groundnut oil, for frying

juice of a lemon

Cut the butter in two, and cut one half into four thin slices. Lay a slice of ham flat on the table, place a slice of butter in the middle, then put one of the trout fillets on top. Roll up the fish in the ham, place a sage leaf over the loose end, and secure with a cocktail stick.

Season the flour with salt and pepper. Heat a thin layer of oil in a frying pan. Dust each fish parcel thoroughly with flour. Place, butter-side down, in the pan and cook for about three minutes, till the ham is crisp. Turn over with the help of a fish slice and cook for a further two minutes.

Remove the fish to a hot plate. Tip the juices from the pan. Melt the remaining butter over a high heat, and as soon as it starts to froth, add the lemon juice and a little salt and pepper. Pour the frothing butter over the fish and serve immediately.

Pan-fried trout

A meal of such simplicity you wonder why you don't do it more often. Serves 2.

50g butter

2 large trout, filleted

a small handful of chopped parsley

2 tbsps chopped tarragon, dill or flat leaf parsley

juice of half a lemon

Heat the butter in a large, shallow pan over a moderate heat. When the butter starts to froth and bubble, put in the fillets, skin-side down. Cook until the skin is golden, spooning the hot butter over the fish from time to time. It should take about seven to eight minutes to cook the fish through, depending on their size. Remove the fish to warm plates. Add the herbs to the butter, squeeze in the lemon juice, and pour over the fish.

One that has had an adventure or two. But for most of us, it is the farmed fish variety, the couch potato of the fish world, or nothing. This is bland fish, make no mistake - complain all you like that trout doesn't taste like it used to, but it will get you nowhere. I am already bracing myself for a ticking off from the Trout Council or whatever body the trout farmers employ to see that we cookery writers do as we are told. But I have never had much truck with the food world's PR merchants. I have had some pleasing suppers this week, however, and four of them involved a trout. There was a baked fish, naked except for a tuft or two of tarragon and a shake of tarragon vinegar. Then there was a salad for which I fried the fish and marinated it with coriander and vinegar; a couple of fillets grilled with lime and scattered with capers, and then a whole fish cooked in its own steam with lemon grass. Do you see a pattern here? You need a snap of piquancy. Throw the cream out of the window and you will eat well enough. Lime, capers, vinegar, lemon grass all have some sort of acidity that, like passion fruit with lacklustre strawberries, breathe life into the dish. On the positive side, trout is high in the omega 3 fatty acids that are so important for guarding against heart disease, it is easily available - with even the simplest supermarket running to a pre-packed version - and it is almost the cheapest fish you can buy. The trout is as happy steamed as baked, and is generally juicy. It smokes delectably and can be used in any of the thousands of recipes you can find for salmon. On the downside, they can taste like mud. Much will depend on the farm your fish has come from, on what it has been fed and how fresh it is. Look for something that is stiff and shimmering, with red gills and twinkling eyes. But it is unlikely to sport the exquisite blue, brown, grey and pink colouring we associate with the wild fish. It wasn't so long ago that the most famous fish dish, trout with almonds, was a luxury. Then again, so were grapes, Camembert and After Eight mints. But that expensive fish with its gilding of thinly sliced nuts was more often than not straight from the deep freeze. I know this much because I spent most of my teenage years fishing bistro classics out of freezers to put on restaurant plates. I do think this is a recipe worth doing, though, especially if you take the trouble (and it is trouble) to skin and slice the almonds yourself and use the sweetest, freshest butter. No matter how much olive oil has taken over from dairy produce in the modern kitchen, it doesn't do much for salmon and trout. Those who seek to impose olive oil on the oilier fish (ie, almost every restaurant in town) seem to have misunderstood that its flesh is already awash with oil - which is why trout tastes so much better when sizzled in a pan with butter till it turns nutty-smelling and brown and, I imagine, even better if that pan is perched on a camping stove by the side of a lake. Warm marinated trout with butter sauce The idea of marinating the trout is both to flavour it and keep it juicy. The marinade is then boiled down and finished with butter. This is not a dish that will hold and wait, as the sauce will split. Do it when there are just two of you and you are ready to eat. Some new potatoes, scrubbed and buttered would be nice here. Serves 2. 2 trout, filleted 150ml white wine vinegar 4 tbsps mild olive oil 1 small onion, peeled and very thinly sliced 1 dried chilli, roughly crushed 1 tsp of coriander seeds, lightly crushed a bay leaf or two a thick slice of butter for frying the fish to finish the sauce 50g cold butter, cut into small chunks Pour the vinegar into a shallow glass, china or stainless-steel dish, add the olive oil, the onion, the chilli and the coriander seeds. Crumble the bay leaves into the dish. Rinse the trout and dry it on kitchen paper, then lay it, skin-side up, in the dish. If the marinade doesn't quite cover the fish, add more vinegar and oil. Roughly crush a few peppercorns and scatter them over, then cover with clingfilm or a plate and set aside somewhere cool for at least an hour. Melt the butter in a shallow pan and when it starts to froth, slide in the trout fillets, skin-side up. After a minute or two, carefully turn the fillets, cover the pan with a lid and continue cooking until the flesh is tinged with golden brown - a matter of three or four minutes. Lift the fish out and keep warm in a low oven. Pour off most of the butter left in the pan, then add the marinade, holding back the onions and chilli with a draining spoon. Let it bubble over a very high heat until it has reduced to a few spoonfuls, now beat in the second lot of butter with a whisk until the sauce is glossy, then spoon it over the fish (there won't be much), and serve. Trout with prosciutto and sage I suspect it is more than my life is worth to give you a veal recipe, so here is Veal Saltimbocca made with trout. It tastes much better than it sounds because of the trout's curious affinity with bacon. Serves 2. 75g cold butter 4 large slices of Parma ham 2 large trout, filleted 4 large sage leaves a little plain flour groundnut oil, for frying juice of a lemon Cut the butter in two, and cut one half into four thin slices. Lay a slice of ham flat on the table, place a slice of butter in the middle, then put one of the trout fillets on top. Roll up the fish in the ham, place a sage leaf over the loose end, and secure with a cocktail stick. Season the flour with salt and pepper. Heat a thin layer of oil in a frying pan. Dust each fish parcel thoroughly with flour. Place, butter-side down, in the pan and cook for about three minutes, till the ham is crisp. Turn over with the help of a fish slice and cook for a further two minutes. Remove the fish to a hot plate. Tip the juices from the pan. Melt the remaining butter over a high heat, and as soon as it starts to froth, add the lemon juice and a little salt and pepper. Pour the frothing butter over the fish and serve immediately. Pan-fried trout A meal of such simplicity you wonder why you don't do it more often. Serves 2. 50g butter 2 large trout, filleted a small handful of chopped parsley 2 tbsps chopped tarragon, dill or flat leaf parsley juice of half a lemon Heat the butter in a large, shallow pan over a moderate heat. When the butter starts to froth and bubble, put in the fillets, skin-side down. Cook until the skin is golden, spooning the hot butter over the fish from time to time. It should take about seven to eight minutes to cook the fish through, depending on their size. Remove the fish to warm plates. Add the herbs to the butter, squeeze in the lemon juice, and pour over the fish.  To order a copy of Nigel Slater's Real Food for £9.99 including p&p (rrp £12.99), freephone 0800 316 8171

fields.headline: The personal touch
fields.standfirst: Stylish and straightforward, Jeremy's at Borde Hill, in West Sussex, lives up to its name, says Jay Rayner
fields.trailText: Stylish and straightforward, Jeremy's at Borde Hill, in West Sussex, lives up to its name.
fields.body:
I have a friend who changed her name between school and university from Debbie to Natasha. She didn't feel like a Debbie, she said. Inside Debbie, it seemed, there was a Natasha just begging to get out. And she was right. Like a transsexual man who has always known they needed to be a woman, Debbie made a much better Natasha than she ever did a Debbie. She had the hair for it. And a lot of handkerchiefs embroidered with the letter N.

Names are much more than mere labels. They are statements of intent. Likewise the use of the owner's name for the title of their restaurant can be a clear and precise way of defining a business. You'd know what to expect from a place called, say, Darren's or Kevin's - I think it would have something to do with fried onion rings, Blue Nun and a punch-up just after last orders. (This is because I'm an outrageous snob.) The best example of this at the moment is a fine restaurant in South London called Chez Bruce, which to me speaks of a perfect balance between French precision and Australian informality. That pretty much describes the place.

You would also know what to expect from a place called Jeremy's, wouldn't you - something comfortable, light, stylish without being overly ambitious, maybe a little fey, a little chintzy around the edges. That just about sums up Jeremy's at Borde Hill, chef Jeremy Ashpool's restaurant set in one of the old buildings on the Borde Hill Garden estate just outside Hayward's Heath in Sussex. A light, airy room decorated in shades of deep blue and peach looks out over a Victorian walled garden, currently playing host to an exhibition of sculpture for sale.

Elsewhere on the estate are formal gardens, an adventure playground for kids and a Tudor mansion house - all of which the diners gain free entrance to. There's also a smallish garden centre. I've had very bad experiences of food around garden centres in the recent past. To me, a garden centre near a restaurant is like a lighthouse to a mariner: a warning to steer clear.

Happily, we didn't. It's not that Jeremy's is without faults. Tasters of tomatoes stuffed with a curried seafood mousse were the sort of underwhelming canapé you would get at an overly ambitious Berkshire wedding. (I told you I was a snob.) And my starter of seared tuna with a niçoise-style salad and anchovy mayonnaise was a bit of a mess; the dressing underpowered, the salad a poor assembly of peppers and over-boiled egg. It was not an improvement on a standard niçoise. But these failings are far smaller than its successes. Jeremy Ashpool uses lots of local produce, and he uses it intelligently, in a way that reflects the abundant greenery beyond the windows.

One of the reasons I am so enamoured of the place was that they were so comfortable with our son Eddie. They laid on a highchair. They did not flinch when he threw the cutlery on to the floor for the third time. They took him on a tour of the kitchens. To be honest, I think they were more comfortable with him being there than we were. I make a conscious point of taking the boy wonder to restaurants because I do not think children should be excluded. But this time, surrounded by lots of pressed linen and shimmering glassware, I felt we'd overstepped the mark. The staff clearly did not agree. They like having babies around; that is not something you can fake for the sake of good service.

While Eddie threw around lumps of bread and cheese, my wife Pat dug into her starter of carpaccio of beef. It came with a sprinkling of basil, good, salty Parmesan and lots of crisp bean sprouts and chopped leeks which worked beautifully against the softness of the beef. For my main course, I had grilled champ of milk lamb at £15. It was spring on a plate, the perfectly cooked young meat accompanied by lots of baby spinach and new potatoes and small, caramelised red onions. There was something very straightforward about this unpretentious dish. It was all so very Jeremy.

Pat's main course of red mullet at £16.50 also came with many of the same vegetables (and why not? If they're good and in season, they should be used), as well as some huge, tempura-ed capers which were a bit much by themselves but grand alongside the fish. A little dish of saffron risotto turned up late with many apologies and boasting the kind of extreme heat usually only obtained with a swift burst of the microwave. It was a nice enough risotto - once it had cooled down - but, to be honest, not really necessary.

Eddie moved on to his grapes and we moved on to our puddings, which were of the 'fuel for long country walks' variety. A sticky toffee pudding was dark and lush, a chocolate brioche and butter pudding with crème frache equally so. We were both sharing driving duties so, apart from a fine kir, we neither of us did any damage to the wine list, but it is an extremely well thought-out document from both the New and Old World. There's a fair selection of halves, lots of bottles well below £20, and none getting too far beyond that psychologically important barrier, either.

It has a loyal local clientele, and I can see why. If I lived nearby, I would come here often; on a warm summer's evening, dinner on the terrace at Jeremy's must be an exquisite experience. The owner should simply give thanks that his parents didn't call him Melvin. That wouldn't have worked at all.

 Jeremy's at Borde Hill, Balcombe Road, Hayward's Heath, West Sussex (01444 441 102). Dinner for two, with wine and service, costs £80

fields.headline: Far Right invades anti-Europe party
fields.trailText: A sudden move to the far right by the UK Independence Party, which won three seats at last year's European elections, has raised fears that extreme racists are gaining a power base in a mainstream party.
fields.body:
A sudden move to the far right by the UK Independence Party, which won three seats at last year's European elections, has raised fears that extreme racists are gaining a power base in a mainstream party. The far-right British National Party has even proposed a merger with the UKIP.

In the most recent edition of the BNP's magazine Spearhead, a leader comment claims that most UKIP members share the BNP's hatred of 'mass immigration and multi-racialism'. It concludes: 'If the power of the Establishment is to be challenged and a movement of national salvation built up, the streams of popular protest represented by the UKIP and the BNP will have to come together in a single political force.'

There is growing evidence that there are an expanding number of far-right sympathisers within the UKIP who would welcome such an initiative. This month a long message praising the BNP appeared on the party's internal Internet bulletin board, under the name of a senior officer in the London UKIP.

The message describes the BNP as being well organised and having an attractive set of policies on law and order, immigration, cultural and family issues. Elsewhere on the UKIP bulletin board there are more extreme postings. A UKIP member from North-east England calls blacks an 'Equatorial African species' who 'pollute our bloodlines'. In another message a senior paid officer of the party indulges in an anti-Catholic rant which describes the European Union as a plot by the Vatican to take over the nation states of Europe.

The impression of growing support in the UKIP for far-right views is reinforced in the latest edition of The Flag, the magazine of the National Democrats, formerly the National Front. A UKIP member writes: 'In the area I come from, almost all the UKIP members I have spoken to agree with most of your policies and would probably join you if it was not for the fact that UKIP is quite a bit larger than your organisation.'

Earlier this year a virulently racist letter written by Richard Clements, who was expelled from the UKIP for his views, and signed by a number of current members, was circulating. The letter, also signed by Dennis Delderfield, leader of the avowedly racist far-right party New Britain, states that 'suburb after suburb and town after town across the land have been taken over by Asians, Africans and Afro-Caribbeans ... In the not too distant future they will have direct control in many areas.'

Michael Holmes, former leader of the UKIP and one of its three MEPs elected last June, has expressed concern about infiltration of the party by individuals with far-right connections. He lost a vote of confidence last January and was thrown out of the party.

More than 200 members are said to have followed him out of the UKIP. 'All I know is that there are now some very odd people involved,' he said last week.

In a letter this month to his supporters, Holmes, a retired newspaper publisher, said four of the party's current senior officers had once been members of Delderfield's New Britain, which advocated repatriation of immigrants. The four are the party's new leader, MEP Jeffrey Titford, chairman Michael Natrass, party secretary Bryan Smalley, and Derek Bennett, on the National Executive.

Tony Bennett, spokesman for Titford, said: 'The UKIP disassociates itself from all forms of racism. We have no links with any extremist or racist parties.' He also dismissed merger ideas. 'We wouldn't even consider talking to the BNP.'
