fields.headline: Stress-free, but no pampering
fields.trailText: Good value all round, but if you expect to be pampered and cosseted then Ryanair is not an option.
fields.body:
Booking

Ryanair was offering discounted flights if bookings were made on its website: www.ryanair.com. The site gave a choice of flight times. Making the booking took 15 minutes. My flights cost £40 plus £21.20 tax, a total of £61.20. I paid by Visa Delta.

Tickets

The airline is ticketless. After booking I printed out a confirmation sheet with flight details, booking conditions and a reference number I was to quote when checking-in at Stansted.

Check-in

Outbound: A bit of a scrum at the Ryanair desks. My flight was listed on the departure screen, but the check-in desk number was not. It was not easy to find a free member of staff, but once I did it was plain sailing.

Inbound: Problem-free. There were no queues at Skavsta airport and check-in staff were friendly and helpful.

Boarding

Outbound: There is no seat allocation. People with children were allowed to board first. Queuing was civilised.

Inbound: Slightly more stressful at Skavsta. A delay meant people were impatient, but I got a row of seats to myself.

Take Off

Outbound: Very smooth and on time (18.15). The safety demonstration was clear and within view. There was plenty of room in the overhead lockers. We arrived at Skavsta 15 minutes early (21.15).

Inbound: A 40-minute delay due to fog at Stansted. There were no free refreshments offered, although there was a bar serving snacks and drinks. We took off at 11.30 instead of 10.50.

Decor

The cabin was airy and reasonably spacious on each journey, with enough leg-room except when the passenger in front reclined his seat. The decoration was a light pastel colour with a dark blue carpet and cabin crew were smart in bright blue skirt suits and hats.

Catering

Outbound: No free in-flight catering. Cabin crew sold soft drinks, alcohol and crisps. A mineral water or juice cost 60p, crisps 20p, beer £2, wine £3, Champagne or sparkling wine £4.

Inbound: Nothing free. Tea and coffee were £1.50, dinner £7. Decent menu offered a choice of starter, main course and dessert, although I did not see anyone order it.

Service

On both legs it was fast, efficient, good-humoured and relaxed throughout.

Arrival

Outbound: A smooth landing. After five minutes at passport control I waited 10 minutes for my luggage. I bought a return bus ticket into Stockholm at the Ryanair desk for 120SKr, a 30SKr discount.

Inbound: The daytime bus journey from Stockholm's Central Station to Skavsta airport took two hours. An easy landing, with transit to London taking only 20 minutes. Verdict

Good value all round and largely stress-free. But if you expect to be pampered and cosseted then Ryanair is not an option.

Rating out of 10:

Service 6

Value 8

No-frills Stockholm

Cheap eat

The Sodermalm area is a bohemian and arty part of the city, with lovely old buildings, bars, restaurants and parks. Try Lasse i Parken, Hogalidsgatan 56. A café housed in an eighteenth-century house with a garden. 00 46 8 658 3395. The 'eat as much as you like' buffet is 65SKr (£4.80). Near to the beaches at Langholmen.

Cheap sleep

The Langholmen Hotel and Hostel (www.langholmen.com), an old prison converted into a modern hostel and hotel on the island of Langholmen. A single hostel room costs £16 a night (lavatory, shower, TV and phone), plus an extra £10 for breakfast, bed-linen, towels and cleaning. A single hotel room costs £70, including breakfast; a double £93. Tel: 00 46 8 668 05 10

Typical sightseeing

The Vasa Museum (www.vasamuseet.se) houses an impressive warship built in 1628, which sank on its maiden voyage and was raised and salvaged in1961. The museum is on the beautiful island of Djurgarden, reached by short ferry ride from Slussen. Entrance £4.50, or free with a Stockholm card.

Less typical sightseeing

See Stockholm by bike. Rental from Kajplats 24, Strandvagen (tel: 00 46 8 660 79 59), £5 a day for an old-fashioned bike or about £15 for a mountain bike. Cycle lanes all over the city.

Traveller's tip

A Stockholm card for unlimited travel on city metro, buses, ferries and some regional trains, entrance to 70 museums and other attractions. £15 for 24 hours, £29 for 48 hours. Available from tourist offices.

A single hostel room costs £16 a night (lavatory, shower, TV and phone), plus an extra £10 for breakfast, bed-linen, towels and cleaning. A single hotel room costs £70, including breakfast; a double £93. Tel: 00 46 8 668 05 10 Typical sightseeing The Vasa Museum (www.vasamuseet.se) houses an impressive warship built in 1628, which sank on its maiden voyage and was raised and salvaged in1961. Rental from Kajplats 24, Strandvagen (tel: 00 46 8 660 79 59), £5 a day for an old-fashioned bike or about £15 for a mountain bike. Cycle lanes all over the city. webTitle: Stansted to Rome: the Observer's verdict

fields.headline: Going is easy, but coming back...
fields.standfirst: Stansted to Rome
fields.trailText:
Rating out of 10:
Service 7
Value 6
fields.body:
Booking

The go website is straightforward. You are offered the lowest available fare and prices include tax. I fancied a trip to Prague but with prices hitting £160-plus it was beyond my budget. So too were Palma, Bologna, Lisbon and Venice. Then I tried Rome, and found a fare at £49 out, £44 back. Total: £93.

Tickets

Go is a ticketless airline, but I was given a flight confirmation number and itinerary online, which I printed off and used at check-in.

Check-In

I've seen worse. Go's check-in desks serve all destinations. Four desks were open when I arrived, dealing quickly with the crowds. I was behind a group of lads off on a stag party (eyeing up the hen party in the queue next door) and queued for a civilised 15 minutes. At the desk I presented my printout and passport and was handed a boarding card. It took three minutes.

Boarding

On go, you are allocated a seat - it avoids a rugby scrum for them. I was early so I got a window seat. Boarding was painless - there were no delays at the gate. There is a five-kilo limit on hand baggage - strictly observed. Go used the same gate to board for Rome and Madrid flights. A few Spaniards almost boarded the wrong plane.

Take-off

Outbound: Cabin crew performed the safety drill clearly and competently in English and Italian. During turbulence, stewards enforced the 'fasten safety belt' rule by wagging fingers and shooing passengers back to seats. Flight 155 to Rome departed on time.

Decor

Our Boeing 737 was light and airy. The plane looked new. Cabin crew wear voguish grey trousers and bright T-shirts. And - a pleasant surprise - I had plenty of leg-room. There is no in-flight entertainment.

Catering

In-flight catering by the Costa coffee chain. Tea is £1.20, coffee £1.50 and rich hot chocolate £1.50. Sandwiches from £2.30 to £3.10 and pastries from £1 to £1.50. Snacks (crisps, nuts and chocolate) £1 or under. Nice, unfussy food.

Service

Swift.

Arrival

Outbound: On schedule. Passengers were rapidly reunited with baggage. A go bus ferried travellers into central Rome - £7 return for the 40-minute journey. A 30-minute bus and train costs £5.50. Taxis cost from £15.50 to £22. Go has a deal with Budget rental cars, prices from £25 a day.

Inbound: The flight, due to touch down at 23.10, was delayed by more than an hour. We missed the last train to London at 23.39. There were no coaches and no go representatives. Most people shared taxis to London - at £70-£80 a pop. Got home at 3.30am.

Verdict

Travelling with go is pleasant. Booking is easy, fares are good value and the service is professional and friendly. However, getting stranded at Stansted left a sour taste.

Rating out of 10

Service 7

Value 6

No-frills Rome

Cheap eat

Rome is full of roadside vendors selling tasty pizza slices and ciabatta sandwiches (£1-£2), ice creams (£1-£2), soft drinks (£1) - all you need for a quick cheap lunch or snack. Rosati, 5 Piazza del Popolo, is on the steep side, but have a coffee on the terrace (about £2) and savour the atmosphere of Rome's most stunning piazza.

Cheap sleep

I stayed in a B&B near St Peter's, booked through Rome B& B (of US B&B) at www.romebandb.com. Rooms, usually in the host's home, cost about £75 for two sharing (£37pp). My accommodation was comfortable and spacious but the agency got my arrival time wrong - and almost left me locked out for the night.

Typical sightseeing

The Vatican is a must; entry to St Peter's is free. You might even see the Pope. Don't miss the restored Sistine Chapel (£5.60).

Less typical

Most visitors will go to the Colosseum ( £3; tours in English available).

But don't stop there. Just outside the ancient amphitheatre is the Foro Romano e Palatino. Entry costs £3 and you are free to wander around the ruins of ancient Rome. This is a beautiful place full of poppies, roses, Cypress trees and basking feral cats.

Traveller's Tip

Take a lover - Rome is ridiculously romantic.

webTitle: Fiji military sets sights on coup plotters

fields.headline: Fiji military sets sights on coup plotters
fields.trailText: Fiji was in a state of emergency last night as the authorities contemplated the use of force to end a coup mounted by a failed businessman in protest at the island's political domination by ethnic Indians.
fields.body:
Fiji was in a state of emergency last night as the authorities contemplated the use of force to end a coup mounted by a failed businessman in protest at the island's political domination by ethnic Indians.

Yesterday Prime Minister Mahendra Chaudhry was beaten and threatened with death by George Speight, who with nine armed men stormed the parliament on Friday. Last night they were still holding hostage Chaudhry, who is said to be in urgent need of medical attention, and some Ministers but had released 20 parliamentary staff.

The coup leaders, who are attempting to overthrow the Indian-dominated government 'on behalf of indigenous Fijians', were sworn in as the heads of an interim government yesterday.

Speight, the son of an opposition MP, declared himself Prime Minister in a nine-member 'Cabinet' during a low-key ceremony broadcast on TV from the parliament building in the capital, Suva.

State-owned Fiji TV said the leaders of the legal government had handed over authority shortly before the swearing-in - but only after a gun was held to Chaudhry's head. Speight was reported to have threatened to kill him unless he called President Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara to order the military away from the parliament. Fiji TV reported that Chaudhry - Fiji's first ethnic Indian Prime Minister - told Speight to go ahead and shoot.

The President warned Speight and his band that he would not bow to threats. 'We wish to see the impasse broken and the captives set free, but we will not bow to threats and coercion,' Kamisese said.

It remained unclear how much support Speight had within Fiji. At a news conference, the military and police pledged their backing for Kamisese, who declared a state of emergency on Friday.

All leave was cancelled and troops summoned back to barracks. The fact that police and the military have not risen with Speight against the government was taken as a strong indication that the coup is doomed even if the use of force is avoided.

Suva itself was recovering after two days of rioting and looting by native Fijians. Scores of businesses have been sacked and destroyed.

The rioters were incensed by Chaudhry's attempts to persuade Fijian landowners to renew expiring leases on farmland held by thousands of ethnic Indians. Chaudhry's year-old administration is the first to be dominated by Fijian Indians, which has angered some indigenous islanders. Fijian Indians account for 45 per cent of the population and indigenous Fijians 50 per cent.

There were also reports of fresh violence in Fiji's second city, Nadi, a major holiday destination and the location of the country's main international airport.

Tourism is Fiji's chief industry, accounting for 17 per cent of GDP. Any impact on it would severely damage the fragile economy of a country which attracts 300,000 foreign visitors each year.

webTitle: Who should pay out for my son's bike smash?

fields.headline: Who should pay out for my son's bike smash?
fields.trailText: When my son worked abroad as a travel rep, he was knocked off the mountain bike he was provided with to get between hotels. The driver was found guilty of dangerous driving. My son's employer had not given him a crash helmet, and did virtually nothing to help him get compensation. They still deny that they are responsible in any way, even though he was on duty and in uniform. He still gets backaches and the bump on his head still shows.
fields.body:
When my son worked abroad as a travel rep, he was knocked off the mountain bike he was provided with to get between hotels. The driver was found guilty of dangerous driving. My son's employer had not given him a crash helmet, and did virtually nothing to help him get compensation. They still deny that they are responsible in any way, even though he was on duty and in uniform. He still gets backaches and the bump on his head still shows.

THE issue here hinges on an employer's duty to provide a safe working environment for employees. An employer would be expected to take 'reasonable' precautions. It is probably a grey area as to whether the employer should have provided a crash helmet. If he had asked them for a helmet and they had refused, he would be on firmer ground.

Most employers should have insurance, and this should pay up. If you want to claim, you would make a personal injury claim in the High Court. Sometimes employers need this kind of threat before they settle. Such claims can, however, be expensive to bring.

The law governing your son's relationship with his employer is probably English law - if he was recruited in England and the employer is based in England.

 Legal advice from Lewis Silkin

 Research from the TUC Guide to Health and Safety Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

fields.headline: Scary Spice fishes for cash
fields.trailText: Last night the disc jockey Zoe Ball and her pop star husband Norman 'Fatboy Slim' Cook were among celebrities at an 'underwater' party held in Hackney, London, to raise finance for  Fish - a new film starring Spice Girl Mel B
fields.body:
It may have been the strangest, glitziest film event of the month. But it took place in east London and not in Cannes.

Last night the disc jockey Zoe Ball and her pop star husband Norman 'Fatboy Slim' Cook were among celebrities at an 'underwater' party held in Hackney, London, to raise finance for Fish - a new film starring Spice Girl Mel B.

In her first major solo acting role, 'Scary Spice' has agreed to play the mother of Jimmy, a young teenage boy obsessed with tropical fish. The film deals with the issue of living in Britain as a mixed-race child and the millionaire singer is believed to have taken part in the low-budget production because the theme is close to her heart.

Unusually, her son will be played by a girl in the film because the director felt the young actors he auditioned were unable to show the right level of sensitivity.

'It may sound odd, but I found it was the only way to cast the right sort of Jimmy,' said Bruce Goodison, the former television director behind the project.

This weekend he announced the film already had £20,000 of backing from Northern Arts. 'The other £25,000 I have so far has been hustled through friends.' He described the film as 'fantastical, magical and with an uplifting story line.'

Guests at last night's party arrived dressed as mermaids or scuba divers or King Neptune, uttered the password 'fish', made a £10 donation and were then invited into a pseudo-underwater environment.

webTitle: Andrew Rawnsley - Peter and Gordon fall out of harmony

fields.headline: Peter and Gordon fall out of harmony
fields.standfirst:
The feud between Mandelson and Brown used to be just personal - now it's business

The Euro debate - Observer special
fields.trailText: In the run up to the last election, Peter Mandelson convened a meeting of New Labour's spinners to discuss how they would deal with a variety of nightmare scenarios during the campaign. For the purposes of this electoral war-gaming, an imaginative and well-informed mind mocked up some black headlines they might confront. Blair went private to straighten teeth was just a giggle.
fields.body:
In the run up to the last election, Peter Mandelson convened a meeting of New Labour's spinners to discuss how they would deal with a variety of nightmare scenarios during the campaign. For the purposes of this electoral war-gaming, an imaginative and well-informed mind mocked up some black headlines they might confront. Blair went private to straighten teeth was just a giggle.

Much more plausible was: Mandelson and Brown stage shouting match in Millbank as Labour lead falls. That headline was never printed in a real newspaper because Brown and Mandelson avoided a shouting match by not talking to each other at all. Tony Blair has thrown his key lieutenants back together again to manage the next election campaign.

Knowing more intimately than anyone else how his two best men bring out the worst in each other, the Prime Minister seems intent on testing the theory of creative tension to destruction.

An ocean of bad blood has been spilt since the last campaign. Mandelson will never forget the pivotal role played by Brown's acolytes in exposing the home loan from Geoffrey Robinson which destroyed him as Trade & Industry Secretary. This was the Chancellor's payback for the crime Brown can never forgive: Mandelson's switch in affections to Blair during the leadership contest nearly six years ago. Like all the great feuds, many of the grudges between them are ancient. It has been poisonously destructive, but at least it used to be only personal. Now it's becoming business. That's much more dangerous.

Contrary to the popular perception of him as nothing more than a skilful opportunist, Peter Mandelson is possessed by some fierce and enduring convictions, among which is a passionate belief that Britain's manifest destiny is as a fully subscribed player in Europe. Heart was speaking with head when he told an audience of trades unionists in Belfast that British industry would suffer from damaging gyrations in its competitiveness in its largest market 'as long as we are outside the euro'.

I suspect that this only hints at the depths of Mandelson's frustration, an anxiety shared with other ardent pro-Europeans in the Government, that New Labour's European strategy has fallen to pieces. When William Hague claims that Tony Blair has a 'secret agenda' to take Britain into the single currency, New Labour's pro-Europeans groan that they wish this were true. Rather than convince Britain of the case for ever-closer engagement, the people are now even more hostile to the single currency and antagonistic towards the European Union as a whole than when Tony Blair came to power, declaring his grand ambition to be a leader in Europe.

That one sentence from Mandelson stating the blindingly obvious about the exchange rate caused such internal ructions because New Labour's leading players sense that there is the potential for a searing conflict between them over Europe, a split perhaps even as traumatic as that which afflicted the Tories. The Northern Ireland Secretary provoked the dark wrath of Gordon Brown, whose entourage swiftly let it be known that Mandelson should confine himself to dealing with the Prods and the Shinners.

There were several dimensions to the Chancellor's fury. Because the author of the remark was Mandelson; because Brown genuinely believes that it is destabilising for the Government to suggest that there is some sort of quick fix for the over-valuation of sterling; and because he is pathologically proprietorial about what he regards as his exclusive hemisphere.

The Chancellor wants to close down all debate on the single currency, at least until after the next election, which he plans to fight on his own estimable domestic economic record. Brown is convinced that the way to win the argument over Europe with the Tories is not to have it. His protagonist in Belfast believes that by avoiding the argument they are losing it to the Conservatives and the North American press. Mandelson has allies in Robin Cook, the Chancellor's auld enemy, and in Stephen Byers, the Trade & Industry Secretary. The latter's remarks about the single currency were much less prominently reported, but carried an even more significant indication of how febrile this struggle is becoming within the high commands of New Labour.

Bearing the scars of what the strength of the pound is doing to the car industry, Byers says: 'It is vital that we don't by default drift back to a policy of wait and see.' It is highly unusual for a Cabinet Minister to issue a public warning to the Government that its policy may be drift ing. I decode this to mean that Byers fears that the Chancellor has already slid into John Major's old position of wait and see.

What intrigues his colleagues is whether the Chancellor has drifted from one-time Europhile into a Eurosceptic. Gordon Brown is intellectually signed up to the idea of Europe. But, emotionally, he displays little empathy for the Continent. He prefers to take his holidays in Cape Cod, and import his ideas from across the Atlantic. From the workfare of the New Deal to his many tax credits, Brown displays himself to be a Yankophile.

His chief economist and closest confidant, Ed Balls, is euro-cautious. The Treasury, as an institution, has never much liked Europe, nor does the Bank of England. Brown does not get on with his European counterparts, partly because the son of the Manse is not a man with any time for Euro-smooching, and partly because he cannot bully other European finance ministers into submission as he does his Cabinet colleagues. I wouldn't go so far as one Minister, who says that 'Gordon hates Europe really', but the Chancellor is clearly not warm to the Continent.

The arbitrator of the Brown-Mandelson argument should be Tony Blair, but he is as much its object. A large element of their rivalry has always been to control the ear of the Prime Minister. Blair is conflicted. Brown seems to make sense when he tells the Prime Minister that they don't want to let the Tories turn the next election into a referendum about Europe. So best shut up about their real intent towards the single currency, even at the risk of the Prime Minister looking timid and evasive.

Mandelson is persuasive when he tells Blair that the influence in Europe he regards as so precious is being lost the more distant appears the prospect that Britain will join. The French and the Germans are now talking about creating a new, hard-core, fast-track élite based on the euro 11. Despite his best endeavours, Blair will never break into the Paris-Berlin axis as long as Britain is self-excluded from monetary union.

It's hard to believe that they will be able to keep the lid on this during the electric heat of an election campaign. The Conservatives and the media will apply intense pressure on Tony Blair to say where he truly stands on the euro, which will effectively be asking him to choose between Gordon Brown and Peter Mandelson, to pick between two rival versions of New Labour's future.

I wonder if they are already mocking up newspaper front pages over at Millbank to prepare them for the campaign. Mandelson and Blair in fight to the death: Labour lead plummets as Blair wrings hands in despair. At the next election, the nightmare scenario may not be fantasy headlines, but real ones.

It is highly unusual for a Cabinet Minister to issue a public warning to the Government that its policy may be drift ing. I decode this to mean that Byers fears that the Chancellor has already slid into John Major's old position of wait and see. What intrigues his colleagues is whether the Chancellor has drifted from one-time Europhile into a Eurosceptic. Gordon Brown is intellectually signed up to the idea of Europe. But, emotionally, he displays little empathy for the Continent. He prefers to take his holidays in Cape Cod, and import his ideas from across the Atlantic. From the workfare of the New Deal to his many tax credits, Brown displays himself to be a Yankophile. His chief economist and closest confidant, Ed Balls, is euro-cautious. The Treasury, as an institution, has never much liked Europe, nor does the Bank of England. Brown does not get on with his European counterparts, partly because the son of the Manse is not a man with any time for Euro-smooching, and partly because he cannot bully other European finance ministers into submission as he does his Cabinet colleagues. I wouldn't go so far as one Minister, who says that 'Gordon hates Europe really', but the Chancellor is clearly not warm to the Continent. The arbitrator of the Brown-Mandelson argument should be Tony Blair, but he is as much its object. A large element of their rivalry has always been to control the ear of the Prime Minister. Blair is conflicted. Brown seems to make sense when he tells the Prime Minister that they don't want to let the Tories turn the next election into a referendum about Europe. So best shut up about their real intent towards the single currency, even at the risk of the Prime Minister looking timid and evasive. Mandelson is persuasive when he tells Blair that the influence in Europe he regards as so precious is being lost the more distant appears the prospect that Britain will join. The French and the Germans are now talking about creating a new, hard-core, fast-track élite based on the euro 11. Despite his best endeavours, Blair will never break into the Paris-Berlin axis as long as Britain is self-excluded from monetary union. It's hard to believe that they will be able to keep the lid on this during the electric heat of an election campaign. The Conservatives and the media will apply intense pressure on Tony Blair to say where he truly stands on the euro, which will effectively be asking him to choose between Gordon Brown and Peter Mandelson, to pick between two rival versions of New Labour's future. I wonder if they are already mocking up newspaper front pages over at Millbank to prepare them for the campaign. Mandelson and Blair in fight to the death: Labour lead plummets as Blair wrings hands in despair. At the next election, the nightmare scenario may not be fantasy headlines, but real ones.

webTitle: No big cheeses for BBC board

fields.headline: No big cheeses for BBC board
fields.trailText: It is dubbed the 'Dyke diet' - a slimmed-down regime to keep the BBC, and its staff, lean and mean.
fields.body:
It is dubbed the 'Dyke diet' - a slimmed-down regime to keep the BBC, and its staff, lean and mean.

After banning croissants and taxis, and encouraging employees to walk or cycle to work, Greg Dyke has taken cheese, 'luxury biscuits' and 'international bread' off the menu, say insiders.

The new director general, who once scrawled 'haven't you heard of sandwiches?' on one extravagant journalist's expense claim, is said to be outraged that the BBC's catering and hospitality budget has ballooned.

At a recent boardroom dinner, BBC sources say, Dyke's jaw dropped when waiters brought in a huge cheeseboard. 'He said: "Bloody hell. We don't even have cheese like that at home when we have a posh dinner party. Get rid of it",' one senior BBC official said.

Dyke 'could not understand why "luxury and country range biscuits" cost 55p each,' one BBC source said. He derided 'Rustico Bloomer' and 'Italian Baguettes' at £17.95 and £18 each.

Dyke's decrees have been dismissed as daft penny-pinching by staff. 'When John Birt ran the show there was always cheese - and biscuits - and croissants at meetings,' one said. 'What's next? Will we soon be forced to bring in Thermos flasks of lukewarm team and garibaldis wrapped in tin foil to keep us going?'

Not all staff have been forced to reacquaint themselves with greasy spoon eateries, however. Senior news executives have special permission to woo new recruits - such as political editor Andrew Marr- at the £50-a-head River Café and the pricey Halcyon Hotel in Holland Park.

webTitle: Saddam in secret talks with Israel

fields.headline: Saddam in secret talks with Israel
fields.standfirst: Iraqi ruler offers peace with West in return for taking Palestinian refugees
fields.trailText: Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi dictator, has made an astonishing bid for peace with the West after months of secret talks with the Israeli government.
fields.byline: Jason Burke, Paul Beaver and Ed Vulliamy, New York
fields.body:
Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi dictator, has made an astonishing bid for peace with the West after months of secret talks with the Israeli government.

At a series of meetings held over the past 15 months, Saddam's representatives have repeatedly told the Israelis that, if Jerusalem works to end Iraq's diplomatic isolation, Baghdad will arrange for more than 300,000 Palestinian refugees living in Lebanon to be airlifted to new lives in Iraq and will tone down its hostile rhetoric towards the Jewish state.

Lebanon's Palestinian population poses the most significant security threat following the Israelis' planned withdrawal from the south of the country later this summer, and moving them to Iraq would solve a significant problem for Jerusalem. It would also mark one of the most significant shifts in regional politics in decades.

The secret discussions will embarrass the Foreign Office which supports the Americans' hardline policy aimed at isolating Iraq.

Official sources in Washington, London, Amman and Jerusalem last week confirmed the contacts between the two nations and the Iraqi proposal. Senior US State Department sources told The Observer: 'We know that this is being talked about. No agreement has been finalised but we are pretty confident it is going to happen.'

An airlift moving the refugees - which would cost more than $100 million (£60m) - would be funded by Israel and its supporters overseas, the State Department source said.

On at least three occasions over the past 20 years Iraq and Israel have held talks - always when Saddam's regime has been under pressure. Israel is keen to neutralise any possible threats from other countries. However, it could merely be humouring Saddam to gain leverage elsewhere in the region.

'Saddam is the consummate pragmatist. He will talk to anyone if he thinks it will help him... He will offer whatever he thinks they want most,' said one former aide of the Iraqi dictator last week.

The Observer has established that representatives of the two countries have met at least four times. The first meeting was at the funeral of King Hussein of Jordan in Amman in February last year when a senior Israeli politician had two conversations with Taha Mohieddin Maarouf, the Iraqi Vice-President. 'It was just protocol though, nothing substantive,' said one Iraqi opposition source in London. The meeting in Amman was confirmed by a Jordanian official.

Later in the spring a second meeting occurred in Athens between an American businessman with strong Israeli connections and a diplomat from a Middle Eastern country supportive of Iraq. A number of issues were discussed including the lifting of specified sanctions and the translocation of the Palestinians. Late last year Nizar Hamdoun, the Iraqi deputy Foreign Minister and former ambassador to the United Nations, travelled to America to further contacts with Jewish groups and representatives of the Israeli government in New York and Washington.

At a series of meetings the question of the movement of the Palestinians to Iraq was raised though no commitments were made. Hamdoun is known as a smooth diplomat with a good reputation internationally. 'He has kept himself distanced from the ugliness of the rest of the regime,' said one Iraq expert.

The most recent meeting known to The Observer occurred last February in Amman though it is unclear who attended. Intelligence sources in Jerusalem confirmed last week that discussions between representatives of Israel and Iraq are continuing. Saddam's favoured son Qusay - recently appointed head of the regime's security operation - is thought to be in overall charge of the talks.

The idea of moving the Palestinian refugees in Lebanon to Iraq has been raised before though this is the first time Baghdad has ever talked practically about how to execute the plan.

The current sanctions regime imposed on Iraq by the United Nations - and maintained through strong pressure from London and Washington - has shattered Iraq's economy but done nothing to weaken Saddam's grip. The Iraqi dictator is increasingly constrained by the current situation.

The contacts will cause serious concern in Whitehall. Britain has doggedly followed the Americans' hardline despite increasing criticism. The diplomacy pursued by Israel will be a significant embarrassment for the Americans and the British who have repeatedly called for a united front.

Experts say there are many reasons for the contacts between Baghdad and Jerusalem. 'Both governments have significant amounts to gain,' said Said Aburish, a biographer of both Saddam and Yasser Arafat and a former adviser to the Iraqi regime.

fields.headline: Hizbollah harries hated Israelis
fields.standfirst: Guerrillas step up attacks as Barak seeks to complete withdrawal of army from southern Lebanon
fields.trailText: The Israeli army, retreating from southern Lebanon after 22 years, is coming under heavy fire from Hizbollah guerrillas determined to show they have the enemy on the run at last.
fields.body:
The Israeli army, retreating from southern Lebanon after 22 years, is coming under heavy fire from Hizbollah guerrillas determined to show they have the enemy on the run at last.

According to Israeli press reports, the army faces ever heavier casualties in its final days in Lebanon , with the guerrillas bringing in tanks and other heavy weapons.

Hizbollah attacks on the Israeli army and its proxy militia, the South Lebanese Army, have doubled over the past month. In reply, Israeli warplanes have stepped up punitive sorties against Lebanon, bombing almost daily.

With Israel at last prepared to heed the United Nations and the Arab world, which have been demanding it quit Lebanon ever since it invaded to flush out Palestinian guerrillas in 1978, the withdrawal is turning into a recipe for further conflict. All signs are that the present attacks are only a prelude for what lies in store when the Israelis return to their side of the international border.

Without an agreement with Syria for an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied Golan Heights, the army is having to fight its way out of Lebanon.

Last Thursday, three Israeli soldiers and two members of the SLA were injured by shelling of the Reihan post, inside the nine-mile strip that Israel has occupied for 22 years. Dozens of mortar shells fell on the Israeli side of the frontier in western Galilee overnight and three more SLA men were hurt 24 hours earlier in attacks by the Islamist militia.

Within the Israeli defence establishment, the surge in fighting is seen as an effort to draw Israel into a larger conflict in the dying days of the occupation, and to prove Hizbollah's claim that it has forced the occupier to flee.

Almost unnoticed by the world last week, Israel handed over the Taibe and Rotem posts in the central and western part of its self-declared security zone to the SLA. Two other positions were moved behind the line that Israel claims as the international border, as yet unrecognised by the United Nations.

'The more outposts the Israeli Defence Forces vacate, the more non-vital equipment the army removes from positions deep in Lebanon, the more Hizbollah steps up its attacks,' said Yoav Krakovsky, a correspondent for Israel Radio. Israel's Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, has admitted he expects the fighting to escalate in the weeks before his 7 July deadline for final withdrawal.

Officially, the transfer of base camps, equipment and soldiers to positions within Israel represents only preparatory moves towards the withdrawal. On the Israeli side of the border, the army is building roads and fences, and is to begin construction of an electronic surveillance system today.

Military officials are coy about revealing the exact date for completing the withdrawal, for fear this would invite more attacks on its positions and on its SLA allies. They are also conscious of the mounting panic among residents of northern kibbutzim and towns, who are horrified at the prospect of being only yards from a border that could be easily infiltrated by guerrillas.

The Israeli media report a rift between Israel's generals, who are chafing for a rapid-fire withdrawal within the next week or two, and Barak who wants to slow the pace.

Barak is also under popular pressure to pull out fast, with Israelis increasingly unwilling to tolerate further casualties in Lebanon.

Barak is hoping to draw Lebanon into an agreement on keeping peace in the border region. Hope of an agreement with Syria has all but evaporated.

Israel is also trying to win United Nations support to bolster and expand the mandate of the peacekeeping force that has monitored south Lebanon since 1978. UN tours of duty are hazardous; the UN Interim Force for Lebanon has lost 234 men since 1978.

Israeli diplomats have extracted promises from 11 countries to send additional forces to bring the UN force up to its full strength of 7,000 men, from the present 4,500. Israel is also reported to have agreed to UN conditions for the expansion of the force: the payment of higher UN dues, the release of inmates from the notorious al-Khayyam prison it maintains in south Lebanon, and stripping the SLA of tanks and heavy artillery. But Israel has refused to take away the SLA's light arms for fear of increasing panic among the 2,500 militiamen and their families.

'As long as it is not safe for them, they are going to have to protect themselves in the Lebanese way,' Israeli deputy Defence Minister Efraim Sneh said. 'They will have the means to defend themselves.' Twenty SLA fighters have been killed this year and most are terrified of the fate awaiting them in a country that views them as traitors. While the SLA commander, Antoine Lahad, has prepared his getaway to a Paris flat, other senior leaders are seeking asylum in Israel.

For lesser men in the SLA, flight is not an option. In the past two weeks alone, at least 12 have defected to Hizbollah, or the Amal militia, or surrendered to Lebanese authorities.

webTitle: Watch closely: it's our turn to judge Cherie

fields.headline: Watch closely: it's our turn to judge Cherie
fields.standfirst: Should she use disposables? Feed on demand? It all becomes more crucial when the spotlight's turned on you
fields.trailText: So, what's it to be? Cashmere baby leggings by Clements Ribiera or Baby Gap and M&S? Will there be terry-towelling nappies permanently on the washing line for the benefit of the eco-friendly paparazzi and a cellarful of disposable nappies? And what do you bet, bottle or breast?
fields.body:
So, what's it to be? Cashmere baby leggings by Clements Ribiera or Baby Gap and M&S? Will there be terry-towelling nappies permanently on the washing line for the benefit of the eco-friendly paparazzi and a cellarful of disposable nappies? And what do you bet, bottle or breast?

For weeks to come, we'll all be going natal, until the nation screams for a break. It's tough on us but far tougher on Cherie. We'll be watching her - and judging. In the run-up to the general election, how the public reacts to bringing up baby will matter a great deal.

Cherie Booth's achievement so far is that, as a feminist, she has managed to adapt the traditional role of Prime Minister's wife to allow a degree of independence, carefully choosing when to step out of her husband's shadow - for instance, on domestic violence or parental leave. The politics of motherhood may be an altogether trickier game: every decision she makes will turn a floodlight on the poverty of options available to others.

'It's about choice,' says Harriet Harman who, as a backbench MP, has pushed hard for improved parental rights. 'The decisions that Cherie Booth makes should be treated as a demonstration of the right of every woman to exercise a similar amount of freedom with sufficient financial support.'

Cherie Booth depends greatly on money. A working-class girl made good, she has plenty of it and can buy the very best care. But the cost of childcare makes poor men and women of even the residents of Middle England.

Leo Blair's arrival coincides with the start of National Childcare Week. Childcare has become a central plank of New Labour's attempt to create a New Britain, in which most are expected to work. A national childcare strategy has been launched; a review of maternity rights and benefits is due; the Working Family Tax Credit and the Childcare Credit have given, on average, £30 a week for childcare to 100,000 low-income families.

But according to a Mori poll published tomorrow and commissioned by the Daycare Trust, 75 per cent of the public does not believe working mothers have sufficient access to affordable childcare and almost half say employers do not do enough to support mothers returning to work.

If Cherie didn't have cause to consider the question before, she may now. She's shown herself to be too committed to social justice not to care and too canny not to recognise how she can exercise a lever for change. So, in the first year of her baby's life, what personal choices and public pronouncements might she make? Will she stay quiet or will she become not just the champion of parental leave but a protagonist for the right of all children to have the very best beginnings?

Cherie is self-employed and allegedly earning £150,000 or more a year. If she was an employee without additional contractual rights, she would be entitled to 18 weeks paid maternity allowance; six weeks at 90 per cent of her wage, the rest at only £60.20 a week - a sum which has halved in value since 1964. It doesn't take a review to know that maternity pay in Britain is too low, too limited and too bureaucratic.

Harriet Harman has come up with a 15-point plan which concentrates particularly on a baby's first 12 months. She suggests maternity leave is extended from six to 12 months and the right to return to a job part-time. In addition, she is calling for grants to small employers to encourage them to accept this proposal; increased benefits to low-income families and a baby tax credit to help with the expense of childcare for the very young, or to enable a parent to remain at home for the first year.

The Blairs have already announced that Cherie's mother will initially take care of the baby. This could not be more core Labour. According to research, only 18 per cent of professionals use relatives to look after their children; in contrast 44 per cent of the manual classes rely on granny, aunts and sisters.

At a later stage, perhaps to allow Baby Blair to have some life outside Numbers 10 and 11, a nursery might be considered. It is at this point that Cherie will learn that across Britain, there is a desperate shortage of baby places, no matter how much money the parents have to offer. It is even tougher for those groups New Labour has pledged to assist most.

'If you are a low-income earner living in a disadvantaged area, the chances of finding your baby a nursery are as likely as getting him into Eton,' says Colette Kelleher of the Daycare Centre.

Even where there is provision, problems exist. At present, half the staff in the childcare industry are unqualified; turnover is high; motivation poor; training inadequate. Who works hard for a BA in childhood studies, only to be offered £4 an hour in a nursery? Of course, good-quality nurseries and highly skilled nannies exist but even as the expensive private sector expands, so the affordable subsidised public sector is being squeezed. Out of 6,000 nurseries, for instance, there are only 250 which are non-profit-making.

Cherie is returning to work in September as one of 22 barristers in the newly created Matrix Chambers, dealing primarily with human rights issues. She returned even more rapidly after the birth of her first three children. 'She is,' says Harman, 'unfazed and without guilt on the issue. We should respect her choice.'

Only 5 per cent of employers contribute towards childcare costs; 5 per cent offer a workplace nursery and 2 per cent have reserved nursery places - figures which have remained unchanged since New Labour came to power. The government's 'light touch' has patently failed. Cherie therefore might decide to support those who advocate stronger government pressure so British bosses, like their European counterparts, treat childcare not as a 'perk' but an employment right.

Cherie Booth has always rationed her public utterances, maximising her impact when she does choose to speak. In the lull before the party conferences, she may give her first post-birth interview in which she makes the case for improved benefits; better maternity leave; high quality affordable childcare; paid parental leave and more input from employers.

The Daily Mail may consider tearing her to shreds but, before it does, it should take a readers' poll. This would reveal Cherie speaks with the voice of Mother Middle England.

A year after the arrival of Baby Leo, it may be the Tories who end up with the baby blues.

Harriet Harman has come up with a 15-point plan which concentrates particularly on a baby's first 12 months. She suggests maternity leave is extended from six to 12 months and the right to return to a job part-time. In addition, she is calling for grants to small employers to encourage them to accept this proposal; increased benefits to low-income families and a baby tax credit to help with the expense of childcare for the very young, or to enable a parent to remain at home for the first year. The Blairs have already announced that Cherie's mother will initially take care of the baby. This could not be more core Labour. According to research, only 18 per cent of professionals use relatives to look after their children; in contrast 44 per cent of the manual classes rely on granny, aunts and sisters. At a later stage, perhaps to allow Baby Blair to have some life outside Numbers 10 and 11, a nursery might be considered. It is at this point that Cherie will learn that across Britain, there is a desperate shortage of baby places, no matter how much money the parents have to offer. It is even tougher for those groups New Labour has pledged to assist most. 'If you are a low-income earner living in a disadvantaged area, the chances of finding your baby a nursery are as likely as getting him into Eton,' says Colette Kelleher of the Daycare Centre. Even where there is provision, problems exist. At present, half the staff in the childcare industry are unqualified; turnover is high; motivation poor; training inadequate. Who works hard for a BA in childhood studies, only to be offered £4 an hour in a nursery? Of course, good-quality nurseries and highly skilled nannies exist but even as the expensive private sector expands, so the affordable subsidised public sector is being squeezed. Out of 6,000 nurseries, for instance, there are only 250 which are non-profit-making. Cherie is returning to work in September as one of 22 barristers in the newly created Matrix Chambers, dealing primarily with human rights issues. She returned even more rapidly after the birth of her first three children. 'She is,' says Harman, 'unfazed and without guilt on the issue. We should respect her choice.' Only 5 per cent of employers contribute towards childcare costs; 5 per cent offer a workplace nursery and 2 per cent have reserved nursery places - figures which have remained unchanged since New Labour came to power. The government's 'light touch' has patently failed. Cherie therefore might decide to support those who advocate stronger government pressure so British bosses, like their European counterparts, treat childcare not as a 'perk' but an employment right. Cherie Booth has always rationed her public utterances, maximising her impact when she does choose to speak. In the lull before the party conferences, she may give her first post-birth interview in which she makes the case for improved benefits; better maternity leave; high quality affordable childcare; paid parental leave and more input from employers. The Daily Mail may consider tearing her to shreds but, before it does, it should take a readers' poll. This would reveal Cherie speaks with the voice of Mother Middle England. A year after the arrival of Baby Leo, it may be the Tories who end up with the baby blues.

webTitle: Leo senior's rise from slum boy to successful barrister

fields.headline: Leo senior's rise from slum boy to successful barrister
fields.standfirst: The grandfather he is named after was born to entertainers and given up soon after birth, says Sarah Ryle
fields.trailText: The new Leo Blair has been born into a life of privilege and stability that could not be more different from the world his grandfather - who he is named after - entered in August 1923.
fields.body:
The new Leo Blair has been born into a life of privilege and stability that could not be more different from the world his grandfather - who he is named after - entered in August 1923.

Leo senior was the son of travelling entertainers who gave him up to a poor Clydeside shipyard worker, James Blair, and his wife, Mary. But details of his origins were shrouded in mystery, with Leo himself unaware of much of his 'real' family's life.

Mary Blair was determined to obliterate her foster child's true beginnings. While he was away on active service in the Second World War, she told his mother and his half-sisters that he was missing, presumed dead. They accepted her story.

It was only after Tony Blair became Labour leader that press articles prompted a reunion which enabled Leo to fit the scattered pieces of his life together.

His real parents, Celia Ridgeway and Charles Parsons, were not married when Leo was born in Filey, North Yorkshire. Celia was the daughter of a wealthy West Sussex landowner. She married at 17 and had two daughters, Jenefee and Pauline, before she became a dancer and started a relationship with Leo's father. The social stigma, combined with the family's lifestyle, prompted his parents to give up their baby to the Blairs, who they met while on tour in Glasgow.

Mary had had two miscarriages and feared she would never have children. She adored Leo, who accompanied her on left-wing rallies. When he left school he worked as a copy boy on the Communist Party newspaper Daily Worker and was secretary of the Scottish Young Communist League from 1938 to 1941.

While he was away during the war, Mary Blair burned the contents of a biscuit tin he kept under his bed: treasured letters, cards and photographs from his sisters and real mother, whom he had last seen when he was 13. Celia had come to ask if she might have Leo back but Mary, apparently, threatened to kill herself. Leo had by then decided that 'Ma Blair' was his real mother and opted to stay in Glasgow.

Leo challenged Mary about the missing tin but he did not know she had killed him off. He did not question the sudden halt in the once-regular flow of correspondence from his blood relatives, believing he had been forgotten by them.

A year after he returned from the army, Leo changed his name by deed poll from Leo Charles Augusta Parsons to Leo Charles Lynton Blair - names inherited by his youngest son.

A classic self-made man, Leo studied law in his spare time and became a barrister and a law lecturer at Durham University. His ambition to be a somebody led him to radical reform of his politics. He became chairman of the Durham Conservative Association and was an admirer of Thatcher and Tebbit.

He spent considerable energy grooming his son Tony who, at 12, stood as a Conservative 'candidate' in his school's mock elections. Leo's own political dreams were effectively dashed two years earlier when he suffered a stroke, aged 40.

By 1995, Tony was leader of the Labour Party and Leo, then chairing the industrial tribunal in Shrewsbury where he now lives, underwent another political conversion at the age of 71. He joined the Labour Party, citing objections to rail privatisation and pride at his son's achievement.

The publicity about Blair's leadership caught the attention of Leo's half-sister Pauline Harding in 1994; by then she was 90 years old, living in Ealing and still in possession of a last, battered photograph of her half-brother.

She contacted the Blair family and this led to a reunion which Jenefee was too senile to attend. After 50 years apart, the meeting at the Islington home of Leo's oldest son, Bill, was emotional. Leo recalled: 'Pauline and I were so overcome we stood hugging each other and she kept saying: "What wasted years? What wasted years?"'

Tony Blair has spoken of his closeness to his father, whom he has described as a 'very ambitious man, successful, a go-getter'. But Leo remains his own man. He and his second wife, Olwyn (his first wife Hazel, Tony's mother, died of throat cancer in 1975) are believed to have taken out private health insurance earlier this year - a propaganda coup for the Tory party.

webTitle: A Taurean who just wants to be noticed

fields.headline: A Taurean who just wants to be noticed
fields.trailText: Born on the last day of Taurus, at 12.25 am, Leo Blair is no Lion but a full-blooded Bull like his father.
fields.body:
Born on the last day of Taurus, at 12.25 am, Leo Blair is no Lion but a full-blooded Bull like his father.

Taureans are invariably described as cautious, practical people, dependable but stubborn. Since Taurus is the sign of Mother Earth in full bloom, its subjects are reckoned natural artists and economists. In the case of Leo, all such bullish qualities are likely to be magnified.

As well as the Sun, three other planets occupy the sign in his horoscope, including the giant planets of Jupiter and Saturn. All this would suggest a jolly but thoroughly conservative personality, except that Leo has a streak of radicalism, thanks to an emphasis on Aquarius. In this he is like his father.

Finding the balance between the traditionalism of Taurus and the revolutionary spirit of Aquarius is a major challenge for both father and son. The contradiction can be seen in the way Tony Blair has pushed through huge changes to the constitutions of his party and his country while continuing to be seen as a conservative.

For Leo, writing or politics might provide a way to reconcile these two strains, since Mercury, the planet of the writer, orator and communicator, is powerfully positioned. Whatever path he chooses, Leo is unlikely to be content with a low-visibility role.

How is the latest addition to the Blair household likely to get along with his parents as he is growing up? If anything, father and son are a little too alike. The horoscopes of Tony and Cherie share many overlaps, so it's no surprise that Leo's relationship with his mother also looks harmonious. Like Leo, Cherie has her Sun in an earth sign, Virgo, and her Moon (representing feelings) in a fire sign.

webTitle: No precedent for the nappy factor

fields.headline: No precedent for the nappy factor
fields.standfirst: Tories fear the worst, but some at Number 10 are wary of a Leo media nightmare
fields.trailText: We've had Prime Ministers who extended their leases on power with 'khaki' elections. Will a cooing electorate sweep New Labour back to a second term in the first ever 'nappy' election?
fields.body:
We've had Prime Ministers who extended their leases on power with 'khaki' elections. Will a cooing electorate sweep New Labour back to a second term in the first ever 'nappy' election?

Though no leading politician will be so indelicate as to talk about this in public, it has privately been the subject of weeks of pre-nativity calculation. 'It has to be good for us, hasn't it?' a Cabinet Minister told me recently.

There is no precedent. The last Prime Minister with a baby at Number 10, Lord John Russell, was in office 150 years ago, long before Dr Gallup and Mr Mori were in business to poll whether it would be a winner with the voters.

The flowers sent to Tony and Cherie by William and Ffion Hague were not poison ivy, but the Tory leader's message of congratulations on a 'happy day for the country as a whole' was surely written through gritted teeth.

The Tories think that this demonstrates once again Tony Blair's genius for goo, a talent which plays well with women voters. At Conservative Central Office, they are resigned to a Nappy Factor in the polls.

Oddly enough, the prognosis that little Leo can only be good for the Government is not universally shared within Number 10. 'We can't win,' groans one of Blair's closest aides, anticipating a 'nightmare' with the media. If the baby is kept swaddled from intrusion, the tabloids will go sour.

If Number 10 provides lots of happy family snaps, Blair will be accused of cynically using his newborn son to manipulate the public. Even before the birth, much of the media commentary was beginning to strike a bitchy note.

The voters' main judgment on the Government will, as usual, turn on its performance in handling public services and the economy. But perceptions are also shaped by whether the electorate thinks of a leader as strong and in touch with the country.

Here, I suspect, the baby will have a subliminally positive effect for the Prime Minister. 'Tony doesn't fire blanks,' was the joking tribute from one Minister to the leader's virility.

Voters will also spot a distinction between Blair and all his leading opponents, a contrast which he was gently guiding the voters towards within hours of the birth.

'I feel like any father who has seen his baby born,' he glowed yesterday. 'It's a very moving experience.' The point is that the words 'like any father' cannot be uttered by the leading lights of the Conservative front bench.

The top three Tories are all childless. There are no little Michael Portillos. Ann Widdecombe is a virgin. Even if William and Ffion do have a baby, it will now be catch-up with the Blairs.

There is no Charles Kennedy Junior, nor a Son Of Newt for Ken Livingstone. And the man who is arguably the Prime Minister's most dangerous rival is also without an heir: Gordon Brown remains a steadfast bachelor.

I think it does make a difference to the party battle. When Hague, Portillo and Widdecombe talk about the importance of family, they may speak with sincerity and conviction, but they can talk only in the abstract. It's not real life for them.

That registers with the electoral audience. Tony Blair will find it easier to convince voters that he empathises with the fears of parents for their children's health and education when he's got hands-on experience of both the joys and the messy end of child-rearing. Literally so, if he keeps his promise to Cherie to do the middle-of-the-night nappies.

And even if all this doesn't produce a baby bouncer in the polls, there is one undeniable advantage to Tony Blair as he runs up to the next election campaign. He will be the first Prime Minister of the television age to have his own baby to kiss.

webTitle: Bringing up baby in  public and private

fields.headline: Bringing up baby in  public and private
fields.standfirst: Downing Street advisers face some tough choices if the world's media are to be placated without being overfed
fields.trailText: When Tony Blair stepped blinking into the bright world outside Number 10 yesterday morning, he looked as relieved as any new father would be a few hours after the birth of a healthy baby son.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair stepped blinking into the bright world outside Number 10 yesterday morning, he looked as relieved as any new father would be a few hours after the birth of a healthy baby son.

But the genuine sponataeity of the moment when he talked about his joy at Leo's birth belied a carefully-crafted strategy to ensure that the media were given enough glimpses of the event to whet an enormous public appetite.

The strategists knew that they had to find a way of dealing with the huge national and international clamour for pictures, comments and details of a baby that has just become the hottest of political hot properties.

Downing Street has always known that this was going to be difficult: treading the fine line between the public's appetite for news and not leaving themselves open to accusations that they were manipulating the situation for their own ends.

Downing Street aides have thought long and hard about the next few days.

Today or tomorrow one picture of Tony, Cherie and the new baby, Leo, will be released. A few days later a second picture of the whole Blair family will be released for sale to the media with any proceeds going to a charity picked by the Blairs.

Then, a few days later again, Cherie and the family will appear on the steps of No 10 for the sake of the cameras which are likely to be camped at the end of Downing Street for the foreseeable future. Cherie will certainly be urged to say something by reporters but it will be left to her as to whether she does.

Such a drip, drip approach to the baby's first week leaves Downing Street open to accusations that it is using the situation to its own advantage. But Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, knows he is in a no win situation. Do nothing and the media will go apoplectic. Do too much and the accusations will start.

When the Blairs announced that they were to have their fourth child last autumn, Campbell argued strongly that it was a private matter that would not be given publicity by the Prime Minister.

But as the due date approached it became increasingly clear that such a strategy would not hold. The first real crack appeared in March when Blair appeared to be left flat-footed when the Today presenter, John Humphrys, asked him if he was going to take paternity leave.

'To be completely honest, I haven't thought about it properly yet,' Blair said. 'I know I should have, and I am sure I will. I will decide in the next few weeks. I know I have got to decide soon.'

The answer started a welter of speculation and debate which raged in the newspapers. Any new political issue of paternity, maternity or family rights was immediately linked to the event.

And then there were the polls. As Blair's record popularity ratings finally began to fail it was clear that the baby was almost guaranteed to increase the Prime Minister's standing.

On the issue of the baby and fatherhood Blair could hardly fail. Campbell knew that Blair would have to say something. An interview had already been arranged with this newspaper in April when Campbell was told that one of the questions would be on paternity.

This time Blair was better prepared. 'I don't ever stop being Prime Minister,' he said. 'But of course I want to spend more time with Cherie when the kid is born to help out and I will do that.

'I don't know if that makes [it] paternity leave _ but it is just the common sense of the situation. I obviously will try as much as possible to cut down in that period what I'm doing.'

The message was reiterated in an interveiw with the New York Times last weekend. In it he made clear his love of his family and that they really were a 'normal' bunch of people. Again it was picked up, again it played positively.

But overall the government's messages are mixed. Baby arrives to father who happens to be Prime Minister - good thing.

The day before Labour MP and mother Tess Kingham announces that she is leaving the Commons because it is almost impossible for anyone who believes in a modern way of working to operate in Parliament's dusty corridors - bad thing.

Fortunately for the Labour project, Leo Blair will get far more coverage than Tess Kingham.

But there are still the major problems of women's dissaffection with the results of the Blair government. There are still the problems of delivering the Government's pledges. There is still Northern Ireland, the high pound, Dagenham.

A few pictures of a smiling son will help. But they are not a solution.

webTitle: Police in hunt for British agent

fields.headline: Police in hunt for British agent
fields.standfirst: Former Army undercover officer wanted for revealing 'dirty tricks'
fields.trailText: A military intelligence officer who leaked details of army 'dirty tricks' operations and the recruitment of IRA informants in Northern Ireland now faces prosecution under the Official Secrets Act.
fields.body:
A military intelligence officer who leaked details of army 'dirty tricks' operations and the recruitment of IRA informants in Northern Ireland now faces prosecution under the Official Secrets Act.

The Metropolitan Police are seeking to arrest and charge the soldier, who uses the pseudonym 'Martin Ingrams', for disclosing information about his role in the undercover Force Research Unit, an elite army undercover squad operating in the Province.

Ingrams claims the FRU broke into and then burnt down an office in 1990 used by John Stevens, the English police officer in charge of investigating claims of collusion between the security forces and loyalist terrorists.

A senior RUC officer has confirmed that the 'hunt is on for Ingrams'. He said both the Met and the RUC, along with the Ministry of Defence, were particularly concerned about Ingrams's revelation that the security forces ran a high-ranking agent inside the IRA, codenamed 'Steak Knife'.

The RUC officer described Ingrams's claims about the IRA agent as 'absolutely on the knuckle'. The security forces fear that the soldier's allegations have enabled the IRA to identify the informer at the highest echelons of the republican movement.

'If they can find Ingrams, they will prosecute him. Some of his claims are true, the others fantasy,' the police officer said.

It is understood that several fellow FRU members who worked with Ingrams in Northern Ireland have agreed to testify against him. A number of FRU soldiers have been questioned about Ingrams including the author Rob Lewis (not his real name). Lewis wrote a book about the Force Research Unit, Fishers of Men , in which he described how the FRU recruited and protected agents from inside the IRA.

Ingrams's most devastating claim is that the FRU burgled and then set fire to the offices of the Stevens Inquiry in January 1990. The inquiry team's headquarters inside the RUC's heavily fortified Seapark complex near Carrickfergus was the centre of an investigation into claims of collusion between both the police and army and loyalist terror groups.

fields.headline: Blairs greet their 'gorgeous' Leo
fields.standfirst: Euan Ferguson in Downing Street reports on the first baby born to a Prime Minister in 150 years
fields.trailText: The first Leo was born the illegitimate son of travelling entertainers who gave him away to equally penniless Red Clydesiders, handing him over with his past rattling in a biscuit tin. The second Leo, his grandson, was born early yesterday to the most popular British Prime Minister since surveys began and taken home to Downing Street.
fields.body:
The first Leo was born the illegitimate son of travelling entertainers who gave him away to equally penniless Red Clydesiders, handing him over with his past rattling in a biscuit tin. The second Leo, his grandson, was born early yesterday to the most popular British Prime Minister since surveys began and taken home to Downing Street.

'Cherie and the baby are absolutely fine. He's a gorgeous little boy,' said Tony Blair, blinking away exhaustion in the sunshine outside Number 10 yesterday as he addressed the world's press, who had been camping out since Cherie Blair went into labour the preceding night, days earlier than expected. The birth was natural, he confirmed, although the labour had been long. Cherie Blair, 45, had never planned a caesarean section, although she knew there was a risk one might have been ordered on medical grounds.

'It was quite a struggle in the end for Cherie,' said her husband, 'and I think she is very relieved it's all over.' He was present throughout: a first for him. His other children were 'thrilled. They've all been holding him and taking pictures with him and everything.'

Leo Blair, weighing 6lb 12oz, was born at 12.25am yesterday in London's Chelsea and Westminster Hospital, 11 hours after Cherie was first taken there. He is already being quoted odds of 1000-1 to follow father Tony as PM (although, it has to be said, the bookies were offering the same odds on Friday that the new baby would be named Lionel).

Instead, he is named after Blair's own father - a 67-year-old former barrister now living in Shrewsbury - who said after being given the news just after the birth: 'It's great, it's really great. It's very exciting.'

His was one of the earliest reactions in what became a day of phone calls and flowers, after a long night which Blair and the press shared awake, he changing nappies while Cherie slept.

Tony had arrived at the hospital at around 8.30pm on Friday night, after what is understood to have been a hectic day of meetings and briefings, on Northern Ireland in particular.

He looked rather drawn yesterday when he spoke to reporters, while a small gaggle of tourists tried to wave their congratulations from behind the gates at the end of the street. Tired, drawn and occasionally stammering - yet strangely relaxed, happy, and significantly more natural than the image the public has grown used to since ... well, since the last time he seemed this relaxed and natural, when he first walked into Downing Street three years ago.

Clutching a coffee mug, he explained: 'I was there, and it was the first. I missed my middle one because he came very early. My eldest there were problems with, and my daughter was a caesarean but it's the first time I have seen the whole thing through. It's quite a struggle.

'I feel... I feel like any father who sees their baby being born. It's very moving really, and if any of you have been through it you'll know. He's been really good through the night. The thing is, you forget how tiny they are, and also changing nappies in the middle of the night.'

Blair, the first PM to father a child in office since Lord John Russell 150 years ago, will now go into 'holiday mode', the limited paternity leave he first revealed in The Observer last month. His diary has been largely cleared but he will still be at key events this week: a meeting of Labour's NEC on Tuesday, Question Time on Wednesday and the Cabinet on Thursday. Parliament then goes into recess.

The first congratulatory call, other than those from close family and friends, came from, of all people, John Major. Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy led the current politicians' congratulations, saying, 'I am absolutely delighted for Tony and Cherie. The most important thing now is that everyone respects their right to privacy and peace for a decent interval.'

The Blairs' other children Euan, 16, Nicky, 14, and Kathryn, 12, have been kept out of the spotlight, and No 10 is insisting on the same treatment for Leo. There was no suggestion that it would agree to frantic photographers' requests yesterday to 'at least hold the baby up to the window'. A Downing Street spokesman explained, succinctly, 'Cherie is knackered.'

William Hague was soon in touch, saying 'Ffion and I were delighted to hear of the birth ... and we send our congratulations to them and their children.' Hillary Clinton telephoned Cherie yesterday afternoon, and Bill Clinton is said to be 'delighted'.

Flowers went through the Downing Street gates from, among others, Cherie's law chambers, the Booth family - father Tony later said, 'I was telephoned in the early hours to be given this wonderful news. I know both his parents and brothers and sister are completely besotted with him. The most important thing is that Cherie and the baby are well' - and from Lord Chancellor Derry Irvine. At about noon, a large bouquet arrived from the Queen and Prince Philip.

At least, we think it was. 'Can't tell you who that was from, mate,' winked the Royal Mail driver as he waited to turn back into the Whitehall traffic. 'But put it this way ... someone important. More important even than ...' and a nod back to Downing Street.

But is she? The small crowds waiting by the gates, the vast bulk of whom were passing tourists, were split over whether a Blair birth was as important as a royal birth. 'Absolutely,' said Sharon McLennan, from Vancouver. 'Who cares about the royals any more... this family are at least real people.' But 'he's just a politician,' countered the Tallis family, down from Yorkshire for the day in London and frankly more interested in their view of the London Eye than in Downing Street. 'What a happy day for them, of course, but we really don't care that much. And you lot should leave that baby alone.'

Nearby, an elderly mother and daughter passed, supremely missing the point by pointing out to each other that 'that's where Mrs Thatcher used to live'.

fields.headline: Relatives may sue Lockerbie charity
fields.standfirst: Trust rejects requests for financial help from families of Pan Am bomb victims
fields.trailText: Relatives of three British victims of the Lockerbie bombing have been refused financial help by the trust fund responsible for distributing the money left over from public donations in the wake of the disaster.
fields.body:
Relatives of three British victims of the Lockerbie bombing have been refused financial help by the trust fund responsible for distributing the money left over from public donations in the wake of the disaster.

Some of the relatives are now considering legal action against the trust, which they accuse of ignoring their needs in order to concentrate on funding community projects in Lockerbie, The Observer has learnt.

The families wrote to the trust to seek help with the costs of their 11-year struggle to establish the truth behind the explosion on Pan Am flight 103 over the town on 21 December 1988, which killed all 259 passengers and crew and 11 Lockerbie residents.

In particular, they asked for assistance to cover the expense of travelling back to attend the trial of two Libyans accused of carrying out the bombing at a specially constructed Scottish court at Camp Zeist in the Netherlands. But on Friday they were told that the trustees' legal advice stated that they did not have the power to make such payments and so they had decided to deny their applications.

The decision has left the families feeling angry and isolated. Pamela Dix, whose brother Peter was a passenger on flight 103, told The Observer 'We are very disappointed that they have rejected our applications. We are not doing this for financial gratification. I was not eligible for compensation from Pan Am and have received only £300 in help since the death of my brother.'

John Mosey, whose 19-year-old daughter Helga was killed, said: 'We are saddened by this but not surprised. It is not that we begrudge the people of Lockerbie this money, but there should be enough there to help us as well.'

But Marjorie McQueen, a Dumfries and Galloway councillor and a trustee, said: 'I can understand the disappointment that they must feel, but we as trustees have our hands tied over what we can do with the money.'

The dispute centres on a decision in 1991 to wind up the original trust and replace it with one which had tighter terms of reference. In the immediate aftermath of the tragedy, with donations pour ing in from around the world, the Lockerbie Air Disaster Trust was set up to use the funds for those 'who require help, now and in the future' as a result of the disaster.

By the time it was wound up, the trust had taken in more than £2m in donations, a figure boosted by more than £370,000 interest. Most of the money was distributed to victims' relatives and to a range of projects in the town, such as playground equipment.

The £250,000 left over after the trust was wound up was used to start the Lockerbie Trust. But the new body adopted much stricter terms, dictating that the funds be used solely for charitable purposes and in the interests of the community of Lockerbie. With investments, the fund has now risen to almost £600,000.

But the relatives claim that these terms of reference are inappropriate because they prevent money from being used for the original purpose intended by the donors.

webTitle: Fight fans rush for Tyson tickets

fields.headline: Fight fans rush for Tyson tickets
fields.trailText: Hampden Stadium has been inundated with calls about tickets for the Mike Tyson fight in Glasgow next month that has provoked a storm of protest.
fields.body:
Hampden Stadium has been inundated with calls about tickets for the Mike Tyson fight in Glasgow next month that has provoked a storm of protest.

Officials at the Scottish Football Association, which runs the stadium, said that within 24 hours of Jack Straw's decision to grant the former world champion a visa despite his conviction for rape, it had received thousands of inquiries from fans seeking tickets for the bout against Lou Savarese.

Officials have applied to Glasgow City Council for a temporary entertainment licence and safety certificate to allow 60,000 people to attend.

But the SFA will this week come under intense pressure to withdraw from the event. Women's groups warned yesterday that they planned to disrupt the fight if it was allowed to go ahead.

The SNP will also mount an attempt to force the Scottish Executive to seek a judicial review of the decision to allow Tyson into Britain despite immigration rules which prevent anybody with a conviction carrying a sentence of more than a year in prison from entering the country.

The bout, scheduled to take place on 24 June, is a joint venture by leading London promoter Frank Warren and Glasgow promoters Alex Morrison and his daughter Katherine.
