webTitle: Britain may arm civil war fighters

fields.headline: Britain may arm civil war fighters
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone's plea for bullets risks sucking Army deeper into conflict
fields.trailText: Britain is considering a request from the President of Sierra Leone to provide its armed forces with ammunition needed to fight the rebel Revolutionary United Front. To do so would be a dangerous new escalation of British involvement in the country's bloody civil war.
fields.byline: John Sweeney in Freetown and Peter Beaumont
fields.body:
Britain is considering a request from the President of Sierra Leone to provide its armed forces with ammunition needed to fight the rebel Revolutionary United Front. To do so would be a dangerous new escalation of British involvement in the country's bloody civil war.

The request, made by President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah to General Sir Charles Guthrie, Chief of the Defence Staff, during his visit to Sierra Leone last weekend, has plunged Britain into an ethical dilemma.

The ammunition would allow Kabbah's army to take the war to the rebel heartlands in the hotly contested diamond fields.

The latest moves increase further the stakes in Britain's military involvement in its former colony following last week's fighting between British soldiers and the forces of RUF leader Foday Sankoh, and the deployment of Sea Harriers to overfly rebel positions.

There were reports that British forces had intelligence that the rebels planned revenge attacks on British troops for killing their comrades in a clash in the village of Lungi Loi.

The Observer understands that the request for ammunition will be considered by Ministers a Cabinet sub-committee meeting in the next few days. Sources at both the Ministry of Defence and Foreign Office confirmed that it had been made.

'The request was made by President Kabbah directly to Sir Charles Guthrie,' a Foreign Office spokesman said yesterday. 'We are considering the request, but clearly there are a number of issues we need to resolve not least the ethical considerations.'

The ammunition needed by the poorly equipped and badly led government forces is not manufactured in Britain. Kabbah's troops use a different calibre of bullets in their main rifle, the AK-47.

Sierra Leone needs more than ammunition, however. It is bankrupt, and officially the world's poorest state. The rebels, on the other hand, control the diamond fields and have a ready supply of arms from their mainstay, President Taylor of neighbouring Liberia.

Britain's drive to see that the Sierra Leone government succeeds on the battlefield is based partly on its own political embarrassment over the Sandline affair, when it was caught out appearing to break arms sanctions which had been put in place by the United Nations.

But with the UN-brokered Lomé peace accord - signed last year - already in shreds, and with more than 300 of its peacekeepers still held hostage by the RUF, no one in Sierra Leone is paying a great deal of attention to what the UN says.

The balance of military advantage is beginning to shift in the government's favour, with 3,000 Nigerian troops due to arrive soon. They will be attached not to the UN but to Ecomog, the pan-regional West African force.

Fresh ammunition for the Sierra Leona Army would make a big difference, said one source in Sierra Leone. 'If have no bullets, how can they fight the RUF?'

fields.headline: Paying fair
fields.trailText: You describe a Government proposal to introduce performance-related pay for hospitals (News, last week) as part of its new national plan for the new NHS.
fields.body:
You describe a Government proposal to introduce performance-related pay for hospitals (News, last week) as part of its new national plan for the new NHS.

If accountability is upwards, to the Secretary of State, the money may follow the performances he likes, but what does this mean for the people in the local areas whose hospitals don't catch his eye?

If accountability is to the community, through directly elected health authorities, or by bringing the responsibility for health service performance under elected local authorities, then performance could be judged by those who experience its outcome more immediately.

John Nicholson
Chief Executive
UK Public Health Association
Manchester

fields.headline: Under a cloud
fields.trailText: Re 'US planned one big nuclear blast for mankind' (News, last week). This foolish experiment may have produced some sort of cloud but it would not have been remotely mushroom-like (unless one quibbles and includes pufballs as mushrooms). Mushroom clouds are a phenomenon caused by convection, which requires an atmosphere. So far as I am aware, the moon lacks an atmosphere, although we only have Nasa's word on that.

fields.trailText: I expect Nick Cohen to be the first to jump to the defence of gay people and their rights, and someone should, but to state that Souter was 'slaughtered' by Boy George on the subject of Clause 28 in the BBC's  Question Time  was entirely biased (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
I expect Nick Cohen to be the first to jump to the defence of gay people and their rights, and someone should, but to state that Souter was 'slaughtered' by Boy George on the subject of Clause 28 in the BBC's Question Time was entirely biased (Comment, last week).

Boy George's defence of Clause 28 sums up the stupidity of his argument: 'Christianity is taught at school but not everybody becomes a Christian.' Maybe not, but an awful lot do. We have to be very careful with young and impressionable minds.

fields.headline: England sold out by Poundbury
fields.trailText: Can Prince Charles's Poundbury really be hailed as a model for future urban regeneration of England? Vanessa Thorpe (News, last week) seems to think so. Prior to publishing the article she asked me, as Chairman of the Government's Urban Task Force, to evaluate the scheme and I suggested the following criteria:
fields.body:
Can Prince Charles's Poundbury really be hailed as a model for future urban regeneration of England? Vanessa Thorpe (News, last week) seems to think so. Prior to publishing the article she asked me, as Chairman of the Government's Urban Task Force, to evaluate the scheme and I suggested the following criteria:

 Is it a dormitory suburb or does it combine a mix of live, work and leisure activities?

 Is it on recycled land?

 Is it socially mixed and inclusive?

 Is it served by a public transport system?

 Is it as compact as traditional villages?

 Is its construction and energy technology relevant to the housing problems of today?

In the week of the opening of Tate Modern, does Poundbury compare as a similarly confident gesture of our cultural development as we enter the 21st century? It seems to me that the answer to all these questions must be a resounding 'No'.

Clearly, my view of Poundbury as a questionable exercise in Hardyesque nostalgia didn't fit Ms Thorpe's remit. None the less, these issues should be properly considered before Poundbury is held up as a paragon of modern urban planning.

Richard Rogers
London W6

That we should return to building the sort of houses we actually like, creates a terrible moral kerfuffle in the minds of the architectural establishment and broadsheet commentators. But why?

A few years ago I was listening to a young art student praising Le Corbusier's housing units in Marseilles. I asked him if he would like to live in one of them. He stopped, went quiet and then said, 'No, you're right, I wouldn't.' Unfortunately, many people don't have the choice.

John Davison
London SW9

Edinburgh

So Paul Smith has not heard a single criticism about Tate Modern. Quite - not even the former satirist, turned professional moaner, Richard Ingrams, has sounded off.

fields.headline: Culture shock
fields.trailText: Andrew Marr (Comment, last week) repeated several times that culture matters, although it clearly doesn't matter much to him.
fields.body:
Andrew Marr (Comment, last week) repeated several times that culture matters, although it clearly doesn't matter much to him.

To say that Jews have not made major contributions to painting in the week when Tate Modern opens with a room devoted to Mark Rothko seems as perverse as ignoring the many other prominent twentieth century Jewish painters, from Chagall and Kokoscka to Lucien Freud.

Mr Marr concludes that, but for the religion and dietary laws, Jews' contribution to civilisation would be similar to that of Syrian farmers. This might possibly be true, but then Jews might also have built the Alhambra, the great mosques of Damascus and Cordoba and the Dome of the Rock. They might also have made major contributions to mathematics, literature and calligraphy. All those Jewish tailors might well have taken up rug-making instead, who knows?

It's good to hear that Andrew Marr's new job will be narrowly concerned with politics. Culture matters.

P. L. Hurst
London

fields.headline: Why Ulster should be independent
fields.trailText: Yet another week of crisis looms for Northern Ireland, with no certainty that David Trimble can persuade his party to accept the latest deal. Behind this lies a truth as curious as it is unnoticed. If its implication are worked out logically, it leads to the one outcome no one as yet publicly advocates...an independent Ulster.
fields.body:
Yet another week of crisis looms for Northern Ireland, with no certainty that David Trimble can persuade his party to accept the latest deal. Behind this lies a truth as curious as it is unnoticed. If its implication are worked out logically, it leads to the one outcome no one as yet publicly advocates...an independent Ulster.

On the face of it, we have here a familiar territorial dispute... the United Kingdom and Irish Republic competing over a province which they both cherish, while nationalists wanting a united Ireland are confronted by unionists who want to remain in the United Kingdom. None of this corresponds to reality.

Plainly the British Government is trying to disengage from Northern Ireland. The negotiations of the past few years, including the latest cosmetic deal with the IRA, might have been inspired by the advice an American gave his country over Vietnam 30 years ago: declare a victory and get out. It might well be the wish of the British people.

The British - 'English' would be more accurate - have no great emotional affinity, or love, for the Ulster Protestants. When Harold Wilson attacked the Loyalist strikers as 'spongers' in 1974 he was echoing, less eloquently, what John Milton said more than 300 years earlier - and what many Englishmen vaguely feel to this day. The Ulster settlers were Scotch 'thieves and red-shanks', Milton said, who had been 'neighbourly admitted ... by the courtesy of England, to hold possessions in our province, a country better than their own', and in return had 'with worse faith than the heathen, proved ungrateful and treacherous guests to their best friends'.

It doesn't seem far from there to the Downing Street Declaration of 1994, which said, truthfully enough, that the British had no selfish strategic or economic interest in Northern Ireland, which begged to be completed with 'so please let us find a way of getting out'.

At much the same time Sir Patrick Mayhew told Die Zeit that the British would leave Ulster 'mit dem Handkuss' - with pleasure - if they could. This is one truth that David Trimble has grasped. Any unionist argument from history is certainly poor: the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland didn't exist 200 years ago, and in its full form lasted for no more than 120 years. The only thing feebler is the historical argument for a United Ireland, given that no independent Irish state ever existed before 1922, and that Ireland has never been politically united in its history, except under the English Crown.

Maybe the southern Irish dimly recognise that. For generations the Irish state made an irredentist claim on Northern Ireland, embodied in Articles 2 and 3 of the constitution. In reality, 'the national question' played a most distinctive role in Irish political life: reunification was a goal which must always be pursued, but must never be achieved.

Not least, the Irish knew that partition had been highly convenient for them. By exporting sectarian conflict to the North, it was the essential factor which made possible the creation of a stable and peaceful Irish state. It isn't really surprising to anyone who knows Ireland that in a poll not long ago, a mere 21 per cent of Irish said they were 'very interested' in reunifcation. And seven years ago a still more pointed question was asked: in order to achieve a united Ireland, would they would be prepared to pay any more taxes? All of 19 per cent of Irish polled said they were.

Is this, as Borges's said, two bald men fighting over a comb? The truth is, no one wants Northern Ireland. With all their noisy violence, republican and loyalist zealots are hooligans at a match neither side wants to win.

Least understood is the position of the Ulster Protestants. Occasionally someone asks why we call them loyalists 'when they don't seem very loyal'. The answer is that not only is 'loyalist' a misnomer, so is 'unionist'. Partition and the Stormont statelet was not a 'unionist' outcome for Northern Ireland: the only part of Ireland which hadn't wanted home rule was the only part to get it. But before long the Ulstermen had come to like Stormont too well, and by the late Thirties, 'Back to Westminster' - the dream of integration which beguiled many, was rejected by the Ulster Unionist Council.

The real nature of 'unionism' was shown by one of the least known, and most extraordinary, episodes in Ulster history. In the spring of 1945, Sir Basil Brooke's unionist junta at Stormont called an early Northern Ireland general election. No sooner had the unionists won a landslide than the Stormont cabinet discussed whether the time was ripe to demand Dominion status from Westminster. When one Minister reminded his colleagues of the huge subsidies Northern Ireland enjoyed from the British Treasury, they backtracked.

What this says is riveting. Had Northern Ireland become a Dominion, Brooke could have still have used the 'British' rhetoric of Crown and Empire. But he would have been governing a country as effectively independent as Canada and Australia, not to say as De Valera's Ireland. In other words, what was unionism was really Ulster nationalism - and so it remains. Henry McDonald's biography of David Trimble is revealing in this respect. In 1974 Trimble was arguing that 'independence may be the only alternative to a united Ireland', and he continued to advocate Dominion status until the late Eighties.

Maybe Trimble is right. If the British don't want Northern Ireland, and the Irish don't want it either, then logic points to a separate Northern Ireland. A sovereign Ulster would be quite as large in area and population as - and much larger in domestic product than - many United Nations member states. It would have to find a way for its two communities to live together, and it would have to stand on its own feet economically. For years, we have been told that there is no alternative to the Belfast Agreement, there is no 'plan B'. Perhaps we should start looking for plan C.

webTitle: Chaos and nappies: it's just what we all need

fields.headline: Chaos and nappies: it's just what we all need
fields.standfirst: Nigella Lawson  says that Cherie's late pregnancy is a liberation from our control freakery
fields.trailText: Once you've had a baby, a birth is always significant. But what's everyone else's excuse? I've been observing the Blair-baby enthusiasts for some time, ever since that autumn announcement in fact, and it seems to me that what the Blairs' late pregnancy is all about - for the public - is reassurance for the Seventies generation.
fields.body:
Once you've had a baby, a birth is always significant. But what's everyone else's excuse? I've been observing the Blair-baby enthusiasts for some time, ever since that autumn announcement in fact, and it seems to me that what the Blairs' late pregnancy is all about - for the public - is reassurance for the Seventies generation.

Those born half a generation after the generation who needed to be perpetually young were always going to have difficulties with ageing. Having children later was a smart move. Perhaps they felt that, like fruit flies, postponing procreation would extend their span.

But the notable thing is that although every commentator has announced the recently delivered mother's age as if it marked some breakthrough in mature parturition, the truth is Cherie Blair is more remarkable for a woman of her profession and milieu for having her fourth child rather than her first at 45. I had my first child at 33 and among most of my friends this was considered almost a teen-pregnancy. I'd say 37 was the usual age of the first pregnancy among my lot. (The difference may seem slight, but in the mind it's the distinction between being just-not-30 and almost-40.) An acquaintance who was 30, his wife 28 when their first child was born, says that hovering around the school playground now he still feels conspicuously young. What a feat to pull off.

The reassurance given now by the Blairs' continuing fruitfulness is simply this: the late-spawning generation feel the time pressure acutely. They might not want to have another child right now, but fear that soon the choice will be gone. Every woman close to me has, in the months of the Blair pregnancy, said that she feels it means that maybe...

And although I don't believe that the Madonnas and Ulrikas of the world have conceived as a direct result of Cherie's late pregnancy, there is obviously something in the air. Call it envious broodiness, however subliminal, if you will. That's certainly what I suffer from.

There is another significance in all this. We think we need to plan everything, work and live to a scheme. Now, most people who have - or want - children realise sooner or later that it doesn't quite operate like that. But the obviously unplanned addition to the Blair household offers something like liberation, the promise of fruitful chaos. If only we could escape the false wisdoms that lie behind all those deliberations. Perhaps, we glimpsingly understand, life might be better if we allowed things to happen rather than have to proceed from responsible decision-making.

And although much is made of the couple's advantages here - they are going to be able to have a lot more help in the home than most people in the same situation - the real difference is not that the Blairs can afford nannies or the full benefits of the contemporary working parents' support-systems, but that they are helped by the oldest network in the book: family. Cherie has her mother in situ ; and one of her sisters is apparently part of the child-rearing circle. Among the professional middle classes this is something of a rarity.

Of course we envy that - and we're right to. And although I hesitate to politicise any of this, it is true that the spectacle of a seemingly tight-knit and functional family does much more - and much more that is helpful - for the family-values business than any amount of Back to Basics exhortations. We want, we need to believe it can all work still. One of the hardest things for a new mother to accept is the isolation that comes with the role. You think you're adding to the family, and you are, but the first, difficult feelings are of being some-how taken out of the group and plunged into the lonely chaos of post-natal abandonment.

But if the Blairs have this resonant advantage, it's also the case that they have burdens that none of us has to bear. For whatever they decide to do - about paternity or maternity leave, breast-feeding, the way they handle the whole, intensely private matter of child-rearing, how much to give in to public curiosity and speculation on the matter - will be read as symbolic in a way that, unless they protect themselves and their family, will become hatefully intrusive.

If Tony Blair takes time off from office, he'll be seen as less of a leader. If it's business as usual, he'll be condemned as not being the contemporary man so many of us look to him to be. If Cherie speeds back to work, the forces of the Mail will be out to get her. If she extends her stay in that glorious, if conflicted newborn bubble, she'll be cited as a disappointment to the sisterhood.

The notion of a late baby was always that it was a child to keep the mother company, look after her even, once the rest of the brood had grown up and away: to give her a continuing purpose. But that's changed, not least because a mother can have a rich enough life outside the home. She is no longer defined simply by her involvement with her off spring. If anything, Cherie might have thought she was getting towards a time when she could devote more of herself to work, not less. Now she will be as haunted as the rest of her consoeurs about bathtimes and the ridiculous evanescence of those early years.

Worse, she knows the score. At least with first-time mothers, the speed with which that time passes is not remotely understood. But once you've had even one child, let alone three others, you know too well that all those minutes that seem to drag like days in the beginning, really sweep past like seconds. And how, when it's really the last baby - although, one should in these matters never say never, and that's the emblematic joy of the present situation - do you make the choice not to savour every sleep-deprived moment?

What this means personally for the Blairs I wouldn't presume to understand. But you don't need to intrude on their privacy to conclude that there is a point of contact for the rest of us in all this. We don't have a Prime Minister mouthing platitudes about the theoretical difficulties of finding a work-life balance; we have one living them. Tess Kingham has resigned from the House of Commons, citing its family-damaging and antediluvian practices. Perhaps we now can hope for a Prime Minister genuinely eager to reform them.

Not that any such reform, unlikely as it might be despite even the sincere desires of such a crucial player, would help the Prime Minister himself. He's landed, honoured, whatever, with a job that could never offer the benefits of flexitime. Yet the strangely old-fashioned largeness of his family is a help in itself. The sparse contemporary family unit, the growing numbers of only-child families, makes the parent so uncomfortably crucial. I'm enough of a Freudian to believe that the parents are always crucial, but the family rests on a number of relationships, and the more relationships possible, between any permutation of numerous siblings, takes at least some of the pressure off. The family continues when the parents aren't there.

And perhaps that's what so many of us are envious. There is a sense in which those of us with the binary brood (or less) feel we're playing at families. The real challenge might, we guess, lie in being outnumbered by our children not matched by them.

For the truth is, however much we are freed by contemporary mores - the first-the-person-then-the-parent line - there is also something rather claustrophobically neat about it. Control seems to bring with it governance and power, but in fact it also constrains. What all (good) parents seem to share is a feeling of anxious inadequacy. Maybe that's only in part due to the intrinsic difficulties of civilising the savage child without stifling it. Perhaps a great part of our struggle is the knowledge that however much we try to keep our house in order, the mess is there waiting to engulf us.

But this mess is good; this mess is life. That the bricks-and-mortar embodiment of political authority that is Downing Street is plunged into the soaked breast-pad littered heaven/hell of chaotic new life can not be other than glorious.

If she extends her stay in that glorious, if conflicted newborn bubble, she'll be cited as a disappointment to the sisterhood. The notion of a late baby was always that it was a child to keep the mother company, look after her even, once the rest of the brood had grown up and away: to give her a continuing purpose. But that's changed, not least because a mother can have a rich enough life outside the home. She is no longer defined simply by her involvement with her off spring. If anything, Cherie might have thought she was getting towards a time when she could devote more of herself to work, not less. Now she will be as haunted as the rest of her consoeurs about bathtimes and the ridiculous evanescence of those early years. Worse, she knows the score. At least with first-time mothers, the speed with which that time passes is not remotely understood. But once you've had even one child, let alone three others, you know too well that all those minutes that seem to drag like days in the beginning, really sweep past like seconds. And how, when it's really the last baby - although, one should in these matters never say never, and that's the emblematic joy of the present situation - do you make the choice not to savour every sleep-deprived moment? What this means personally for the Blairs I wouldn't presume to understand. But you don't need to intrude on their privacy to conclude that there is a point of contact for the rest of us in all this. We don't have a Prime Minister mouthing platitudes about the theoretical difficulties of finding a work-life balance; we have one living them. Tess Kingham has resigned from the House of Commons, citing its family-damaging and antediluvian practices. Perhaps we now can hope for a Prime Minister genuinely eager to reform them. Not that any such reform, unlikely as it might be despite even the sincere desires of such a crucial player, would help the Prime Minister himself. He's landed, honoured, whatever, with a job that could never offer the benefits of flexitime. Yet the strangely old-fashioned largeness of his family is a help in itself. The sparse contemporary family unit, the growing numbers of only-child families, makes the parent so uncomfortably crucial. I'm enough of a Freudian to believe that the parents are always crucial, but the family rests on a number of relationships, and the more relationships possible, between any permutation of numerous siblings, takes at least some of the pressure off. The family continues when the parents aren't there. And perhaps that's what so many of us are envious. There is a sense in which those of us with the binary brood (or less) feel we're playing at families. The real challenge might, we guess, lie in being outnumbered by our children not matched by them. For the truth is, however much we are freed by contemporary mores - the first-the-person-then-the-parent line - there is also something rather claustrophobically neat about it. Control seems to bring with it governance and power, but in fact it also constrains. What all (good) parents seem to share is a feeling of anxious inadequacy. Maybe that's only in part due to the intrinsic difficulties of civilising the savage child without stifling it. Perhaps a great part of our struggle is the knowledge that however much we try to keep our house in order, the mess is there waiting to engulf us. But this mess is good; this mess is life. That the bricks-and-mortar embodiment of political authority that is Downing Street is plunged into the soaked breast-pad littered heaven/hell of chaotic new life can not be other than glorious.

fields.headline: Straight records
fields.trailText: I thought the reporting on the changes at the BBC was unfair to both the incoming and the outgoing political editors.  The Observer, for example, reported that Robin Oakley is known to have Conservative sympathies. In all my dealings with Mr Oakley I have never had cause to question his political independence or his professional integrity. Others have said that Andrew Marr is likely to be a New Labour mouthpiece. Not long ago, some of the selfsame people were accusing me, falsely, of having tried to get Mr Marr removed as editor of the Independent .

fields.headline: Let foreign films be heard
fields.trailText: Philip French's 'Sounding Off' article (Review, last week) on the failure of television stations to show foreign language films rings hollow. Elsewhere in the paper he devotes his report from the Cannes Film Festival to three English language films, one of which he hasn't even seen.
fields.body:
Philip French's 'Sounding Off' article (Review, last week) on the failure of television stations to show foreign language films rings hollow. Elsewhere in the paper he devotes his report from the Cannes Film Festival to three English language films, one of which he hasn't even seen.

He ignores films by Jean-Luc Godard, the sensational 20-year-old Iranian director Samira Makhmalbaf, and several other Asian and European makers of films which don't happen to be in English.

Until Philip French and his colleagues who write Screen devote the same sort of attention to foreign language films as they now do to ones in English he should leave off attacking TV stations for doing the same thing.

John Petherbridge
London SE19

Editor's note: Philip French reviews Makhmalbaf's film and other foreign entries at Cannes in Review, page 9

I wholeheartedly agree with your film critic, Philip French. Each language, each culture observes life from a different perspective. To help us become citizens of the world the best of foreign movies, past and present, should be available on 'free to air' channels.

Any country worth its salt would regard this as a birthright for all its people.

A. C. Williams
Hove
Sussex

Can I add my voice to that of Philip French (Review, last week) and call for a halt to the disappearance of international movies from our TV schedules. Many people living in rural areas do not have easy access to cinemas or video hire shops (not that either take much interest in the past or present international scene).

Those who lack access to satellite or subscription systems depend upon the four 'free' channels. Why should we be deprived of access to quality international cinema?

Adrian Barritt
Chichester
W Sussex

fields.headline: Roar, Leo, roar
fields.standfirst: Show them who's the real boss
fields.trailText: Welcome, Leo! We had feared you might be born a few hours earlier and give the Saturday papers the fun of reporting your arrival and speculating on the coming upheavals to the lives of your illustrious parents. But your timing was perfect (and we like your name).
fields.body:
Welcome, Leo! We had feared you might be born a few hours earlier and give the Saturday papers the fun of reporting your arrival and speculating on the coming upheavals to the lives of your illustrious parents. But your timing was perfect (and we like your name). Babies change things. Their uncompromising demands usually affect just their families. But sometimes their yells reverberate through their parents' offices, factories, county courts or schools and non-parents are forced to acknowledge that life sometimes throws up greater imperatives than the next management meeting or sales conference.

If, Leo, you one day read today's issue of this paper, you will find that we had barely begun to sort out how parents should raise children while earning money for their needs: the 'life-work balance' it was called. You may learn that as your mother went into hospital to give birth, another 'Blair babe', Tess Kingham, was forced to concede that she could no longer represent her constituents and answer the demands of her family within today's archaic parliamentary system.

We have high hopes of you, Leo. Babies do not respect rank or stand on ceremony. They state their needs with deafening conviction. You will be stating yours in the heart of government at Number 10 Downing Street. Louder, Leo, louder! We will all benefit.

fields.headline: Tough on crime
fields.standfirst: Hurd, not Hague, is talking sense
fields.trailText: William Hague, in his attack on Britain's 'failed liberal consensus', has raised the bidding in the unsavoury political auction for the law-and-order vote. Having cut down asylum-seekers with a few of his karate chops, he has now turned to criminals and the leniency with which he thinks we treat them.
fields.body:
William Hague, in his attack on Britain's 'failed liberal consensus', has raised the bidding in the unsavoury political auction for the law-and-order vote. Having cut down asylum-seekers with a few of his karate chops, he has now turned to criminals and the leniency with which he thinks we treat them. Liberalism brings a curl to the lip of New Labour too, on whose own authoritarian tendencies the House of Lords has emerged as a restraining influence, and it has taken an old Tory softie, Lord Hurd, to offer the most elegant critique of Hague's populist programme.

The violation of person or property rightly arouses revulsion. Yet our politicians continue to give an easy ride to tax-evaders and white-collar criminals whose depredations may cost the public more dearly than burglary. Successful fraud prosecutions are brought with pitiful rarity and, even when convicted, the guilty often find the bench sympathetic to pleas for leniency.

Nor is the public beyond a little hypocrisy on its own account. While demanding summary treatment for common criminals, it habitually inflates its insurance claims and may be perfectly willing to buy cheap white goods offered for sale in pubs. We are all victims of white-collar crime, of fiddling, of tax evasion and pay for it in higher taxes, prices and premiums. We are consumers of justice, too, but the rights of victims do not exclude the hope of redemption for the criminal, nor can they be allowed to impair the impartial administration of the law. Such an attitude reflects not so much a 'liberal consensus' as the Christian ethic itself.

webTitle: Boys taught to torture and maim

fields.headline: Boys taught to torture and maim
fields.standfirst: John Sweeney  reports from Freetown on the sickening reality of the conflict in Sierra Leone which is turning children as young as nine into bloodthirsty killers
fields.trailText: John Sweeney  reports from Freetown on the sickening reality of the conflict in Sierra Leone which is turning children as young as nine into bloodthirsty killers
fields.body:
The whites of his eyes fluttering like moths in their sockets, he staggered forward and groaned softly but repeatedly, taking weaker and weaker steps before he collapsed. Giggles all around.

At just 12 he had the face of an old man who has seen too much and had just acted out what a man does when you have slashed the back of his neck. It was so well done, you knew he had seen it for real.

Sierra Leone is a country not just of amputated limbs; nine years of war have left the children with amputated minds.

They called him Burn You - real name Sheku Jalloh - and he sat underneath the palm trees by the South Atlantic in what once must have been a very beautiful hotel, now run by two Catholic priests to give something back to the child soldiers. St Michael's rehab centre is half an hour south from Aberdeen, where the clatter from British Army Chinooks fills the sky and the car parks of the swankiest hotels are stuffed with white UN Land Cruisers, their chrome gleaming in the sun.

Burn You was with two friends - a boy they called Corporal Highway, 11, (real name Saidu Kargbo) and a girl called Small Rebel, 12, (real name Tity Gbayo). The rebels had burnt a tattoo, RUF, which stands for Foday Sankoh's Revolutionary United Front, into her chest, but she was so ashamed she poured acid on the letters. The burns had corrugated the scar tissue, blurring the out line of the letters, but the pity of it was you could still make out RUF behind the scabs.

All three had been taken to fight at the age of nine. Small Rebel and Corporal Highway were with the RUF; Burn You had been with the old SLA, the Sierra Leone Army. All sides had Small Boy Units, they said, but people tell you the RUF were the worst. The New SLA - trained and now supported by the British - are the government forces. They won the election and now have the coast. The RUF have the bush and the diamond fields. The war will continue until the RUF takes the coast, or the government takes the diamond fields.

Corporal Highway demonstrated the trick of cutting off an adult's hands, if you belong to a Small Boy Unit. You force the man down on the ground and shove a gun barrel at the back of his neck. Lying prone, the subject is helpless. Then another boy takes the man's arm and rests it on a piece of wood, and then brings down the machete. Corporal Highway had done this many times.

He used an AK47, which would have been only a little smaller than him. Burn You's weapon of choice was an SMG, a sub-machine gun. Small Rebel said she had a pistol, but she looked a little embarrassed, as though she might not have been allowed to use it all the time. Small Rebel's commander had been a woman, 'Colonel Gaddafi's wife', a woman called Mammy, around 27 years old. Small Rebel insisted to the others that this woman was Libyan, not local. This may sound incredible, but Libya and Liberia's president, Charles Taylor, back the RUF. It is quite likely one of Gaddafi's famous female bodyguards may have fought for the cause in the bush.

Burn You showed how you cut down the rib cage and get at the liver, to eat it for 'main power'. Once you have chopped off a man's hands, you can do anything. Burn You ran through the options: you can cut off the ears and nose and lips, and give them to the victim to eat. You drink the blood from the back of the neck. If you slash the neck at the front, the blood spurts too fast and is wasted, he said.

Children around the world tell tall stories, but I didn't think these three were making much up. The detail was too precise.

Burn You's favourite torture was rubbing hot pepper into the eyes of a victim. Some of the peppers in West Africa are so ferocious they can burn your fingers when you touch them. Ordinary people were terribly afraid of the Small Boy Units, they said. They would enter villages to find everyone gone. Burn You said their name for dogs was Town Commandos, because when they appeared they were the only living things that had stayed on.

They all suffered flashbacks, though none of them was quite as bad as one poor boy, who went round the centre screaming: 'I want to drink blood'. For Small Rebel, the worst memory was the time the rebels came to her home. They poured petrol over the mother, father, two brothers and sister and set fire to them, watching as they ran around, burning alive. And then they took her.

That, and the times when the Small Boy Units caught a pregnant woman. 'They'd argue whether there was a boy child or a girl child in the belly,' she said. 'To solve the argument, they would cut open the belly with machetes. I saw this many times.' The British Army is here to secure the airport and evacuate any British nationals - that's the official line, which no one believes. The Paras and the Royal Marines out to sea and the SAS in the bush are here to try to put an end to the barbarity evidenced by these three children.

Brigadier David Richards hasn't had the opportunity to talk to the child soldiers. But he has seen their work at the amputee camps. 'When I came out of there, my eyes were streaming,' he said. He is not a sentimentalist, but sharp as mustard, bespectacled, tough. He needs to be for the game of three-dimensional chess ahead of him.

A Lebanese trader explained the problem of bringing peace to Sierra Leone: 'The rebels have the diamond fields. They sell the diamonds to Liberia. This makes good money for Charles Taylor. He sells the rebels the weapons. So long as the rebels have the diamonds, they have more money than the government. The war will continue until the government takes the diamond fields.'

But won't the rebels collapse, now that Foday Sankoh has been arrested? 'Sankoh was just a card for Taylor,' he said. He has many cards. There is a new one, Colonel Issay. The diamond fields are the key. If they remain in rebel hands, then this place is condemned to war, with the government on the coast and the RUF in the bush, just like Angola.'

British military sources in Sierra Leone agree that the diamond fields in the east are the RUF's centre of gravity.

But the Parachute Regiment, which is securing Lungi airport, is bored out of its mind. In the ladies', a skinhead Para washed his face over and over again. Down the road in the police station a corporal read a two-week- old Sun , and yawned. A third, from Maghull, near Aintree, watched his mates snooze away: 'I've been here two weeks and I've only seen the airport. We've come all this way, but it's like going on holiday and spending the entire time in Gatwick.'

There is, of course, the United Nations. The 12 O'Clock follies, when the UN people strut their stuff, is straight from the Theatre of the Absurd. The spokesman made a plea for the rebels to release the 300-odd hostages, mainly Kenyan and Zambian troops, on humanitarian grounds. This plea was directed, remember, at the RUF, its troops zonked out of their minds on palm wine, the army which teaches its child soldiers how to cut off hands. The word on the streets of Freetown - not exactly Han-sard - is that some of the UN hostages have been mutilated, and they will be disappear after being killed, because their wounds are evidence of how the RUF behaves; too grim ever to be shown to the wider world.

The UN's spokesman in New York, Fred Eckhart, has called for an immediate ceasefire. This would freeze the war where it is now, giving the rebels the diamond fields. The Lebanese trader believes that if this happens the war will start up again.

In the meantime, the war against the RUF is being carried out on the ground by the SLA. The bad news is that the SLA has run out of bullets.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Tate & Lyle | PowerGen
fields.body:
Sweet and sour
Tate & Lyle mustn't half be bitter right now. Higher US interest rates, not to mention the search for the next Internet firm to go bust à la boo.com, are likely to tip the scales further in favour of old- economy stocks. But the sugar producer has missed out in the swing of sentiment that has already happened.

As broker Charterhouse points out, and as this column foresaw, good high-yield shares have recovered ground as so-called TMT (telecoms, media and technology, for resolute old fogeys out there) stocks have plunged.

At 243p and yielding 9.2 per cent, however, Tate & Lyle has underperformed the market and now trades on a price-earnings ratio of just 8 times.

The Mr Cube company is not going through the easiest of times. But with results due on 8 June, there have been no rumblings about a dividend cut. Buy for income and recovery potential.

Foot on the gas
By the same token, shares in PowerGen are a must-buy. True, there are still worries about UK electricity wholesale prices. But the group has a strong management team and is well placed to win new retail customers in both electricity and gas.

It has also just diversified, with the £3.2bn acquisition of LG&E in the US. While UK profits will be stagnant over the next few years, the deal should allow future earnings growth.

Despite recovery of late, at 473p PowerGen shares are still trading on a prospective price-earnings multiple of just 7 times. The net yield is 7.8 per cent, and the dividend policy is progressive. Attractive on all grounds: income, capital appreciation and takeover prospects.

Exel should excel
While staples such as PowerGen have dropped out of the blue chips, transport group Ocean is likely to enter the FTSE-100 index in June following its merger with National Freight Corporation. Under its new name, Exel, the group has good prospects: e-commerce will give a welcome boost to transport and logistics outfits. With postal deregulation in Europe, it will also inevitably attract takeover speculation.

As Deutsche Bundespost's link with Securicor shows, soon-to-be-privatised postal services are already on the prowl, as are big US parcel carriers such as UPS. Exel will be big, but is a mere mouthful to giants like these.

webTitle: Is National Power steering towards disappointment?

fields.headline: Is National Power steering towards disappointment?
fields.trailText: Throg Street
fields.body:
Now it is clear why National Power had to sell its three power stations, almost halving its generating capacity. It needed the £1.31 billion profit on these disposals to mop up the massive £1.37bn write-offs and other charges against everything from gas contracts to power stations in Pakistan.

That did not worry investors: the shares rose by around 20 per cent last week as the City dismissed what is past and anticipated a better performance - including a higher-than-expected dividend - in the future. But that better performance is largely a product of the write-offs and a reduced tax charge.

This should not deflect attention from the fact that last year's results were abysmal, and the prospects for both parts of the business following the planned autumn demerger are not particularly bright.

Take npower - as the British supply business will be called. It makes much of the fact that it has 2.6 million customers and is now winning new ones a bit faster than it is losing existing ones. But it will have to start winning them a lot faster if it is to achieve its target of 4 to 5 million customers within the next five years - a level most analysts think essential if it is to be profitable in the long term.

The alternative is acquisitions, and npower's chief executive elect, Brian Count, said it would be interested in buying Norweb, the retail supply business being sold by United Utilities.

Whether that would be a good move depends on price - and npower's ability to integrate it with its existing supply business.

The adverse reaction to warnings in The Observer that the dividend could be halved again this year, despite the cut from 28.6p to 15p in the year to last March, has encouraged npower to think again.

The £495m provision against forward gas contracts will, like the lower tax charge, boost its profits going forward - although not its cash, as it will still have to fork out to pay the contract price.

The upgrade in earnings which results has encouraged the more pessimistic analysts to increase their dividend forecasts from around 8p to 10p - some even hope it will be maintained at the 15p level seen last year.

International Power will pay no dividend but will use its funds to build its global business. It has had its fair share of write-downs too: £246m 'to recognise the current circumstances' in some of its markets, including £131m specifically in Pakistan.

Philip Hollobone, utilities analyst at WestLB Panmure, warns that the remaining half of the investment in Pakistan could have to be written off.

The new chief executive will be paid in shares, so he will have a real incentive to make the business perform. Last week's share price rise makes no allowance for disappointment, something that National Power has provided plenty of in the past. Avoid.

Compel-ling facts
One of the key things a chief executive should have is information about what the different bits of the business are doing. The mechanisms for supplying that at Compel, the software services group, seem to have gone awry.

Last autumn, it issued a profits warning within weeks of assuring Throg Street that its prospects were rosy. Last week, it was at it again. Three months ago the trading statement in its interim results claimed it had a 'strong flow of substantial new contracts with FTSE 100 companies' and was confident that its customers' spending would 'materially increase during the first half of 2000'.

Last week, it warned that lower-than-expected demand at Compelsource, the bit of the business that sells hardware, meant its results would fall 'materially short' of expectations.

The shares almost halved. Last time round, they quickly recovered, helped by both reassurances from Neville Davis, chief executive, that it was a temporary lull and results that backed this.

The recovery this time is likely to take far longer. The departure of Compelsource boss Mark Howling shows he is taking much of the blame for the disappointment.

But the buck should stop at the top, and the fact that Davis is giving up his role as chairman shows that he recognises his culpability. He will have to demonstrate far more foresight than so far before investors should trust him again.

Not safe yet
Back in the far-off days when consumers actually went out and bought things, Sir Richard Greenbury, then boss of Marks & Spencer, warned; 'Sales is vanity, profits is sanity.'

But that was in the good old days, when inflation and space expansion meant that sales increases were easy to come by, and profits only a little bit harder. Now that too many shopkeepers are falling over themselves to attract us, keeping sales steady, let alone increasing them, is becoming ever harder. That allows Safeway, the supermarket group, to gloss over a 29 per cent slump in profits in the year to 1 April while trumpeting a 10 per cent increase in sales.

The City seems happy about the strategy. The shares rose again last week and are now almost 60 per cent above their February low. But even Carlos Criado-Perez, the new chief executive who worked out that cutting prices could actually boost total sales, must realise that higher sales on their own are not enough. The only sensible reason for chasing sales is if they bring you higher profits.

On that, Safeway still has much to prove. Its sensible decision to abandon loyalty cards will save £60m, helping to repair some of the damage to its margins from its £110m investment in cutting prices. Its high-profile promotions are attracting customers back into its stores: it has added 750,000 shoppers - an 8 per cent increase - in the past four months.

It is hoping to keep them coming back by investing in availability, better own-brand goods and fresh produce, and improved decor.

This is building momentum. The sales figures show a steadily improving trend over the last year. It is confident that the increase in price promotions means that will continue, despite the withdrawal of its loyalty card. But it should not expect rivals to stand still.

Tesco and Asda will not be pleased that they are losing customers to Safeway; both are well-placed financially to respond. Safeway deserves credit for its success in fighting back, but the recent rise in its shares means that success is already discounted. Hold.

webTitle: Blair is sidelined by Chirac and Schröder

fields.headline: Blair is sidelined by Chirac and Schröder
fields.trailText: The vast eighteenth-century hunting lodge at Rambouillet outside Paris has an inauspicious record as a venue for high-level, international diplomacy. It was here, the official summer residence of the French President, that a doomed accord was hammered out with a view to preventing last year's war over Kosovo.
fields.body:
The vast eighteenth-century hunting lodge at Rambouillet outside Paris has an inauspicious record as a venue for high-level, international diplomacy. It was here, the official summer residence of the French President, that a doomed accord was hammered out with a view to preventing last year's war over Kosovo.

Marie-Antoinette would not have been surprised by Rambouillet's failure to inspire confidence among the warring sides - she described the place as a 'toad-hole'.

But a four-hour conversation over dinner at the castle on Friday night could rescue Rambouillet's place in history and link its name for years to come with the moment when a federal Europe came back on to the Continent's diplomatic agenda.

President Jacques Chirac and his Prime Minister Lionel Jospin had invited Germany's Chancellor Gerhard Schröder and his Foreign Minister, Joschka Fischer, to a brainstorming session. No details of their discussion were made public and there was no press conference after the meeting.

Officials from both sides acknowledged, however, that the main item on the agenda was Fischer's call last week for the creation of a fully federal Europe, with a written constitution, an elected parliament and a two-chamber legislature. As a first step, he wants a core of EU states, led by France and Germany, to be allowed to press ahead towards political union.

Fischer's plan received a cold reception in Britain, with Europe Minister Keith Vaz insisting on Friday that it does not represent official German policy. This is strictly true but Schröder has publicly backed his Foreign Minister and German opposition politicians queued up in the Bundestag on Friday to offer their support.

The Christian Democrats were at pains to point out that they proposed a similar plan six years ago and their European Affairs spokesman, Peter Hintze, implored the government to let his party climb on the bandwagon.

'It has always been the tradition in the Bundestag that we work together on the major European questions. Let us do this now,' he said.

France assumes the rotating EU Presidency for six months on 1 July, during which Paris must appear to be an honest broker between all EU states. The French presidency will be dominated by a new EU treaty to be signed in Nice in December.

It now looks certain that Germany will press for a clause in the treaty to allow a group of EU states to form a closer union - even if all other states do not approve.

Schröder, a cigar-puffing bon vivant with an easy, personal style, has had a prickly relationship with the more formal, ascetic Jospin. But the Chancellor has a good rapport with Chirac and the two foreign ministries have been working closely on EU reform for the past year.

One reason for the recent improvement in relations between Berlin and Paris is Schröder's apparent abandonment of his flirtation with London and Tony Blair. Last year's Blair-Schröder 'Third Way' paper has been quietly forgotten and, following the departure of Finance Minister Oskar Lafontaine, Schröder has sought to reassure left-wingers in his Social Democratic Party that he is not about to abandon the party's fundamental principles.

The move to Brussels of Schröder's former adviser, Bodo Hombach, who had a close relationship with Peter Mandelson, has weakened Berlin's ties with London.

German officials have concluded that there is no point in waiting for Britain to join the euro before pressing ahead with further integration and Berlin has found itself closer to Paris on a growing number of issues, including a number of high-profile disputes with the US.

This week the influential Sueddeutsche Zeitung said: 'London does not, despite all Blair's remarks, lie "at the heart of Europe". What the French see there is the original six Common Market members, but above all themselves and the Germans.'

Denis Staunton writes for the Irish Times

webTitle: Blame the parents not Oedipus, says Freud critic

fields.headline: Blame the parents not Oedipus, says Freud critic
fields.trailText: The knives are out in France again for Sigmund Freud and his Oedipus complex. It is alleged he invented the theory because he could not face parental responsibility for his own personality problems.
fields.body:
The knives are out in France again for Sigmund Freud and his Oedipus complex. It is alleged he invented the theory because he could not face parental responsibility for his own personality problems.

A psychiatrist, Michel Juffé, who leads the challenge to Freud a century after his Interpretation of Dreams , said the accepted view of Sophocles's 2,400-year-old drama should be replaced by emphasis on the guilt of Oedipus's parents, Jocasta and Laius.Juffé argues for a complete reversal of Freud's interpretation of the story told in Oedipus Rex written in 429BC. In the legend, Laius, king of Thebes, was warned by an oracle that he would be killed by his son, Oedipus, who would then marry Jocasta, his mother.

Abandoned on a mountainside as a baby, Oedipus was adopted by the King of Corinth, whom he believed to be his real father. He eventually blinded himself after the prophecy came true and Jocasta, mother of his four children, hanged herself.

'Freud... made the mistake of placing the responsibility on the supposedly irresistible impulses of Oedipus which compelled him to kill his father and marry his mother.

'But it is obvious that Oedipus was ignorant of his origins and is completely innocent. The real guilt lies with Laius and Jocasta, his parents. Jocasta must have been aware that she was marrying her son whose feet had been pierced when he was abandoned. Oedipus was the victim of the criminal behaviour of his father and mother.'

Freud's own interpretation of the tragedy was made after self-analysis in which he became aware of the hysteria of his brothers and sisters and described his father as perverted.

'His letters show that Freud started investigating the inter-generational causes of neuroses and then made an about turn when he came close to the truth in his own case,' Juffé said.

'He could not accept that parents - including his own parents - could be responsible for the psychic problems undergone by children. In the end, he censured or attenuated the parents' role by elaborating the Oedipus complex so as not to take account of his own experience.'

Juffé concludes: 'The Oedipus complex has developed a life of its own and forms a screen in uncovering the reality of family suffering.

'Responsibility is collective and intergenerational. When we recognise this we can repair the faults of our parents and prevent the transmission of suffering and violence to our descendants.'

webTitle: Giuliani pulls out of battle for the Senate

fields.headline: Giuliani pulls out of battle for the Senate
fields.trailText: Goodnight Rudi Giuliani, good morning Rick Lazio. New York woke up yesterday to a brave new world in which their irascible mayor, newly tender, had abandoned the field of electoral combat and his little known successor had, within hours, stepped up to the plate.
fields.body:
Goodnight Rudi Giuliani, good morning Rick Lazio. New York woke up yesterday to a brave new world in which their irascible mayor, newly tender, had abandoned the field of electoral combat and his little known successor had, within hours, stepped up to the plate.

Thus did the most highly charged Senate contest in recent American history spin into uncharted territory. And the big question was whether the 'hate factor' for Hillary Clinton, now the clear front-runner, was big enough to give Gingrich-Republican Lazio a fighting chance.

Giuliani's ambitions for higher office have been derailed by prostate cancer, an affair and a nasty split with his wife. An unusually wistful Giuliani fought back tears late on Friday afternoon as he told astonished reporters there was more to life than politics - his health and the people he loves.

'I used to think the core of me was in politics. It isn't,' said Giuliani.

'I'm thinking of deeper, deeper things than politics. You know, life... number one... the medical treatment... and I'm going to think about how I can be a better person.'

Within minutes of the final curtain on the gripping theatre at City Hall, all eyes were focused on the First Lady and the man almost certain to challenge her.

First up was Hillary, by unfortunate contrast to Giuliani, appearing remote and coolly unemotional, living up to her contrived and carefully scripted image as she told a hastily-convened news conference that she had called the mayor after his remarks 'to wish him well, to tell him that I knew this was a difficult decision, and I certainly hope and pray - and I know all New Yorkers do - that he will have a full and speedy recovery.'

She looked concerned, and so she should, Republicans were quick to assert.

The usually bickering state and national top party brass had united around a candidate they now think has a better chance of defeating Clinton than Giuliani.

Then up popped Lazio. An ambitious but relatively unknown Long Island Republican congressman with long-advertised designs on the Senate race and a $3.4 million war chest. Lazio proclaimed himself 'the strongest Republican candidate... and best able to unite our party and defeat Hillary Clinton in November.'

The Republican establishment agrees, with New York state governor George Pataki, considered the strongest contender, having made it clear he intends to remain in Albany for some time.

Lazio, who planned to challenge Giuliani for the nomination until Pataki persuaded him not to at the behest of GOP Presidential nominee George W Bush, got the nod days ago.

By early Friday evening, TV cameras were already focused on the 'Lazio for Senate' posters and the 'Lazio 2000' T-shirts adorning a busy campaign headquarters, its phone banks already up and running.

Galvanising the hate-Hillary vote is Lazio's best hope, say political pundits, but many now believe he may have a better chance than the controversial mayor.

Lazio's telegenic youthfulness and amiable nature, along with his eight years experience representing his native New York in the House and moderate stance on abortion and gun control, could present a formidable challenge to the First Lady.

'Lazio is one thing Hillary is not - likeable,' says New York Daily News columnist Mike Barnicle. 'He's a suburban middle class "local guy", and all the better that he's an ethnic Italian Catholic and a younger, more amiable version of the mayor. If he positions himself as the guy taking on the elites, he really has a chance.'

For the time being, Clinton can take comfort in the latest polls, showing Lazio trailing her 50 per cent rating by 19 points.

'It's hers to lose, but the numbers will tighten up within 72 hours,' said John Zogby of the independent pollster Zogby International. 'There is a large anti-Hillary vote out there; she appears to have a ceiling of acceptability in the mid-40s.

'Lazio is largely unknown, but there will be tremendous interest and he will be everywhere. It won't be long before he reaches a mid-40 rating - and we're back to a tight race.'

Even the Rev Al Sharpton, the black leader and Giuliani nemesis, had words of warning for the Democratic candidate: 'She has a real challenge now. What she was going to get for free, she's now going to have to earn.

'Against Giuliani she could rely on a record turnout of black, minority and progressive voters, which is now less certain.'

webTitle: Son sues mum for his upkeep

fields.headline: Son sues mum for his upkeep
fields.trailText: A mother's love lasts for ever - and so does her duty to maintain her children in the style to which they are accustomed, even if they are grown up. But a divorced mother of three, ordered by the Spanish courts to pay for the upkeep of an adult son, has launched a crusade to change a curious law which requires parents in Spain to provide for their children, even if they are aged over 18.
fields.body:
A mother's love lasts for ever - and so does her duty to maintain her children in the style to which they are accustomed, even if they are grown up. But a divorced mother of three, ordered by the Spanish courts to pay for the upkeep of an adult son, has launched a crusade to change a curious law which requires parents in Spain to provide for their children, even if they are aged over 18.

María Dolores Rey, 54, was shocked to receive a summons from her 27-year-old son, Javier Polo, who has lived with his father since his parents divorced in 1990.

'Javier sued me just as my youngest boy [Roberto] turned 18, arguing that they were now both in the same situation,' María explains in a phone call from her home in Aviles, on the north coast of Spain. 'And the law said he was right.'

But Roberto, now 20, is a university student about to move to college in Madrid, while Javier qualified as a draughtsman in September last year. 'He is old enough to make his own life, but Roberto still needs help to finish his education,' their mother argues.

It is perfectly normal in Spain, for a twentysomething - even a thirtysomething - to live at home with his or her parents. It is almost the norm to stay at home until your wedding day - and Spaniards marry late (women at 28, men at 30-plus). Fernando Polo, Javier's elder brother, now 31, only left his mother's home four years ago to get married.

But María believes Javier is abusing the law, and should be out getting himself a life, or at least a job. Mother and son have barely spoken since the divorce. 'He does not understand he can be with his father and still have a good relationship with his mother.'

Under the court ruling, which she is appealing against, she will have to pay Javier 15 per cent of her (net) salary, which works out at around 33,000 pesetas (£120) per month. She fears this will seriously affect her ability to finance Roberto's studies.

Now María Rey is intent on trying to change the law, and has been inundated with phone calls from parents offering support. Her lawyer, Montserrat Gonzalez Rufo, says Javier not only failed to prove he had done all he could to find work, but 'we have documentary evidence that he was offered work and he rejected it'.

If Javier ever does land a paying job, he might consider another curious Spanish law: that adult children of independent means who live at home are obliged to contribute a reasonable sum to cover household expenses.

webTitle: Russia's draft dodgers prefer  suicide to Chechnya

fields.headline: Russia's draft dodgers prefer  suicide to Chechnya
fields.standfirst: A demoralised and underfunded army faces a new crisis - a lack of manpower
fields.trailText: A demoralised and underfunded army faces a new crisis - a lack of manpower
fields.body:
Just after eight last Wednesday morning a group of Ilya Sobel's closest friends and family gathered in the corner of a windy Moscow square to drink warm beer and weep. Passers-by glanced sympathetically at them, unsurprised by the funereal atmosphere of the gathering.

Like 191,000 other 18-year-old men across the country last week, Sobel was saying goodbye before starting his stint as a conscript in the Russian army.

The annual Spring conscription returns in the third week of May, and for those families unable to secure their sons an exemption, the call-up papers are viewed as a family tragedy. This year, however, growing opposition to the system has meant that record numbers of draftees have managed to avoid con scription - with just 13 per cent of those called upon actually turning up for service. Military officials are worried that the small intake will leave the army inadequately manned.

This recruitment problem is an unwanted extra worry for Russia's generals. Plagued by difficulties since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the army remains in crisis. Russia's military placed hope in its president, Vladimir Putin, to reinvigorate the armed forces, but with limited resources it is likely his pre-election rhetoric may prove hollow. The hopes of those who expected him to institute radical changes to the way the Russian army is organised were crushed last week when he re-appointed former Defence Minister Igor Sergeyev, a member of the old guard, who is unlikely to preside over a shake-up.

In the meantime, conditions for the conscripts look set to remain bleak; during their two years in the army most soldiers experience a system of bullying, poor rations and outdated equipment. They have to survive on 36 roubles a month (81p).

But this year the prospect of active service in Chechnya has led even more draftees to resort to extreme measures to avoid entering the army. An early government commitment to keep conscripts away from frontline fighting was swiftly reneged upon last year. Of the 2,284 Russian soldiers dead and 6,645 wounded in the war so far, a significant proportion of these were conscripts - a strong disincentive to anyone contemplating their call-up papers.

Traditionally, those teenagers who manage to evade service tend to be from Russia's privileged classes - studying at university, or with parents rich enough to pay up to $1,000 (£670) to pro cure a medical certificate testifying ill-health or bribe an army official to strike their name from the list. Some draftees, without such resources, embark on starvation diets so that they weigh below the acceptable level at the medical. Others affect psychiatric illnesses.

Those unable to escape the draft face service in an army where conditions - according to the Soldiers' Mothers Com mittee, a pressure group dedicated to improving the lot of Russia's conscripts - 'are not worthy of human life'.

The group says that about 1,000 draftees a year commit suicide to escape the misery. The worst fears of conscripts and their families are reflected in the experience of Alexei Kluchkov, now 19, a novice soldier who was brought in to fight in Dagestan last August at the start of Russia's battle against Chechen rebels.

He said: 'We were given a few months' training, where the officers taught us tactics unchanged since World War II - and not at all suitable for the kind of combat we would be going into. Even the officers who were teaching us knew it was nonsense.'

On his second day of active service, he and other ill-prepared conscripts from his unit came under fire. Kluchkov's left leg was blown off and he was pensioned off with a monthly payment of 240 roubles (£5.45).

Ilya Sobel, a trainee mechanic, did not try to escape the draft. 'He wanted to serve,' said his father, Pavel Sobel, a taxi driver. 'It's very worrying for us, especially with the situation in Chechnya, but it's only the rich New Russians who try to worm out of it.'

The degradation of the armed forces has been starkly illustrated in the Chechen conflict. Despite the triumphalism which accompanied announcements that Russia now has the entire territory of the rebel state under its control, even a summary look at the facts of the war undermines any suggestion of victory. Some 92,000 Russian troops faced a band of Chechen rebels, thought to number no more than 10,000.

The Russians had the upper hand in air power (the Chechen air force was comprehensively destroyed in the previous war), more artillery and many more tanks (at a ratio of something like 300:7) - and yet their progress through the region was tortuously slow and bloody.

Military analysts argue that a shift to a professional army would improve Russia's performance. Aside from humanitarian concerns about the dire conditions endured by conscripts under the present system, they argue that with limited resources, the army wastes money every year on training for new recruits who are going to be available for just 24 months.

Earlier this year Putin said he wanted 'to move in the direction' of a professional army, but other signals indicate the opposite. A decree issued by the President stipulated that Russian boys aged over 15 will receive mandatory military training classes during school hours to equip them for the day they join the army. Besides, such a radical reform currently looks unaffordable. Although the President pledged to boost defence spending by a third last year, the bulk of this money is expected to drain into the Chechen struggle - which is costing the government some £60 million a month.

Putin's own assessment of the army's condition has also been contradictory. In a recent report on national security he said the army's combat readiness was 'critically low', while declaring publicly: 'All talk about the collapse of the army and its low level of fitness for battle is just brazen lies.'

But whatever the true extent of its weaknesses, the importance of the military's role in Putin's new Russia is clear. As the President carved up the country's internal boundaries into seven new districts to give himself greater power over the regions last week, five of his seven new representatives were picked from the senior ranks of the police, security forces and the army.

webTitle: Rare find deepens mystery of a genius

fields.headline: Rare find deepens mystery of a genius
fields.standfirst: Debate rages over Internet photograph of poetic recluse, writes  Melinda Wittstock
fields.trailText: At first, Philip Gura could not believe his eyes. There, staring back at him on the Internet auctioneer site eBay.com, was the startling visage of nineteenth-century American poet Emily Dickinson - startling because up until now only one authentic photograph of the prolific poet had been known to exist.
fields.body:
At first, Philip Gura could not believe his eyes. There, staring back at him on the Internet auctioneer site eBay.com, was the startling visage of nineteenth-century American poet Emily Dickinson - startling because up until now only one authentic photograph of the prolific poet had been known to exist.

More astonishing still was the seller's opening bid price, a trifling sum of $24 for what the American literature professor now believes will prove to be a rare treasure - the only image of an adult Dickinson, captured at the height of her creativity in her early thirties, when she was producing a poem a day.

Just about any devotee of American poetry can attest to the camera shyness of Emily Dickinson - clearly an insight shared neither by the portrait's peddler, Janos Novomeszky, himself an aficionado of Hungarian poetry, nor the Los Angeles dealer who sold him the image, Stephen White.

'I guess they must be kicking themselves,' says Gura, who placed a $481 bid with less than a minute left on the eBay auction clock to become the proud possessor of a slightly faded albumen print of the dark-haired, dark eyed woman who bears a striking resemblance to the 17-year-old Dickinson captured in the authenticated 1847 daguerreotype - down to the prim posture, overbite, hairstyle and serious expression. 'If this is what I believe it is, the only portrait of one of the most famous American poets at the height of her powers, it's tremendously significant.'

A Dickinson expert at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill and 'born collector' of early photographs, Dura was quick to get over his scepticism about the older, chubbier-cheeked image. 'My first reaction was, there are no other images of Emily Dickinson. But the resemblance was uncanny, so I e-mailed Novomeszky and asked "How do you know?" When he wrote back saying there was handwriting on the back of the print identifying it as Dickinson, I decided it was worth the risk.'

Proving the photograph's authenticity will be difficult. Experts say there are no known references to the photograph in existing literature or correspondence.

Peter Nelson, curator of special collections at the Jones Library in Amherst, Massachusetts, Dickinson's birthplace, is among those awaiting the forensics. 'My first reaction was "Wow",' Nelson told the New Yorker magazine last week - but on Friday he wasn't so certain. 'It will be difficult to prove either way; for every doubt about its authenticity there will be plausible arguments to suggest that it is in fact her image. It may never be resolved.'

Gura seems convinced. 'My gut instinct tells me this is the real thing. We know she put on weight - there is a letter from her sister Lavinia in 1852, just three or four years before we think this photograph was taken, saying, and this is a direct quote, "Emily is getting fat". That would explain the chubbier cheeks.' A US Justice Department expert in analysing photographic evidence will soon set to work comparing the bone structure and anatomy of the Dickinson daguerreotype with the new print.

Gura says he's also researching portraits by Amherst and Boston photographers of the time to see whether any used the distinctive carved chair in which the supposed Dickinson is posed. He has asked dress historian Joan Severa to assess the clothes in the photograph, thought to have been taken in the late 1850s or early 1860s. Severa has deemed the fashion around 10 years out of date, but that, he insists, adds to its persuasiveness, since Dickinson was known to dress behind the times.

More clues may be found in the inscription in period handwriting on the back of the print, 'Emily Dickinson/died/rec 1886'. Gura, now comparing the handwriting with that of the people the poet knew, says the 'rec' may be shorthand for 'received', a common indicator of the time a picture joined a collection.

Gura is certain he has not been duped. 'I've been pretty lucky at this before,' he said, having authenticated two daguerreotypes of Henry Thoreau last year. But there have been other notable Dickinson forgeries in the past. A purported Dickinson photo surfaced in Richard Sewell's 1974 two-volume biography of the poet, The Life of Emily Dickinson, but it was proved to be spurious 10 years ago.

Collectors are already speculating about the photograph's monetary value, should it prove genuine. 'It's hard to estimate,' says Nelson. 'Dickinson's original manuscripts go for $20-30,000, so I would guess this photo, if authenticated, would fetch at least half that sum.'

But photography experts at Sotheby's and Christie's say images of famous Americans without documented provenance rarely do well at auction. But Gura plans to hang on to the photo for some time. If his find proves genuine he will find an appropriate home for 'a national treasure', most likely the Dickinson Homestead National Historic Site in Amherst or Harvard University. 'I realise something like this shouldn't remain in private hands forever.'

Back in Amherst, Nelson awaits a meeting with a local woman who called him to say she thinks she also has a photo of Emily Dickinson. 'I'm not taking it seriously yet,' he says. 'When I see it, I'll let you know.'
