Back in Amherst, Nelson awaits a meeting with a local woman who called him to say she thinks she also has a photo of Emily Dickinson. 'I'm not taking it seriously yet,' he says. 'When I see it, I'll let you know.'

webTitle: Don't turn your back on science

fields.headline: Don't turn your back on science
fields.standfirst: An open letter from biologist Richard Dawkins to Prince Charles
fields.trailText: An open letter from biologist Richard Dawkins to Prince Charles
fields.body:
Your Royal Highness,

Your Reith lecture saddened me. I have deep sympathy for your aims, and admiration for your sincerity. But your hostility to science will not serve those aims; and your embracing of an ill-assorted jumble of mutually contradictory alternatives will lose you the respect that I think you deserve. I forget who it was who remarked: 'Of course we must be open-minded, but not so open-minded that our brains drop out.'

Let's look at some of the alternative philosophies which you seem to prefer over scientific reason. First, intuition, the heart's wisdom 'rustling like a breeze through the leaves'. Unfortunately, it depends whose intuition you choose. Where aims (if not methods) are concerned, your own intuitions coincide with mine. I wholeheartedly share your aim of long-term stewardship of our planet, with its diverse and complex biosphere.

But what about the instinctive wisdom in Saddam Hussein's black heart? What price the Wagnerian wind that rustled Hitler's twisted leaves? The Yorkshire Ripper heard religious voices in his head urging him to kill. How do we decide which intuitive inner voices to heed?

This, it is important to say, is not a dilemma that science can solve. My own passionate concern for world stewardship is as emotional as yours. But where I allow feelings to influence my aims, when it comes to deciding the best method of achieving them I'd rather think than feel. And thinking, here, means scientific thinking. No more effective method exists. If it did, science would incorporate it.

Next, Sir, I think you may have an exaggerated idea of the natural ness of 'traditional' or 'organic' agriculture. Agriculture has always been unnatural. Our species began to depart from our natural hunter-gatherer lifestyle as recently as 10,000 years ago - too short to measure on the evolutionary timescale.

Wheat, be it ever so wholemeal and stoneground, is not a natural food for Homo sapiens. Nor is milk, except for children. Almost every morsel of our food is genetically modified - admittedly by artificial selection not artificial mutation, but the end result is the same. A wheat grain is a genetically modified grass seed, just as a pekinese is a genetically modified wolf. Playing God? We've been playing God for centuries!

The large, anonymous crowds in which we now teem began with the agricultural revolution, and without agriculture we could survive in only a tiny fraction of our current numbers. Our high population is an agricultural (and technological and medical) artifact. It is far more unnatural than the population-limiting methods condemned as unnatural by the Pope. Like it or not, we are stuck with agriculture, and agriculture - all agriculture - is unnatural. We sold that pass 10,000 years ago.

Does that mean there's nothing to choose between different kinds of agriculture when it comes to sustainable planetary welfare? Certainly not. Some are much more damaging than others, but it's no use appealing to 'nature', or to 'instinct' in order to decide which ones. You have to study the evidence, soberly and reasonably - scientifically. Slashing and burning (incidentally, no agricultural system is closer to being 'traditional') destroys our ancient forests. Overgrazing (again, widely practised by 'traditional' cultures) causes soil erosion and turns fertile pasture into desert. Moving to our own modern tribe, monoculture, fed by powdered fertilisers and poisons, is bad for the future; indiscriminate use of antibiotics to promote livestock growth is worse.

Incidentally, one worrying aspect of the hysterical opposition to the possible risks from GM crops is that it diverts attention from definite dangers which are already well understood but largely ignored. The evolution of antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria is something that a Darwinian might have foreseen from the day antibiotics were discovered. Unfortunately the warning voices have been rather quiet, and now they are drowned by the baying cacophony: 'GM GM GM GM GM GM!'

Moreover if, as I expect, the dire prophecies of GM doom fail to materialise, the feeling of let-down may spill over into complacency about real risks. Has it occurred to you that our present GM brouhaha may be a terrible case of crying wolf?

Even if agriculture could be natural, and even if we could develop some sort of instinctive rapport with the ways of nature, would nature be a good role model? Here, we must think carefully. There really is a sense in which ecosystems are balanced and harmonious, with some of their constituent species becoming mutually dependent. This is one reason the corporate thuggery that is destroying the rainforests is so criminal.

On the other hand, we must beware of a very common misunderstanding of Darwinism. Tennyson was writing before Darwin but he got it right. Nature really is red in tooth and claw. Much as we might like to believe otherwise, natural selection, working within each species, does not favour long-term stewardship. It favours short-term gain. Loggers, whalers, and other profiteers who squander the future for present greed, are only doing what all wild creatures have done for three billion years.

No wonder T.H. Huxley, Darwin's bulldog, founded his ethics on a repudiation of Darwinism. Not a repudiation of Darwinism as science, of course, for you cannot repudiate truth. But the very fact that Darwinism is true makes it even more important for us to fight against the naturally selfish and exploitative tendencies of nature. We can do it. Probably no other species of animal or plant can. We can do it because our brains (admittedly given to us by natural selection for reasons of short-term Darwinian gain) are big enough to see into the future and plot long-term consequences. Natural selection is like a robot that can only climb uphill, even if this leaves it stuck on top of a measly hillock. There is no mechanism for going downhill, for crossing the valley to the lower slopes of the high mountain on the other side. There is no natural foresight, no mechanism for warning that present selfish gains are leading to species extinction - and indeed, 99 per cent of all species that have ever lived are extinct.

The human brain, probably uniquely in the whole of evolutionary history, can see across the valley and can plot a course away from extinction and towards distant uplands. Long-term planning - and hence the very possibility of stewardship - is something utterly new on the planet, even alien. It exists only in human brains. The future is a new invention in evolution. It is precious. And fragile. We must use all our scientific artifice to protect it.

It may sound paradoxical, but if we want to sustain the planet into the future, the first thing we must do is stop taking advice from nature. Nature is a short-term Darwinian profiteer. Darwin himself said it: 'What a book a devil's chaplain might write on the clumsy, wasteful, blundering, low, and horridly cruel works of nature.'

Of course that's bleak, but there's no law saying the truth has to be cheerful; no point shooting the messenger - science - and no sense in preferring an alternative world view just because it feels more comfortable. In any case, science isn't all bleak. Nor, by the way, is science an arrogant know-all. Any scientist worthy of the name will warm to your quotation from Socrates: 'Wisdom is knowing that you don't know.' What else drives us to find out?

What saddens me most, Sir, is how much you will be missing if you turn your back on science. I have tried to write about the poetic wonder of science myself, but may I take the liberty of presenting you with a book by another author? It is The Demon-Haunted World by the lamented Carl Sagan. I'd call your attention especially to the subtitle: Science as a Candle in the Dark .

 Richard Dawkins is the Charles Simonyi Professor of the Public Understanding of Science at Oxford University. His latest book is 'Unweaving the Rainbow' .

fields.headline: NEWS IN BRIEF
fields.trailText: Ex-topless dancer Sandy Murphy, known as the 'Irish Venus', and her lover Rick Tabish face life imprisonment after they were found guilty by a Las Vegas jury of the murder of her multi-millionaire 'sugar daddy' Ted Binion, former head of the Horseshoe casino.
fields.body:
Topless dancer and lover face life for 'sugar daddy' killing

Ex-topless dancer Sandy Murphy, known as the 'Irish Venus', and her lover Rick Tabish face life imprisonment after they were found guilty by a Las Vegas jury of the murder of her multi-millionaire 'sugar daddy' Ted Binion, former head of the Horseshoe casino.

Polls in the balance

Hopes that Italians will turn out today for seven referendums took a knock when polls showed most will stay at home. More than 50 per cent must vote to validate the polls.

Egypt in crackdown

Egyptian authorities have effectively frozen the activities of the small, Islamist-oriented opposition Labour Party and closed its newspaper al-Shaab .

Submarine dead honoured

A lone bugler played and laurel wreaths floated over the resting place of British submarine HM Perseus as relatives gathered to pay homage to the 60 seamen who died when it hit mines in 1942.

Crisis over asylum seekers

Bavaria's anti-refugee politicians threaten to block Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's plan to grant 20,000 work permits to foreign computer specialists if he lifts a ban on work for asylum seekers.

Star flautist Rampal dies

French flautist Jean-Pierre Rampal, who popularised the flute as a solo instrument and became one of classical music's brightest stars, has died of heart failure in Paris, aged 78.

Singer sued

Lisa Ross Agbalay, a former executive for singer James Brown's company, has sued him for more than $1 million, claiming she was fired for refusing his sexual advances.

Bikers busted

More than two dozen people were arrested as federal agents across the United States raided the homes of members of a motorcycle gang, the Mongols. The raiders confiscated firearms, drugs and thousands of dollars.

webTitle: All you need to know about GM food

fields.headline: All you need to know about GM food
fields.trailText: Mankind has tinkered with plants for 10,000 years, creating hybrids and strains that now sustain nearly all our planet's six billion inhabitants. These crops are by-products of standard breeding techniques. What alarms green supporters and Prince Charles is the artificial nature of modern genetic technologies.
fields.body:
Mankind has tinkered with plants for 10,000 years, creating hybrids and strains that now sustain nearly all our planet's six billion inhabitants. These crops are by-products of standard breeding techniques. What alarms green supporters and Prince Charles is the artificial nature of modern genetic technologies.

So what do these gene engineering methods involve?

Scientists take a gene for a particular attribute - such as resistance to a herbicide - and splice it into a crop. Farmers then use that herbicide to eradicate weeds in a field.

What is the supposed advantage of such a system?

Scientists and crop companies say farm ers should be able to cut their weedkiller and fuel bills. At present, plants have to be dusted with a range of different herbicides, each designed to get rid of one specific species of weed. By making their crops resistant to a powerful, all-purpose herbicide, weedkilling can be done in a single spray each season.

Why do environmentalists object?

They claim that gene crops will cause farmers to use more herbicides, damage the environment and create dangerous monopolies in which a handful of GM crop companies will control seed and herbicide sales throughout the world. The first point is vociferously rejected by scientists. Gene crops are designed to cut herbicide use, they say. Early studies back this claim.

But what about damage to the environment?

Scientists believe that reduced use of weedkillers should cause less poisoning of insects and wild animals. Some ecologists disagree. To discover the answer, GM crop trials have been set up round the country. In three or four years, these should provide answers - if the fields are not first dug up and destroyed by green activists.

What about the danger of herbicide resistance genes spreading to wild flowers and plants?

This danger is accepted by scientists. However, pollen from a gene crop can only be taken up by plants of a similar species. The GM rape plants - mistakenly planted in Britain - are unlikely to affect the environment because they have no natural close corollary in this country.

So why has the planting of GM crops provoked such fury in the West?

Most analysts believe genetically modified foods arrived at a time when green activists were spoiling for a fight over the increasing industrialisation of food production. GM crops provided a convenient battle ground. In addition, the public - which distrusted gene technologies but accepted their use in the making of medicines and treatment of genetic disorders - saw no advantage in agriculture, other than making farmers and plant companies richer.

webTitle: Charles: right or  wrong about science?

fields.headline: Charles: right or  wrong about science?
fields.standfirst: Andrew Marr welcomes the Prince's promotion of spiritual values and argues that, unwittingly or not, Charles has hit the key issue: money and markets
fields.trailText: Andrew Marr welcomes the Prince's promotion of spiritual values and argues that, unwittingly or not, Charles has hit the key issue: money and markets
fields.body:
It is a disconcerting thing, a shaking thing, to find I share a private passion with the Prince of Wales. But there it is. The passion is for a man, a writer, a tobacco farmer, a poet and essayist from Henry County, Kentucky, whom history may remember as the single most important and influential political thinker alive today. It is unlikely you have heard of Wendell Berry. Fame is fickle and prediction mostly daft; but it is likely that your descendants, assuming they are literate, interested people, will know his name.

Berry is one of the influences on Charles's thinking on spiritual values and sustainable development, the subject of last week's Reith lecture. Charles's agonising, his large cars, personal extravagances and spiritual quest have been much mocked on these pages. Distinguished and wise scientists have been badly hurt by his generalised attacks on them. But in the longer term perhaps none of that matters so much. Charles has chosen to be part of a real world-sized political argument about power, science and control - nothing less than the direction of society - and in that argument, Berry's writing is becoming more and more influential.

A word of warning: like many great political thinkers, Wendell Berry is an extremist, in much the same way as Thoreau was. His loathing for most of the sprawl, waste and junk of modern urban life is unrestrained; his stiff-necked local pride and his constant assertion of the importance of farming, the local and the specific, put him far beyond the reach of most professional politicians. He's against big corporations, free trade, computers and industrial farming. He is outside the ordinary conversation of politics but his secret power is that he's also a prose writer of genius. Searching for his books around the house I reflected that he's one of these writers whose books one keeps pressing on friends and never getting back - and a fine poet too, with a wildness and energy in his thought that makes him a dangerous guru for anyone.

On some of these questions, including trade and admiration for science, I am on the other side of the fence. But the core of the oppositionist case put best by Berry goes wider than trade deals or pesticides. It is really about what it means to be human. The poet-farmer deals with this again and again, emphasising we are not to be defined by consumption but by our relationships with land, family and community, and above all by our capability for 'good work' - work done with care, affection, intelligence.

Somewhere, in our scientific confidence and economic giantism, we have lost the plot, stopped being whole, broken contact with the world around us. It is not an original argument -- there are clear lines running from Rousseau, with his idealised Swiss peasants, to Prince Charles. There is, or is supposed to be, a connection between ever-greater scientific specialism, the narrowing of the liberal mind, and the reduction of people to mere consumers. No whole vision, no spiritual unity, no more generous human society. The Spanish philosopher José Ortega y Gasset (1883-1955), with his attacks on 'mass man', is perhaps the best example of this thinking; in each generation, he argued, 'the scientist through having to reduce the sphere of his labour, was progressively losing contact with other branches of science, with that integral interpreta tion of the universe which is the only thing deserving of the names of science, culture, European civilisation'. This is close to Prince Charles today: 'Of course our descendants will have scientific and technological expertise beyond our imagining but will they have the insight or the self-control to use this wisely...?'

The prince is a very rich and unelected man whose views have blighted good people's careers, but here he asks a hugely important question - is humanity a species charging out of control, following one kind of thinking, lemming-like; or are we really sapiens, with the internal, democratic, philosophical levers to control the consequences of our own curiosity? Today, I'd say, our most striking common experience is acceleration - the speeding up of change in everyday life, the exponential growth of biological knowledge and computer power, the 24-hour financial spasms, the dizzying churn of technology. The same goes for the extinction of rival species - the biologist Edward O. Wilson speaks of the 'Hundred Heartbeat Club', his grimly witty name for the animal species which have 100 or fewer members, and are that number of heartbeats away from total extinction - eagles, Javan rhinos, Hawaiian crows, dolphin species, and so on. If the current rate of habitat destruction continues in forests and coral reefs alone, he says, half the species of animals and plants will be gone by the next century: 'Our descendants would inherit a biologically impoverished and homogenised world.'

So, for Charles to raise the question of speed and control, the duty of one generation to the next, the problem of reconciling the acceleration of today with the longer rhythms of planetary life, is something he can hardly be mocked for.

What, though, of the answer? A return to 'nature' is not it. As Charles suggests, the complexity of life on Earth ought to (and does) inspire humble awe in scientific atheists as well as spiritual believers. But mankind, inside nature, has altered it irrevocably, not least by reproducing with such exponential success. Even if we wanted to clamber back in again to the pre-industrial natural world, with its harsh choices and smaller populations, it is not possible. Nature was never stable, particularly since we were always part of it. Now, with our sprawling populations and needs, there is no return journey available - not short of the greatest catastrophe to occur to our species so far.

None of this rules out a more intelligent, knowing approach to land-use, of course: but a return to organic and sustainable farming is a slow thing, which will probably be led by the richest parts of the world and driven by consumer power. The bigger issue is consumer power itself. Charles often puts this in the context of spirituality, but he understands, surely, that to advocate self-restraint, as he does, is to fundamentally challenge consumer capitalism. It is based on appetite, consumption and waste; they are not by-products but driving forces.

Wendell Berry's ideal is a deliberately frugal farmer on the banks of the Kentucky river, who does not squander and has put decades of human sweat into his land. He is a model of self-control or, as he would put it, 'good work'. He is the opposite of mass man. Charles's position is unique, so far outside ordinary experience he can offer little practical advice.

He is a highly privileged Westerner, crammed with literary knowledge, owning good land and with the leisure and mental gifts to think. Most of the world's population are not living in plenty, have no ambition to return to peasant lives and would greet the news that their materialism was the problem with no little bemusement.

Indeed, as the Prince tip-toes towards a full-throated critique of consumer economics, he moves closer to some curious companions, such as the anti-free trade movement and anarcho-green organisations such as People's Global Action. This group, barely mentioned in mainstream journalism, originated in a protest in southern Mexico in 1994 against the North American Free Trade Association, and has held key meetings or 'encounters' in Bangalore, Geneva, Belem in the Amazon and the US. Its keenest supporters include French and Indian farmers, Indonesian trade unionists, even Ukrainian environmentalists. Its geographical reach is as impressive as that of many multi-national corporations.

This is possible thanks to the Internet, which is to this generation of anti-capitalists what the illegal printing press was to the Leninists a century ago. There are literally hundreds of links between different anti-capitalism sites and a great slew of advice, information and argument spinning round the world. It all has a tremendous idealistic and romantic appeal. One of the protest groups, Mayday 2000, describes itself as 'a maverick wild child' while the PGA itself speaks of its origins in 'the humid mists of the Chiapas' whence the rebels emerged 'using a jungle-battered laptop computer... people everywhere soon heard of the uprising'. Soon this lot will have their Che as well. Meanwhile, they use homely revolutionary saws, such as 'If you think you are too small to make a difference, try sleeping with a mosquito'.

This is hardly, yet, a movement. It is more of a hubbub of concern and anger, a mood, a ragged world-wide heckle against science-driven, free-trading consumerism, which runs from Prince Charles at one extreme and anarchists at the other, with millions of trade unionists, religious groups and non-governmental organisations such as Greenpeace, Jubilee 2000, Christian Aid and the World Development Movement in the middle.

It is the inevitable reaction to the vast power of global business, riding on the back of our scientific flowering - ultimately a protest at the effects of the Enlightenment. It won't 'win'; there will be no final settlement. But it will shape choices and change the politics of the next few decades. The important thing for Prince Charles to remember is that it is not a 'safe' thing, all this, limited to spiritual musing and hesitation about science. There is now no gap between humanity on the one hand and science on the other. The real argument is between angry people and is about power, markets and democracy. It is not about 'natural values' - Charles's 'grain of nature' is a cruel, predatory cycle - but about how to regain self-restraint and an understanding of time that goes beyond fashions or five-year electoral cycles. And that's a political matter.

In one essay, Wendell Berry says the problem is that America (but the same goes for us) has become 'a nation of fantasists. We believe, apparently, in the infinite availability of finite re-sources... We believe democratic freedom can be preserved by people ignorant of the history of democracy and indifferent to the responsibilities of freedom'. Berry is a great figure because he is also a passionate democrat.

This is my last column: I am off to the BBC to report politics from there, though I hope to keep writing on other things. But it seems a good theme to end on. Prince Charles's intervention speaks to two great truths that are vital for people like me to remember in the 'who's up, who's down' world of Westminster. First, politics doesn't stop at tax rates or the result of the next election - it touches our all our futures. But second, whatever the problem, democracy will be part of the answer.

Poet who sees sermons in stones

Wendell Berry is a farmer-poet of the Patrick Kavanagh ilk who sees sermons in stones. He is a prolific writer of mystic poetry and ecological essays, a mainstream American poet.

Berry is a professor at Kentucky University and a teacher at Schumacher College, an ecological studies centre in Devon. An agricultural seer, he espouses a return to a more low-tech, considered existence, and farms tobacco, sheep and vegetables in Kentucky. One of his greatest concerns is the 'industrial eater' - typical city consumers who eat mass-produced food without knowing or caring about its origins.

Another of Berry's hobbyhorses, shared with Prince Charles, is saving rural communities. Not that everyone should turn to the Good Life:

'Anyone who understands farming would be aghast at the idea of a lot of city people rushing into the country to farm. It would be like a mass movement to play the violin.'
fields.bodyText: It is a disconcerting thing, a shaking thing, to find I share a private passion with the Prince of Wales. But there it is. The passion is for a man, a writer, a tobacco farmer, a poet and essayist from Henry County, Kentucky, whom history may remember as the single most important and influential political thinker alive today. It is unlikely you have heard of Wendell Berry. Fame is fickle and prediction mostly daft; but it is likely that your descendants, assuming they are literate, interested people, will know his name. Berry is one of the influences on Charles's thinking on spiritual values and sustainable development, the subject of last week's Reith lecture. Charles's agonising, his large cars, personal extravagances and spiritual quest have been much mocked on these pages. Distinguished and wise scientists have been badly hurt by his generalised attacks on them. But in the longer term perhaps none of that matters so much. Charles has chosen to be part of a real world-sized political argument about power, science and control - nothing less than the direction of society - and in that argument, Berry's writing is becoming more and more influential. A word of warning: like many great political thinkers, Wendell Berry is an extremist, in much the same way as Thoreau was. His loathing for most of the sprawl, waste and junk of modern urban life is unrestrained; his stiff-necked local pride and his constant assertion of the importance of farming, the local and the specific, put him far beyond the reach of most professional politicians. He's against big corporations, free trade, computers and industrial farming. He is outside the ordinary conversation of politics but his secret power is that he's also a prose writer of genius. Searching for his books around the house I reflected that he's one of these writers whose books one keeps pressing on friends and never getting back - and a fine poet too, with a wildness and energy in his thought that makes him a dangerous guru for anyone. On some of these questions, including trade and admiration for science, I am on the other side of the fence. But the core of the oppositionist case put best by Berry goes wider than trade deals or pesticides. It is really about what it means to be human. The poet-farmer deals with this again and again, emphasising we are not to be defined by consumption but by our relationships with land, family and community, and above all by our capability for 'good work' - work done with care, affection, intelligence. Somewhere, in our scientific confidence and economic giantism, we have lost the plot, stopped being whole, broken contact with the world around us. It is not an original argument -- there are clear lines running from Rousseau, with his idealised Swiss peasants, to Prince Charles. There is, or is supposed to be, a connection between ever-greater scientific specialism, the narrowing of the liberal mind, and the reduction of people to mere consumers. No whole vision, no spiritual unity, no more generous human society. The Spanish philosopher José Ortega y Gasset (1883-1955), with his attacks on 'mass man', is perhaps the best example of this thinking; in each generation, he argued, 'the scientist through having to reduce the sphere of his labour, was progressively losing contact with other branches of science, with that integral interpreta tion of the universe which is the only thing deserving of the names of science, culture, European civilisation'. This is close to Prince Charles today: 'Of course our descendants will have scientific and technological expertise beyond our imagining but will they have the insight or the self-control to use this wisely...?' The prince is a very rich and unelected man whose views have blighted good people's careers, but here he asks a hugely important question - is humanity a species charging out of control, following one kind of thinking, lemming-like; or are we really sapiens, with the internal, democratic, philosophical levers to control the consequences of our own curiosity? Today, I'd say, our most striking common experience is acceleration - the speeding up of change in everyday life, the exponential growth of biological knowledge and computer power, the 24-hour financial spasms, the dizzying churn of technology. The same goes for the extinction of rival species - the biologist Edward O. Wilson speaks of the 'Hundred Heartbeat Club', his grimly witty name for the animal species which have 100 or fewer members, and are that number of heartbeats away from total extinction - eagles, Javan rhinos, Hawaiian crows, dolphin species, and so on. If the current rate of habitat destruction continues in forests and coral reefs alone, he says, half the species of animals and plants will be gone by the next century: 'Our descendants would inherit a biologically impoverished and homogenised world.' So, for Charles to raise the question of speed and control, the duty of one generation to the next, the problem of reconciling the acceleration of today with the longer rhythms of planetary life, is something he can hardly be mocked for. What, though, of the answer? A return to 'nature' is not it. As Charles suggests, the complexity of life on Earth ought to (and does) inspire humble awe in scientific atheists as well as spiritual believers. But mankind, inside nature, has altered it irrevocably, not least by reproducing with such exponential success. Even if we wanted to clamber back in again to the pre-industrial natural world, with its harsh choices and smaller populations, it is not possible. Nature was never stable, particularly since we were always part of it. Now, with our sprawling populations and needs, there is no return journey available - not short of the greatest catastrophe to occur to our species so far. None of this rules out a more intelligent, knowing approach to land-use, of course: but a return to organic and sustainable farming is a slow thing, which will probably be led by the richest parts of the world and driven by consumer power. The bigger issue is consumer power itself. Charles often puts this in the context of spirituality, but he understands, surely, that to advocate self-restraint, as he does, is to fundamentally challenge consumer capitalism. It is based on appetite, consumption and waste; they are not by-products but driving forces. Wendell Berry's ideal is a deliberately frugal farmer on the banks of the Kentucky river, who does not squander and has put decades of human sweat into his land. He is a model of self-control or, as he would put it, 'good work'. He is the opposite of mass man. Charles's position is unique, so far outside ordinary experience he can offer little practical advice. He is a highly privileged Westerner, crammed with literary knowledge, owning good land and with the leisure and mental gifts to think. Most of the world's population are not living in plenty, have no ambition to return to peasant lives and would greet the news that their materialism was the problem with no little bemusement. Indeed, as the Prince tip-toes towards a full-throated critique of consumer economics, he moves closer to some curious companions, such as the anti-free trade movement and anarcho-green organisations such as People's Global Action. This group, barely mentioned in mainstream journalism, originated in a protest in southern Mexico in 1994 against the North American Free Trade Association, and has held key meetings or 'encounters' in Bangalore, Geneva, Belem in the Amazon and the US. Its keenest supporters include French and Indian farmers, Indonesian trade unionists, even Ukrainian environmentalists. Its geographical reach is as impressive as that of many multi-national corporations. This is possible thanks to the Internet, which is to this generation of anti-capitalists what the illegal printing press was to the Leninists a century ago. There are literally hundreds of links between different anti-capitalism sites and a great slew of advice, information and argument spinning round the world. It all has a tremendous idealistic and romantic appeal. One of the protest groups, Mayday 2000, describes itself as 'a maverick wild child' while the PGA itself speaks of its origins in 'the humid mists of the Chiapas' whence the rebels emerged 'using a jungle-battered laptop computer... people everywhere soon heard of the uprising'. Soon this lot will have their Che as well. Meanwhile, they use homely revolutionary saws, such as 'If you think you are too small to make a difference, try sleeping with a mosquito'. This is hardly, yet, a movement. It is more of a hubbub of concern and anger, a mood, a ragged world-wide heckle against science-driven, free-trading consumerism, which runs from Prince Charles at one extreme and anarchists at the other, with millions of trade unionists, religious groups and non-governmental organisations such as Greenpeace, Jubilee 2000, Christian Aid and the World Development Movement in the middle. It is the inevitable reaction to the vast power of global business, riding on the back of our scientific flowering - ultimately a protest at the effects of the Enlightenment. fields.headline: Lament of a lost people
fields.trailText: The publication of Susan McKay's book,  Northern Protestants - An Unsettled People, as we approach the crucial meeting of the Ulster Unionist Council in Belfast next weekend, could hardly be more timely.
fields.body:
'Everything is black and white. They never realise that it is what lies between that is colourful and interesting. They don't understand shading. In their naivety, they stick to this unquestioning belief in right and wrong. And so they miss all the lovely magic.'

Dermot Seymour was born in the Shankill Road, the Protestant heartland of working-class Belfast. Now one of Ireland's leading painters, these are the words he uses to describe the community into which he was born.

Seymour is one of many people to whom Susan McKay spoke for her book, Northern Protestants - An Unsettled People. Its publication, as we approach the crucial meeting of the Ulster Unionist Council in Belfast next weekend, could hardly be more timely.

The author, one of Ireland's finest journalists, is herself a Northern Protestant who attended the Londonderry High School for Young Ladies.

One of the most telling chapters is her portrait of Derry's Protestant community - which once controlled the city politically but now feels itself a beleaguered minority - and how individuals have tried to come to terms with the new order.

The core of the book is 60 interviews, ranging from middle-class professionals in North Down, the well-heeled 'Gold Coast' which has hardly been touched by the Troubles, to hardline loyalists in Portadown.

The extremes are revealing. An interior designer from North Down admits she has no interest in politics: 'I don't care if it's a united Ireland or British rule, as long as everyone is happy. When things are good politically, people are happy to spend.'

In Portadown, a loyalist talks angrily of betrayal, but looks forward to a different, possibly better, future: 'The paramilitaries are sick of the leadership. The young ones have the hatred. You put a gun in their hands and you'll see.' He ruffles a child's hair and adds: 'I'm bringing up to the gun.'

In between are many nostalgic for a past when a Catholic neighbour would help you out with the milking on 12 July, and fearful of the future. They see the Belfast Agreement as 'a reward for terrorists' and are concerned it will lead to an erosion of the values they hold dear. These include a deep fidelity to evangelical Protestantism, attachment to the land, a civility when dealing 'with the other side' which all too often conceals a mistrust bordering on contempt.

McKay is open about the fact that people would not have talked to her with sometimes uncomfortable honesty unless they had known she was a Protestant. Often an interview starts with hedging questions designed to discover whether the interviewer is 'one of our own'. But this has enabled her to probe into complex and painful elements in the Protestant psyche - the sense of loss and defeat engendered over 30 years, the importance of personal religious experience, the fact that even those who voted for the Agreement often did so reluctantly.

There were exceptions. Poet and critic Tom Paulin wept when he heard that there was a 71 per cent majority in favour of the Agreement and spoke of 'the new model Ulster rising from the wreckage'. But Paulin lives mainly in Oxford and is mainly known in Northern Ireland for his acerbic appearances on BBC2's Late Review.

The jacket of An Unsettled People shows a tattered Ulster flag flying over the deserted field at Drumcree, which Susan McKay describes as 'the last bastion of No Surrender'.

The title comes from John Robb, the Belfast surgeon who founded the New Ireland Movement, dedicated to finding an honourable compromise between the two communities. He described Ulster's Protestants as feeling 'increasingly demoralised and threatened. They are an unsettled people'.

It could be a description of those Ulster Unionist delegates whose support David Trimble will have to win on Saturday.

This book is not without hope. There are people who want to move forward from the bitterness of the past, such as the woman whose husband was murdered by the IRA, but who struggled to overcome her hatred and voted for the Agreement as 'a glimmer of hope'.

Trimble still faces a daunting task. It would help if many people outside his community had a more sympathetic understanding of the complex emotions and fears which have formed the Ulster Protestant community.

This book should be read by the Sinn Fein leadership, Irish Ministers and officials in Dublin and Belfast who are trying to make the new model Ulster a reality for all.

webTitle: Downing St weighs TV debates plan

fields.headline: Downing St weighs TV debates plan
fields.trailText: He is the telegenic Prime Minister, the man who can be trusted to say the right thing in front of the cameras.
fields.body:
He is the telegenic Prime Minister, the man who can be trusted to say the right thing in front of the cameras.

Now it looks as if he could put his talents to good use. Tony Blair is considering going head to head with Opposition leaders in a remarkable series of televised presidential-style debates in the run-up to the next general election.

Proposals put together by the major broadcasters for an unprecedented series of hour-long programmes are being considered by Downing Street.

'The response has been positive,' said one senior ITV executive. 'It was dealt with so badly last time that we thought we would get our request in early so there was plenty of time for discussion.'

Richard Tait, editor-in-chief of ITN, has drawn up a position paper detailing how the debates would work. Blair would appear with the Conservative leader, William Hague, and the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy. The broadcasts would be shared between the main channels.

Downing Street is still weighing up the options. Officials are convinced that, if the Prime Minister's poll lead declines further before the election, expected next May, he will be boosted by a televised debate, as they believe he is a better performer on screen than either Hague or Kennedy.

It would also give Blair a way of communicating more directly with the public without being 'edited' by the media in an interview.

Blair believes that newspapers and broadcasters breed cynicism in the voters because they concentrate on splits and rows. Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, is keen to find new ways for Blair to get his message across. Evidence from America shows that televised presidential debates give the incumbent an advantage rather than the challenger.

If Blair maintains a strong lead in the polls, then Downing Street sources said that it was less likely that he would agree to a debate, as he would have more to lose and less to gain. They are also aware of critics who will accuse Blair of indulging in 'presidential-style' politics. The head-to-head debate is a mainstay of the campaigning armoury in the United States.

Broadcasters are throwing their full weight behind the campaign to get Blair to agree to a debate. The programmes would have a heavyweight presenter as mediator, probably David Dimbleby, and each party leader would be given time for opening statements before detailing their own policies and questioning their opponent.

It is hoped that by having strict rules drawn up in consultation with an independent arbiter, possibly the Hansard Society which promotes democracy, they can convince Blair that the programmes will not simply descend into slanging matches.

The media industry is keen to find new ways of televising political campaigns which have witnessed growing viewer apathy over recent years. During the last election campaign news programmes suffered marked declines in popularity.

It is argued that, by doing the debate, Blair will revitalise political discussion. Television executives say that they are on fertile ground, as low Labour turnouts are worrying the party's election strategists.

If Blair agrees to a head-to-head debate, then broadcasters know they will become a huge television event. In the United States a single mistake can colour a whole campaign. When the Vice-President, Richard Nixon, appeared against the then challenger for the presidency, John Kennedy, Nixon looked flustered and hot under the camera lights. Many analysts put his narrow loss in the election down to his poor television performance.

In outlining the proposals well before the campaign starts, broadcasters are hoping to avoid the row that developed during the run-up to the last election in 1997 when proposals were put together very close to the polling date.

Although John Major agreed to a televised debate, Blair finally declined because he was so far ahead in the polls. 'The Labour leader challenged me to a debate. To his dismay, I accepted. To everyone's amusement, he has run away,' Major said at the time.

The Conservatives accused Blair of being too scared to go ahead with the plan, despite originally saying that he would meet Major in the television studios 'any place, any time'.

Peter Mandelson was a supporter of the idea, but said negotiations with the Tories had broken down because they had played 'party politics' with the plans.

After Blair had withdrawn, Paddy Ashdown, then leader of the Liberal Democrats, also declined to go head-to-head with Major, saying that without all three leaders involved it would be little more than an 'election gimmick'.

webTitle: UK working mothers get poorest deal

fields.headline: UK working mothers get poorest deal
fields.trailText: Leading businesswomen launched a scathing attack on the Government's record on maternity rights last night, claiming that Britain is 'the worst place in Europe to be a working mother'.
fields.body:
Leading businesswomen launched a scathing attack on the Government's record on maternity rights last night, claiming that Britain is 'the worst place in Europe to be a working mother'.

The condemnation came as female executives from overseas, on an advanced management course at the London Business School this month, heard with astonishment of the poor leave arrangements and employer attitudes that high-flying British women face.

Julia Martin, a fund manager, drew gasps from her foreign counterparts when she said she could take just 14 weeks' maternity leave after the birth of her second baby.

'It took me three months just to get used to being a mum,' said Randi Birkeland, mother to four children and a vice president of Norway's Hydro Supply Network. In Norway, as in Denmark and Sweden, women are entitled to a year's paid leave and for a year after they return to work they are entitled to work shorter hours while they continue breast-feeding.

Margareta Le Calvé, general manager of Swedish communications giant Telenordia, has recently been promoted. She is six months' pregnant and expects to make the most of her country's generous parental rights. These include an incentive to fathers to take 10 days' paid leave after the birth and then a further four weeks during the child's first year. Men are also entitled to take some of their partner's entitlement, meaning the total leave can be shared.

Martin said: 'Some of the blokes say "Don't you have to rush home for the children?" They assume it's the woman who will rush home. They think women won't want to travel away from home.'

Mary-Ann Stephenson, director of the Fawcett Society, which campaigns for equality between women and men, said: 'This is not limited to small companies. The majority of male directors of FTSE-100 companies are married with children. The majority of the few women directors are single without children. Yet when we look abroad it is obvious that a company can still be efficient and make lots of money if it looks after its female employees.'

The average woman in Britain has just eight weeks' maternity leave on full pay compared to the European average of 32 weeks.

Stephenson said women in this country have come to accept a poor deal as normal. 'They were allowed into the workplace so long as they worked like men. But the normal working model here is based on just half the population. The whole issue of long hours, the attitude to job-sharing and part-time working for men and women needs to be addressed.'

Julia Mellor, head of the Equal Opportunities Commission, said: 'Employers as well as employees have much to gain from better parental leave and maternity arrangements. Many are concerned about the number of people leaving good jobs because they are not prepared to sacrifice family life for their career.'

Firms in Scandinavia try harder to attract mothers - and then keep them. Le Calvé said: 'Women are now asking for some help or other benefits than salaries so instead of getting a company car or a raise in salary they say, "I want 20 hours a week cleaning paid for by the company".'

Labour MP Ruth Kelly, a member of the 101-strong Labour parliamentary women's group, who wants parents to be paid £150 a week to take three months' leave, said: 'We need a complete rethink of our maternity and parental leave and this is what is going on at the moment at the DTI. We have the Department of Health saying on the one hand that it is wise to breast-feed your baby for the first six months and on the other hand we have maternity leave which means that after the first six weeks the statutory pay is only £59.55 per week.'

Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union, said yesterday at the the National Women's Conference: 'There is a disgraceful pay gap between men and women, and most women suffer in silence from discrimination at work.'

He said that the right for all workers to be represented by a union, which comes into effect on 6 June, will benefit women especially.

webTitle: Forgery scare clouds work of US master

fields.headline: Forgery scare clouds work of US master
fields.trailText: Lewis Hine's iconic photographs, which immortalised the honest, hard-working labourers who built America, hang on tens of thousands of restaurant and living-room walls. But now his famous images - including the one of workmen lunching precariously on scaffolding during the construction of the RCA Building in New York, above - are the focus of one of the biggest forgery scandals to rock the art world.
fields.body:
Lewis Hine's iconic photographs, which immortalised the honest, hard-working labourers who built America, hang on tens of thousands of restaurant and living-room walls. But now his famous images - including the one of workmen lunching precariously on scaffolding during the construction of the RCA Building in New York, above - are the focus of one of the biggest forgery scandals to rock the art world.

Hundreds of prints now appear not to be the work of the photographer at all. Hine, who died in 1940 in poverty, kept a careful record of how many prints were made of each of his pictures, which can fetch up to £30,000 at auction. In New York recently, a print of his classic 'steam fitter' photograph was offered for $60,000 (£40,000).

But a New York dealer discovered the possibility of forgery after he had a print tested forensically and found that the paper dated from a decade after Hine's death. A major inquiry, involving galleries, private collectors and dealers on both sides of the Atlantic, has called into question the provenance of up to 600 prints, worth millions of pounds. Many are believed to be in Britain and Europe.

The revelations shocked the art world. Photography has been seen as relatively immune from forgery, but in recent years there has been an explosion in prices of photographic prints and dealers fear it will be paralleled by a rise in fakes. The false Hine prints appear to have fooled many. At least six leading New York art dealers are embroiled in a lawsuit and a number of British collectors are anxiously checking their own works. At least one expert has speculated that one Hine print - 'Three Riveters on the Empire State Building' - sold by Sotheby's last year for £12,000 might be 'one of the posthumous prints'.

The forgeries have been cleverly done. Many carry his signature and a stamp from his studio on the back. Some had been artificially made to look older.

fields.headline: New Establishment parties on
fields.standfirst: Kamal Ahmed  finds out who's on the new  A-list for cocktail parties, media soirées, book launches and birthday parties
fields.trailText: Durbar Court is one of the most remarkable pieces of architecture in Whitehall. Light filters through a glass roof made up of hundreds of separate panes. The tile friezes are designed by Minton. Guests sweep down palatial stairs onto paving of the finest Greek, Italian and Belgian marble.
fields.body:
Durbar Court is one of the most remarkable pieces of architecture in Whitehall. Light filters through a glass roof made up of hundreds of separate panes. The tile friezes are designed by Minton. Guests sweep down palatial stairs onto paving of the finest Greek, Italian and Belgian marble.

The court, designed by Matthew Digby Wyatt and first used for a reception for the Sultan of Turkey in the 1870s, sits at the heart of the Foreign Office - a place for entertaining the great and good, world leaders, kings and queens, a home for the Establishment.

On Friday, 12 May, Helena Kennedy, liberal lawyer, scourge of the Right, promoter of human rights, head of the British Council, held her fiftieth birthday party there.

The guest list was a window on a new British phenomenon, peopled by those who eat together and drink together in a series of parties and gatherings that mark a departure from the old season of Ascot, Henley and tennis at Queen's club.

This is the new summer season: the birthday parties and 'at homes', the publish ing bashes and media shindigs at which members of a New Establishment and their friends meet and swap anecdotes about life at the top of government, the law, arts, publishing and the media. Many are of Britain's liberal Left. But not all: the New Establishment prides itself on being non-exclusive in a faintly exclusive kind of way.

Kennedy's party was the first event of the 'new season'. The guests included Clive Hollick, a Labour peer and head of the United News and Media group, which owns Express Newspapers.

Also there was Melvyn Bragg, another Labour peer and head of his own production company.

Alongside, drinking champagne and eating canapes, were the actor Alan Rickman and his partner Rima Horton; Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland Secretary and New Labour architect; Derry Irvine, Lord Chancellor and the man who launched Cherie Booth and Tony Blair's legal careers; Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman; Jenny Topper, the head of Hampstead Theatre and often tipped as the next director of the National Theatre in London; John Birt, former director-general of the BBC, and his wife Jane; and actor Bill Patterson.

The following Thursday came another key event - Jeremy Paxman's birthday party, also his fiftieth, at the Cobden Club in west London. Robert Harris, author and journalist, was there, as were Ruth Rogers, the woman behind the River Café restaurant in London, and her husband, the architect, Richard. Lenny Henry sang.

Here we take a short diversion before continuing on the new season trail. It needs to be carefully defined early on what exactly the New Establishment is.

This is not the old Establishment, which keeps its dirty linen hidden and its arguments carefully locked away, an impenetrable linking mechanism between the Government, the judiciary, the police, often by way of the freemasons.

The New Establishment is more obvious and therefore, some argue, less influential than it seems on the surface. Lose a few of the key power brokers (for example at a general election) and the grouping would flounder.

It would be easy to say that the New Establishment is a New Labour grouping. Easy, but wrong. Many of its members would blanch if they were described as New Labour, even though they count Cabinet Ministers as their closest friends. Spikiness bordering on the contrary is a key trait of new season guest lists.

Take two as an illustration: Kennedy and Richard Rogers. Both have fallen out with the Government to a greater or lesser extent.

Last week Kennedy, in an interview with the New Statesman, said that Labour was in danger of being seen as a bunch of 'fixers' rather than a modern government.

Then there is Rogers, the architect who thinks that New Labour is not doing enough to promote regeneration of the inner cities.

Last night, at another of the new season events, the New Establishment gathered at the house of Will Hutton, economics expert, former editor of The Observer and now head of the Industrial Society, for yet another fiftieth birthday. Being 50 is not a prerequisite for membership, by the way.

Hutton is perfect new season material, residing comfortably in the semi-attached world of not quite in, not quite out of the New Labour tent - a well-connected critic and sometime friend.

Also there were the Women's Minister Tessa Jowell, Kennedy, the Rogers and Alan Rusbridger, editor of the Guardian.

This afternoon they will meet again at the Rogers home for a party laid on for Matthew Evans, chairman of publishers Faber and Faber and new head of the Museums, Libraries and Archive Commission, and his wife Caroline Michel, head of publishers Vintage. Other guests include authors Martin Amis (who will no doubt bump into a few people he saw at his own book launch last week) and Ian McEwan, Chris Smith, Minister of Culture, Media and Sport, Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate, Richard Eyre, former director of the National, Baroness Jay, Labour leader in the Lords, and Higher Education Minister Tessa Blackstone.

There are two other key events in the new season calendar, which must of course be over by the end of Wimbledon tennis fortnight, as people begin making their plans for the school holidays and their annual leave before returning for a brief sojourn to the Edinburgh International Festival.

Both are in June and both, of course, are in London. One is the Faber and Faber summer party, where once again it will be 'hello, you again'. Evans is the host at the evening event, held for the past four years in a billowing marquee in Queen's Square gardens. Among the candles and champagne will be the Rogerses, Bragg, Mandelson, Kavanagh, Barnes, Kennedy, poet laureate Andrew Motion and playwright David Hare.

The event is organised by Joanna Mackle, Faber's publishing director, herself a good new establishmentarian who was a guest at the Rogers' party. She, as ever, will be resplendent in a Phillip Tracey hat, a rose affair this year which will cause the usual admiring glances.

The other key event is Rusbridger's summer party, which will be held at that new cathedral to the new establishment, the Tate Modern.

This event has a new season invite list par excellence - Barnes, Amis, the Rogerses, Bragg, the political heavyweights of Mandelson, Brown and Alastair Campbell. The party is also the place to spot some of the newcomers, the people who have made an impact in the past year. Expect to see new authors Zadie Smith and Harland Miller, Sacha Baron Cohen (alias Ali G), Daisy Donovan of The 11 O'Clock Show and a whole host of dot.com millionaires including Martha Lane Fox and Brett Hoberman.

Already there is talk of a new New Establishment, but that might get a little confusing.

webTitle: Revealed: IRA man's key role in Trimble's desperate peace bid

fields.headline: Revealed: IRA man's key role in Trimble's desperate peace bid
fields.trailText: A former IRA killer has emerged as a key player in David Trimble's bitter struggle to persuade his fellow Ulster Unionists to back the latest phase in the peace process.
fields.body:
A former IRA killer has emerged as a key player in David Trimble's bitter struggle to persuade his fellow Ulster Unionists to back the latest phase in the peace process.

Sean O'Callaghan, the former IRA commander, helped Trimble rally his wary troops last week, launching a battle against the rising tide of scepticism over the IRA's offer to put their arms beyond use.

O'Callaghan is understood to have told a number of sceptics inside the Ulster Unionist Party, including the deputy leader John Taylor, that the IRA was serious about its proposal and that the war was well and truly over.

Speaking from a secret location in Britain yesterday, O'Callaghan - who still fears for his life - said: 'My advice to the Ulster Unionists is that the war is over, historical armed republicanism is no more.

'The new war will be fought on the political and cultural battlefield and I believe unionists and democrats should take up that fight. The question is do unionists want to take up that new fight or are they prepared to fight on with the old war? They have to realise that the IRA's armed struggle is over.'

Several of Trimble's closest allies were nervous and deeply uncertain about the IRA plan to put arms beyond use and allow international observers to monitor arms dumps. Their caution led to the postponement of yesterday's proposed Ulster Unionist Council meeting.

According to informed sources O'Callaghan spoke with Taylor following the MP's meeting with Tony Blair at Downing Street last Wednesday. Taylor was said to have been 'disappointed' in the Prime Minister's attitude but O'Callaghan retorted: 'And do you think Blair is happy with you?'

In recent days O'Callaghan has been lobbying UUP members who are uncertain which way to vote next Saturday when the 860-strong party council decides if it will return to government, sharing power with Sinn Fein.

As a volunteer in the East Tyrone brigade, O'Callaghan shot dead a Catholic RUC offi cer and was involved in a mortar attack on an army base which killed a woman soldier. He subsequently recanted and offered his services to the Irish police. Among the plots he helped the security forces foil was an attempt to kill Princess Diana and Prince Charles at a charity rock concert in London.

The former IRA killer first met Trimble after leaving prison in December 1996. Following the second IRA ceasefire in July 1997, he sent Trimble a fax outlining why he should enter political talks with Sinn Fein - at a time when many other unionists were threatening to boycott negotiations if republicans were included.

While in prison O'Callaghan corresponded with an eclectic array of individuals - including establishment figures such as Lord Cranborne, then leader of the Tories in the House of Lords. He subsequently persuaded Cranborne to back the Good Friday accord and canvass support for it among the unionist community.

This week O'Callghan is poised to write press articles and give television interviews in the run up to Saturday's critical decision.

Trimble strategists have also deployed the arguments of other republicans - who would regard O'Callaghan as a traitor to the cause. An article by Tommy McKearney, a former IRA hunger striker is being distributed to delegates this weekend. In it, McKearney argues that the IRA offer effectively marks the end of the Provisionals' war and that putting weapons beyond use is 'decommissioning by other means.'

But the strategy of using republican voices to win over loyalists may fall on deaf ears. Even some Unionist MPs are unaware of who the republican sceptics are and what they are saying. One such is Willie Thompson, MP for West Tyrone, a consistent opponent of the Good Friday Agreement and critic of Trimble's leadership. He fears that if republicans do not get their way, they will revert to force.

When it was put to him that those with intimate knowledge of the republican movement - former prisoners like McKearney and other dissident republican intellectuals - were convinced the IRA offer signalled the end of the war, the MP said: 'I'm sorry, who are they? I've never heard of them.'

One of Trimble's closest allies summed up the prob lems that beset the UUP leader as he attempts to persuade his party that the IRA is serious about peace: 'If an MP doesn't know or care to read what the most articulate republican sceptics are saying about the IRA offer, then look how difficult it's going to be to get through to the farmer from Fermanagh or the businessman in Ballymena.'

By the end of this week we will know if the influence of a man who once vowed to physically destroy the union, Sean O'Callaghan, will be strong enough to help persuade a sufficient number of Ulster Unionists that the war machine of which he was once a part of is about to be decommissioned.

webTitle: Penny-pinching Brits spend least on food

fields.headline: Penny-pinching Brits spend least on food
fields.trailText: There may be a consumer boom under way, but British shoppers are among the canniest in Europe when it comes to bargain hunting for food,  writes Sarah Ryle.
fields.body:
There may be a consumer boom under way, but British shoppers are among the canniest in Europe when it comes to bargain hunting for food, writes Sarah Ryle.

Spending on leisure and homes may be buoyant, but new research shows more than a million British shoppers spend less than £20 a week on groceries.

And it's not just people on meagre incomes who shop on the cheap.'What we have found is that millions of our customers buy the sort of things that they think nobody will notice are cheap from the value line range,' said Simon Soffe, spokesman for Tesco, which carried out the research. 'They mix value loo roll, bin bags, margarine, beans and even lager in with other items.'

Supermarkets have locked horns in a year-round price war in response to increasingly cost-conscious shoppers. Two litres of washing-up liquid for 15p and tins of lager for 32p are some of the examples that are proving increasingly popular alternatives to household name brands.

'The products have to have some element of quality, otherwise people won't buy them,' added Soffe. 'We also have to include healthy options, such as wholemeal rolls and vegetables, because we are aware that many of the one million people who spend £20 or less are genuinely having to count every penny.'

Average spending on food has fallen from 26 per cent of the average household's weekly budget in 1968 to 17 per cent, according to recent official figures. The weekly shop costs an average £59 but households now spend £60 on leisure activities.

'The products have to have some element of quality, otherwise people won't buy them,' added Soffe. Average spending on food has fallen from 26 per cent of the average household's weekly budget in 1968 to 17 per cent, according to recent official figures. The weekly shop costs an average £59 but households now spend £60 on leisure activities.

webTitle: Straw braced for benefit cut revolt

fields.headline: Straw braced for benefit cut revolt
fields.trailText: Prominent Labour peers are likely to join Tories and Liberal Democrats tomorrow to crush government plans to slash benefits for people who breach community punishments. Among the rebels will be Labour's Baroness Helena Kennedy QC.
fields.body:
Prominent Labour peers are likely to join Tories and Liberal Democrats tomorrow to crush government plans to slash benefits for people who breach community punishments. Among the rebels will be Labour's Baroness Helena Kennedy QC.

This latest rebellion, the most serious since the Lords overturned the Government's plans on jury reform, will be a serious embarrassment to the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, already under fire this weekend for allowing boxer Mike Tyson into Britain for the second time.

Under plans drawn up by the Home Office and the Department of Social Security, benefits could be withdrawn for up to six months. Last year 30,000 people failed to comply with a community order, a number which the Government hopes the tough new deterrent will reduce.

Probation officers will be obliged to inform the courts when a community order is breached for the second time, at which point benefit will be automatically cut.

Opponents of the legislation, contained in the Child Support, Pensions and Social Security Bill, argue that it will encourage offenders to return to crime and deter probation officers from taking offenders back to court.

The rebel peers say the measures also target the poorest members of society.

The Lords' rebellion is led by the Conservative peer, Lord Windlesham, who has tabled an amendment to delete the relevant sections of the Bill along with Baroness Kennedy, Liberal Democrat Lord Russell and the Bishop of Lincoln.

'This impacts on the poor and not anyone else. This legislation is fundamentally flawed and goes against the values of the Labour Party,' said Kennedy.

The legislation passed through the House of Commons with ease, but its second reading was only narrowly passed by the Lords. The rebels, backed by the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders and the National Association of Probation Officers, are confident of victory at committee stage.

Opponents believe the measures contained in the new legislation breach the right to a fair trial under the European Convention of Human Rights, introduced into British law in October.

webTitle: British cash behind bid to combat Mugabe

fields.headline: British cash behind bid to combat Mugabe
fields.standfirst: Top Tories backing pro-democracy trust are accused of promoting their own interests, report  Pete Sawyer and  Martin Bright
fields.trailText: A prominent group of British and American politicians and businessmen - many with energy and mining interests in Zimbabwe - are behind an international organisation to fund opposition to the regime of Robert Mugabe.
fields.body:
A prominent group of British and American politicians and businessmen - many with energy and mining interests in Zimbabwe - are behind an international organisation to fund opposition to the regime of Robert Mugabe.

The Zimbabwe Democracy Trust, whose patrons include former Tory Foreign Secretaries Malcolm Rifkind, Douglas Hurd and Geoffrey Howe has been accused of using the organisation as a cover for promoting the interests of Western multi-nationals in the troubled region.

Violence erupted in the southern African country when veterans of the colonial struggle began occupying the farms of white settlers and attacking members of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. So far about 19 supporters have been killed and around 400 homes destroyed or occupied.

According to ZDT literature, the organisation 'has the simplest of goals: to help the democratic will of the people flourish'. But The Observer can reveal that several of the patrons of the newly formed trust are directors of companies which have substantial commercial interests at stake in Zimbabwe. ZDT keeps its membership secret for fear of reprisals from the Mugabe regime, but The Observer has discovered that they largely come from the white business community in Zimbabwe.

In April, ZDT organised the visit to London and Washington of Morgan Tsvingirai, the leader of the Movement for Democratic Change, the main opposition group in Zimbabwe. During the visits he met British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook and the US Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, Susan Rice.

The visits followed a visit to South Africa with an itinerary which included meetings with prominent figures in the business community, including the mining giant Anglo-American, which has interests in Zimbabwe.

The driving force behind ZDT is Sir John Collins, the Zimbabwean Chairman of National Power, Britain's largest energy company, who organised a letter to the Times, published in April, calling for free elections. He did not say his company had substantial interests in Zimbabwe; in 1998 National Power won a $1.5 billion contract to develop a power station in the country.

Sir Malcolm Rifkind has a long-standing connection to the country where he worked as a lecturer prior to independence. He works for the Australian mining company Broken Hill Proprietary which has been involved in a wrangle with the Mugabe government over a mine in Zimbabwe.

Former US Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs Dr Chester Crocker is another patron - a director of Ashanti Gold Fields, which owns Zimbabwe's largest gold mine. When approached by The Observer, he said: 'I have nothing personally to gain from supporting the Zimbabwe Democracy Trust. They were reaching out for like-minded people and I am like-minded.'

Lord Hurd, who has no known interests in Zimbabwe, said that the patrons of ZDT were aware that some people would accuse the organisation of neo-colonialism: 'The risk was in our minds when we decided to proceed, but we are not going to just sit with sticking plaster on our mouths. If anybody chooses to make xenophobic and racist comments about what we are doing, then so be it.'

Concerns about 'European' funding of the MDC were raised by South African Ministers visiting Britain last week with President Thabo Mbeki.

Analysts and advisers close to the MDC have raised concerns that Zimbabwe Democracy Trust could be playing into Mugabe's hands by allowing him to suggest the opposition is a front for white 'Rhodesian' business interests.

John Makumbe, lecturer in political science at Harare University and a supporter of the MDC, said: 'It cannot be ruled out that the ZDT viewed the Movement for Democratic Change as a way of facilitating their own interests. It is largely white Rhodesians who are backing the trust. Morgan is fully aware of the ZDT agenda'

On Friday, Harare's Herald newspaper, which acts as the mouthpiece for Mugabe, claimed that American and British financial interests were plotting to overthrow the Government. ZDT has threatened to sue over the claims. Zimbabwe Democracy Trust spokesman Patrick Robertson said: 'The ZDT was set up to make sure there is a free and fair election in Zimbabwe. All our patrons have been involved in the country in one way or another. All the more reason to want to protect it.'

David Anderson, a Zimbabwe expert at London University's School of Oriental and African Studies, said: 'The Movement for Democratic Change is backed by a mixture of self-serving Europeans and those who are genuinely liberal. The opposition wants to remove Mugabe and corruption, but they are not radicals.

'They get support from the lower orders, as any opposition would, but they don't really represent the landless.'

webTitle: Men wax up to gain more pulling power

fields.headline: Men wax up to gain more pulling power
fields.trailText: Men are tearing their hair out to attract the opposite sex, according to high street retailers and beauty salons.
fields.body:
Men are tearing their hair out to attract the opposite sex, according to high street retailers and beauty salons.

Women have said it for years: back hair is seldom appealing, but men expect their partners to put up with it. The fairer sex spends millions of pounds a year on keeping legs smooth, bikini lines neat and underarms fuzz-free to conform with male expectations of beauty. Now men are responding to women's demands that they too must make sacrifices.

'Sales of home-waxing kits rose by 41 per cent this month and our customer panel and focus groups report that the increase, which is higher than anything we've seen in previous years, is because men are asking women to buy kits for them,' said a spokeswoman for Tesco.

Boots, which has two shops in Bristol and Edinburgh specifically for men's products and grooming treatments, introduced back and chest waxes two months ago.

'It used to be something only gay men did,' said Boots Men project manager Phil Thomson. 'Now there are two main reasons why men want to have a smooth back or chest. The first is that women don't like really hirsute men. The second is for sport.

'Chest waxes are promoted as the boxer's wax, back waxes as the swimmer's wax and leg waxes as the cyclist's wax.'

John, a 42-year-old builder from Hertfordshire, would die rather than admit he let his girlfriend rip the hairs off his back for the first time this year. 'I reckon quite a few of them do it, just like they dye their hair but won't admit it. I just had a hairy back and of course I can't even see it, but my girlfriend didn't like it. In the end I let her wax it. It wasn't really that painful. It felt like pinpricks.'

But Dave Parkin, a 29-year-old business writer from Wales, is one of the new breed of men who waxes without shame, if not without pain. 'I decided to get it done before I went on holiday,' he explained. 'All the women I know say how much they hate hair on shoulders and backs. I decided I would feel more confident on the beach if I got rid of it. 'It was the most painful thing I have ever experienced. I had to grit my teeth each time she put the wax on and laid that cloth strip on it.'

Tesco said sales of home-waxing kits and depilatory creams to women are fairly constant through the year, because they always feel the need to be hair-free. 'We noticed that suddenly the wax strips were shooting off the shelves and our routine market research tells us that women are buying them for men,' said the spokeswoman.

Wax kits are more popular for men than the creams that women favour because male hair is much tougher and the creams are not strong enough to do the job, she added.

Tesco believes the exposure given to David Beckham's new back tattoo and to smooth-chested icons such as flamenco dancer Joaquín Cortés are also having an impact on men's self-image.

A seasonal factor is also at play, said Boots. 'Back waxing is a new summer service for men,' said Thomson. 'It isn't something they would really bother about while they can cover it up.'

fields.headline: Alliance support ready to rally
fields.trailText: The Countryside Alliance is threatening to mobilise half-a-million rural campaigners in the biggest demonstration seen in post-war Britain if the Government bows to pressure to introduce anti-hunting legislation.
fields.body:
The Countryside Alliance is threatening to mobilise half-a-million rural campaigners in the biggest demonstration seen in post-war Britain if the Government bows to pressure to introduce anti-hunting legislation.

The Alliance claims it has 400,000 members, but believes it could call on thousands more if it took to the streets, as it did with the Countryside Rally three years ago.

In the run-up to the next election, the Alliance leadership has decided to rebrand the organisation as the voice of rural Britain in an attempt to counter claims that it is merely a front for the bloodsports lobby.

Countryside Alliance spokesman Nigel Henson said members would await the response of the Government to the inquiry by Lord Burns into hunting with dogs - due out at the end of this month. But he added: 'The Government will find fierce resistance if it goes ahead.'

Over the next year the Alliance plans to campaign on rural crime and spearhead the fight against cutbacks on post offices, banks and bus services.

Later this month the Alliance will endorse 'Crime Protection Kits' produced by the police for people living in isolated farms. These kits will contain information on securing vulnerable properties and identifying possible perpetrators to the police.

The Staffordshire force will be the first to issue kits, but the Alliance plans to roll out the scheme across the country.

The organisation has also printed tens of thousands of postcards to be placed in the windows of rural post offices with instructions on how to campaign against closures.

Simon Pope, spokesman for the Campaign for the Protection of Hunted Animals, an umbrella group for the RSPCA, International Fund for Animal Welfare and League Against Cruel Sports, said: 'The Alliance is interested in one thing. To stop the Government banning hunting. They know 90 per cent of public opinion is against them so they are trying to wrap up this issue with general countryside concerns. It just won't wash.'
