webTitle: British women feel the benefit of sex revolution

fields.headline: British women feel the benefit of sex revolution
fields.standfirst: But new Shere Hite report says men fail in bed, writes  Anthony Browne
fields.trailText: After years of research, what British women have long complained about and British men have secretly feared has been confirmed: British men are flops in bed. British women, by contrast, are the most sexually liberated and self-confident in the English-speaking world.
fields.body:
After years of research, what British women have long complained about and British men have secretly feared has been confirmed: British men are flops in bed. British women, by contrast, are the most sexually liberated and self-confident in the English-speaking world.

The findings are from a new report from the researcher credited with fuelling the sexual revolution when she lifted the lid on women's sexuality in the Seventies. Shere Hite's groundbreaking book, The Hite Report on Female Sexuality - an exposé of American women's secret sexual feelings - caused a sensation when it was published in 1976, and has since sold 20 million copies worldwide. In The New Hite Report , to be published next month, she has extended it to look at the differences between US women and those from the UK, Australia and New Zealand.

After extensive interviews and surveys, Hite concludes that British women have got more out of the sexual revolution - and have less reservations about it - than women elsewhere. British women are less likely to think that the new sexual freedom cheapened sex and less likely to think that it increased social instability. They are also less likely to be concerned by double standards such as 'sexy women are not respectable'.

'Women in the US, Australia and New Zealand more often make ironic or barbed comments when asked their opinion of this [sexual] freedom than their UK counterparts, whether Scottish, Irish, Welsh or English. UK women are most likely to point out the positive sides of the "new sexual freedom for women,"' writes Hite.

British women are also more self-confident about sex, and more likely to want it. According to the report, 29 per cent of British women say they desire it daily, compared to 22 per cent of Australians.

British women are also more at ease with their bodies, with a far greater proportion likely to think their genitals smell good and are much less likely to think they are ugly. 'Clearly UK women now show a more positive regard to their sexual anatomy than US women,' says the report, which points out that sales of vaginal deodorants are lower in the UK.

Within the UK, it seems to be English women in particular who are the most liberated. 'English women seem to have a richer fantasy life, including fantasies they tell their partners, than women in Scotland and Northern Ireland,' says Hite.

However, British men consumed by sexual angst will find the book depressing reading - apparently, there are plenty of good reasons for them to feel inadequate. British women may be more likely to know what they want but they are less likely to get it. They are slightly more likely to have an orgasm during sex, but overall they are far less satisfied with their partners than women elsewhere.

Almost two-thirds of British women complain that their men are ill-informed about the sexual desires of a woman's body - far more than in other countries. Only a third praise their husbands or lovers for their sexual skill and imagination. British men are also far more likely to put in routine performance during sex. More than 60 per cent of UK women complained that sex with men followed a regular pattern, compared to just 44 per cent of New Zealand women.

'UK women are most likely to say that a new partner needs to be taught everything and that before that he is completely unaware and misinformed,' concludes Hite. Almost two-thirds of British women allow their partners to think they have climaxed when they haven't.

One woman interviewed by Hite echoed a common theme when she said: 'No, my partner is not sensitive to what I like and frankly doesn't seem to notice if I am enjoying what he likes or not.'

But despite their complaints, British women show a remarkably stoical - even tolerant - attitude towards their men. The book says that, compared to elsewhere, women from Britain are more likely to have regular sex with a man if they don't have an orgasm with him. They are also more likely to feel guilty about masturbating.

Despite the inadequacies of British men, British women are also less likely to have a sexual relationship with other women. The survey shows that that 15 per cent of British women have had a sexual relationship with another women - although 71 per cent told Hite that they were curious and would like to try.

In contrast, 19 per cent of Australian women have had a sexual relationship with another women, with 78 per cent saying that they were curious.

The New Hite Report will be published by Hamlyn on 5 June at £12.99.

The measure of our satisfaction

 British women are more positive about the sexual revolution: 14 per cent thought it had cheapened sex, compared to 21 per cent in Australia, and 17 per cent in New Zealand.

 British women are more likely to want sex: 29 per cent said they desired sex daily, compared to 22 per cent in Australia, and 24 per cent in New Zealand.

 English women are less embarrassed about their genitalia: 12 per cent of English women think their genitals are ugly, compared to 18 per cent in Australia, 24 per cent in Scotland and 30 per cent in the US.

 British women are more frustrated with their men: Only 17 per cent said their partners were well informed about their bodies, compared to 21 per cent in Australia, and 25 per cent in New Zealand.

fields.headline: Driving you wild
fields.standfirst: The Toyota Land Cruiser Amazon thinks it's a tiger, but it's more of a pussycat, says Natalie Sutton
fields.trailText: The Toyota Land Cruiser Amazon thinks it's a tiger, but it's more of a pussycat.
fields.body:
I may not look like a petrol-head, or a diesel-head for that matter, but I consider myself an old hand when it comes to Land Cruisers. I last drove one a couple of years ago when working on a safari park in the South Luangwa, Zambia. We prided ourselves on providing a rather more authentic approach to game viewing and, in keeping with our theme, my vehicle looked as though it had emerged, Livingstone-like, after many years in the wilderness. It would be impolite to mention its exact age but I suspect that it belonged to one of the earlier generations of Land Cruisers from half a century ago. It was an open pick-up with benches screwed onto the back, allowing the tourists to feel at one with the wildlife. Scornful of the zebra-striped, air-conditioned vehicles used in Kenya and Tanzania, our clients came for a taste of the real Africa.

But all hopes of a peaceful game-viewing drive disappeared the moment the diesel-powered engine started up with a roar and an enormous cloud of black smoke. Any animal within a 10-mile radius could hear us coming. The interesting ones had a habit of scarpering and those that knew we were no threat just looked a little bored. The clients swayed around with precious little suspension to protect them from rough terrain, roads with potholes the size of swimming pools and from bumpy rides through sand rivers and waterholes. The steering wheel was huge and needed all my body weight to turn it. My face betrayed my embarrassment as I often had to struggle when changing from two-wheel to four-wheel drive.

Apart from having to get out of the vehicle and manually adjust the wheel locks, the shift only behaved after a strange ritual of driving backwards and forwards a few times. There was usually a tense atmosphere when the engine was left idling while we observed the game at close range, even though I remained in first gear and reassured the clients that taking my foot off the brake was all we needed if a leopard looked ready to pounce or an elephant was showing signs of charging. (For your information, if their ears start flapping, it's time to hit the accelerator.) We had a few close shaves but none that could be blamed on the trusty, rusty Land Cruiser, which was reliable to the end and which, despite its faults and its driver, was great fun.

Comparing my African experiences with driving the new Toyota Land Cruiser Amazon (admittedly in deepest, darkest Surrey) is a bit like trying to find similarities between a sit-up-and- beg bone-shaker and a Harley-Davidson. The 4.7 litre, V8 petrol engine is not quite silent but certainly a purr compared to a roar. It is clearly very powerful and acceleration to 80 mph on the motorway felt stable and smooth. Its top speed is given as 109 mph and apparently this is due to the independent front suspension and the steering control. I'm a bit of a novice when it comes to four-speed electronically controlled automatic gearboxes and, personally, I prefer the challenge of a manual, but driving on the flat was an effortless pleasure.

I was seated higher than most other drivers and felt that nobody was going to argue with me, whatever I did. Nobody flashed at me for hogging the middle lane, and when I came up behind cars in the fast lane they got out of my way. The Amazon is also undeniably comfortable. It seats seven in business-class style, making long journeys a delight for passengers and driver alike. Economically, however, 17 miles per gallon is a high price to pay for the back-seat headrests and all that legroom. Also, despite its impressive power steering, the Amazon's size makes parking much more of an effort - especially in central London.

At the risk of upsetting ramblers, I took the Amazon off-road and was amazed at the ease with which this permanent four-wheel drive dealt with steep hills, thick mud and uneven or nonexistent road surfaces. I imagine that driving a Hovercraft must feel like this. It was so easy, though, that I felt a bit cheated and missed the thrill and sense of achievement that comes with scaling great heights (usually termite mounds) by driving skill alone. Another niggle: it strikes me that a cream carpet and matching leather upholstery is a strange choice of interior decor for an off-road vehicle.

Overall the Amazon left me feeling confused; I can't work out who it is aimed at. It's too smart, too perfect and, I imagine, too easy for the 'gripped' fraternity of serious off-roaders. Personally, I would be frightened of splattering it with mud and ruining the luxurious finishes. Having a six-disc CD changer, storage space for sunglasses and drink holders between the two front seats seems similarly at odds with a vehicle that claims to be 'designed to cope with the most arduous conditions'.

So, although a climate-control function might have been tempting, I don't think I would have swapped the Amazon for its Africa-based counterpart which, in my opinion, was far more fun to drive. I imagine that the Amazon is largely bought by families who need it for school runs and overloaded trips from the supermarket. Forgive the cynicism, but their off-road parking is probably about as 'gripped' as it'll get.

fields.headline: Potted history
fields.standfirst: When it comes to the peculiarly British shrimp, there's no such thing as pot luck. By Sybil Kapoor
fields.trailText: When it comes to the peculiarly British shrimp, there's no such thing as pot luck.
fields.body:
An American diner in Simpson's-in-the-Strand was recently appalled to discover that her potted shrimp contained butter. Were they trying to kill her? The shrimp were duly whisked away. How could they explain to such a guest the intense pleasure of eating such a dish?

The appreciation of potted brown shrimp, infused with mace, cayenne pepper and a hint of anchovy essence, is peculiarly British. Prize the butter off the top of their little plastic tub, dip into the pink succulent meat below, and for a brief moment you are near the sea. An intense shrimpy aroma tickles your nose as you crumble and scoop the tiny crustaceans on to your toast. And then that taste...

The best ready-made potted shrimp come from James Baxter & Son in Morecambe, Lancashire. For 200 years, the Baxter family has sold the local brown shrimp ( Crangon crangon ) that scavenge on the shallow, sandy beds. 'We no longer catch them ourselves,' explains Richard Baxter, now 70, 'but we have used the same fishing families for 40 years or more.' As soon as the netted shrimp are pulled in, they are riddled (sorted by hand) so that the smallest can be returned to the sea. The shrimp are then boiled in seawater to retain their sweet freshness. Once landed, deft-handed 'pickers' will straighten out each shrimp, twist off its head and unwrap its shell. Mr Baxter buys six to eight tons of these each year.

Like all canny food producers, he refuses to be drawn on his potting methods, except to say that everything is done manually. 'We re-clean, cook and cool them, and that is as far as I'm going to say,' he firmly states.

I prize off their buttery crust and take a speculative bite from the densely packed flesh. A hint of lemony mace, a touch of cayenne when simmered in butter? By bite three, I have given up - they are just too good to analyse.

However, if you cannot wait for the post, you could always sample Richard Blades' version at Simpson's-in-the-Strand. His are an unorthodox but delicious modern variation. The peeled brown shrimp are gently stewed in unsalted butter with sautéed onion and a little white wine, then seasoned with cayenne pepper, nutmeg, mace, anchovy essence and finely chopped dill, tarragon, chervil and parsley. Once cool, they are packed into pots and covered by a thin layer of butter. They must be eaten within a day or two. Hardly a problem among Simpson's customers, who snaffle them up faster than the smoked salmon and roast beef.

 To order, contact James Baxter & Son, Thornton Road, Morecambe, Lancashire LA4 5PB (01524 410 910) and allow for some delay, as orders are dependent on the catch. Also available from: Blagden Fishmongers, 65 Paddington Street, London W1 (020 7935 8321). Simpson's-in-the-Strand, 100 Strand, London WC2 (0207 836 9112)

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Newspapers in fresh legal bid over Shayler documents
fields.body:
Newspapers in fresh legal bid over Shayler documents

The Observer and the Guardian return to court tomorrow to challenge a decision by the Central Criminal Court in March that the newspapers should hand over any material concerning alleged breaches of Official Secrets Acts by the former MI5 officer David Shayler. Editors Roger Alton and Alan Rusbridger are applying for judicial review of the decision by Judge Martin Stephens, which their lawyers believe is in breach of the European Convention of Human Rights.

Prisoners face tighter security

New security measures at Rampton, Broadmoor and Ashworth mental hospitals are to be ordered by the Government.

The new measures include random drug-testing and locking high-risk prisoners in their rooms at night.

Straw brother on sex charge

William Straw, the 46-year-old brother of the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, has been charged with indecently assaulting a 16-year-old girl.

Straw already faces a charge of common assault against another 16-year-old girl.

He was granted police bail and is due to appear before Nottingham Magistrates Court on Tuesday.

Robin Oakley and the BBC

In an article headed 'BBC risks row over key TV post', May 14 2000, we reported on Robin Oakley's retirement as political editor of the BBC and the appointment of Andrew Marr as his successor later this year.

We wish to confirm that Robin Oakley's political views (of which we have no knowledge) have not influenced him in his role at the BBC, and he has always acted with complete impartiality.

The Observer Debate

Welcome to Britain? Is Britain's treatment of asylum-seekers fair? A panel including Jack Straw, Ann Widdecombe and Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, will debate the issues, with contributions from an invited audience and questions from the public.

The debate is on Monday, 5 June, from 7-8.30pm at Church House, Great Smith Street, London, SW1. For tickets, priced £4.50, call 0870 842 2224.

Rhythm prince

The Prince of Wales impressed a dance teacher in Edinburgh with his 'natural rhythm' as he performed a Caribbean merengue sensual at a lottery-funded arts centre.

Record trio

Triplets Alice, Doris and Gladys Kingston, from West Haddlesey, near Selby, who celebrate their 74th birthdays next month, are hoping to enter the Guinness Book of Records as the oldest identical female triplets.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: A radical report argues schizophrenicsshould listen to the voices they hear - not drown them out with drugs
fields.trailText: A radical report argues schizophrenicsshould listen to the voices they hear - not drown them out with drugs.
fields.body:
Alan Leader has been hearing voices since he was 15. The first time it happened he was in a television shop. He had been upset by images of starving children in Biafra. Now a voice coming from a TV was telling him the famine was his fault, that somehow he was to blame. 'I felt completely bazooka-ed by it,' he recalls. For a year he told no one, afraid of the stigma attached, while the voices grew increasingly distressing. Eventually he was diagnosed as a schizophrenic, spent the next 15 years in and out of psychiatric units, and was put on long-term medication in an effort to staunch the noises in his head. He still hears voices. There are five in all: two are aggressive and often argue with each other, while the others make trivial comments about wallpaper patterns or car number plates. But Leader, 47, who lives in north London, has been out of psychiatric care and off medication for more than 10 years. He has a full-time job, working in mental health services to help others with similar experiences. He has learned to live with his voices and, by accepting them, to control them. 'I wouldn't know what to do without them now. They are part of me,' he says. The idea that voice-hearing can be an acceptable, even enriching, experience is anathema to conventional psychiatrists - and may well strike fear in the minds of the general public, which is used to headlines shrieking that voices 'ordered' someone to kill. Mainstream psychiatrists regard hearing voices as simply a symptom of mental illness, typically schizophrenia, which must be eliminated by medication at all costs. They argue that prolonged exposure to voices is dangerous and strongly discourage discussing what voices say for fear of legitimising them. Nonetheless, the approach of teaching people who hear voices to control the whispers in their ears is fast gathering pace within the NHS. The method was pioneered by a Dutch psychiatrist, Professor Marius Romme, and his journalist partner, Sandra Escher, after they discovered voice-hearers in the late 80s who had never undergone psychiatric treatment and who lived quite happily with their voices. They drew on historical research which throws up a distinguished list of people who claimed to have heard voices, including Socrates, Galileo, Pythagoras and Joan of Arc. Often, the Dutch researchers found, voices begin in childhood. People whose families are more tolerant then are more likely to cope with them in later life. Romme and Escher came to the radical conclusion that hearing voices in itself is not a problem - it is the individual's and society's inability to cope with the phenomenon that causes distress - and set out to teach coping techniques to voice-hearers. Their work has spawned self-help movements in Holland and the UK - the Hearing Voices Network now boasts 80 groups - and challenges the very roots of modern psychiatry.
Next month, Romme and Escher visit Britain to run a training course for the mental-health charity Mind, which will teach health professionals in the NHS their controversial techniques. Their latest book, outlining their methods, is published by Mind this summer. Alan Leader first tried the Romme/Escher approach after meeting the pair in the early 90s. Medication had never fully worked for him - although he does not rule out using it again if necessary - and left him overweight, shaking and tired. Now he keeps the voices firmly under control by allowing them a set time every day - between 6pm and 7pm - when they can chatter uninterrupted, avoiding situations that might trigger them at other times, and working on detaching himself from them. He imagines the two argumentative voices as the moaning old men in The Muppet Show. 'I would rather live with them and feel alive,' he says, 'than be medicated up to the eyeballs and emotionally dead.' Others are also using the techniques to live in harmony with their voices. Ron Coleman was 25 when he heard his first voice: it was that of a priest, who had abused him at 11, telling him he should burn in hell. His first reaction was to 'get bladdered'. But as the voice grew more persistent, he drank more, lost his job and his house. He spent six of the next nine years in psychiatric units, where he was forcibly medicated and underwent 40 bouts of ECT. Nothing dimmed the voices - the drugs don't work for a sizeable minority - until he met Romme and Escher and tried their approach. It was the first time anyone had attempted to make sense of what his voices were saying. 'For me it was very much about the fact that I hadn't dealt with certain issues,' he says. Now Coleman, 41, who lives in Gloucester, hears seven voices but controls them sufficiently to work full time as a freelance trainer in mental health care. He has taken no medication for seven years. Sue Mayhew, who is 36 and lives in Gloucestershire, has also come to terms with her voices and even believes they saved her life. She first suffered a breakdown when she was 19 after losing a baby in a cot death. It was during a second breakdown that she first heard them. She was about to throw herself off a multi-storey car park when a chorus of voices - she thought of them then as angels - pulled her back. The third breakdown occurred just after the birth of her daughter, now nine, but since then she has had no more psychiatric episodes. She still hears voices occasionally, and takes low-dose medication to diminish them, but treats them as she would background noise in a pub, picking them up or ignoring them as she pleases. Mayhew believes psychiatrists should be more open-minded towards voices. 'I think it is about time they started to listen to their patients and have a bit more humility when it comes to admitting that they don't know everything they claim to know about the manifestations of the human psyche.' But the whole approach rings alarm bells for Dr Cosmo Hallstrom, consultant psychiatrist at the private Charter Clinic in London, and a member of the public education committee of the Royal College of Psychiatrists. He finds the idea of training NHS staff in the Dutch methods 'scary'. 'We spend an awful lot of time trying to persuade people to have treatment. For someone to come along and say, "Live with your voices" is not very helpful,' he says. 'I think untreated schizophrenia is dangerous, and the longer you delay treatment, the worse the outcome.' Yet Dr Phil Taylor, a consultant psychiatrist in Bradford, believes that suppressing people's voices with drugs is even more dangerous. He has been successfully helping patients in Bradford to accept their voices for 10 years - including people who are seriously disturbed - and teaches the method to medical and nursing students. Although he still prescribes medication for patients, the aim is to calm, rather than eliminate, their voices, so they can then discuss them and - eventually - learn to live with them. 'I don't think voices are necessarily signs of mental illness,' he says. 'For some people, the experience is brought about by intense distress, and that tends to get them into contact with mental health services.' Incidents of people hearing voices have been documented for more than 2,000 years, says Dr Taylor, who has co-written a book, Voices of Reason, Voices of Insanity (Routledge, £15.99), which analyses the phenomenon throughout history. Socrates heard a 'daemon' which advised him where to walk, while Galileo heard the voice of his dead daughter, it reveals. Only recently has the hearing of voices been interpreted as a sign of mental illness, while in some cultures the experience is revered. When children of the Xhosa people in southern Africa hear voices, they are trained as healers, the book notes. Dr Taylor believes that more people here would admit to hearing voices, too, but for the social taboo. His research shows that voices rarely give orders; most are actually mundane. People who blame violent acts on their voices are still responsible for their own actions, he argues. In fact, violence is rarely associated with schizophrenia. The number of homicides committed by people with a mental illness has stayed at the same low level for 10 years, while total homicides have risen. And while orthodox psychiatrists still object to the new approach, there are signs of growing sympathy in the NHS for more flexibility towards hearing voices. Professor Julian Leff, of the Institute of Psychiatry, thinks that there has been 'a sea change in attitudes towards this experience. As studies reveal how common voice-hearing really is, it can no longer be regarded as "abnormal".' One sign of acceptance, he says, is the growth in treating schizophrenia with cognitive behavioural therapy, where psychologists discuss with patients what their voices say and gently challenge them - although this is still rarely available on the NHS. The vast majority of people who hear voices today are still treated by psychiatrists who refuse to discuss what the voices say. Professor Leff believes that 'if a person experiencing voices doesn't find them difficult to live with, and isn't impelled towards dangerous acts like suicide or homicide by them, who are we to say that they should be got rid of?'

Hearing voices

* Between 0.5 and 4 per cent of people regularly hear voices.

* Nearly half of people who are recently bereaved report hearing, seeing or feeling the person who has died.

* The Dutch psychiatrist, Professor Marius Romme, estimates that only one-third of voice-hearers seek professional help.

* Conventional psychiatrists generally view voice-hearing as a sign of mental illness, typically schizophrenia.

Schizophrenia

* About one in 100 people is diagnosed with schizophrenia at some point in their lives. The condition is highly controversial. There is no known cause and no laboratory test exists for diagnosis. Some radical psychiatrists argue it is an artificial label - it does not exist - while others believe it is due to chemical changes in the brain.

Symptoms

* Thought disruption

* Hallucinations

* Delusions and apathy

* Most people are diagnosed as young adults. About a third have one episode and recover, another third have further occasional episodes, while the remaining third live with schizophrenia.

* Schizophrenia doesn't denote a split personality and sufferers are rarely violent.

Treatment

* Antipsychotics or neuroleptics are effective for many people but some have serious side-effects. Seek professional help before you stop medication.

* Counselling or cognitive behavioural therapy - help but are not widely available. Useful contacts

Mind infoline 0845 7660163; National Schizophrenia Fellowship advice service 020 8974 6814; Royal College of Psychiatrists 020 7235 2351; Hearing Voices Network 0161 834 5768; Voices Forum, c/o NSF, 020 8547 3937

Reading

Voices of Reason, Voices of Insanity , Ivan Leudar and Phil Thomas, Routledge, £15.99; Making Sense of Voices: A Guide for Professionals Who Work with Voice-hearers , Marius Romme and Sandra Escher, Mind Publications, published this summer.

Training

Making Sense of Voices, a course for professionals working with voice-hearers, is being run by Mind on 27-28 June. For details, 020 8221 9672.

Sources: Mind and NSF

They drew on historical research which throws up a distinguished list of people who claimed to have heard voices, including Socrates, Galileo, Pythagoras and Joan of Arc. Often, the Dutch researchers found, voices begin in childhood. People whose families are more tolerant then are more likely to cope with them in later life. Romme and Escher came to the radical conclusion that hearing voices in itself is not a problem - it is the individual's and society's inability to cope with the phenomenon that causes distress - and set out to teach coping techniques to voice-hearers. Their work has spawned self-help movements in Holland and the UK - the Hearing Voices Network now boasts 80 groups - and challenges the very roots of modern psychiatry. Next month, Romme and Escher visit Britain to run a training course for the mental-health charity Mind, which will teach health professionals in the NHS their controversial techniques. Their latest book, outlining their methods, is published by Mind this summer. Alan Leader first tried the Romme/Escher approach after meeting the pair in the early 90s. Medication had never fully worked for him - although he does not rule out using it again if necessary - and left him overweight, shaking and tired. Now he keeps the voices firmly under control by allowing them a set time every day - between 6pm and 7pm - when they can chatter uninterrupted, avoiding situations that might trigger them at other times, and working on detaching himself from them. He imagines the two argumentative voices as the moaning old men in The Muppet Show. 'I would rather live with them and feel alive,' he says, 'than be medicated up to the eyeballs and emotionally dead.' Others are also using the techniques to live in harmony with their voices. Ron Coleman was 25 when he heard his first voice: it was that of a priest, who had abused him at 11, telling him he should burn in hell. His first reaction was to 'get bladdered'. But as the voice grew more persistent, he drank more, lost his job and his house. He spent six of the next nine years in psychiatric units, where he was forcibly medicated and underwent 40 bouts of ECT. Nothing dimmed the voices - the drugs don't work for a sizeable minority - until he met Romme and Escher and tried their approach. It was the first time anyone had attempted to make sense of what his voices were saying. 'For me it was very much about the fact that I hadn't dealt with certain issues,' he says. Now Coleman, 41, who lives in Gloucester, hears seven voices but controls them sufficiently to work full time as a freelance trainer in mental health care. He has taken no medication for seven years. Sue Mayhew, who is 36 and lives in Gloucestershire, has also come to terms with her voices and even believes they saved her life. She first suffered a breakdown when she was 19 after losing a baby in a cot death. It was during a second breakdown that she first heard them. She was about to throw herself off a multi-storey car park when a chorus of voices - she thought of them then as angels - pulled her back. The third breakdown occurred just after the birth of her daughter, now nine, but since then she has had no more psychiatric episodes. She still hears voices occasionally, and takes low-dose medication to diminish them, but treats them as she would background noise in a pub, picking them up or ignoring them as she pleases. Mayhew believes psychiatrists should be more open-minded towards voices. 'I think it is about time they started to listen to their patients and have a bit more humility when it comes to admitting that they don't know everything they claim to know about the manifestations of the human psyche.' But the whole approach rings alarm bells for Dr Cosmo Hallstrom, consultant psychiatrist at the private Charter Clinic in London, and a member of the public education committee of the Royal College of Psychiatrists. He finds the idea of training NHS staff in the Dutch methods 'scary'. 'We spend an awful lot of time trying to persuade people to have treatment. For someone to come along and say, "Live with your voices" is not very helpful,' he says. 'I think untreated schizophrenia is dangerous, and the longer you delay treatment, the worse the outcome.' Yet Dr Phil Taylor, a consultant psychiatrist in Bradford, believes that suppressing people's voices with drugs is even more dangerous. He has been successfully helping patients in Bradford to accept their voices for 10 years - including people who are seriously disturbed - and teaches the method to medical and nursing students. Although he still prescribes medication for patients, the aim is to calm, rather than eliminate, their voices, so they can then discuss them and - eventually - learn to live with them. 'I don't think voices are necessarily signs of mental illness,' he says. 'For some people, the experience is brought about by intense distress, and that tends to get them into contact with mental health services.' Incidents of people hearing voices have been documented for more than 2,000 years, says Dr Taylor, who has co-written a book, Voices of Reason, Voices of Insanity (Routledge, £15.99), which analyses the phenomenon throughout history. Socrates heard a 'daemon' which advised him where to walk, while Galileo heard the voice of his dead daughter, it reveals. Only recently has the hearing of voices been interpreted as a sign of mental illness, while in some cultures the experience is revered. When children of the Xhosa people in southern Africa hear voices, they are trained as healers, the book notes. Dr Taylor believes that more people here would admit to hearing voices, too, but for the social taboo. His research shows that voices rarely give orders; most are actually mundane. People who blame violent acts on their voices are still responsible for their own actions, he argues. In fact, violence is rarely associated with schizophrenia. The number of homicides committed by people with a mental illness has stayed at the same low level for 10 years, while total homicides have risen. And while orthodox psychiatrists still object to the new approach, there are signs of growing sympathy in the NHS for more flexibility towards hearing voices. Professor Julian Leff, of the Institute of Psychiatry, thinks that there has been 'a sea change in attitudes towards this experience. As studies reveal how common voice-hearing really is, it can no longer be regarded as "abnormal".' One sign of acceptance, he says, is the growth in treating schizophrenia with cognitive behavioural therapy, where psychologists discuss with patients what their voices say and gently challenge them - although this is still rarely available on the NHS. The vast majority of people who hear voices today are still treated by psychiatrists who refuse to discuss what the voices say. Professor Leff believes that 'if a person experiencing voices doesn't find them difficult to live with, and isn't impelled towards dangerous acts like suicide or homicide by them, who are we to say that they should be got rid of?' Hearing voices * Between 0.5 and 4 per cent of people regularly hear voices. * Nearly half of people who are recently bereaved report hearing, seeing or feeling the person who has died. * The Dutch psychiatrist, Professor Marius Romme, estimates that only one-third of voice-hearers seek professional help. * Conventional psychiatrists generally view voice-hearing as a sign of mental illness, typically schizophrenia. Schizophrenia * About one in 100 people is diagnosed with schizophrenia at some point in their lives. The condition is highly controversial. There is no known cause and no laboratory test exists for diagnosis. Some radical psychiatrists argue it is an artificial label - it does not exist - while others believe it is due to chemical changes in the brain. Symptoms * Thought disruption * Hallucinations * Delusions and apathy * Most people are diagnosed as young adults. About a third have one episode and recover, another third have further occasional episodes, while the remaining third live with schizophrenia. * Schizophrenia doesn't denote a split personality and sufferers are rarely violent. Treatment * Antipsychotics or neuroleptics are effective for many people but some have serious side-effects. Seek professional help before you stop medication. * Counselling or cognitive behavioural therapy - help but are not widely available. Training Making Sense of Voices, a course for professionals working with voice-hearers, is being run by Mind on 27-28 June. For details, 020 8221 9672. Sources: Mind and NSF

fields.headline: Four of the best...
fields.standfirst: ...places to find rainbow trout, brown trout, sea trout and golden trout. By Jim Ainsworth
fields.trailText: ...places to find rainbow trout, brown trout, sea trout and golden trout.
fields.body:
Tomorrow is the start of National Trout Week, apparently designed to make us all more aware of how easy it is to cook and how healthy it is to eat. To visit a trout farm and learn more, ring 0131 332 2433 for Scotland, or 01676 522 754 for England and Wales. Virtually all the trout we buy is rainbow, a species originating in America's Pacific Northwest and first imported 50 years ago. It is all farmed, which ensures a consistent, fresh supply at a reasonable cost; most fish merchants sell it. One producer is Belhaven Trout Company (2 Beveridge Row, Belhaven, East Lothian; 01368 863 244), which sells whole fish at £3.75 per kg and fillets at twice that.

Brown trout - native to the Atlantic coast and rivers of western Europe - is the one British anglers fish for sport and throw back in the water. John Williams, at Trafalgar Fisheries in Wiltshire, breeds them organically and sells them to Waitrose, where they cost £6.99 per kg. Brown trout, considered to have a finer flavour than rainbow, are more difficult to farm because they require lower stocking densities, more careful handling, and reach the slab at 19 months old (rather than 12 for rainbow trout). Trafalgar also produces golden trout, a native of California introduced here 15 years ago, notable for its striking, deep-orange colour and firm flesh. Tesco sells them whole at £6.06 per kg.

Brown trout exists in two closely related forms, one of which stays happily in the river all its life. The other heads out to sea, to return a couple of years later, having fed on sand eels, shrimps and prawns, as a larger and more interesting sea trout or salmon trout: to some, this is the finest of all the trout family. Those on sale at Heritage Fine Foods (Lakeside, Bridgewater Road, Barrow Gurney, near Bristol; 01275 474 707) are netted at the mouth of Irish rivers, and cost £5.50 per lb (plus £10 delivery charge).

Sea trout can be farmed, just like salmon. Paul Featherstone started his Shetland Sea Trout farm in 1993, using wild stocks to get him going. Now the whole process is finely controlled from eggs to plate using their own breeding stock: youngsters are transferred from freshwater to seawater cages when they weigh about 50g, and harvested at about three years old when they weigh 1kg. Then they are shipped to Waitrose, and sold at £10.49 per kg.

Sea trout that swim up Welsh rivers are called sewin. They are caught by a few fishermen and sold to restaurants such as Carlton House (Dolycoed Road, Llanwrtyd Wells, Powys; 01591 610 248). When Evans the Fish bags one on the Towy, he rings Mary Ann Gilchrist, who might put it on the menu as gravlax or ceviche, or sear it and serve it with home-made squid-ink pasta and leek fondue, in a fish velouté with crayfish tails.

Char is another relative. Some were stranded after the Ice Age in English lakes, including Coniston, Wastwater and Crummock Water, where a few are fished. Some out-of-work coal miners, who used their redundancy money to buy equipment, now supply Peter and Sue Dixon at White Moss House (Rydal Water, Grasmere, Cumbria; 015394 35295). Char can appear potted, or on a 'compare and contrast' plate alongside Nidderdale trout, or in a soufflé.

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide

fields.headline: Alternative remedies
fields.standfirst: Asthma research comes clean, how to look back on anger and the comforting properties of comfrey. By Richard Lawrence
fields.trailText: Asthma research comes clean, how to look back on anger and the comforting properties of comfrey.
fields.body:
Your body

According to new research from Southampton University, cleanliness is more likely to lead to asthma than godliness. John Warner, of the Department of Child Health, says that modern high standards of hygiene fail to expose babies to bacteria that should flourish in the bowel and kick-start the immune system to fight allergens. With less dirt in our lives, there has been a dramatic rise in the incidence of asthma in this country: one in five children and one in seven adults now suffer from it. To combat this, Warner and his team are planning to feed bacteria to babies of a few weeks old; they believe that educating the immune system to respond effectively could reduce the incidence of asthma in children from 20 per cent to 5 per cent. In the meantime, current sufferers should seek immediate medical advice, and consultation with a specialist in allergies is also highly recommended. Additionally, there are a number of natural remedies available on the market, including galeopsis, a herbal remedy produced from hemp nettle.

Your mind

The University of North Carolina released a report earlier this month detailing links between heart attacks and anger. It concludes that a person that is prone to anger is three times more likely to have a heart attack or sudden cardiac death than those who are less anger prone. Janice Williams and colleagues at the university say that this is especially true among middle-aged men and women. The results, which were based on people with normal blood pressure, indicate that emotional states such as anger, anxiety and depression are likely to have a detrimental effect on health. While this is far from a new concept, it is certainly one of the most rigorous research programmes of its kind to date.

At the beginning of the study, subjects were given a 10-question scale. High scorers were likely to be smokers and drinkers, but smoking, diabetes, cholesterol levels and excess weight were looked at independently to the relationship between anger and heart attacks. Researchers analysed data from 13,000 people over a six-year period, 256 of whom had heart attacks. Extensive work has been done on anger management over the past few years, especially in the US. American psychologist Leonard Ingram identifies four main keys to managing anger: not misinterpreting others people's behaviour to you as hostile; identifying factors in your upbringing which predispose you to anger; learning ways to express legitimate anger, and forgiving those who hurt you.

Your questions

I am frequently bruised after a game of rugby. Is there any natural way to speed up the healing process? David Engwell, Eynsham

A warm bath with a few drops of rosemary and lavender essential oils is a good start. The homeopathic remedy for bruising is arnica, which can be taken in pill form prior to and just after the game. It can also be obtained in a cream and applied to the bruised area. A herbal remedy which is often recommended for bruising and swelling is comfrey. Make a poultice of crushed fresh comfrey leaves mixed with some warmed olive oil. Alternatively, there are many preparations containing comfrey, such as tablets, tinctures, ointments and teas.

 Enquiries to Richard Lawrence c/o Life Magazine, The Observer , 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER

fields.headline: Morning becomes her
fields.standfirst: Whether it's morning sickness or stressful stomach cramps, you've more chance of keeping your breakfast down if you stay on top of your diet
fields.trailText: Whether it's morning sickness or stressful stomach cramps, you've more chance of keeping your breakfast down if you stay on top of your diet
fields.body:
I intended to devote the whole of this column to an issue that can seriously dampen the initial euphoria about becoming pregnant - the dreaded morning sickness, but I've just had a call from a friend saying how sick to the stomach she felt on her way to work. For her, there was no joyful reason that could compensate for the nausea, only work and stress.

Her call reminded me of when, as a child, I used to hate going to school (where I was bullied) and my fear manifested itself as a deep-seated sickness - it was a battle to get through breakfast without rushing to the loo. Of course pregnancy, hormone-induced sickness has a different physiological make-up and can also have more serious consequences. If a mother doesn't eat, she not only loses out, her baby can suffer in extreme cases, especially if the morning turns into the afternoon and evening which is not as uncommon as it sounds. Some of my patients feel sick the whole time - they'd see 'morning' sickness as a luxury. It has to be said, though, that in the majority of cases your baby will not be harmed because your baby sucks nutrients from your body for a long time, it's you who will become nutritionally compromised and drained.

Most women have good and bad days, but if you haven't kept any food down for more than a day or are worried, do seek the advice of your doctor, they'll be able to check on both of you. Morning sickness is caused by a large amount of reproductive hormones circulating during the first trimester; luckily once that passes, the sickness subsides and you can get back to normal eating habits.

Anxiety-related nausea is usually due to a large amount of adrenaline flowing around the body, but whatever is causing your sickness - baby, work or school, there are things you can try to help it disappear.

First, check your iron supplement. Some women may be taking a supplement which can be responsible for nausea, in which case check with your doctor before stopping - you might like to consider taking a herbal iron supplement called Floradix as, in my experience, this tends not to cause nausea. But if you have to stop the supplement, ensure your diet is full of iron-rich foods - lean red meat, green leafy vegetables, etc. Remember pregnant women should not eat liver (a useful source of iron in other situations), as it contains too much vitamin A.

Eating small meals often is much better than going for longer periods without eating. It can be tempting not to eat when you feel sick, but if you can manage a little something it's better than having an empty, acid-full stomach - starving only makes your blood sugar drop, which can make you feel sick.

The foods to go towards are the carbohydrate-rich ones - bread, plain biscuits, a crisp bread, or a little pasta, rice or potatoes. A bowl of simple pasta with a little cheese and a dash of olive oil can sit well - but, as with soups, don't overload on the creamy sauces. Fatty foods are hard to digest and tend to sit heavily in the stomach. Fat also causes the muscle rings around the top of the stomach to temporarily weaken - which can cause you to vomit.

Keep a stock of biscuits in a tin by your bed; it helps to nibble one before you get up in the morning. Ginger biscuits are particularly good, as ginger is one of the most settling plants. Ginger makes a good anti-nausea tea, too. Just place a very thin slice of fresh root ginger in a cup; add boiling water and leave to infuse for a few minutes. Remove the ginger and drink in small sips - gulps can aggravate nausea.

Avoid caffeine in all forms as it also aggravates nausea. If you're not hot on ginger, peppermint and camomile tea are very soothing, as is jasmine. The Chinese, among others, believe in rice water which can work wonders. Save the hot water in which you've cooked the rice and take small sips. Fizzy drinks can go down well, ginger beer or sparkling water with sliced fresh lime are good for starters.

When it comes to non-pregnancy-related sickness, which is frequently caused by adrenaline, it's best to stick to foods which don't take a lot of preparation. Don't start making scrambled eggs in the morning, stick to some toast or a bowl of cereal. Some people find the temperature of foods makes a difference - I used to hate hot food and all I could manage was a cold yoghurt with honey - so try to experiment with the type of food. Some people find milk sits horribly when they're feeling anxious, in which case stick to toast.

If you really can't face breakfast, or you can't get an anxious child to eat any, you should carry a snack with you to work or school - a few ginger biscuits, crackers or dried fruits to nibble on will help keep your energy up and get you to lunchtime. If your sickness continues throughout the day, as with pregnancy nausea, go towards the carbohydrate foods - potato, rice, bread, pasta, etc - rather than fried, sugary or protein-rich foods. For kids, the worst things can be a bag of crisps, or a croissant. They're too high in fat and tend to make you feel even worse; much better to have a couple of plain biscuits - the ones without the cream or chocolate fillings - or even a bowl of dry cereal can work.

It also helps not to over-drink when you eat as large amounts of liquid sloshing around in a vulnerable stomach tends to tip you in the wrong direction. It's important, however, to make up your fluid intake between meals. Some women find acupuncture extremely effective in relieving nausea, so if all else fails and if you can stomach the thought of needles (which I have to say I find completely painless), it's worth a shot.

fields.headline: Morris men's war on morrisettes
fields.standfirst: All-male folk tradition enjoys upsurge as sex barriers fall
fields.trailText: This spring, folk dance is enjoying a revival as women are controversially admitted to some dance groups - or, more properly, dance 'sides'. And to mark this upsurge in folk fortunes, a new touring stage show is set to do for the morris tradition what Riverdance did for the Irish jig.
fields.body:
It was the only thing, bar incest, that you were advised not even to try once. Historically, the morris dancer - with his beard, crossed braces and pint of real ale - was about as far away from 'street cred' as he was from being accepted as a real artist. Now that has changed.

This spring, folk dance is enjoying a revival as women are controversially admitted to some dance groups - or, more properly, dance 'sides'. And to mark this upsurge in folk fortunes, a new touring stage show is set to do for the morris tradition what Riverdance did for the Irish jig.

The show, called England Dances, is an attempt to convince the English that they do have a national identity.

It is choreographed by the traditional dance expert Steve Rouse and combines early 'mummers' movements with authentic nineteenth-century sailors' hornpipes and clog dances as well as with the better known white-suited antics of the morris dancer on the village green.

'I am as English as fish and chips,' said Rouse, who has worked with ballet dancers on interpretations of Russian and gypsy dance. 'But for some reason the English have not yet seen the worth of their own dance forms in the way that, say, the Irish and the Spanish have.

'We have had wonderful, subtle composers, such as Ralph Vaughan Williams and Percy Grainger, who understood the beauty of our traditional folk themes, but it has not happened with dance until now. It has terrific choreographic potential and I hope this show will establish the idea of an English national dance tradition at a higher artistic level.'

The cast of England Dances - five women and five men - reflects a growing interest in traditional dance across the shires, but also shows the increased involvement of women in a pastime usually seen as an all-male preserve. Many morris 'sides' have now agreed to accept women, in spite of a November ruling from the official Morris Dancing Ring of England that they must be excluded as members.

One of these revisionist morris dancers is Patrick Purves, the 'squire' of the Alford Morris side and brother of the radio presenter Libby Purves. He regards women as the salvation of the dance form.

'First we had some women musicians and then we were approached by some who wanted to dance,' he said.

'It makes a side much more viable because we have more people to call upon. People forget that it was kept alive by women after the First World War anyway."

But in Thaxted, Essex, the official ring member Peter King disagrees. He said: 'It should be kept all male, that's the tradition. We have 28 members, so we are doing fine without women, although it is true that we are all getting on a bit now.'

In all other respects the excluded, mixed-gender side in Alford follow tradition slavishly. 'It all started with eighteenth-century farm labourers and our dress reflects that,' said Patrick Purves. 'The ties around the trousers were designed to keep the rats out at harvest time, for example.'

The retired founder of the Alford side, Michel Ducos, has danced for 25 years and fully backs the squire's admission of women.

Ducos, who is French by birth, joined because the dancers seemed to be having such fun and he puts the current healthy state of the side down to the decision to allow women in. 'We may have been chucked out of the ring, but it was worth it,' he said.

Nevertheless, dancing in an all-male ring meeting at Thaxted when he belonged to the Grimsby side is one of his proudest memories.

'It was a wonderful thing,' he remembered. 'You get shivers down your spine.'

With his England Dances, Steve Rouse is determined to spread this sense of excitement. He said: 'At its best morris has a streak of madness about it.

'It is typically English because it has a kind of taking the mickey about it and none of the haughtiness of other national dances.'

fields.headline: My brushes with Bacon
fields.standfirst: Art critic David Sylvester was friends with Francis Bacon for 40 years. During that time, he recorded many of their conversations. Here, he introduces a selection of the artist's previously unpublished thoughts - about sex, about God, and about cricket...
fields.trailText: Art critic David Sylvester was friends with Francis Bacon for 40 years. During that time, he recorded many of their conversations. Here, he introduces a selection of the artist's previously unpublished thoughts - about sex, about God, and about cricket...
fields.body:
I 'm not sure whether I was Francis Bacon's concierge or his butler, but intrusive strangers certainly believed that I had the entrée to his domain. I used to get calls from famous photographers saying that they were great fans of my writing and could they take my picture. I knew what was coming if I didn't speedily decline. 'Would it by any chance be possible to photograph you in Francis Bacon's studio and then perhaps do the two of you together if he happens to be there at the time?' The comedy of being importuned in this way was a nice bonus for having done a book called Interviews with Francis Bacon, which had been widely translated.

My relationship with Bacon began in 1942, when I was 17 and had just become interested in painting. One of the books I absorbed was Herbert Read's Art Now , a veritable bible first published in 1933. It reproduced a Crucifixion, painted that year by a young artist with the name of the great Elizabethan writer, and this painting therefore stayed in my mind, although the artist had disappeared from view. But at the end of the war, new works by him started to appear in galleries. They were sensationally disturbing and widely considered worthy of the Chamber of Horrors.

It was in 1949 that I realised he was not only an arresting image-maker but very much a painter, and I started saying so in print. I also met him by chance and was soon seeing a good deal of him. In 1951, I was asked to give a talk about his art for the BBC's Third Programme , my first substantial radio talk. I described him as the most important living painter, by which I didn't mean he was the greatest, but the most relevant to the age. I was told afterwards that Harman Grisewood, head of the Third Programme , swore that it would be a long time before I did another talk for them.

Bacon and I became quite close friends. We drank and dined together, went dog racing together and shared off-course bets on horses. I also sat for him a few times, helped him to write a short piece in praise of an older artist, Matthew Smith, and acted as his agent in selling works to dealers behind his accredited dealer's back when he urgently needed cash. I idolised him as a man - this never stopped - and until 1956, I loved his work unreservedly. But I thought it then took a wrong turn and I became rather alienated from his current production. I was also put off by the way he jeered at the work of abstract painters such as Jackson Pollock: my own pantheon had plenty of room for them both.

So between 1957 and 1962 I stopped writing about him; nor did we see much of each other. In 1962 he had a retrospective at the Tate, and as art critic of the New Statesman , I had to review it at length. I wrote with admiration but reservations and dismissed the work of the past few years, but concluded that he had returned to form in his latest piece, a big Crucifixion triptych.

Shortly after, the BBC radio Talks producer, Leonie Cohn, who had commissioned that 1951 talk and had lately got me to do interviews with several American Abstract Expressionists and also with Stanley Kubrick, asked me to interview Bacon. I said I wasn't sure whether Bacon would agree, as he didn't readily give interviews and may not have liked my review of his show. But he did agree, and the result was brilliant, producing passages endlessly quoted since, such as: 'What is fascinating now is that it's going to be much more difficult for the artist, because he must deepen the game to be any good at all.'

Four years later I was asked by Michael Gill to interview Bacon in a BBC TV film he was making. This time we were quite aggressive at moments. I asked tougher questions than last time and he accused me of liking abstract art because I was a slave to fashion. But we were now seeing a lot of each other again and we were both saying that it would be interesting to do more interviews, especially if we could talk as we did among friends, without having to think of a lay audience. So we did some private recordings at my flat and then we decided to publish a book of interviews. This happened in 1975, and Graham Greene wrote that it was 'an exciting document which can rank with the journals of Delacroix and the letters of Gauguin'.

We went on recording interviews, some for ourselves, some for TV, one for an audio company. We published an enlarged edition of the book in 1980 and a further enlarged one in 1987. Meanwhile, they got translated into about 10 languages; I don't know whether any of the translators managed to create an equivalent for the amazing vividness and rhythmic power of Bacon's talk. The reason we went on doing interviews for about 25 years was that Bacon loved getting in- volved in theoretical talk about art. This is a rare thing in English artists, who tend to poke fun at a custom so French. And it's a key aspect of Bacon's personality which is not sufficiently emphasised in most accounts of the man.

His love of talking about art made the recordings easy. The hard part was the editing. Interviews with artists, even when they have Bacon's turn of phrase, tend to sprawl and repeat themselves; I wanted the printed version to be economical in exposition and coherent in structure. I therefore did most of the editing in collaboration with Shena Mackay, whose work as a fiction writer suggested that she was the ideal person to help to achieve that.

Now, if one is aiming for structural coherence, a lot of the best things said are not going to fit in anywhere; so they get left, so to speak, on the cutting-room floor. I was always aware how much was being lost in this way and had it in mind to return to the transcripts, retrieve some of the best rejected bits and publish them torn from their context as fragments of talk. The ones that follow are The Observer 's selection from my selection.

Bacon on bacon

Francis Bacon I love watching the idiocy of other people, and of myself. And they can watch my idiocy. David Sylvester People you know and people you don't know, passing people? FB Yes. I love passing people. I love going to towns and places where I know nobody at all but very quickly talk to them. It's so easy to talk to them. DS You can't really imagine living outside of town, can you? FB I can't imagine lying on the seashore, for instance, for hours, like people can do, with the dumb satisfaction that the sun is shining on them. That I couldn't do at all. DS And what about, say, moving to the country to work? FB That would be impossible for me. DS Why's that? FB Because I like crowds. I mean, I'd rather be in a station than in the country. [1975]

DS Do you at all enjoy the kind of star quality which you have always had when moving among people? FB That's a thing that you are not conscious of yourself at all. I have no idea of what impression I make on other people. DS You have not been conscious that, when you come into a bar, you immediately become the centre of attention? That is something I have seen happen ever since I have known you, which means before you became famous as a painter, so it wasn't influenced by that. FB Perhaps I was drunk and garrulous, had a lot to say. I think it can only be for that reason. I certainly am not conscious of those things. This is not false modesty; I am just not conscious of it. [1984]

DS Did you go to the theatre when you were younger? FB I drifted from bar to bar. DS And when did you start gambling seriously? FB Well, I have always been brought up with it, because when we were very young, we used to be sent to the local post office to put on bets. So, as I was brought up in that sort of atmosphere in Ireland of everybody gambling, I suppose that that influenced me. I don't know. Perhaps I would have been a gambler in any case. [1984]

DS It's often said about you by hostile critics that your work reflects a feeling of disgust about human beings and of self-disgust. FB Well, I may have, I may very often be very discontented and loathe myself but I'm not trying to bring that out. In any way whatsoever. Nor have I a disgust with life. Life is all we have. I mean, here we are for a moment. [1984]

Bacon on religion

FB Of course one knows how very potent some of the images of Christianity have been and how they must have played very deeply on one's sensibility. And after all, one believes in the ethics of Christianity, or a great number of them, without actually believing in the practice of the Church. DS You believe in the ethics of Christianity? FB Well, I think that they are a carry-over of Greek ethics really, and I think that so far a better code of ethics for the Western world hasn't yet been found, though of course the religious side of it is something I can't accept. DS But then at the heart of Christianity is the idea of salvation and of a life after this life in which one gets punishment or reward for what one has done here. FB I think you can accept the ethics without believing that the good you do will be rewarded or the evil you do will be punished. [1966]

Bacon on work

FB The only thing that really keeps me going on is that I want to work - but work, I may say, for no reason. I just work; it still excites me to work. You see, unless you have religious feelings or something of that kind, how can you not think that life is totally futile - and becomes more so with age, because it hasn't got the pleasures of youth? Probably the only thing, although I know it has no meaning, is that I like working. I like the possibilities of invention and the possibilities of something happening. Not because I think they've got any value, but because they excite me. [1979]

FB I know that teaching is one of the methods by which many artists survive, but how can you teach? In a period when there is no tradition, there is nothing to teach. You can teach your own attitude. The only thing that I can understand for art schools would be for them to have a few extremely intelligent people whom the people who are striving to be artists of some kind can come and discuss their problems with... But many people have to teach because they can't make the money out of their work. In my own case, even when I could earn no money, I never taught. Except that once a friend went to the West Indies and he asked me to take his job for three months at the Royal College of Art, which I did. It's true to say that I did it very badly. I didn't often go there; there was nothing I could teach them whatsoever. DS And what effect did that have upon your own work? Did you feel it was just using energy which you needed for your own work, or...? FB Not especially, because it was only for three months. Otherwise I would never have done it. I'd rather go out and just do a job working. After all, I can cook, I can clean floors, I can earn my money that way. It would use physical energy, which would be so much more interesting than mental energy. Because I've got plenty of mental energy, because I never stop thinking, myself. After all, I think about painting. Not that I think thinking finally helps, and yet it does. [1975]

Bacon on books

DS What are you mostly reading nowadays? FB Well, you know, I read generally the same thing over and over again. I very often read translations of Aeschylus; I read Proust; I read anything that comes to my hand. Or any rubbish as well. DS What rubbish do you read? FB Well, most things are rubbish. So I can't tell you exactly what rubbish. There are piles of rubbish and very little stuff that is any good. DS Do you read Shakespeare a lot? FB I read a certain amount, yes. I'll tell you what I really read: things which bring up images for me. And I find that this happens very much with the translations of Aeschylus, and with Eliot. For some reason I read them, and when I read them another time, a different image comes up. I mean, I don't say that these images are really to do with the poems of Eliot or even with the plays of Shakespeare, but they open up the valves of sensation for me and so images drop in like that from reading those things. It could happen just as easily from reading any of the trash. So it doesn't really make much difference. Except that I'm less bored by those than I am by the trash. DS In the same way that you can be influenced by a news photograph or you can be influenced by Velazquez? FB Exactly. Exactly. Exactly. [1984]

Bacon on michelangelo

FB Do you think Michelangelo was an erotic artist or not? DS Very. But almost embarrassingly. I find the Slaves almost embarrassing in the longing they conveyed for these boys. FB He was, after the Greeks, the great male voluptuary, wasn't he? He made the male body really voluptuous. DS But with the Greeks, you feel that the artist has had these boys, and with Michelangelo, that he'd just longed for them. And that's one reason why I find there's a morbid quality in Michelangelo which doesn't stop him from being the greatest artist of our civilisation. FB I think that Michelangelo, from what one knows about all of his history, had a deeply morbid side to him. But it's more voluptuous than the Greeks. Because I think in those Slaves the longing is more poignant than anything you find in Greek art. [1973]

Bacon on cricket

DS As to working from documentary photographs, one interesting case of this was your recent use of a photograph of David Gower batting: you translated the pads to the legs of a headless male nude. FB Well, I have often seen cricket, and cricket is such an important game in this country, I am very conscious of it. When I did this image I suddenly said: 'Well, I don't know why, but I think that it's going to strengthen it very much and make it look very much more real if it has cricket pads on it.' I can't tell you why. DS The painting is in Paris, and some French people I know, while very much admiring it, have been extremely puzzled by what the figure had on its legs. Some of them thought they might be bits of Etruscan armour. FB Don't the French have games in which they use pads? They're deformed cricket pads, in any case. DS I take it that your attitude to bringing in the cricket pads was rather like the attitude you took about 20 years ago when you brought that armband with a swastika into a Crucifixion triptych. When I asked you whether the presence of the swastika had a meaning for you and also whether you were concerned that people might take it to have a meaning, you said the swastika was there simply because the armband had been in the photograph you'd used and you'd put it in without thinking about how it might be interpreted. Did you have the same attitude to bringing in the cricket pads? FB It wasn't quite the same. You see, with those enormous crowds that have so often been filmed and photographed at the Nuremberg rallies, I had seen all these people, and they all had armbands on with the swastikas on them, and I wanted that in this image: it was stupid to put in the swastika, but there it is. I didn't think about it, I didn't think that people would interpret it all the different ways they have. But with the cricket pads, I didn't put them in because I am particularly interested in cricket; I did so because it made the image more real. [1982]

FB Well, you know, I read generally the same thing over and over again. I very often read translations of Aeschylus; I read Proust; I read anything that comes to my hand. Or any rubbish as well. DS What rubbish do you read? FB Well, most things are rubbish. So I can't tell you exactly what rubbish. There are piles of rubbish and very little stuff that is any good. DS Do you read Shakespeare a lot? FB I read a certain amount, yes. I'll tell you what I really read: things which bring up images for me. And I find that this happens very much with the translations of Aeschylus, and with Eliot. For some reason I read them, and when I read them another time, a different image comes up. I mean, I don't say that these images are really to do with the poems of Eliot or even with the plays of Shakespeare, but they open up the valves of sensation for me and so images drop in like that from reading those things. It could happen just as easily from reading any of the trash. So it doesn't really make much difference. Except that I'm less bored by those than I am by the trash. DS In the same way that you can be influenced by a news photograph or you can be influenced by Velazquez? FB Exactly. Exactly. Exactly. [1984] Bacon on michelangelo FB Do you think Michelangelo was an erotic artist or not? DS Very. But almost embarrassingly. I find the Slaves almost embarrassing in the longing they conveyed for these boys. FB He was, after the Greeks, the great male voluptuary, wasn't he? He made the male body really voluptuous. DS But with the Greeks, you feel that the artist has had these boys, and with Michelangelo, that he'd just longed for them. And that's one reason why I find there's a morbid quality in Michelangelo which doesn't stop him from being the greatest artist of our civilisation. FB I think that Michelangelo, from what one knows about all of his history, had a deeply morbid side to him. But it's more voluptuous than the Greeks. Because I think in those Slaves the longing is more poignant than anything you find in Greek art. [1973] Bacon on cricket DS As to working from documentary photographs, one interesting case of this was your recent use of a photograph of David Gower batting: you translated the pads to the legs of a headless male nude. FB Well, I have often seen cricket, and cricket is such an important game in this country, I am very conscious of it. When I did this image I suddenly said: 'Well, I don't know why, but I think that it's going to strengthen it very much and make it look very much more real if it has cricket pads on it.' I can't tell you why. DS The painting is in Paris, and some French people I know, while very much admiring it, have been extremely puzzled by what the figure had on its legs. Some of them thought they might be bits of Etruscan armour. FB Don't the French have games in which they use pads? They're deformed cricket pads, in any case. DS I take it that your attitude to bringing in the cricket pads was rather like the attitude you took about 20 years ago when you brought that armband with a swastika into a Crucifixion triptych. When I asked you whether the presence of the swastika had a meaning for you and also whether you were concerned that people might take it to have a meaning, you said the swastika was there simply because the armband had been in the photograph you'd used and you'd put it in without thinking about how it might be interpreted. Did you have the same attitude to bringing in the cricket pads? FB It wasn't quite the same. You see, with those enormous crowds that have so often been filmed and photographed at the Nuremberg rallies, I had seen all these people, and they all had armbands on with the swastikas on them, and I wanted that in this image: it was stupid to put in the swastika, but there it is. I didn't think about it, I didn't think that people would interpret it all the different ways they have. But with the cricket pads, I didn't put them in because I am particularly interested in cricket; I did so because it made the image more real. [1982]

fields.headline: Time regained - and with profit
fields.standfirst: Andrew Bibby reports on a 'bank' for good neighbours
fields.trailText: For the past few months, residents in the Catford area have been able to earn and spend 'time', building up credit balances (or overdrafts) in the 'time bank' held at the neighbourhood health centre.
fields.body:
Forget the euro - people in South-east London are trading in a completely new currency. For the past few months, residents in the Catford area have been able to earn and spend 'time', building up credit balances (or overdrafts) in the 'time bank' held at the neighbourhood health centre.

The idea comes from America, where time dollars have become a familiar concept in urban community regeneration schemes. But what may seem like the latest wacky import seems to be working well in SE6.

Hyacinth Thomas, for example, built up several hours of credit in the time bank by visiting an elderly blind woman in her area. She has recently been able to spend some of these savings: 'I've got a lot of garden furniture, but the garden shed was leaky. I have used the time I'd got from chatting to the old lady to get the shed done. The time bank is a very, very good idea.'

Another member of the scheme, Mary Millar, is a wheelchair-user who has been spending time money to arrange to be taken out of her house on trips. In exchange, she has been busy utilising her baking skills to produce traditional sponge and butterfly cakes.

David Boyle, an associate of the New Economics Foundation and author of a recent book on alternative currencies, Funny Money, sees time banks as potentially fulfilling an important role in rebuilding community life.

There are about a dozen pioneering time banks in Britain. The Catford one is a joint initiative of the New Economics Foundation and the local Rushey Green group practice. The practice will be evaluating not only whether time bank members benefit economically, but also whether their health is helped.

Hyacinth Thomas's example suggests that this may be the case. She admits that the death of her mother two years ago and the break-up of her marriage left her very depressed: 'I used to sit at home, just wake up and watch TV all day. The time bank is what brought me out.' she says.

Her life now includes participating in an Afro-Caribbean women's performance group, which visits schools and old people's homes. Hyacinth says: 'Long ago, neighbours would do things for one another. The time bank is about bringing back a friendly neighbour attitude.'

While time banks can be run informally, Boyle recommends that groups use the manual and software developed by Edgar Cahn, creator of the time bank concept, in America. This can be downloaded from the New Economics Foundation website - www.neweconomics.org.
