webTitle: Left out of pocket in a legal slow lane

fields.headline: Left out of pocket in a legal slow lane
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
In 1998, I was involved in a traffic accident when the car behind me failed to stop. I sent a claim form to AGF Insurance, who provided a hire car. First they lost my claim, then they lost the assessor's report. Eventually the car was repaired and we paid the £150 excess. In July 1998, we were offered £170 for the excess and out-of-pocket expenses, but we have still not received the money. The guilty party's insurer is refusing to reimburse AGF with the car hire charges, which were £1,565 - more than the value of our car. Apparently we have to wait for a ruling from the House of Lords before we can get our £150 back. Why should we be penalised, particularly as it was my hard work that kept the repair time to five weeks? CL, Royston

Arguments between AGF, the other driver's insurer and the car hire company ground to a halt, leaving you stranded. The guilty driver's insurer said AGF had been unnecessarily slow, resulting in excessive hire car costs, which they refused to pay. AGF denied this. Since contacting me, you have received a cheque for £170 from the other side's solicitors, inexplicably forwarded by the car hire firm.

This was before the Lords' judgment, which finally arrived 10 days ago. The court case, Dimond v Lovell, concerned how much insurers should have to pay for cars that the innocent victims of motor accidents hire while theirs are being repaired.

Insurers argued that the new credit hire companies in this business charged too much and the Lords decided that insurers had to refund only reasonable car hire costs.

Last September, the Association of British Insurers launched a scheme for innocent victims not provided with courtesy cars by their own insurer or the guilty party's. You can get details from www.abi.org.uk/tphire or from car hire firms Enterprise (0800 800227) and National Car Rental (020 8358 9860).

Jobless claim: Never valid

A year ago I was laid off work and claimed on my redundancy insurance policy with Britannia building society. In December, Britannia wrote saying they were closing the case as they had not heard from me. I told them it was me waiting to hear from them. They then said they would activate my claim by the end of January, but I have heard nothing. AH, Bury St Edmunds

You were told that you qualified for payment by call centre staff at Britannia's external administrator, which the society has since dropped. In fact, your claim was never valid because you took a temporary job two days short of the 60-day qualifying period after being made redundant.

Britannia says the claims department should not have kept chasing documents when your claim was invalid.

The society is making an ex-gratia payment of £100.

Share deal: The true cost

I instructed my stockbroker to sell 200 On Line shares. They sent a share transfer form and a request for the share certificate. As we had never received the certificate, we returned the transfer form and went on holiday. On our return, we found letters from my broker saying that as they did not have a share certificate, they would have to buy the shares on the market to close the deal, with a bill for £2,500. I pointed out that there was no need to purchase the shares, as we already owned them. PB, Bushey

You did not own the shares once you gave instructions to sell. The deal is done then, even though the share certificate is not due until settlement day, five days later. Unless your shares are in a nominee account, you must produce a certificate. If you do not, Stock Exchange rules allow brokers to buy more shares, so the next buyer has a certificate and they can reclaim the cost from you.

Policy mix-up: Delay payment

We have an endowment policy with Scottish Life maturing this month, but they said it was assigned to NatWest Bank. I told them it wasn't, but they said I must sort it out myself. I called five different departments at NatWest but none could help. They say another policy is assigned to Alliance & Leicester, which it is not. Surely Scottish Life should be sorting this out? EP, Lenham

NatWest has tracked down your file, which shows that the policy was assigned to the bank for a few years but discharged in February 1997. It looks as though NatWest sent the policy back to you without informing Scottish Life, but it has now written to the insurer confirming the facts. Because of the delay, Scottish Life is paying you an extra week's interest, £4.68. The second policy is assigned to Kent Reliance Building Society, but Scottish Life typed in the wrong name when your original lender, Chatham Reliance, amalgamated with the Herne Bay.

Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. We accept no legal responsibility for advice.

fields.headline: Why featherbed fat-cat fund managers?
fields.trailText: What do you pay your investment manager? If you do not know, you should check: their charges could be seriously damaging your wealth.
fields.body:
What do you pay your investment manager? If you do not know, you should check: their charges could be seriously damaging your wealth.

Conventional wisdom holds that the performance of the fund manager is all that matters. Provided their fees are not excessive, their charges will make little difference to the long-term performance of the investment.

The performance of investment funds which meet the Government's Cat criteria suggests that this is wrong. Cat funds cannot charge initial fees and must have total charges of no more than 1 per cent a year. That compares with a 5 per cent initial fee and annual costs of between 1.25 and 1.75 per cent charged by the average unit trust or individual savings account. The impact of the higher charges is dramatic. Cat-marked Isas were first introduced in April 1999. In the 12 months since, the average actively managed UK fund has produced a return of 30.41 per cent through a Cat-marked Isa, nearly four times the 8.88 per cent return from those not meeting the standard.

The figures are produced by statisticians at Fitzrovia for Norwich Union which, as the leading provider of Cat-marked funds, has a vested interest in talking about how good they are. But the difference - which amounts to £1,500 on the maximum Isa investment of £7,000 - is too large to be dismissed as random.

The Financial Services Authority published a paper last week which concluded that, for many of us, a Cat-marked Isa would be a better way of saving for retirement than a personal pension, despite the latter's tax advantages. The high initial charges, coupled with the fact that more than a third of us stop contributing to our pensions within four years, can make pensions an expensive way of investing.

That is not true of stakeholder pensions, which the Government has also decreed will be low cost. The tax advantages and the low costs made these better than an Isa, even for those who stop saving very soon.

Why, then, are so few fund managers offering Cat-marked Isas, and why are so few committed to stakeholder pensions? The answer, of course, is profits - theirs, not ours. Fund management is a lucrative business, and the industry wants to keep it that way.

Take away their initial fee and half their annual charges, and their profits would look a lot less healthy. But that does not mean you have to keep providing these profits. You can put your money in a low-cost product and keep more of those profits for yourself. Norwich Union is the largest Cat provider, but many others - Legal & General, HSBC and M&G among others - also offer Cat funds, albeit usually indexed.

All this does not mean you shouldn't consider performance, but you should stop assuming that you have to pay a high price to get the best. The more of us who do so, the more pressure there will be on the industry to get fees down.

fields.headline: Loyalty doesn't always pay
fields.standfirst: Insurers tempt with discounts for existing customers. But using a broker can be more rewarding, Virginia Wallis says
fields.trailText: Do insurance companies deserve our loyalty? Certainly not, if it goes unrewarded. But buying more than one policy from the same company can be worthwhile if the insurer offers a financial incentive in cheaper premiums.
fields.body:
Do insurance companies deserve our loyalty? Certainly not, if it goes unrewarded. But buying more than one policy from the same company can be worthwhile if the insurer offers a financial incentive in cheaper premiums.

Multi-buy insurance discounts are nothing new. These days, it's a rare insurer who fails to offer at least 5 per cent off the premiums when you buy both buildings and house contents insurance. Many have also recognised the opportunity for increased sales by reducing the price of their breakdown cover for people who have bought car insurance. Less common are insurers who take 'loyalty' discounts one step further by offering reduced premiums to car-insurance customers who also buy house insurance, and the other way round.

One of the most generous discounts for existing motor policyholders is from Direct Line. Customers who also take out its combined buildings and contents policy are being rewarded with a premium discount (on the new policy) of 25 per cent; the discount will fall to a maximum of 10 per cent when this offer ends.

On policies it sells through brokers, Norwich Union cuts the cost of either a buildings or contents policy by 10 per cent for holders of a Norwich Union car policy. The discount rises to 17.5 per cent if existing customers buy both types of house insurance. The same sort of reductions are built into premiums for policies sold by Norwich Union Direct.

Eagle Star also cuts house insurance premiums by 10 per cent but rewards existing customers further by giving the same discount on the existing car insurance premiums as well. Less generous is the flat £20 reduction offered by CGU Direct to motor policyholders taking out a household policy - although if they take out a combined house policy, they save the greater of £20 and 15 per cent of the combined policy premiums.

CGU offers the same flat £20 reduction to existing house insurance customers who buy CGU's car insurance. Direct Line, Eagle Star and Norwich Union cut car insurance premiums by 10 per cent for customers who have their house policies.

But are the discounts worth having? Yes - compared with the insurer's normal price. Possibly not when compared with the price you could get by shopping around (or getting a broker to do it). If your car or house insurer offers you lower premiums on its other policies, whether it is a good deal or not depends on your circumstances. This is because different insurers have different attitudes to factors such as age, postcode, kind of car you drive, security measures and your claims history.

The table gives the combined yearly cost of buildings, house contents and car insurance - including loyalty discounts - for the insurers already mentioned, together with the total cost of buying each policy from a different insurer through independent brokers John Charcol. The figures are for a couple (aged 40) who live in a subsidence-free, three-bedroom semi built in 1980. They have fully comprehensive car insurance for a six-year-old Citroën ZX fitted with an alarm and immobiliser. They have made no claims in the last five years.

For a low-risk area, none of the insurers could beat the broker quote overall. Direct Line and Eagle Star quoted lower premiums for the car insurance but combined with the cost of their house policies both were more expensive. But you may feel an extra £13 a year for loyalty to Eagle Star is a small price to pay for what the company says is the convenience of having all claims dealt with by the same insurer.

The premiums for a high-risk area told a different story. Buying all three policies from Eagle Star would save nearly £150 a year compared with using a broker. Norwich Union's house insurance (discounted for an existing car-insurance customer) was slightly cheaper than a broker's quote. But at £661, car insurance was over £250 more than the £395 quoted by John Charcol; around £350 more than Eagle Star's £307 premium.

CGU Direct: 0800 121004

Direct Line: 0845 246 8888 (motor); 0845 246 8000 (house)

Eagle Star: 0800 868686

John Charcol Insurance Brokers: 0800 939393

Norwich Union Direct: 0800 888222.

webTitle: 'Super Brain' to eclipse the Net adds to power of machines

fields.headline: 'Super Brain' to eclipse the Net adds to power of machines
fields.standfirst: Web guru warns of all-powerful Grid's threat to survival of humanity
fields.trailText: Scientists plan to link the nation's major computers in a single, all-powerful 'thinking' network.
fields.body:
Scientists plan to link the nation's major computers in a single, all-powerful 'thinking' network.

Known as The Grid, the massive connection project would allow computers in different centres and technology companies to exchange computing tasks and gain access to unlimited amounts of data without using search engines.

The Grid - which some researchers compare to omnipotent robot systems in science fiction films such as The Matrix and The Terminator - would be millions of times more powerful than the Internet.

Its creation is seen as vital to the viability of future research projects such as the new particle smasher to be built at Cern in Geneva, the unravelling of the human genome and the launch of a series of massive Earth observation satellites.

These projects will generate vast volumes of data which would swamp present computing systems. To prevent that, researchers believe that only by linking their machines with special communication systems can they create a network powerful enough to prevent an information overload.

'Think of this as the Mark II Web,' said Professor Ian Halliday, who chairs the committee set up to investigate the building of the Grid. 'The first Web was invented by British scientists but exported to the United States. Now we have to buy back our access from Microsoft or Netscape. We don't want that to happen again.'

This urge to ensure the continued viability of UK science is balanced by warnings that such a system brings closer the day when computers will take over the running of the world and discard humanity. One such gainsayer is Bill Joy, inventor of the web language Java and chief scientist at computer giant Sun Microsystems.

'It is no exaggeration to say we are on the cusp of the further perfection of extreme evil,' he states in the magazine Wired. 'I may be working to create tools which will enable the construction of technology that may replace our species.

'Unable to afford the necessities of life, biological humans would be squeezed out of existence,' he adds.

Most researchers disagree, however. 'The issue of consciousness in such a powerful thinking system has to be considered, but that is different from suggesting The Grid would be a threat to Homo sapiens,' said astronomer Dr Paul Murdin.

This point was backed by Professor Ian Hillier of the Molecular Environmental Science Centre at Manchester University. 'Just compare this Grid with the national electricity grid. When you switch on the kettle, you have no idea of the vast network that is working to provide power.'

Research councils have asked the Government to provide an extra £80 million to help set up the Grid, and a similar amount is being sought from the Department of Trade and Industry to support commercial applications.

'Many countries are thinking about setting up something like the Grid,' added Cambridge scientist Dr Ewan Birney, of the European Bio-infomatics Institute. 'We already have one model system in operation. The Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence organisation is currently searching through radio astronomical signals for intelligible transmission using volunteers' personal computers, and these machines carry out the operations. The Grid will do the same sort of thing - but on a much grander scale.'

webTitle: Even if you don't like lentils...

fields.headline: Even if you don't like lentils...
fields.standfirst: There are simple steps you can take to make your life - and your finances - more ethical, writes Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Many people would like to live in a way that benefits society and the environment, but most are put off by the prospect of having to reorganise their lives - and in a way that could lower their standard of living.
fields.body:
Ethical, environmentally sound and socially responsible. Sounds grim doesn't it?

Many people would like to live in a way that benefits society and the environment, but most are put off by the prospect of having to reorganise their lives - and in a way that could lower their standard of living.

But it doesn't have to be lentils or nothing. You could help by doing as little as lagging your hot water tank properly, or turning the tap off while you brush your teeth. If you want to go a bit further, you could use cloth nappies instead of disposables or go for the ultimate recycling experience - a green funeral.

Shelley Simmons of Animal + World 2000, an exhibition that aims to show just how painless it is to alter your way of life, says: 'You don't have to change your whole lifestyle to help the environment. Do as much as you feel comfortable with, whether it's switching to organic chocolate or cruelty-free hair products, or going vegetarian.'

The same is true of your finances. Amanda Davidson of London independent financial adviser Holden Meehan, which gives specialist advice on ethical finance, says that when it comes to investment, it is better to stagger the conversion of your portfolio to ethical standards.

'You can arrange virtually all your finances on an ethical and environmental basis now - from bank accounts, through life insurance and pensions to Isas, and venture capital trusts.

'But people are often a little uncertain about switching all their investments; they may be happier putting a third of their pension fund into an ethical fund to see how it goes. Others are keen to go the whole hog, but even then we would recommend that they switch their portfolio over gradually to avoid selling investments at inopportune times or to avoid incurring tax bills.'

A good place to start is with your current or savings account. The Co-op Bank (0800 905090), and its Internet subsidiary Smile (www.smile.co.uk), are the only banks in the UK to offer a current account run on ethical criteria. Money in Co-op or Smile accounts will not, for example, be invested in or used to provide financial services to companies, organisations or regimes involved in arms, human rights abuse, animal testing of cosmetics and household goods or factory farming.

Triodos Bank (0500 008 720), a small Dutch-registered bank based in Bristol, has a range of socially responsible accounts, including an Isa that currently pays 6 per cent gross. Triodos is the only bank to publish a full list of where it lends money, and to allow people to target their deposits to benefit areas of particular interest to them, such as organic products or social housing. You can even chose to sacrifice some of your interest to causes close to your heart.

If this sounds too much like hard work, what about a credit card that benefits an ethical group? If you take out an affinity credit card issued by a charity or organisation that interests you, the card issuer will give the charity an initial donation of typically £5 or £10, plus a small proportion of the amount you spend using the card - usually about 0.25 per cent.

While this sounds tiny, it adds up. The RSPCA, for example, has received more than £1.5 million since the launch of its card 10 years ago. The main providers of affinity cards are Bank of Scotland, the Co-op, MBNA and Royal Bank of Scotland.

 The Animal + World 2000 show runs from 10am to 5pm today at the Novotel Exhibition Centre in West London. Tickets cost £5 for adults, £3 for children and £10 for families.Exhibitions include a cruelty-free beauty zone, a fur and leather-free fashion show and free hairstyling (subject to a donation to the National Anti-Vivisection Society) by celebrity stylist Daniel Field.

 For a free copy of Holden Meehan's 'Millennium Guide to Ethical & Environmental Investment', visit www.holden-meehan.co.uk, or call 0800 731 4505.

 For a list of IFAs that specialise in environmental and ethical financial advice call 0845 606 0324.

webTitle: Blair needs to take the lead on Europe

fields.headline: Blair needs to take the lead on Europe
fields.standfirst: He must act as the EU issue hots up
fields.trailText: Britain is a European country. Europe's rivalries, its prosperity, its evolving cultural and political trends have always impacted on the British. Our decision is whether we remain aloof and accept the consequences, or attempt to shape Europe in ways that suit us.
fields.body:
Britain is a European country. Europe's rivalries, its prosperity, its evolving cultural and political trends have always impacted on the British. Our decision is whether we remain aloof and accept the consequences, or attempt to shape Europe in ways that suit us.

The lop-sided, xenophobic character of the debate over the European Union disguises this reality. We need to have an idea of what kind of Europe we want, and build coalitions that will serve that end. This necessity is becoming more urgent. France and Germany have always been the locomotives of the EU, but after Mitterrand and Kohl the alliance has faltered.

But soon France assumes the EU Presidency, and there are signs that France and Germany are trying to re-establish the momentum. The French want to construct a top-down political and economic directorate around the 11 members of the single currency. The Germans want to 'parliamentarise' the Union, with Joschka Fischer, their Foreign Minister, floating the idea of an elected European President. Both countries want a Europe that proceeds at different speeds, its inner core committed to full economic and political union and having sufficiently close living standards to not encourage too much intra-European immigration.

This debate will intensify as the blueprint for the new EU constitution, to be agreed in December, hardens up. British eurosceptics will criticise the EU for its lack of accountablity, while resisting attempts to democratise the EU or make its leadership more effective. Should the Blair Government accept marginalisation, or enter the discussions over building Europe as a constructive and active participant? And if so, over what agenda?

The Government hopes it can escape this dilemma because the Spanish and Nordic countries will be allies in doing as little as possible. But this underestimates the desire and need to move forward which animates the French and Germans. Europe is about to get hot.

The Government needs to spell out Britain's choices, to stop being closet pro-Europeans. Britain wants an economically liberal Europe with an effective single currency that includes as many European states as possible. This EU should be run by more accountable institutions with maximum power delegated to nation states. New Labour must sell this to the British, along with its intent to join the euro. And to argue fiercely for this vision in the constitutional talks that lie ahead. The alternative is to be sandbagged by the euro-sceptics and allow its enemies to set the agenda. We need more than Peter Mandelson to stand up and be counted, as he did last week. We need the Government to follow suit.

webTitle: How can I rid myself of this millstone?

fields.headline: How can I rid myself of this millstone?
fields.standfirst: Diane loved her dream apartment. But falling values and an unhelpful building society turned it into a nightmare, writes Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Diane feels she is part of a forgotten problem. Ten years ago, in August 1990, she became the proud owner of a studio apartment in the Medway Towns, which cost her £39,950. But things soon started to go pear-shaped.
fields.body:
DIANE MACFARLANE

Age 33

Lives in Rochester

Occupation Civil servant

Earns £19,600

Mortgage £36,000

Debts £2,000 on credit cards, £4,000 personal loan

Savings £1,000 in instant access account

Pension Occupational scheme

Aims To solve mortgage problems and clear debts

Diane feels she is part of a forgotten problem. Ten years ago, in August 1990, she became the proud owner of a studio apartment in the Medway Towns, which cost her £39,950. But things soon started to go pear-shaped. Within a year of her moving in, the prices of apartments in her block started to drop, slowly at first and then ever faster.

After about two years, owners had begun moving on and properties were either sold or rented out. Diane believes many of the original purchasers had their apartments repossessed. By 1997, the flats were being sold for £15,000, and she was the only owner- occupier left.

In 1992, she had approached her lender, the Yorkshire Building Society, to find out what help or advice they could give about her rising negative equity problem. They said they had no policy on negative equity. Realising she had no alternative, she went on paying her mortgage and her endowment premiums to Winterthur. By 1997, she was desperate to move to a larger property. So she went back to the Yorkshire.

She says: 'This time they did have leaflets, but they were of no practical use to me. They told me that if I wanted to move, the maximum negative equity I could take with me was £9,000. This was no good because my negative equity was nearly £20,000.'

In the end she decided to move out and rent a larger place for herself and find a tenant for her apartment. 'When I told the building society I wanted to let the property, they said they would charge me an extra 1 per cent on my mortgage, and they have done so ever since. They really don't seem to have been interested in helping me at any stage.'

Since she started letting out the property she has had tenants at most times, but on one occasion she had to wait four months to find a new one. That is when her credit card bills started mounting, because she was having to pay both her own rent and the mortgage.

The recent rise in property prices in the South-east has boosted the value of her apartment, but she believes it is still only worth around £25,000. She would dearly love to get rid of it and buy a small house of her own, but that would cost around £68,000 to £70,000.

Her endowment is another disappointment to her. She says the last notification showed it was worth just £5,000, even though it has been running for nearly 10 years. She is waiting to hear whether it is on track to pay off her mortgage at the end of the term, but is pessimistic.

Her main priority is to do something about the apartment. 'It has been a real millstone round my neck. It has pulled me off the housing ladder and I would really like to get back on it again.'

Adviser 1: Ray Boulger

Based on her desire to buy a house for £68,000 to £70,000, Diane's options are limited.

It will be impossible to do this without getting outside help or selling her endowment policy. She will lose out if she surrenders her policy, but will just about be able to buy the type of property she desperately wants and get back on the housing ladder. Over the long term, the profit she is likely to make on the house may compensate her for selling her endowment policy.

If Diane sells her studio for £25,000, after allowing for costs she will have to find about £12,000 to pay off the mortgage; £5,000 of this could come from the endowment policy, leaving £7,000 to find. She could finance this and refinance her other borrowings of £6,000 with a 10-year personal loan for £13,000. The cheapest lender offering a loan over 10 years at present is NatWest.

Her £1,000 savings would almost cover the stamp duty and legal costs, but she would need a 100 per cent mortgage. Northern Rock would lend her up to £67,000 on its Together mortgage. In addition to a reasonable variable interest rate of 7.29 per cent, there are no arrangement fees, no mortgage indemnity guarantee premium, no redemption penalties and no compulsory insurances.

Based on current interest rates, her mortgage and loan repayments would be just over half of her net income. She should go ahead only if she is confident she can afford these monthly payments.

Ray Boulger works for independent mortgage adviser John Charcol

Adviser 2: David Hollingworth

One possible solution for Diane is Northern Rock's Together scheme, which allows 95 per cent of property value to be borrowed on a secured basis with a further 30 per cent unsecured.

This could work well in raising capital to cover not only the negative equity but possibly rolling in the debts. However, on a multiple of 3.5 times income, Diane would have a borrowing capacity of £68,600, which does not reach the required level. It seems she will have to tough it out a while longer but should take heart from the rising market which will hopefully continue to negate the deficit.

Measures that Diane must concentrate on now are reducing her debt, particularly her mortgage balance if cashflow allows - rising rents may give some surplus that she could use.

As regards Diane's endowment, she must wait to see if it is on track. If it is not, she will have four options: increase her payments; save extra in an alternative investment vehicle, such as an Isa; put the shortfall amount of the mortgage onto a repayment basis; or surrender the endowment and put the whole mortgage on a repayment basis.

She should bear in mind that if she surrenders, the value is likely to be significantly less than on maturity. But if Diane's main drive is to get rid of the property then there could be grounds for the surrender to reduce the mortgage and speed up progress towards parity with the market value.

David Hollingworth works for London & Country Mortgages

Advice is for guidance only

webTitle: TV harks back to Ice Age

fields.headline: TV harks back to Ice Age
fields.standfirst: Neanderthal tribe is subject of latest epic drama in footsteps of Walking With Dinosaurs
fields.trailText: It has every hallmark of racy, raunchy television: violence, explicit sex scenes, dynastic rivalry and a brutal struggle for survival.
fields.body:
It has every hallmark of racy, raunchy television: violence, explicit sex scenes, dynastic rivalry and a brutal struggle for survival.

But the TV series now being filmed in Ulster is no gritty soap opera to rival Brookside: it is the latest big-budget science documentary set for screening in Britain.

In an attempt to rival the massive BBC hit series Walking with Dinosaurs, producers, make-up artists and choreographers, backed by leading UK archaeologists and fossil experts, are bringing to life another set of extinct creatures: the Neanderthals. And they have chosen a decidedly unusual setting: Glenveagh National Park in Donegal.

Here, among its peat bogs, oak woods and midgies, actors - sporting Neanderthal face masks, constructed using latest prosthetic techniques, have been huddling in polystyrene caves, skinning real deer carcasses, scavenging 'meat' from life-size models of mammoths, and speaking in a specially created Neanderthal language.

'It was a bit of a shock for some backpackers, especially the ones who stumbled on the life-sized mammoth model that we had left in a lake over a bank holiday,' said director Simon Lloyd of Wall to Wall Television, the programme's makers.

However, his aim was to create a natural history programme that was 'visceral and immediate,' he said. 'Most people do not realise we once shared Europe with an entirely different species of human being - the Neanderthals - who became extinct about 30,000 years ago when they encountered modern men and women.

'It was one of the most significant events in human history, and we are trying to bring it to life, to explain in what ways Neanderthals were different from us, and to understand why we survived and they did not.'

Neanderthals - once depicted as slouching, grunting sub-humans - are now known to have buried their dead, cared for their sick and had brains as large as ours. They dominated Europe through several Ice Ages and differed from us in only relatively minor ways.

Yet they perished when modern humans poured into the continent from Africa, and the programme, to be screened on Channel 4 in autumn, aims to dramatise the crucial features that accounted for our survival and their extinction.

The Neanderthal's World depicts a tribe, riddled by male rivalries, that is seen squabbling over food and sex. The action is set in the Dordogne during the last Ice Age - hence the choice of Donegal as location.

Each actor needed more than three hours each day just to put on his or her prosthetic head, with its massive nasal cavities and heavy browridge, two of the Neanderthal's most distinctive facial features. Then they were all 'dirtied down' with mud and rubber, and taught various Neanderthal skills - deer-skinning, making stone tools, and lighting fires using flints.

'It was the most bizarre experience of my career,' said actor Miltos Yerolemou. 'We were running about in the pouring rain wearing these false faces, jumping through bramble bushes and scraping ticks off our bodies.

'Then the weather improved - and the midgies came out. When we did night shoots, there would be blankets of them swarming about, all attracted by the banks of lights. The only way we could survive was to make a fire in our polystyrene cave and huddle in the smoke for protection. I played a mouse in the RSC's The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe before doing this. It was an awful lot easier.'

Each actor was also taught Neanderthal speech, a language originally created by Anthony Burgess for the film Quest for Fire, and which consists of a pared down vocabulary of a few dozen words: prenj, to take; ska, small; and vir, man, for example.

'We had workshops so the actors could get Neanderthal gestures and motion as we envisage them,' said movement consultant Ailsa Berk. 'These people had squat physiques, round chests and torsos and a big, wide-legged stance. They would have moved in a very distinctive manner.'

However, the programme's most controversial scenes will focus on the Neanderthals' encounters with modern humans - tall, thin, dark-skinned people called the Cro-Magnons who had poured westward into Europe after having migrated from Africa .

Initially these meetings are peaceful, but become increasingly menacing until violence breaks out. The Cro-Magnons kill the leader of the Neanderthal tribe and take over the cave which had been serving as their home. Later, a Neanderthal woman is enticed back to the cave by a male Cro-Magnon with the promise of food in exchange for sex. The coupling between the pair - a inter-species first for television - was filmed at length using two cameras. 'How it ends up on screen, depends on how carefully I edit it,' said Lloyd.

On top of the graphic depictions of sex and violence, the programme - which is either to be shown as a full two-hour special, or as a two-part series - will include computer reconstructions of major sites and the creation of a full mock-up of Neanderthal skeleton.

'Despite the fact that they buried their dead, no completely intact set of Neanderthal bones has ever been found,' said palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer of the Natural History Museum, London, a programme adviser. 'It is hoped we can put together a full replica to get a proper idea of their anatomy.'

webTitle: The Cat's whiskers on lower charges

fields.headline: The Cat's whiskers on lower charges
fields.trailText: The imminent arrival of child number four is one of the few bright spots on the horizon for the Prime Minister. All about him there are difficulties, but he can take encouragement from the Government's work on the investment industry.
fields.body:
The imminent arrival of child number four is one of the few bright spots on the horizon for the Prime Minister. All about him there are difficulties, but he can take encouragement from the Government's work on the investment industry.

The Government has not got everything right in this area, but its efforts to drive down charges are having an effect. As Heather Connon writes, investors' returns on funds that carry the Catmark are much higher than for others.

True, many Catmarks are based on index funds, which have some shortcomings. But we now know that charges do matter - and given the mediocre perfor mance of many expensive 'active' funds, the odds are clearly stacked against their investors.

Some investment managers have not taken Catmarking seriously, but the early results should put pressure on them to drop charges.

Endowment mortgages will be back in the news this week because Panorama is to broadcast the results of its investigation tomorrow night. It has also emerged that the FSA is preparing to fine some firms over their selling methods.

A pensions-style review of endowment mis-selling would not necessarily clean up the mess. Worried homeowners are instead being directed towards the Financial Ombudsman if they are unhappy but it is difficult to make a case unless you can prove that you were misled.

If, as Panorama suggests, recent sales are suspect, past ones will be no purer. It is time for insurers to volunteer guarantees to homeowners whose loans fall short.

fields.headline: New storey of upward mobility
fields.standfirst: Extra floors on old buildings are the green route to big money, says Christine Webb
fields.trailText: It's the ultimate 'loft conversion' - not just a room in the roof but a whole castle in the air. Developers are creating new homes by adding more floors to the top of existing buildings.
fields.body:
It's the ultimate 'loft conversion' - not just a room in the roof but a whole castle in the air. Developers are creating new homes by adding more floors to the top of existing buildings.

This is a moneyspinning idea, but it is also ecologically sound as it lessens the pressure on greenfield sites.

It is its moneymaking potential that particularly appeals to developers, especially when they convert offices into flats. And the idea is being picked up by the owners of top-floor flats in flat-roofed blocks, who are sometimes able to build new apartments on their roofs.

Nick Davies, a planning consultant, has such a client in Wandsworth, South-west London. 'This person lives on the top floor of a modern block, and wants to add a storey: he's just been granted permission,' he says.

Davies is senior vice- president of the Royal Town Planning Institute, which is very much in sympathy with this, where it can be done without harming the rights of existing residents. 'So long as there is car parking, and you are not spoiling the roofline in a conservation area, it's a thing to encourage,' he says. It it also in line with government moves to repopulate cities.

How much value can be gained from adding floors is illustrated at Stockleigh Hall, near Regent's Park in London, where three new penthouses have been built atop a Grade II-listed Thirties building, to sell at between £1.6 million and £3m apiece.

In nearby St John's Wood, developer Gainstride has added three new floors to a block of ex-council flats set in three acres of gardens at Boydell Court, to provide 12 new apartments, with breathtaking views across Primrose Hill to central London. Prices range from £685,000 for apartments of about 1,100 sq ft, to £1.75m .

The developer won the residents' agreement by offering new lifts, a refurbished staircase and entrance hall, and landscaped gardens.

However, Roy Ilott, a spokesman for the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors, once acted for homeowners in a block where a developer had bought the freehold so that he could add two flats in a new storey on top.

'My clients were living on the floor below these new flats, and had problems with damp, noise and vibration. It was a case of coming in as an independent professional to make sure what was being done was fair.

'But it's not all bleak. If a block of freehold flats has a leaky roof, it really is worth the residents' while asking a developer to do a deal and add a floor or two. This neatly solves the roof problem, and the residents may get other perks.'

At a former post office building in Birmingham, the Mailbox, Crosby Homes is adding two storeys to create the largest mixed-use building in Europe, with 143 flats.

The logistics were daunting, even though the building was empty. 'It has taken an awful lot of planning to get this absolutely right,' says Crosby's managing director, David Walker. 'The scheme has spent 12 months on the drawing board.'

Already 83 of the homes are sold, although the first will not be ready until August. Prices of the one-, two- and three-bedroom flats that remain range from £135,000 to £395,000.

Cala Homes has added a floor to the five-storey Britannic building in Birmingham to provide seven penthouses. Four of them will have two storeys, offering 2,500 sq ft of living space and 1,000 sq ft of private roof terraces. Prices start at £600,000.

In Manchester, two new floors have been added to 25 Church Street, boosting the number of flats in the old BT building to 78. The interiors were designed by Sir Terence Conran's company, CD Partnership, to appeal to the style-conscious. Prices range from £60,000 to £350,000.

But there is a warning from Andrew Waller, of estate agent Strutt & Parker, for those thinking of becoming upwardly mobile. 'The worry is that a penthouse can be devalued if someone builds above it. Being on the top floor has kudos. And sometimes leaseholders think it's unfair for the freeholder to make a profit at their inconvenience. It pays to try to solve neighbour problems before you start.'

Stockleigh Hall, FPD Savills: 020 7472 5000

Boydell Court, Knight Frank: 020 7431 8686

Birmingham Mailbox, Knight Frank: 0121 633 4400.

Cala: 0121 629 1300.

25 Church Street, Knight Frank: 0161 833 0023

webTitle: Active steps to cut our debt

fields.headline: Active steps to cut our debt
fields.trailText: Robert and Ann Burns took out a current account mortgage with First Active earlier this year on the advice of broker John Charcol. Their mortgage is £87,500 at present, but will soon be reduced to just over £50,000 after the couple transfer equity from the sale of two family properties to the account.
fields.body:
Robert and Ann Burns took out a current account mortgage with First Active earlier this year on the advice of broker John Charcol. Their mortgage is £87,500 at present, but will soon be reduced to just over £50,000 after the couple transfer equity from the sale of two family properties to the account.

The couple have sold their own home and Ann's parents' home. Their new property, a bungalow, is to have an annexe added for Ann's father to live in, and Robert says they have budgeted about £25,000 for that. When that bill is due, they will increase the loan to pay for the work.

Robert and Ann, who have three children, are also paying school fees, and although most have been paid from income so far, they may pay some out of the mortgage. They plan to deposit money maturing from a school fees investment plan that they have not yet needed to the account as well.

Ann is a taxation manager for a firm of accountants, and convinced Robert that it did not make sense to earn, say, 5 per cent on savings when a mortgage would cost more.

Robert is self-employed; he sells insurance to farmers and also works as a recruitment manager for the National Farmers' Union.

His income can be irregular, which is why John Charcol recommended the First Active product, which accepts lump sum payments at any time.

Although the couple were originally looking for a mortgage - and this is still the primary purpose of the product - Robert says that they are increasingly using it as a way to manage savings.

He says: 'With First Active we are paying 4.9 per cent interest. The best rate we could get in a deposit account is 3.5 per cent to 4 or 5 per cent.'

Overall, however, he wants to keep repaying the loan as quickly as possible.

In his part of the country, he says, house prices are not increasing at anywhere like the levels of those in the South-east, and the mortgage seems to remain a heavy burden. This is the incentive for repaying it.

'We seem to be throwing money at a thundering black hole,' he says of the mortgage burden.

His aim is to chop as much off the mortgage as possible with a view to eventually getting rid of it.

fields.headline: Global warning
fields.standfirst: They're the hottest names in haute couture, making clothes no one buys and no one can wear. But the latest shock from Dutch designers Viktor and Rolf is a collection that will sell all over the world
fields.trailText: They're the hottest names in haute couture, making clothes no one buys and no one can wear. But the latest shock from Dutch designers Viktor and Rolf is a collection that will sell all over the world.
fields.body:
'Jokey is the wrong word.' Rolf Snoeren does not like my choice of adjective. He is not laughing. Nor is Viktor Horsting, the other half of Viktor & Rolf, the Dutch design duo who are among the top five most influential fashion designers working today. Viktor's pointy little dog is not amused either: Vicky is just sitting on Viktor's lap, taking in the conversation.

No, Viktor and Rolf are not the clowns of the fashion world, even though that is how many of the journalists who have watched their fashion shows over the past five seasons may perceive them. Just because they make clothes fit for Pierrot, with great ruffles at the neck and comedy humps at the shoulders, it does not follow that they are having a laugh. Even when they produced a limited-edition perfume - something to which more experienced designers can only aspire - only to advertise the fact that it did not smell of anything, they were not laughing. Not so much as a giggle or a smirk. I stand corrected. This is no joke.

What is extraordinary about Viktor and Rolf is that eight years since leaving college, they are only just gearing up to put their first collection into production. Up until this autumn, Viktor and Rolf have concentrated on the highest and most expensive level of fashion: haute couture. Like artists, they have sold a piece here and a piece there. By their own admission, the majority of their output has been bought by museums, galleries and fashion institutes. These are clothes that are absolute one-offs and would take even the most adventurous follower of fashion several stiff drinks before she would venture out in them. And even then, she'd have to have a pretty good excuse. When one Sunday Times journalist took to the streets in a £15,000 V&R harlequin outfit - all in the name of research - she found herself to be the source of the evening's entertainment. These are not clothes designed to flatter, but they will certainly make passers-by stop and stare. 'I would rather spend the rest of my life looking like a dwarf,' she concluded. 'The effect of the outfit was to make me look like a pierrot after he had been trodden on by Godzilla.' Not the usual response you'd imagine from a woman slipping on a little haute couture for the first time in her life.

But come September, the first Viktor & Rolf ready-to-wear collection will sell out before it even hits the rails. 'We wanted to do something global,' says Rolf. So they have gone straight for the jugular. The designers, who have previously been all about exclusivity and obscure, arty experimentation, have produced a collection called Americana - an all-singing, all-dancing, cheerleading celebration of American sportswear. If Ronald McDonald him- self were to design a fashion collection, he couldn't have done a better job. The clothes are not subtle, making full use of the American flag, which is the collection's motif.

'The collection is based on American sportswear. We wanted to use something that has a global image,' says Viktor. So they took that most clichéd of images, the Stars and Stripes, and printed it on sweatshirts and jeans. 'The collection is about globalisation, about how American culture is very present everywhere.' But this is not a protest. The designers are ambivalent about America's influence. 'That's just the way it is,' they shrug. 'American companies have the formula of how to go global. For us, it's about taking icons and using them.'

But how is their use of the stars and stripes any different from the way Tommy Hilfiger or Ralph Lauren uses them? 'For us, it's a metaphor,' they say. 'For Tommy Hilfiger, that's really what he does. We are taking the cliché and pushing it further.' Kate Betts, editor-in-chief of the US Harper's Bazaar , sums it up with just one word: 'Irony. They have a really unique, intelligent, humorous take on fashion,' she says. 'They love fashion, but they are not afraid to poke fun at it, which is very unusual in this world.'

Americana was hailed a hit by the New York Times ' tough fashion critic, Cathy Horyn, who declared: 'The collection of natty jeans, ruffled shirts and sleek pantsuits that draw on their distinctive silhouette is terrific.' Betts agrees: 'It really proved that they can apply their wit and flair to wearable clothes. I think that the press reacted so positively because they were clothes that were inspired, but not abstract.' This month's issue of Bazaar devotes two spreads to the designers. 'Americans love Americana,' says Betts.

And it is not just the press that is cheering. It has been snapped up by nine key stores in America as well as in Japan, and in London by Liberty and the underground Soho boutique, Pineal Eye - which is almost unheard of for a first collection. Yuko Yabiku, the owner of Pineal Eye, feels privileged to have had two pieces of Viktor & Rolf already. They are from their first couture collect- ion in January 1998 - a jacket with gold spangles on the shoulder, and a white silk wedding dress. The pieces cost about £4,000 each. They have not yet sold, having been on sale since the shop opened three years ago. 'You have to have the right person,' says Yabiku, optimistically. 'I don't mind that they haven't sold yet. They are very special pieces, and anyway, they won't age. They are couture items, but they have to find the right person to fit them.' They are more art objects than shop stock. But this has not put Pineal Eye off buying the ready-to- wear collection.

'I thought they were so clever,' enthuses Yabiku. 'The clothes still have the feeling of couture in shape and design, but they are easier to wear. Instead of putting their logo on the clothes, they have used the American flag.' The stars and stripes have become their logo, and will be as instantly identifiable as a Louis Vuitton Damier print, which is exactly what the wearer will want. 'We've ordered most of it,' says Yabiku. 'From a simple jacket with striped shirt linings to the sweatshirt-fabric trousers.' Viktor and Rolf have gone from one extreme to the other. Not only is the collection wearable and washable, it is cheap. The most expensive piece is a coat, which will retail at £300. The jeans will be around the £70 mark.

This week, they take part in La Beauté, a major art show in Avignon - part of the city's celebrations as cultural city of France 2000 alongside other artists, designers, musicians and architects, including Hussein Chalayan, Alexander McQueen, Björk, Nick Knight, Jeff Koons, Arvo Pärt, Nan Goldin and Christian Boltanski. The show takes over the whole town, from 27 May to 1 October. Viktor and Rolf's installation centres around their collection of press cuttings and reviews, which they have made into a short video. They are fascinated by their own reviews, not least because at times they have felt that their fashion has not actually existed until it has appeared in print. Their career so far has been an exercise in how to generate publicity - a mixture of pranks, PR stunts, and clothes that not only push the boundaries of wearability, but at times appear to have been designed for creatures from another planet.

It has not been easy being Viktor and Rolf. These two talented designers met in the fashion department of the Academy of Fine Arts in Arnhem - the Netherlands' answer to Saint Martin's School of Art - in 1988. They realised that they went together like frites and mayonnaise in 1993, when they jointly entered the prestigious annual young designer prize at Hyères in the south of France. They didn't even have a name for their student experiments, and called themselves Viktor & Rolf because, well, those were their names. 'When we participated together in the contest, it was meant to be for one time only,' says Rolf. Completely unexpectedly, they won the prize. From that point on, they have been a partnership, working seamlessly as a single entity, just like the fashion world's very own Gilbert and George.

Viktor and Rolf's studio is situated up a quiet mews, between the queen's palace and Amsterdam's Red Light District. It is literally one small room, with their desk and lots of chaotic-looking filing cabinets at one end, and the pattern cutting table at the other. There is just about enough room to stand between the rails that line the walls - packed with great hulking clothes bags containing pieces of previous collections - and the table. And this is where the haute couture collections are conceived, designed and made, as well as the new ready-to-wear line. As a sign of their own intended small-scale globalisation, they are looking for a bigger place to work.

Viktor appears at the door, a slim, lanky figure with long arms and a studious look about him helped, perhaps, by his wire-rimmed specs. He wears jeans, with a red, white and black Argyle sweater - the sort of thing you might imagine Ronnie Corbett to wear. Rolf is close behind. He seems a little more nervy, and reserved, with small, rectangular glasses, a stubbly moustache and a tiny dimple of a goatee under his bottom lip. He's dressed in a plain jumper and jeans. There is a saying in the Netherlands that roughly translates as: 'Just be normal. It's crazy enough.' And it sums up Viktor and Rolf. The creators of some of the most extreme clothes the Paris catwalk has ever known appear to be the most normal Joes you could ever meet. But then, you look around the streets of Amsterdam and realise that everybody looks average. The way people dress is very everyday, even at night. People do not get dressed up. They don't seem to make an effort at all.

'Fashion does not exist in Holland,' says Viktor. 'There's a lot of money here but it's not done to show it. Holland is a very egalitarian society.' Showing off is not encouraged. Congratulations and compliments are rare. Everything is on a very even keel. Despite the fact that Viktor and Rolf are the kings of the international avant-garde fashion scene, f ted from Paris to New York, at home, they are barely noticed. And that is perhaps why they feel comfortable in Calvinist Amsterdam. They've lived in Paris, but found it too much of a struggle: 'We were so isolated, disconnected. It was very good for our creativity - we like to make life hard for ourselves.' Their parting shot to France was to take a trip to Disneyland Paris on their way home. The experience would have appealed to their sense of the surreal. Although they take their work seriously, it is with great relief that I realise they do have a sense of humour after all. And a wicked streak of irony. 'You have to put things in perspective,' they say, 'otherwise you take things too seriously.'

They are both obsessed with fashion, and have been since they were teenagers. Rolf recalls spending his adolescence locked away in his bedroom in a suburb in the south of Holland, fantasising over magazine features on Thierry Mugler or Claude Montana. He was interested in little else, dreaming of launching himself into this other world that seemed only to exist in Paris, New York and glossy magazines. And, now, aged 30, he and Viktor, who turns 31 this month, are at the epicentre of that world. They say they aren't interested in politics (although they think the queen of Holland should be de-throned, and they left their prestigious teaching post at the Academy for Applied Art in Vienna when the rightwing government was elected so as not to be employed by it), go to see films and art shows just as anyone does (rather than, as many fashion designers do, to 'be inspired'), and while it was their interest in fashion that first brought them together, it seems to be one of the few things they have in common. What else is there?

'We're not really into "things",' says Rolf. The only things they collect are press cuttings about their work, and a few treasured works by their friends, the avant-garde Dutch photographers Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin. They don't have a sense of nostalgia about anything - not even their own work. 'Once a collection has been showcased, we quite easily let it go,' they say. 'It is not important for us to keep it.' And anyway, the Groninger Museum in Groningen archives their work and buys pieces every season. In November, the museum will host a major retrospective of their work.

In Amsterdam, living is easy. Rolf can walk to work, while Viktor lives in the south of the city, an easy bike ride away from the studio. They do not have to live in Paris to show their haute couture collections there twice a year, nor to sell their ready-to-wear. But they do not consider themselves particularly Dutch. Strange though it may seem, the Netherlands is a hotbed of innovative new talent. Thanks to the efforts of Viktor and Rolf, to be Dutch in the fashion world right now is to be born with a passport straight into the hippest fashion magazines of London and Paris. The fact that one of those style bibles happens to be called Dutch , has of course, helped. But the Netherlands also has an exceptionally enlightened attitude when it comes to arts funding. The government offers an annual bonanza of grants to anyone who can prove that they have an innovative idea, or a fashion or design business that needs funding. The fact that Viktor & Rolf has only just launched a selling collection after almost a decade in business is a case in point.

It is not surprising that they have become pigeonholed as part of the art-as-fashion fraternity. Before they began showing collections during Paris Haute Couture week, they took part in exhibitions and staged their own pranks and happenings. In March 1996, instead of having a show, they declared they were on strike and produced a 'Viktor & Rolf on strike' poster. Their work has appeared in fashion exhibitions around the world, including the Visions of the Body show at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Japan. They have also produced costumes for the Netherlands Scapino Ballet, and were recently commissioned to design the uniforms for the staff of the Central Museum in Utrecht.

If their work is unorthodox, so too are their working methods. They cannot tell who has done what on a particular collection, and they work in total collaboration. Instead of sitting down and sketching, or nipping off on some exotic research trip, they seem to thrive working in a vacuum. 'We like trying to erase all references.' They simply talk to each other, and out of their conversation they piece together a collection. 'For us, the most creative thing is to create our own language,' they say. 'We talk, and try to figure out why certain things come up all the time, and then we ask why. We don't just wake up with a great idea.' And when one is in a bad mood, the other usually follows. 'We feed on each other's moods,' says Rolf. 'We don't have a lot of creative contact with other people.'

Fame and fortune have not happened overnight for the twosome. After Hyères, they worked away in relative obscurity, showing their clothes as part of a Netherlands collective, and exhibiting at arty shows around Europe. In 1998, however, they rocked the rarefied Paris couture world. John Galliano and Alexander McQueen had already given dying-on-its-feet haute couture an adrenalin injection. But V&R's second show had the effect of electric-shock treatment. It was based on the atom bomb, and the clothes - a tuxedo suit, a grotesque clown outfit - were all in the shape of a mushroom cloud, bizarrely exaggerated around the neck and shoulders, padded with blown-up balloons and cuddly toys, and strewn with party streamers and pompoms. The models walked, sombrely, to a slowed-down soundtrack of Prince's '1999', a sinister premonition of a dark and terrible Millennium Eve. 'We were thinking of New Year's Eve '99 and Nostradamus,' says Viktor. 'Not that we believed in any of it. For us, the millennium was just a number.' Despite the clown outfits and the bright polka-dot prints, the decadent collection was spine-chillingly pessimistic. And, of course, the fashion pack loved it. 'We didn't see it was so extreme when we were working on it,' says Viktor. But extreme it was, both in subject matter and silhouette.

Their next collection both infuriated and enchanted by showing their entire collection of black-and-white clothes virtually in the dark. UV light picked out the white trim and edging on the clothes, while the audience squinted to see the rest. She began with a tiny slip and ended almost collapsing under the weight of a typically exaggerated Viktor & Rolf coat. The piece, still in their studio, is so heavy I could barely lift it from the hanger.

Van Lamsweerde is a regular contributor to The Face and the US Harper's Bazaar, as well as working for designers including Yohji Yamamoto and the high-powered glossy advertising campaign for Louis Vuitton. She has championed Viktor & Rolf from the start, featuring their work in such publications as the cult American art-and-fashion quarterly, Visionaire. By their own admission, the majority of their output has been bought by museums, galleries and fashion institutes. These are clothes that are absolute one-offs and would take even the most adventurous follower of fashion several stiff drinks before she would venture out in them. The designers, who have previously been all about exclusivity and obscure, arty experimentation, have produced a collection called Americana - an all-singing, all-dancing, cheerleading celebration of American sportswear. fields.headline: Three lions
fields.standfirst: After scoring with their World Cup hit 'Vindaloo', Damien Hirst, Keith Allen and Alex James are back  with the official song for Euro 2000. But the Fat Les-version of 'Jerusalem' will be more than just a football anthem. The goal is to replace 'God Save The Queen'
fields.trailText: After scoring with their World Cup hit 'Vindaloo', Damien Hirst, Keith Allen and Alex James are back  with the official song for Euro 2000. But the Fat Les-version of 'Jerusalem' will be more than just a football anthem. The goal is to replace 'God Save The Queen'.
fields.body:
One thing you can definitely say about Damien Hirst the artist is that he's got balls. I know this because I am looking at them. They are unusually round and swollen-seeming and present themselves with a tomato-like impudence. A small indentation runs along each side, from front to back, as though two testicles are fighting to occupy the space normally claimed by one. You wouldn't say they were beautiful to behold - or even anything other than mildly unpleasant - but might describe them as thought-provoking. The renowned art critic Clement Greenberg once noted that all great art looks ugly at first, and the same, I suppose, is true of bollocks.

Right now, the Hirst bits are suspended about two and a half feet above a hill in Devon, lording it over one of the most green and pleasant tracts of land you are ever likely to encounter. Most of what is seen from here belongs to them, for this is the Hirst farm, home to the Hirst family and a dozen or so builders who are forever rearranging it like paint on a canvas, not to mention a collection of understandably twitchy- looking animals.

All morning, I've been chuckling at visions of sheep in market pens dolefully rolling their eyes heavenward upon being told who their new owner is, and am sure I hear the livestock muttering cautionary imprecations to each other every time we pass. I've been telling myself that they're just not accustomed to seeing grown men traipsing across fields in women's knickers, tights and St George's cross jumpers, but can't help noticing that the woman cab driver who arrives to take five-year-old Connor Hirst to a birthday party doesn't bat an eyelid. In the village, they refer to the squire merely as 'Damien'. The conclusion has to be that they're used to such sights in these parts.

Hirst is only nominally here in his capacity as the third most expensive living British artist (after Lucian Freud and David Hockney, both of whom have seen approximately twice his 34 years). Rather, he is engaged in a promotional photo session for Fat Les, the prank art collective who blew the English Football Association's vapid official World Cup anthem clear out of the water in 1998, with a brash romp called 'Vindaloo'.

Now, it's not often that a group of indiv- iduals are accused of lowering the tone of terrace chants, but on that occasion Hirst and his partners - the hell-raising actor Keith Allen and Blur's urbane bassist, Alex James - were. The words to that song went: 'Vindaloo, vindaloo, vin-da-loo, vin-da-loo na-na/Vin-da-loo, vin-da-loo-oo: we're gonna score one more... than... you...' and, once heard, could be expunged from the mind only by means of a frontal lobotomy. The record made number two in the UK singles chart and was one of that year's 10 bestsellers, but was regarded in chattering circles as an irritating, pretentiously proletarian jape on the part of three millionaire artists who should have known better.

This opinion was held, not least, by the leader of James's own band, Damon Albarn, who reportedly considered the Blur man's participation undignified and demeaning. As with so much else in Fat Les's world, however, all was not quite as it seemed.

As a piece of art, 'Vindaloo' was deceptively brilliant. It might have sounded like a yobbish din and been less musical than William Hague singing in the shower, but that summer Allen, James and Hirst persuaded, among others, a lot of xenophobic, racist Little England football supporters to celebrate an item of Indian cuisine as a quintessential expression of Englishness. As Allen had it at the time, 'Getting a load of reactionary fuckers to sing "Vin-da-loo" was actually quite hilarious.' And he was right. Somehow, Hirst's bravado is less convincing, more forced.

A stone farmhouse with spare, modern interior stands amid picturesque gardens and Hansel and Gretel woods and grassy hills. The ground floor contains a smart open-plan kitchen and sitting area, scattered with art debris and a large tank in which fish swim among a selection of rubbish, including false teeth, a model shark and an old beer bottle. Ask friends and acquaintances to describe their owner and the phrase you will hear again and again is 'the cleverest person I know.' Often this will be quickly followed by 'and the rudest'. Charged with finding words to describe his colleague, the first thing Allen comes up with is 'Tourette's-like', a reference to the medical condition where sufferers lose all social inhibition, becoming progressively more foul-mouthed and intemperate.

Short, with a gruff Yorkshire accent and head that looks as though it was intended for someone a foot taller, the people he most immediately puts me in mind of are Robin Williams, Bill Hicks and John Cooper Clarke. In conversation, you feel like the taxi driver who's been ordered to follow a car which is already disappearing round a bend. 'You recently admitted that you "got sick of being Damien Hirst" after winning the Turner Prize. Is that what your reinvention as a tycoon was about?'

'Yeah, he's a week and one day old and I've already learnt more from him than I could ever possibly teach him. Not bad in a week, though, is it? Bet your dad never told you that. I'm not going to tell him, either - haha.'

He's got no idea who Damien Hirst is or what Fat Les is, or what art is_ I think our denial of death is what our lives are about, but I don't think that's negative. I mean, I'll tell you what. I don't believe in God, or I didn't believe in God_ I don't believe in God, but I find it very difficult to not believe in God and still believe in art at the moment. I don't know where it's going to go.'

Hirst continues on the theme of fatherhood, bringing Allen into the equation. Allen has between five and seven children, with different mothers. He is the type of man self-respecting women tend to disapprove of, while being highly attracted to. Hirst's mum once suggested that he was a negligent father, but Damien disagreed.

'I said, "How can you say he's not a good father? He doesn't lie to his kids." My dad said he was going to be there forever, then stood up and fucked off. Keith says that all kids need is eye contact. When he told me that, I said, "You what?" But it's true.'

Which provides a dramatic representation of how I feel when I leave its maker's space.

If you really want to know about Fat Les, the person to ask is Keith Allen. Four days after Devon, we've arranged to meet for a game of golf at a nine-hole course in Hampstead. Allen, still a keen and fit footballer, took the game up a couple of years ago and is besotted with it. In the event, he's an hour late, having returned from a session at the Groucho a few hours before, and it's raining hard. We repair to a driving range in King's Cross, belt some balls and chat. He's in a good mood, exclaiming delightedly when he catches one on the sweet spot, which he does with impressive regularity.

'Has the idea of Fat Les changed?'

'No, it's what we in the business call fluid.'

'You mean you haven't a clue?'

'That's the truth, actually [laughs]. I mean, members come and go. Joe Strummer [of The Clash] was on tour while we were making the record, so we replaced him with somebody of the same stature. Michael Barrymore. Obviously.'

'So "Jerusalem" was Alex's idea, right?'

'No. No. He knows it was mine. Don't put that in. You can if you want.'

'Is this just a larf to you?'

'We're having fun, but it's not just that. When Alex pitched it to the FA, they said, "Right, but where's the gag?" People still say that to me when they hear it. They listen expecting something funny to happen and then it doesn't. 'Yeah, that's right. So we get left behind, with no sure sense of our own identity. Years ago, I remember going to a party after a football match, where there were lots of Scots and Welsh and everyone got up to do a national turn. When it came to ours, no one could think what to do. Someone started singing "Pack up your troubles in your old kit bag!" I thought, come on, you're 24, why don't you sing "Anarchy in the UK" or "Satisfaction" or something. I think this song, "Jerusalem", could really help to crystalise some kind of English culture. I believe that. I do. And how wonderful it is to have Trevor McDonald saying the name Fat Les - "the popular music ensemble Fat Les" - on TV. Twice!'

Allen goes on to talk about reclaiming this song, with words penned by one of the more radical thinkers of his time, from the Right. He also relishes the thought that the fans at Euro 2000, whether they know it or not, will be led by the London Community Gospel Choir and the London Gay Male Voice Choir.

'The idea of great big white fascist thugs singing along with this, going, "'ang on - a choir of nonces? What's this...?" I love that. What an amazing world we live in. This is the second time we've hijacked football for our own purposes. You know, the money, people have used it quite cynically in the past few years. Well, so have we, but to an entirely different end.'

What does it sound like? Fat Les has treated the song with respect. The straight, marshall-style beat is a shame, shattering the devotional fragility of those extraordinary melodies, though I'm prepared to accept it as a sacrificial necessity under the circumstances. Fortunately, the Pet Shop Boys and Two Bobs at Hendon Folk Club remixes (in which Allen does a fine impersonation of Bob Dylan) are worth three quid of anyone's money. How fanciful are Allen and James's hopes for the song? Well, the day we meet for golf, The Sun is running an article headlined 'YOU HAVE 31 DAYS TO LEARN THESE WORDS FOR EURO 2000'. Then, there they are, the words to one of the loveliest poems in the English language. Within a few days, there is expected to be another piece entitled '10 THINGS YOU DIDN'T KNOW ABOUT WILLIAM BLAKE.' An amazing world indeed.

He's in a good mood, exclaiming delightedly when he catches one on the sweet spot, which he does with impressive regularity. 'Has the idea of Fat Les changed?' 'No, it's what we in the business call fluid.' 'You mean you haven't a clue?' 'That's the truth, actually [laughs]. I mean, members come and go. Joe Strummer [of The Clash] was on tour while we were making the record, so we replaced him with somebody of the same stature. Michael Barrymore. Obviously.' 'So "Jerusalem" was Alex's idea, right?' 'No. No. He knows it was mine. Don't put that in. You can if you want.' 'Is this just a larf to you?' 'We're having fun, but it's not just that. When Alex pitched it to the FA, they said, "Right, but where's the gag?" People still say that to me when they hear it. They listen expecting something funny to happen and then it doesn't. When we were discussing what to do next, we found ourselves talking about devolution, which was in the air - the Jocks have it, and the Welsh, on paper at least - and, of course, no one ever thinks about England devolving.' 'We have nothing to devolve from. We can only evolve.' 'Yeah, that's right. So we get left behind, with no sure sense of our own identity. Years ago, I remember going to a party after a football match, where there were lots of Scots and Welsh and everyone got up to do a national turn. When it came to ours, no one could think what to do. Someone started singing "Pack up your troubles in your old kit bag!" I thought, come on, you're 24, why don't you sing "Anarchy in the UK" or "Satisfaction" or something. I think this song, "Jerusalem", could really help to crystalise some kind of English culture. I believe that. I do. And how wonderful it is to have Trevor McDonald saying the name Fat Les - "the popular music ensemble Fat Les" - on TV. Twice!' Allen goes on to talk about reclaiming this song, with words penned by one of the more radical thinkers of his time, from the Right. He also relishes the thought that the fans at Euro 2000, whether they know it or not, will be led by the London Community Gospel Choir and the London Gay Male Voice Choir. 'The idea of great big white fascist thugs singing along with this, going, "'ang on - a choir of nonces? What's this...?" I love that. What an amazing world we live in. This is the second time we've hijacked football for our own purposes. You know, the money, people have used it quite cynically in the past few years. Well, so have we, but to an entirely different end.' What does it sound like? Fat Les has treated the song with respect. The straight, marshall-style beat is a shame, shattering the devotional fragility of those extraordinary melodies, though I'm prepared to accept it as a sacrificial necessity under the circumstances. Fortunately, the Pet Shop Boys and Two Bobs at Hendon Folk Club remixes (in which Allen does a fine impersonation of Bob Dylan) are worth three quid of anyone's money. How fanciful are Allen and James's hopes for the song? Well, the day we meet for golf, The Sun is running an article headlined 'YOU HAVE 31 DAYS TO LEARN THESE WORDS FOR EURO 2000'. Then, there they are, the words to one of the loveliest poems in the English language. Within a few days, there is expected to be another piece entitled '10 THINGS YOU DIDN'T KNOW ABOUT WILLIAM BLAKE.' An amazing world indeed.

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: ...the National Botanic Garden of Wales
fields.trailText: ...the National Botanic Garden of Wales
fields.body:
If the Welsh landscape conjures up visions of hillsides nibbled bare by sheep, think again. This week it will be enhanced by the opening of the National Botanic Garden of Wales. The first garden of its kind to be created in the UK for 200 years, it occupies a former 568-acre regency estate in Carmarthenshire. Work began three years ago and the project is costing £43.3m, including £21.6m of Lottery money, so why has Wolfgang Bopp, the splendidly named garden curator, already set fire to part of the collection, and an endangered species to boot? The answer lies not in the soil but in the southwest Australian grass trees, which he has set alight in a simulation of a lightning strike and bush fire. 'It seems a destructive thing to do, but it's part of the natural life cycle of these trees,' says Bopp.

Setting a botanist loose with a blowtorch may seem like a pretty wild idea, but the fact that Bopp performed his pyrotechnics inside a new Norman Foster building is even more extraordinary. The Great Glasshouse takes up a third of the site, making it one of the world's largest single-span glasshouses. Visitors can marvel at its rock terraces, waterfalls, Spanish olive grove and interactive exhibitions. Beyond the glasshouse, the biomass furnace uses recycled wood to heat the buildings. There is also a Zen garden and a 220m herbaceous border, complete with pools.

It's still early days for much of the collection, including a prairie project simulating North American plant life. Not all of the 50 species are expected to survive in what the literature diplomatically describes as a wet climate.

Sounds like a great day out, but don't forget your mac.

 The National Botanic Garden of Wales, Middleton Hall, Llanarthne, Carmarthenshire (01558 668 768; www.gardenofwales.org.uk) opens on 24 May
