fields.headline: Nursing Mothercare back to health
fields.standfirst: Shops we don't want to visit, clothes our kids won't wear...  Nick Mathiason on crisis at the former bedrock of family life
fields.trailText: Shops we don't want to visit, clothes our kids won't wear... Nick Mathiason on crisis at the former bedrock of family life
fields.body:
No one can ever be prepared for the shock of encountering a new life and all its attendant joys, but at least buying things for the baby used to be a doddle.

The answer to every parent's practical problem was Mothercare. You want a cot? Mothercare. A buggy? Ditto. Maternity gear, newborn babygrows, even threads for pre-teens? Mothercare was the word. The chain, founded in 1961 by Selim Zelkha, had a trustworthy, fail-safe aura.

But for Mothercare those innocent days are gone. Consumer choice and a penchant for style have permeated the British psyche, making the chain's place in the world less certain. Last Tuesday, its parent, Storehouse, was consigned to the dustbin of British corporate disasters.

Storehouse, which went through four chief executives in 10 years, finally sold its loss-making subsidiary British Home Stores for £200 million to asset stripper Philip Green. Green's bid was rubber-stamped by disgruntled shareholders, who saw the value of their investment dive from a high of 361p in 1996 to 40.5p at Friday's close.

The Storehouse empire was formed by Sir Terence Conran in 1986, when he merged BhS with Mothercare and Habitat. In its heyday it included Heal's, Richard Shops and Blazer - now it can boast only Mothercare.

For the company's management team, led by chairman Alan Smith and finance director Chris Martin, last Tuesday represents year zero - and the final chance to revive one of Britain's most famous brands.

The team faces an enormous challenge. Recent trading figures suggest that last year, Mothercare just about broke even. Yet only three years ago the company posted pre-tax profits of £31m.

Since then, it has been beset by a trading crisis. At the root of its problems was the fact that its 350 high street stores did not stock enough items, and thus failed to make money.

The answer to this was to close 82 stores and concentrate on its larger Mothercare World outlets, where mums-to-be can manoeuvre more conveniently through aisles stocked with a comprehensive range of products.

But just as serious for Mothercare has been its disastrous clothing strategy. Martin admits his own pre-teen children 'wouldn't be seen dead in Mothercare clothes'.

Until recently, Mothercare sold clothes for children up to the age of 10, but they contributed a tiny portion of its £440m sales. However, Martin is adamant that the company will now focus on pre-school children.

The company is striving to find a balance between the upmarket, designer label babywear market led by Tim Waterstone's Tom & Daisy chain - along with DKNY and Ralph Lauren - and the supermarkets, led by Asda's George range and Tesco.

To an extent Martin is succeeding. It was a measure of how far Mothercare has come that Green said recently he didn't want to buy Mothercare, because the management team was already implementing the changes he would make.

Next month, for instance, Mothercare customers will be able to buy anything from buggies to mobiles over the Internet.

The group is attempting to reposition itself as a leading authority on motherhood: its website will also offer chat pages and entertainment guides for mothers with youngsters.

Within a year, the company will probably join a number of Britain's leading multiples in signing up for BSkyB's Open home shop ping service which will enable consumers who subscribe to digital satellite television to buy goods from their screens.

But there are indications that more executive blood will be spilt. Persistent rumours suggest that chief executive Greg Tuffnell will soon be replaced.

'He has to go,' confided a retail analyst. 'In the new order, his face doesn't fit. He is too associated with the past.'

Martin failed to give cast iron assurances that Tuffnell's job was safe - but did say that the team delivering the the recovery will stay basically the same. Whatever happens to the internal structure, it is thought that Smith and Martin will concentrate on reviving the business to make it attractive to a prospective buyer.

'Actually, Mothercare is not a bad brand,' said a leading Storehouse shareholder. 'They have closed most of its crap stores and sorted out the babywear range. I can't see a UK buyer coming forward, because it has been touted around for so long. 'But as progress is made, I can see an overseas company bidding for it.'

Kids' stuff
The £1.5 billion clothing market pandering to the needs of Britain's nippers has shown zero growth in real terms for the last three years. Retailers labour under the curse of a static birth rate and a fragmented market. However, doting mums, dads and grandparents are now prepared to shell out more.

The clothing for pre-schoolers is divided between up-market designer brands, sport labels and supermarkets who sell to the market's lower end. For the affluent, style-conscious parent, entrants include Ralph Lauren, Paul Smith, DKNY and Calvin Klein.

Gap is very guarded about sales, although it says they have increased year-on-year and that their fleece-and-jean jacket format 'is incredibly successful'.

Early learning centre

Its name may chime with ambitious middle-class parents eager to give their children every advantage, but until recently the chain, owned by John Menzies, the Edinburgh-based distributor and retailer, has struggled.

fields.headline: Mandelson the destabiliser
fields.trailText: Six months ago an American hedge-fund manager asked me who was going to win the next British general election. I told him that everybody expected Labour to walk it. 'That's not good enough for me,' he replied. 'In my business you have to make provision for all contingencies.'
fields.body:
Six months ago an American hedge-fund manager asked me who was going to win the next British general election. I told him that everybody expected Labour to walk it. 'That's not good enough for me,' he replied. 'In my business you have to make provision for all contingencies.'

Until now New Labour has comforted itself with the thought that, however badly it did in local and European elections - and Parliamentary by-elections since May 1997 - at least it had a strong lead in the opinion polls. Now even that has narrowed.

At times such as this, I consult my friends at Ladbrokes. Sure enough, the odds about a Labour victory have lengthened and the odds against the Tories have shortened. Labour had been such a racing certainty in the run-up to May 1997 that Ladbrokes stopped taking bets on it. It reached 10-1 on - you stake a thousand pounds to win a hundred. After the election it was 6-1 on for the next election; more recently the odds eased to 5-1 on. On Friday, I learned that the odds for Labour had eased further to 4-1 on. Over the same period odds against a Tory win narrowed from 9-2 to 3-1, and last week to 5-2 - so you can win £500 from a £200 stake.

Labour is still odds-on favourite, but no longer a racing certainty. This is a reflection not only of recent abysmal election results and the way the money has been flowing, but of Ladbrokes' assessment that many of those who voted Labour in 1997 are now 'floating'.

I wonder if there can be any connection between this and reports that Tony Blair is to drop the New from New Labour. Are those focus groups in Watford now saying 'New Labour - No Way'?

This train of thought is the result of a question last week from a member of the British Establishment: 'Is Gordon Brown still going to be Chancellor in the next Government?' We decided he probably was, and that there was no other Cabinet job that interested him, apart from the top one.

Enter Peter Mandelson. It is clear that my good friend the Chancellor is not amused by Mandelson's sudden foray into his territory. As far as the Treasury is concerned, Mandelson's province, as it were, is Northern Ireland, not the economy. Brown's relationship with Mandelson was nicely epitomised by his famous joke: 'It's not true that I don't get on with Peter Mandelson. Why, I haven't even spoken to him for 15 months.' Once Brown decided not to take the job of managing director of the International Monetary Fund, he must have been tempted to nominate Mandelson. Washington is a lot further away than Belfast. But Mandelson was hardly qualified for the job; and he would no doubt have used the post to proffer a lot of advice about the need for Britain to be more positive about the euro.

The problem with Mandelson's excursion into economic policy last week was not just that it diverted attention from the tough 'we shall not be moved' speech on economic policy that the Prime Minister had agreed with the Chancellor before the Confederation of British Industry annual dinner. It was that, with one word, Mandelson opened up the weakest flank in Brown's (on the whole) widely admired economic policies.

Look at it this way: you would surely have to be living on another planet not to be aware that the Chancellor has preached the virtues of economic 'stability' until the cows come home. He has reiterated the need to achieve stability and avoid 'boom and bust' at every opportunity. Mandelson's crime was to concede that 'swings in the value of sterling' had been 'destabilising'.

You see the point? The Prime Minister and Chancellor may finally have followed the lead of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee and admitted that the pound is overvalued. But to take this to its logical, and empirical, conclusion and acknowledge that an overvalued currency is destabilising is something one is simply not allowed to say. After all, the Ministry of Truth has declared that we now have stability.

I notice that the Government is trying to counteract the bad news about job losses associated with an overvalued pound by pointing to the new jobs created by inward investment by firms such as Marconi. But inward investment decisions take years to come to fruition; if the country is on the verge of an industrial crisis because of the high pound, the portents for future inward investment are hardly propitious.

Much damage has already been done by the high pound, but it is just possible that things are on the turn. The pound has been falling against the dollar, probably reflecting the fact that US interest rates have moved above the UK's. Various pieces of economic data indicate that the British economy may be slowing down, whereas the European economy is picking up.

It is just possible that the necessary adjustment to sterling will take place before the 'destabilising' factor ruins all the Chancellor's good work on stability. But I am not putting money on this at Ladbrokes yet.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Airtours seeks partner | Facia chief's trial set
fields.body:
Airtours seeks partner in Germany
Airtours is set to hold merger talks with rival C&N Touristic after the German firm failed to take over Britain's Thomson last week in the package holiday shake-up of the decade.

UK sources described the tie-up as 'logical' after German market leader Preussag trumped C&N to win an agreed takeover of Thomson for £1.8 billion last Monday. C&N, which had finally persuaded Thomson into talks after weeks of fruitless wooing, now desperately needs a fresh deal. Airtours is seen as an ideal partner. Chairman David Crossland owns 10 per cent of the company he founded; US cruise firm Carnival holds around 25 per cent, enough to ward off a hostile takeover by C&N.

Talks to see if a price can be agreed are more likely. Airtours will announce its half-year results on Thursday, and the City is expecting an increased winter loss of between £60 million and £80m up to 31 March 2000.

Facia chief's trial set
Four years after the collapse of his Facia High Street shopping empire, colourful Sheffield businessman Stephen Hinchliffe will finally stand trial at the Old Bailey at the end of the month. Hinchliffe, 50, faces one charge of conspiracy and 10 counts of corruption relating to nearly £1 million of bribes allegedly shared by two executives of an Israeli bank which lent Facia more than £10m

The trial, which is due to begin on 31 May, follows one of the biggest investigations ever undertaken by the Serious Fraud Office.

Before it called in the receivers on 1 June, Facia was one of Britain's biggest retail chains. With 850 shops, it owned a string of household names, including Sock Shop, Freeman Hardy Willis, Saxone and Contessa.

Hinchliffe is charged with allegedly conspiring with John Doherty and Paul Brady, two former senior managers at the London branch of United Mizrahi Bank (UMB), to defraud the bank by corruptly gaining loans for Facia.

Correction
On Sunday 14 May we stated that Martin Baker, former editor in chief of www.theStreet.co.uk had decided to launch proceedings for unfair dismissal against his former employer. This was untrue. We unreservedly apologise to Mr Baker for the distress and damage caused by this inaccuracy.

fields.headline: Matra targets US forces
fields.trailText: After months spent locked in battle with US missile maker Raytheon in the hardest fought defence contract for years, the victorious european bidder, Matra BAe Dynamics, is rubbing salt into American wounds with plans to sell its winning product to US forces.
fields.body:
After months spent locked in battle with US missile maker Raytheon in the hardest fought defence contract for years, the victorious european bidder, Matra BAe Dynamics, is rubbing salt into American wounds with plans to sell its winning product to US forces.

MBD deputy chief executive Alan Garwood said the Europeans - who have a partnership with US aircraft manufacturer Boeing - had been given 'clear indications' that the US Air Force and Navy would be interested in buying its missile for their F18 fighters.

He said American orders could be worth as much as £4 billion - on top of the £3bn expected from European air forces. Negotiations would be headed in the US by Boeing.

Last week, Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon announced an £800 million order for the Meteor missile to equip the RAF's planned force of 232 Eurofighters - despite US president Bill Clinton repeatedly lobbying Tony Blair to buy a rival from Raytheon.

The 'ramjet' missile, which has yet to be developed, will travel at more than 3,000mph and is intended to be in service by 2008. MBD will now open detailed negotiations with the Government about the fixed-price contract.

Included in this will be 'breakpoints' audited by defence research agency DERA to ensure progress. In addition, German, Italian, French, Swedish and Spanish governments will contribute to the estimated £450m development costs within the £800m total.

Garwood said the Spanish government was planning to integrate Meteor into its American F18 fighters.

webTitle: Safety casts a shadow over Rail Summit

fields.headline: Safety casts a shadow over Rail Summit
fields.standfirst:
Paddington fallout will dominate this week's talks, reports Joanna Walters
Paddington train crash: special report
Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Paddington fallout will dominate this week's talks, reports Joanna Walters
fields.body:
The dignity of survivors of the Paddington rail crash as they gave evidence to the Cullen inquiry last week put Ministers and rail industry bosses to shame.

It will be very difficult for Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott and the new rail barons to pat each other on the back for a job well done at the second Rail Summit this week.

First, there is limited progress to report beyond organisational changes that have yet to produce results for the travelling public.

Second, the great and the good will gather at a London conference centre just feet away from the sombre hall where the victims who lived through Paddington last October are daily telling their raw tales.

One, Peter Palmer, a music industry executive in his thirties, sobbed last week as he told the inquiry how he crawled over dead bodies to get out of coach H of the Great Western train before it turned into an inferno. Palmer escaped death and the endless, agonising skin grafts of those who were so terribly burnt, but he has to live with the memory.

Seven months after the crash, there has been no commitment by the industry or the Government to fit automatic train protection (ATP) across the national network.

A senior industry source told The Observer last week: 'We must wait for Lord Cullen. If we decided what to do before his report and got it wrong we would be accused of prejudging the inquiry.'

Waiting is currently the name of the game on the railways. In the spring, Railtrack issued its £52 billion 'menu' for investment over 12 years to bring us a 21st-century network. All but £5.5bn of that is unaccounted for as yet and will need input from the public purse and the operators and as well as Railtrack.

Railtrack is waiting for rail regulator Tom Winsor's vital announcement in July of what its charging regime will be for the five years from next spring. Until it knows what return it can make on its assets, how they are valued, and how much of its future revenue will be directly in its control it cannot spell out its part of the spending plan. Meanwhile, Transport Minister Gus Macdonald is drawing up a 10-year transport plan, also expected in July. But until Macdonald 'shows us the money' there is no knowing whether we are looking at patch and mend on what badly-burnt Paddington victim Pam Warren called 'our third-world railway' or at a system worthy of the world's fourth-biggest economic power.

Finally, there is the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority (SSRA), which is meant to work with the regulator to glue everything together. Chairman Sir Alastair Morton is due to come up with his own plan for the railways, padding out the Government's vision and channelling money to worthy projects accordingly. This plan should come through in September, about the time the Transport Bill becomes law and gives Morton the power to dictate to Railtrack. He is also considering greater competition for big projects so that other contractors can price against Railtrack - potentially a double benefit that will reassure the public that their money is not being poured down Railtrack's profit-hungry, low-efficiency black hole while forcing the company to clean up its act.

And SSRA chief executive Mike Grant is working on the complicated 'refranchising' process. This partly redraws the rail map and, in theory, forces the recalcitrant train operators to fight for their futures by re-letting the existing contracts early and on better terms - provided the operators improve performance and invest in better facilities for passengers.

The first three franchises, Chiltern, Connex South Central and Great North Eastern, will be declared this summer and the whole process will be completed by the end of 2001.

But the refranchising process itself has thrown operators, which had reluctantly agreed to work together at the last rail summit, back at each others' throats.

The senior source admitted: 'There is a commercial bid process going on, we cannot deny that. But we are trying to do the best job possible and this is going to shape the railways for the next 20 or 30 years. It may feel to passengers that things are not happening, not crystallising. But there are no quick wins and in the context of the next decade, the next few months is a short space of time.'

And what of performance?

After the kicking of its life over the past few months, Railtrack was fined £10 million last week for failing to meet its 'delay' targets.

But it feels it is making progress. It also reported that during 1999-2000 the number of broken rails on the network fell by 4 per cent, track quality was only 1.2 per cent short of the 2001 target and the incidences of signals passed at danger (Spads) dropped 12 per cent to 595, the lowest annual figure at a time of passenger boom. And the modernisation of the West Coast main line is under way with new management (but rocketing costs).

Railtrack chief executive Gerald Corbett told The Observer that the public now comes before the shareholders - which doubles as a belated admission that he is answerable to the public, the Government and the regulator and a cryptic message to Macdonald: if you want a posher, safer railway - pay up.

For the operators, more new trains are coming on to the network but overcrowding and punctuality worsen while fares rise. Jonathan Bray, of pressure group Transport 2000, said: 'The Government wants to show that things are going well. But without a clear agenda the rail summit will just be a public relations job.'

Chairman Sir Alastair Morton is due to come up with his own plan for the railways, padding out the Government's vision and channelling money to worthy projects accordingly. This plan should come through in September, about the time the Transport Bill becomes law and gives Morton the power to dictate to Railtrack. He is also considering greater competition for big projects so that other contractors can price against Railtrack - potentially a double benefit that will reassure the public that their money is not being poured down Railtrack's profit-hungry, low-efficiency black hole while forcing the company to clean up its act. And SSRA chief executive Mike Grant is working on the complicated 'refranchising' process. This partly redraws the rail map and, in theory, forces the recalcitrant train operators to fight for their futures by re-letting the existing contracts early and on better terms - provided the operators improve performance and invest in better facilities for passengers. The first three franchises, Chiltern, Connex South Central and Great North Eastern, will be declared this summer and the whole process will be completed by the end of 2001. But the refranchising process itself has thrown operators, which had reluctantly agreed to work together at the last rail summit, back at each others' throats. The senior source admitted: 'There is a commercial bid process going on, we cannot deny that. But we are trying to do the best job possible and this is going to shape the railways for the next 20 or 30 years. It may feel to passengers that things are not happening, not crystallising. But there are no quick wins and in the context of the next decade, the next few months is a short space of time.' And what of performance? After the kicking of its life over the past few months, Railtrack was fined £10 million last week for failing to meet its 'delay' targets. But it feels it is making progress. It also reported that during 1999-2000 the number of broken rails on the network fell by 4 per cent, track quality was only 1.2 per cent short of the 2001 target and the incidences of signals passed at danger (Spads) dropped 12 per cent to 595, the lowest annual figure at a time of passenger boom. And the modernisation of the West Coast main line is under way with new management (but rocketing costs). Railtrack chief executive Gerald Corbett told The Observer that the public now comes before the shareholders - which doubles as a belated admission that he is answerable to the public, the Government and the regulator and a cryptic message to Macdonald: if you want a posher, safer railway - pay up. For the operators, more new trains are coming on to the network but overcrowding and punctuality worsen while fares rise. Jonathan Bray, of pressure group Transport 2000, said: 'The Government wants to show that things are going well. But without a clear agenda the rail summit will just be a public relations job.' joanna.walters@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Ford finally seals Land Rover deal

fields.headline: Ford finally seals Land Rover deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: Ford at Dagenham
fields.trailText: Ford is set to buy the four-wheel-drive maker Land Rover this week, despite last- minute wrangles over price prompted by losses which soared to almost £100 million last year, The Observer has learnt.
fields.body:
Ford is set to buy the four-wheel-drive maker Land Rover this week, despite last- minute wrangles over price prompted by losses which soared to almost £100 million last year, The Observer has learnt.

The US carmaker is likely to switch at least half of Land Rover's component purchasing to the Continent and America over the next two years, at a cost of more than £1 billion and the loss of thousands of jobs to the UK motor supply industry.

BMW agreed to sell Land Rover for £1.8bn when it broke up and disposed of its Rover arm earlier this year, and Ford has since been looking at the books.

BMW and Ford are still haggling this weekend, but a source familiar with the deal said the sale was expected to go through in the next two or three days.

Ford is planning to increase Land Rover production at its Solihull plant in the West Midlands from 180,000 last year to its capacity of 250,000 - which could see hundreds of new jobs created.

But the move to switch away from UK component companies because of high sterling prices will be a blow to the industry. Land Rover buys 90 per cent of its parts in the UK. But Ford will seek to share parts with its US-made Maverick and Explorer off-road models - and buy more in the eurozone.

Ford is also considering doubling output of the Land Rover brand by building the vehicles at its US factories.

The strength of sterling is also causing problems for the Phoenix consortium, which took over Rover's Longbridge plant in Birmingham from BMW earlier this month.

Phoenix director Nick Stephenson said it was drawing up plans to switch component suppliers from the UK to continental Europe, where the pound-euro exchange rate would deliver savings.

fields.headline: Interiors angles
fields.standfirst: Forget Tate Modern - kitchens and bathrooms across the nation are crying out for a Chapman brothers makeover
fields.trailText: Tate Modern: the Enemy Within | House Invaders | House Doctor | Changing Rooms
fields.body:
Tate Modern: the Enemy Within BBC2

House Invaders BBC1

House Doctor C5

Changing Rooms BBC1

Apart from those sculptures of children with penises stuck to their heads - which possibly makes them to contemporary British art what Chris Morris is to television - I don't know much about the Chapman brothers, but I know which one I like.

If cute, earnest, verbose Jake had decided to be a bin-man, he would describe himself as an executive waste- disposal operative. But as it is, he and his brother create clever, hilarious art which they try to pretend isn't enormously playful and naughty, by having Jake say on Tate Modern: the Enemy Within: 'We've always tried to make work that is ambivalent about its surroundings. Or at least tactically active and entirely strategic in that respect', when what he really means is: 'We like winding people up.'

Anyway, while the Chapmans aren't particularly bothered whether or not they have their work displayed in Tate Modern, given that they do, they'd quite like it to act as a metaphor-virus upon the host body of the gallery-art establishment.

But perhaps it is the artist Michael Craig-Martin, a man with a deliciously subversive giggle that he isn't afraid to use in any medium, who is even more of a plague upon the art establishment's smart new house. Indeed, he was so disarmingly un-arty when describing his piece, Oak Tree, that he might have been auditioning for Changing Rooms: 'Frankly, it's a perfectly ordinary glass of water on a plain bathroom shelf. And anybody can have a work of art, too.'

'But,' interjected his interrogator, 'if this cropped up in museums all around the world... ?'

'Well, of course they'd be fakes!' Cue the viral laugh, which spread through its host, out of the TV and into the rest of the world, completely reducing this viewer to a giggly sofa-blob.

Tate Modern, of course, has one of Craig-Martin's sanctioned 'fakes', though, according to the artist: 'There is only one Oak Tree. It belongs to the National Gallery of Australia.' In the week that Damien Hirst settled a copyright infringement claim against his sculpture, Hymn, out of court (the £1-million, 20 foot-bronze is a scale copy of Humbrol's Young Scientist Anatomy Set, £14.99 at all good toy shops), surely B&Q will be straight on the blower to Craig-Martin: 'Er, we couldn't help noticing that your work, Oak Tree, is in fact currently on special offer for £14.99 at our branches nationwide, subject to availability.'

Practically everybody who was visited by this week's House Invaders and appeared on Carol Vorderman's Better Homes and Changing Rooms also had (or wanted) a nice little Craig-Martin of their own. But they also made the mistake of situating it in the bathroom, above the basin and underneath the mirror, not to mention cluttering it up with tubes of Colgate and Bonjela. As at the Tate, your fake Oak Tree can make a major statement only if placed pointlessly very high up on a plain white wall (no Anaglypta, dados or picture-rails, thank you) and accessed by stepladder.

In last Thursday's House Invaders (a regular daytime treat featuring punters who, though perhaps not telegenic enough to appear on Changing Rooms, still get a makeover from a cheery TV decorator), Linda Barker conceptualised some very nice, modernist-looking shelves from the seats of old chairs, dotting them over the walls of an ugly Edwardian terrace in Leicester where one of the inhabitants was a former art student, though this obviously wasn't enough to make Linda's shelves 'art'.

Interestingly, however, 24 years after Carl Andre's infamous bricks first littered the floor of the 'old' Tate and invited the derision of the tabloids, Monday's House Invader subjects, Sharon and Mitch from Yardley in Birmingham, were quite comfortable with Anna Ryder-Richardson recycling breeze blocks as candleholders and putting them on their bedside tables. 'Though I might paint the breeze blocks cream,' mused Sharon, diplomatically, after Anna had left.

Sharon and Mitch had a pet snake called Rot, while the next day's subjects, Stephanie and Derek, also from Birmingham, had a pair of rats. Funnily enough, Jake and Dinos Chapman have a tarantula and though I don't know if it has a name, it lives in 'Hell' - which is not in the Midlands but, according to Jake, is 'a 1:32 scale reproduction of the McDonald's drive-thru just up the road from our studio', replete with plastic miniatures eating tiny headburgers 'mooning' through the windows and 'begging' on the street outside.

Aside from the giant spider crawling over the roof, this was indeed 'hell' - all those little plastic people would be potentially lethal anywhere near children under five, so if Tate Modern buys it, they should get Anna Ryder-Richardson in to design a big toybox of brightly-coloured MDF the better to keep 'Hell' away from tiny, prying hands. It worked a treat for keeping Sharon and Mitch's living- room tidy: toys at one end, snake in the middle, sofa at the other. Sorted.

In House Doctor (the best programme on Channel 5), Californian home stylist Anne Maurice (Gucci sunglasses, brisk, no-nonsense charm) went to Chester to try and help Mr and Mrs Renshaw sell their spacious Victorian home. The house was hell, if not 'Hell', and the cultural chasm yawned hilari ously. The Renshaws (divorced, mannered, mildly bonkers, an 'Is there honey still for tea?' parody of Englishness) needed all the help they could get from Ann, who diplomatically persuaded Mrs R to pack up her vast collection of Franklin Mint-cum-car-boot sale bird objets and store it elsewhere.

'Oh, the owls! You're dealing with the owl family just now, aren't you?' exclaimed Mrs R, just before Ann moved on to the seabirds. Which was shortly before Mrs R (nothing as vulgar as first names for the Renshaws) unexpectedly exited the programme, waving from the back of a taxi. I so wanted to know what she made of the seagrass carpet and painted floorboards in an attic which was just crying out for a Chapman brothers makeover, having caused one prospective buyer to shiver and remark that: 'There's no way I'd allow any living creature up here.'

Meanwhile, in a particularly delightful Changing Rooms, Laurence Llewellyn-Bowen allowed the caravan-dwelling proprietor of a Cumbrian bird-of-prey centre to keep his wooden swan sculpture in exchange for some kinetic (ie the walls moved, the floor rocked. It was, after all, inescapably a caravan) designer minimalism. While creating soft furnishings on a scale of which Claus Oldenberg would approve, Laurence sewed his cuffs to some fabric and asked for 'approximate parameters in a completely hypothetical scenario - how are we getting on with the curtains?' I doubt Jake Chapman could have put it better himself - and though the result was lovely, unfortunately the caravan's ceiling wasn't nearly high enough for a Craig Martin Oak Tree, so they probably had to settle for a shelf in the bathroom.

fields.headline: Back on the wild side
fields.standfirst:
Lou Reed
Royal Albert Hall, London SW7
fields.trailText: Lou Reed
fields.body:
In the bar, the bets were on for what would be Lou Reed's token 'old one' encore number. We know he's going to be mainly performing songs from his latest rather good album, Ecstasy, but we also know it's extremely bad form for rock legends, even notoriously snotty ones like Reed, not to throw at least one Sixties or Seventies classic to the hordes.

My companion for the evening thinks 'Vicious'. I'd really love Reed to play the Velvet Underground's 'Venus In Furs', but the smart money is on 'Perfect Day', simply because of the infamous BBC interpretation, featuring countless rock and pop icons yodelling away like their back catalogues depended on it.

The show is three exhausting hours long but exquisitely paced. Surrounded by his band, Reed stands centre-stage with a guitar. He still has the same bad mullet haircut and well-worn leather trousers, still reeks of arrogance and bile.

Ecstasy is all about the souring of personal relationships, and you could see why Reed might have problems if he swaggers around his own house like he swaggers around a stage. There's an edge to him sadly missing in most performers. You keep thinking he's going to leap off the stage and give you a good slap for not paying attention properly.

The first number is 'Paranoia In the Key of E', the new album's sensual opening track. Many agree that Ecstasy is a welcome return to form, raising Reed's creative stock back up a few notches after a rather dirgey mid-Nineties. The album's songs are classic Reed with a twist. While Reed and John Cale wrote 1990's Songs For Drella for Andy Warhol, Reed clearly wrote Ecstasy for himself and the personal demons which continue to taunt, provoke, heckle and obstruct him. Which, one feels, is just the way Reed likes it.

Occasionally, there's the faintest whiff of self-indulgence about his dogged loyalty to his newer material, but the execution saves the night. Reed sings sexy, druggy songs, such as 'Ecstasy', licking and lapping at the microphone like a refugee from a porn movie. He thrashes through more populist ditties such as 'Romeo And Juliet' with a 'catch this' smirk. He makes snide remarks ('Of course, people from London would know all about what it's like to come from a small town'). He wriggles his non-existent bottom at us, grinning like a deranged monkey. In short, Lou Reed is every bit as great as he obviously considers himself to be.

As a young music fan, I felt umbilically linked to the Velvets' 'Banana' album, and the solo classic, Transformer, to the point where Reed was more important to me than all four Beatles combined. Bearing that in mind, it's a credit to Reed's performance that I don't really miss not hearing all those old numbers tonight.

Unusually for an artist of his pedigree, Reed has managed to transcend his glorious past and move forward. When he does finally play 'Sweet Jane' for the encore, it's initially quite confusing ('Who wrote this then?... Oh God, of course!'). Then comes 'Perfect Day'. It looks like the after-show drinks are on me.

webTitle: It looks like the new Ealing comedy. But then it goes to pot

fields.headline: It looks like the new Ealing comedy. But then it goes to pot
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Saving Grace | The Whole Nine Yards | One Day in September | Final Destination | Nora | Down to You | Elmo in Grouchland
fields.body:
Saving Grace (92mins, 15).
Directed by Nigel Cole; starring Brenda Blethyn, Craig Ferguson, Martin Clunes

The Whole Nine Yards (99mins, 15).
Directed by Jonathan Lynn; starring Bruce Willis, Matthew Perry

One Day in September (92mins, 15).
Directed by Kevin Macdonald

Final Destination (98mins, 15).
Directed by James Wong; starring Devon Sawa, Ali Larter

Nora (106mins,15).
Directed by Pat Murphy; starring Ewan McGregor, Susan Lynch

Down to You (92mins, 12).
Directed by Kris Isacsson; starring Julia Stiles, Shawn Hatosy

Elmo in Grouchland (72mins, 12).
Directed by Gary Halvorson; starring Kevin Clash, Mandy Patinkin

One step forward: two steps back. The search for the next hit British comedy doesn't so much progress as (cheerfully) regress. Saving Grace, which won the audience award at Sundance this year, is a simple Ealingisation for the twenty-first century. You've seen Whisky Galore ? Here it is again, but this time the natives are Cornish and the moonshine is marijuana.

Feisty widow Brenda Blethyn finds her deceased rat of a husband has left her broke. Out on the streets like her Scottish gardener (Craig Ferguson)? Not if her green fingers and greenhouse can turn his wilting pot plants commercial. Otherwise, little changes. A ripe repertory company of the UK's finest do their honed stuff. Phyllida Law gets memorably stoned. Ken Campbell plays a funny policeman. Leslie Phillips, a link across the decades, is an elderly vicar not a randy curate. Martin Clunes, as the boozy GP from hell, has most of the best lines and milks them deftly. You don't miss Alec Guinness and Peter Sellers, though you wouldn't mind if they turned up. Blethyn, her eyes at once flashing and calculating, wouldn't be overshadowed in any case.

So far, so good. Nigel Cole bowls things along at an amiable pace. Mark Crowdy and Ferguson (doubling up) have written a script that stays funny most of the time. But even the Twenty-First Century Fox isn't ready for a family hymn to hemp financed by Rupert Murdoch, and the plot goes up in predictable smoke at the end. How can having such a good time be so wrong? Don't argue: this is still the never-never land of Titfield Thunderbolts, and (yes, Minister) the big weed's name is Jack Straw.

Meanwhile, a No-No, Minister. Jonathan Lynn, who co-wrote the sublime Whitehall series, departed long ago for Hollywood and a less sublime directing career. The Whole Nine Yards is his latest and (in America at least) one of his most successful. Bruce Willis is a hit man on the run in Montreal. Matthew Perry, the porkiest of the Friends, is the dentist next door. Perry's wife (Rosanna Arquette) wants him dead. Willis's former employees want him dead too. Willis wants his wife (Natasha Henstridge) dead. Why? Don't ask. It doesn't much matter. This could have been The Ladykillers for the new millennium, but too much slapstick and mugging - not to mention bad lip-synch - get in the way. The last 20 minutes break into a welcome trot and Bruce Willis stays pleasantly relaxed, but only Amanda Peet (dentist receptionist turned hit woman) leaves a luminous mark.

When is a British Oscar winner more an event than a movie? When it's One Day in September. Kevin Macdonald, weaving together old film and contemporary interviews, has turned the murder of 11 Israeli athletes at the Munich Olympics into a gripping, dismaying narrative. The single surviving Black September terrorist tells his own story at last. The relatives of the slain remember with poignancy. There's a definitive investigative thrust as the real, hapless role of the German government is laid bare. This is a sizzling documentary, but it still doesn't quite fit the big screen. So much of the footage is familiar TV dross and Colemanballs that the imagery, too, is debased, somehow pining for its front parlour home.

What matters isn't vague denunciation of an unfeeling Olympic Committee (which didn't stop the Games quickly enough) or human grief in an Israeli graveyard: what matters is Macdonald's vivid reconstruction of Bonn's botched airport rescue - a malign masterpiece of Murphy's Law. Anything that could go wrong went ludicrously, tragically wrong. The final nine hostages died in vain. Amateurism beyond words, compounded a few weeks later by a sly pantomime of renewed hostage-taking which saw the three remaining Palestinian terrorists handed over to Libya. That's the essential tale, and for completeness it needs the context of a greater awareness; it needs to acknowledge more generously that Willy Brandt's Germany, in its unpreparedness, was essentially seeking to exorcise the ghosts of its own past, another victim not a villain. More, it needs to reflect on the role of the media whose hectic reporting shaped so much - including Macdon ald's possibilities. That would have been a television exposé to make Panorama proud again. A formidably trenchant non-movie.

Susan Lynch is formidable, too, and the hype about her was right. She is the eponymous Nora, the hotel maid from Galway who became James Joyce's life support system, and she's wonderful: spiky and soft, chilly and warm, tragic and hilarious, always lit by genuine fire. Your eyes follow wherever she goes: which is, alas, just as well, for this is a performance in a wax museum.

Brenda Maddox's original biography of Nora Barnacle was distinguished because her words and Joyce's flowed together, a cross-referencing and explanation of genius. Here there are no words to remember - apart from much effing and Jaysus-ing - and Ewan McGregor's supposed genius is as dull as Dublin ditchwater, a petulant bore in silly glasses who not even this adoring Nora could truly love. That's fatal, and Pat Murphy, plodding from one setpiece to another as though turning the pages of a colour supplement, is powerless to compensate. What's going wrong with McGregor, in dire need of a charisma transplant? It isn't the roles that are thrust upon him: he is co-producer of this dud. He thrust, nay impaled, himself.

There is, as ever, good teen stuff - and the other kind. Final Destination comes roaring out of the top drawer. James Wong, the director, is an old X Files hand with a Mulderesque scenario to explore. Forty high-school kids are off to Paris for a field trip when, strapping into the runway jumbo, one of them (Devon Sawa) has a mighty premonition of doom. He and six others get off the plane. Doom explodes in the night sky: and the question is whether the Grim Reaper, thwarted of his predestined haul, will return to finish off the fortuitously saved seven. It's an interesting and comprehensible idea, worked out at a breakneck pace in short, sharp shocks. Sawa is a convincingly thoughtful hero, Ali Larter his sensible helpmate. The jolts keep coming until the last second with wholly professional zest.

So to the duffer stuff. Freddie Prinze Junior ( She's All That ) and Julia Stiles ( 10 Things I Hate About You ) are the reigning Cary Grant and Grace Kelly of teen movies and, given a plot with an edge to it, both likeable enough. But Kris Isacsson's script for Down to You is an affair to forget from an Ann Landers agony column. Boy wins-loses-wins girl in lugubrious march from here to maturity. Stiles looks pug-faced glum, Prinze merely bemused: Isacsson has given himself nothing to direct. Henry Winkler, the Fonz of yore, resurfaces as a TV chef. It makes you wonder what Prinze will be doing 30 years on.

For the Spring Bank holiday, the Jim Henson company bring you Elmo in Grouchland, 72 minutes of Sesame Street in very distant homage to Lewis Carroll. It's harmless enough, but devoid of the slightest freshness after a quarter of a century of similar offerings. The kids I know would probably rather stay home on their computers.
fields.bodyText: Saving Grace (92mins, 15). Directed by Nigel Cole; starring Brenda Blethyn, Craig Ferguson, Martin Clunes The Whole Nine Yards (99mins, 15). Directed by Jonathan Lynn; starring Bruce Willis, Matthew Perry One Day in September (92mins, 15). Directed by Kevin Macdonald Final Destination (98mins, 15). Directed by James Wong; starring Devon Sawa, Ali Larter Nora (106mins,15). Directed by Pat Murphy; starring Ewan McGregor, Susan Lynch Down to You (92mins, 12). Directed by Kris Isacsson; starring Julia Stiles, Shawn Hatosy Elmo in Grouchland (72mins, 12). Directed by Gary Halvorson; starring Kevin Clash, Mandy Patinkin One step forward: two steps back. The search for the next hit British comedy doesn't so much progress as (cheerfully) regress. Saving Grace, which won the audience award at Sundance this year, is a simple Ealingisation for the twenty-first century. You've seen Whisky Galore ? Here it is again, but this time the natives are Cornish and the moonshine is marijuana. Feisty widow Brenda Blethyn finds her deceased rat of a husband has left her broke. Out on the streets like her Scottish gardener (Craig Ferguson)? Not if her green fingers and greenhouse can turn his wilting pot plants commercial. Otherwise, little changes. A ripe repertory company of the UK's finest do their honed stuff. Phyllida Law gets memorably stoned. Ken Campbell plays a funny policeman. Leslie Phillips, a link across the decades, is an elderly vicar not a randy curate. Martin Clunes, as the boozy GP from hell, has most of the best lines and milks them deftly. You don't miss Alec Guinness and Peter Sellers, though you wouldn't mind if they turned up. Blethyn, her eyes at once flashing and calculating, wouldn't be overshadowed in any case. So far, so good. Nigel Cole bowls things along at an amiable pace. Mark Crowdy and Ferguson (doubling up) have written a script that stays funny most of the time. But even the Twenty-First Century Fox isn't ready for a family hymn to hemp financed by Rupert Murdoch, and the plot goes up in predictable smoke at the end. How can having such a good time be so wrong? Don't argue: this is still the never-never land of Titfield Thunderbolts, and (yes, Minister) the big weed's name is Jack Straw. Meanwhile, a No-No, Minister. Jonathan Lynn, who co-wrote the sublime Whitehall series, departed long ago for Hollywood and a less sublime directing career. The Whole Nine Yards is his latest and (in America at least) one of his most successful. Bruce Willis is a hit man on the run in Montreal. Matthew Perry, the porkiest of the Friends, is the dentist next door. Perry's wife (Rosanna Arquette) wants him dead. Willis's former employees want him dead too. Willis wants his wife (Natasha Henstridge) dead. Why? Don't ask. It doesn't much matter. This could have been The Ladykillers for the new millennium, but too much slapstick and mugging - not to mention bad lip-synch - get in the way. The last 20 minutes break into a welcome trot and Bruce Willis stays pleasantly relaxed, but only Amanda Peet (dentist receptionist turned hit woman) leaves a luminous mark. When is a British Oscar winner more an event than a movie? When it's One Day in September. Kevin Macdonald, weaving together old film and contemporary interviews, has turned the murder of 11 Israeli athletes at the Munich Olympics into a gripping, dismaying narrative. The single surviving Black September terrorist tells his own story at last. The relatives of the slain remember with poignancy. fields.headline: A brighter shade of Gray
fields.standfirst: Songwriter David Gray's career was dead in the water. Now he's on Letterman and in the charts - and it's all thanks to the Irish
fields.trailText: Songwriter David Gray's career was dead in the water. Now he's on Letterman and in the charts - and it's all thanks to the Irish
fields.body:
On the campus of Santa Monica College in Los Angeles, suntanned students loiter on the grass. From a transistor radio, you can hear an advert for a plastic surgery deal to make you look like the celebrity of your choice. And, lounging incongruously on the grass amid all this low-cal Californian swagger, is one pale Englishman - David Gray.

Gray is at the college to perform a live set of songs from his album, White Ladder . Right now, everything is going swimmingly: his show at the El Rey theatre has sold out, he's on the David Letterman show next week and the album is selling 6,000 copies a week across the States. In the UK, his album has been rereleased by EastWest to a chorus of critical acclaim and the new single, 'Babylon', is playlisted on every major pop radio station. But it wasn't always thus. The story of David Gray's rise is a refreshing, inspiring one, of the power of good songwriting to triumph over the cynical machinations of the music industry.

Not so long ago, Gray's career seemed dead in the water. The brief approbation mustered by his 1993 debut album, A Century Ends, was long since faded, and the release of his fourth, White Ladder, passed pretty much unnoticed. Out of desperation, he toured Ireland, playing places remote enough to experience power cuts when the local dairy's milking machines turned themselves on. Slowly, the country grew to love him and the album went to number one.

The organic Irish success of White Ladder has made Gray the 'priority act' at EastWest, above the likes of the Corrs and Busta Rhymes. As Gray says: 'They'll soon be stuffing me down everyone's throat.' Well, at least his music - influenced by early Dylan and Van Morrison - is a lot more palatable than most of the teen-pop and novelty dance tracks record companies stuff down our throats.

Gray's rough ride through the industry has taught him how to deliver his natural passion in a more generally accessible way. 'It's taken me five years to tame the confrontational delivery I used to have - to stop shouting, learn to underplay it and pick my moments,' he says. 'I used to sound like a complete lunatic.'

Gray first surfaced aged 23, garnering comparisons to Bob Dylan, and was carried away by the hype. Once, he and his band, while supporting Radiohead on tour, had a few drinks, and - in an attempt to moonwalk like Michael Jackson - covered their dressing-room floor with crisps (the grease makes it easier). They then tried the same thing in Radiohead's dressing-room, but found their carpet too sticky, so they used ice cubes instead. Radiohead, so the story goes, returned, sighed and dutifully tidied up.

The fun began to ebb when sales slowed and Gray's mentor left the record label, Virgin. 'I was rudderless. There was no one in charge of me when we did the second album, Flesh. Idiotically, I thought I could handle it.' Flesh floundered commercially and Virgin dropped him.

At this time, though, new faces made the jolt easier. He got married and then met drummer Craig McClune ('Clune'), his co-writer on White Ladder . Then he signed to EMI, but the company promptly imploded. 'We did this horrible tour for the third LP across the States, where at each venue we were almost second on the bill to the BBQ ribs on the menu. Things fell apart.'

Realising he had reached a dead end, Gray extricated himself from EMI and returned to writing music with Clune, a man with a penchant for Hawaiian shirts and flailing his wiry arms on stage as if he were the drummer from the Muppets. They recorded at Gray's old home in Stoke Newington, the energy of the sessions drowning out both their very real money worries and the noise from Hackney council digging up the street outside. It was a turning point. 'I could have become Mr Acoustic Misery and lived behind some sort of partition,' he says. Instead, he opened himself up to other people's opin ions. 'They're essential to the creative process - and make it more fun.'

Gray formed his own label, IHT, and recorded a song for the Kathy Burke film This Year's Love. 'I needed the money, so I churned it out.' The result, recorded in one take, is one of the most effortlessly touching songs of recent years, despite what Gray calls the 'cynical motivation' behind its writing. After that came the Irish tour - and redemption.

Tonight, beneath the pink chandeliers of the El Rey theatre, Gray playfully asks the crowd if there's 'anyone famous here'. With the exception of the man who plays the portly hospital porter in ER standing by the front door, there isn't. It's a plus. Gray has come this far without cosmetics or hype; it would be a shame to change that now.

 David Gray plays Shepherd's Bush Empire on 3 August. Babylon is released 12 June on IHT/EastWest

fields.headline: Death and the maidens
fields.standfirst:
Life's no picnic in Sofia Coppola's elliptical directorial debut. You won't understand it, but you should see it
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Life's no picnic in Sofia Coppola's elliptical directorial debut. You won't understand it, but you should see it.
fields.body:
The Virgin Suicides (97mins,15). Directed by Sofia Coppola; starring James Woods, Kathleen Turner, Kirsten Dunst

The Virgin Suicides is a film apart. It hovers on the edge of genre familiarity - high-school romance, American Beauty 2 , horror whydunit - and yet it is none of these things. Sofia Coppola, writing and directing, captured all the elliptical complexity of Jeffrey Eugenides's cult novel and added something haunting of her own. You'll love it or hate it. I thought it was terrific.

We're in a leafy Michigan suburb 25 years ago and the Lisbons live across the street. Dad Lisbon (James Woods), a downtrodden maths teacher; Mom Lisbon (Kathleen Turner), a dumpy Bible basher; and their five lissom, golden-haired daughters. The spotty boys of the neighbourhood look on and lust inchoately. But this isn't adolescent paradise. Thirteen-year-old Cecilia (Hanna Hall, with the blank eyes of a young Uma Thurman) inexplicably slits her wrists. The local psychiatrist recommends a little male company. Mom throws an awful, awkward party. Cecilia impales herself on a railing.

The four who remain, led by Lux (Kirsten Dunst), persuade Mom to let them go to the school prom. Lux finds splendour in the grass with the local hunk (Josh Hartnett), who loves her and leaves her. Turner locks up her daughters. Dunst goes wanton. The denouement of the title begins to brew. Yet the plot is merely a smidgen of the full story. We never discover why what happens is allowed to happen. Our lack of understanding is echoed by the boys, now grown, looking back on events that shaped the rest of their lives. There is, in one sense, no reality, because the precision of defined personality is washed away. The girls are seen as unknowable symbols in a fairy tale; the themes of longings and incomprehensions across the sexual divide are universal.

Does that make it sound forbidding? It isn't at all. The playing is spot on - Woods and Turner, both shrewdly cast against type (where have you gone, Mrs Robinson?). Danny De Vito's bemused psychiatrist. The languor of the golden girls and the gaucheness of the unlikely lads. Dunst is radiant and wildly mysterious.

There's acute social comedy and a moody, drifting score from the French group Air. It is lovely to look at and unsettling to know, a transference of pain. As you sit there, your own memories come flooding back. I remembered the girl called Jacqueline of long ago who died, trapped in her bedroom, when the house caught fire, and I remembered how I felt. I was meant to remember, invited to look back in melancholy. That, in the fullness of its sorrow and pity and awakening, is the power of The Virgin Suicides . The questions it asks are the questions you must ask for yourself, and you will only fail to respond if those questions are foreign to you.

Sofia Coppola has carried a grinding weight of expectation into her debut. How could it be otherwise for the 28-year-old daughter of Francis Ford Coppola and wife of Spike Jonze (who was shooting Being John Malkovich at the same time)? Those kind of connections spell inflated expectation. But this is a subtle triumph, a film that owes nothing to father or husband. Here's another rare talent to cherish.

fields.headline: Iranian beauty
fields.standfirst:
Last year's festival was a French farce. This year's jury will surely reward the serious contenders
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Last year's festival was a French farce. This year's jury will surely reward the serious contenders.
fields.body:
Mny of the fanfares at Cannes are for films that don't exist yet - and probably never will. In 1984, planes were flying over the bay trailing banners advertising Michael Winner's remake of Gunga Din, which has still to come forth. This year, there are ads for Elian: the Gonzales Boy Story, a Menahem Golan production 'shooting now on a secret location, delivery September'.

A more likely film for which drums have literally been beating is Buñuel and King Solomon's Tables. A band of Spanish drummers from Buñuel's birthplace, Calenda, paraded along the Croisette to mark both the director's centenary and the Carlos Saura biopic shortly to go into production.

The real films in competition have an odd geographical spread - six from South-east Asia, three from Sweden, two with Israeli directors, one from former Warsaw Pact countries, one from Latin America, none from Africa or Australia.

And they invite us to ignore their quality and experience their length. Of the 23 pictures up for the Palme d'Or, only seven are under 110 minutes. Ten are more than two hours and five are more than two-and-a-half. It would take from nine in the morning until 9.15 at night, without an interval, to watch Taiwanese Yi Yi, the French Les Destinées Sentimentales, the Japanese Eureka and the Chinese Devils on the Doorstep back to back. There's a lack of focus here.

Brevity, however, is not necessarily the soul of wit. Among the shortest pictures was the risible Gohatto (Taboo), Nagisa Oshima's first film since 1986, in which a flirtatious, 18-year-old, gay samurai creates sexual havoc among the imperial bodyguard of the 1860s. Someone suggested that the movie should have been called 'Ugetsu Homogatari', and it could put back the case for gays in the military for decades.

But one of the most impressive pictures on view, Blackboards, was both the shortest and the work of the youngest director ever to have had a movie in competition - Samira Makhmalbaf, 20. Her first film, The Apple, was chosen for the Un Certain Regard section two years ago. This lean fable about itinerant schoolteachers in a desolate area of Iran near the Iraqi border is a confident advance on that promising debut. It opens with a memorable image of nine teachers carrying blackboards on their backs along a dusty mountain road, looking like prehistoric birds or Lynn Chadwick sculptures.

Two of them break away, one joining a party of boys carrying contraband goods across the border, the other attaching himself to a horde of elderly men and one young widow with a child heading for their homeland in Iraqi Kurdistan. Everyone is too busy or wary to want to learn reading, writing and arithmetic, and the blackboards are variously used for splints, shelter and camouflage. This astonishing film is unlikely to go unrewarded; the Special Jury Prize seems a possibility.

The jury, presided over by the French director Luc Besson, a specialist in large-scale international productions, is clearly charged with making up for the embarrassingly foolish prizes handed out last year by a jury under the eccentric Canadian provincial, David Cronenberg. The 1999 Palme d'Or, the Grand Jury Prize and the best actor and actress awards went to a pair of dedicatedly uncommercial movies, one of them stiltedly amateur, featuring wooden, unprofessional actors, while some distinguished pictures, including Raul Ruiz's, Time Regained , were ignored.

Yet as the festival approached its final days, no consensus over front runners had emerged, though French critics were pressing the suit of Edward Yang. His three-hour Yi Yi looks at a troubled, but by no means dysfunctional, middle-class Taiwanese family, their friends, relatives and neighbours, as they cope with everyday problems at the office, at school, in the home, and within their hearts, minds and consciences.

Three films the jury will be taking seriously are black comedies that suddenly erupt into truly disturbing violence. My favourite among these is by a little-known Frenchman, Dominik Moll. Harry: He Is Here to Help You begins with a chance encounter one hot summer's day in a motorway lavatory between two old school acquaintances, the wealthy playboy Harry (Sergi López) and an underachieving language teacher Michael (Laurent Lucas), who is driving his wife and two small daughters in their battered car to a modest holiday home in the country.

The over-solicitous Harry, convinced that Michael has not fulfilled his teenage promise as a writer, insinuates himself into the teacher's life. But the trouble with Harry is that he is a homicidal psychopath, and what starts out like a Michael Frayn comedy subtly modulates into a reworking of Hitchcock's Strangers on a Train .

The second black comedy, Nurse Betty, sees Neil LaBute, hitherto known as writer-director of the misogynistic chamber piece, In The Company of Men, spreading his wings. In his road movie, a pair of jokey hit men (Morgan Freeman and Chris Rock as father and son) pursue a dim housewife (Renée Zellweger) across America to acquire a cache of heroin hidden in her car.

They have killed her car-dealing husband (Aaron Eckhardt) in a peculiarly horrendous way, first scalping him, then shooting him as he runs around like a headless chicken. Much of the humour in Nurse Betty derives from the traumatised Zellweger believing she is a nurse in her favourite soap opera, which she happens to be watching at the moment her husband is slain.

The third black comedy, Jiang Wen's three-hour Devils on the Doorstep , turns on a group of peasants forced by Kuomintang guerrillas to hide two prisoners-of-war - a Japanese sergeant and a Chinese collaborator - in Japanese-occupied China in the last months of the Second World War.

The songs are terrible, the choreography a joke, the performances lamentable. Seemingly inspired by Pennies From Heaven, it finishes up like Springtime For Hitler. Some observers think it might appeal to Luc Besson.

fields.bodyText: Mny of the fanfares at Cannes are for films that don't exist yet - and probably never will. In 1984, planes were flying over the bay trailing banners advertising Michael Winner's remake of Gunga Din, which has still to come forth. This year, there are ads for Elian: the Gonzales Boy Story, a Menahem Golan production 'shooting now on a secret location, delivery September'. A more likely film for which drums have literally been beating is Buñuel and King Solomon's Tables. A band of Spanish drummers from Buñuel's birthplace, Calenda, paraded along the Croisette to mark both the director's centenary and the Carlos Saura biopic shortly to go into production. The real films in competition have an odd geographical spread - six from South-east Asia, three from Sweden, two with Israeli directors, one from former Warsaw Pact countries, one from Latin America, none from Africa or Australia. And they invite us to ignore their quality and experience their length. Of the 23 pictures up for the Palme d'Or, only seven are under 110 minutes. Ten are more than two hours and five are more than two-and-a-half. It would take from nine in the morning until 9.15 at night, without an interval, to watch Taiwanese Yi Yi, the French Les Destinées Sentimentales, the Japanese Eureka and the Chinese Devils on the Doorstep back to back. There's a lack of focus here. Brevity, however, is not necessarily the soul of wit. Among the shortest pictures was the risible Gohatto (Taboo), Nagisa Oshima's first film since 1986, in which a flirtatious, 18-year-old, gay samurai creates sexual havoc among the imperial bodyguard of the 1860s. Someone suggested that the movie should have been called 'Ugetsu Homogatari', and it could put back the case for gays in the military for decades. But one of the most impressive pictures on view, Blackboards, was both the shortest and the work of the youngest director ever to have had a movie in competition - Samira Makhmalbaf, 20. Her first film, The Apple, was chosen for the Un Certain Regard section two years ago. This lean fable about itinerant schoolteachers in a desolate area of Iran near the Iraqi border is a confident advance on that promising debut. webTitle: A doctor, his wife and the lover

fields.headline: A doctor, his wife and the lover
fields.standfirst: The Country is a triumph - and not just because of Juliet Stevenson
fields.trailText: The Country | Dolly West's Kitchen | Solemn Mass for a Full Moon in Summer
fields.body:
The Country, Royal Court, London SW1

Dolly West's Kitchen, Old Vic, London SE1

Solemn Mass for a Full Moon in Summer, Barbican Pit, London EC2

In Vicki Mortimer's inspired design at the Royal Court, a sitting-room has a forest hovering over it; the sawn-off trunks look like the landing pads of an alien spaceship. In this sitting- room, a couple wrangle, sometimes in the manner of mechanical toys, sometimes with relaxed naturalness. Riffs of percussive music - wheezing, clanking and tapping as from a grandfather clock - suggest that the action is caught up in a giant piece of machinery.

Everything about The Country is at once completely ordinary and sinisterly strange. It features a doctor and his wife, drug abuse, an affair, an enigmatic stranger and a move from urbanity. Its dialogue is packed with neat linguistic points, both acerbic and desolate: 'Kiss me,' pleads a wife. 'I've already kissed you,' retorts her logical shit of a husband.

The Country is a breakthrough for its writer, Martin Crimp, and for its director, Katie Mitchell. Crimp, whose plays are celebrated in Europe, has been mainly known in Britain for his translations and the oblique and spiky drama Attempts on her Life . In The Country , he has produced something more open and driving. Mitchell has made her mark as a meticulous director of classic plays; here she shows a new, ferocious energy.

It's not surprising that Juliet Stevenson is magnetic as a subdued but seething wife. Nor that Owen Teale is plausibly alluring and slippery as her husband. Indira Varma will be more of a surprise. She's outstanding, still and stealthy, as she runs her tongue round her lips and rings round her hosts. A compelling new actress.

Frank McGuinness has a great gift for looking aslant at Irish history. He exercised it in the lacerating Observe the Sons of Ulster Marching Towards the Somme . He exercises it again in his new play at the Old Vic which considers the question of Irish neutrality during the Second World War by looking at attitudes to sexual freedom and sexual ambiguity.

Dolly West's Kitchen pictures two glamorous GIs ('Gorgeous trousers,' comments one admirer) arriving in a Donegal household and charming the pants off a frustrated married woman and a repressed young man. In doing so, they spread sexual tremors everywhere. The scenario allows McGuinness ample opportunity to demonstrate his other big talent - for letting rip with a gag. There's a story here about a saint in a pub which alone is worth the ticket price.

The result, as directed by Patrick Mason for the Abbey Theatre, is genial but over-egged. Everyone is too delightful, too cajoling. It's difficult to credit the campness - 'My name's Mary' - of the homosexual GI when he greets an unknown family in the Forties. Joe Vanek's cumbersome design dwarfs and slows up the action. But two fine performances shine out. Pauline Flanagan anchors the play as the wise old bird who licenses all behaviour. And Donna Dent is a beautifully changeable Dolly.

The Barbican's International Theatre Event has opened with a short but ambitious work by the Quebecois dramatist Michel Tremblay. Solemn Mass for a Full Moon in Summer uses the Catholic Mass as a map of human love (one scene is called 'Dies Irae', another 'Lacrymosa').

In this Gallicised Traverse Theatre production, directed by Philip Howard and Ros Steen and designed by Neil Warmington, a Montreal tenement building is lit by a huge, orange moon. From each balcony a love story arises. An estranged female couple come close to blows; a widow describes her loss; two 20-year-olds restrain themselves from copulating in the street. Sometimes, the tales are spoken as a duet; sometimes as a debate.

By treating a text as if it were music, the precision of words is smudged; there is too much sob and throb. And yet the play is wonderfully revealing about the dynamics of the theatre. As a conversation starts on one balcony, spreads to another and turns into a cascade which engulfs the whole stage, you begin to see the groundplan of drama.

fields.headline: Bonfire of the profanities
fields.standfirst: The grotesque glories of Europe's carnivals give anarchy a good name
fields.trailText: Carnivalesque | Susan Hiller: Witness
fields.body:
Carnivalesque
Brighton Museum and Art Gallery, Fabrica Gallery and University of Brighton Gallery until 2 July. Then Nottingham followed by Edinburgh

Susan Hiller: Witness
The Chapel, Golborne Road, London W10 (details on 020 7336 6801) until 25 June

Do Not Open, warns the tantalising message on the closed doors of the diptych. Naturally we slip the catch, unable to resist. On one panel, painted with all the meticulous devotion of the sixteenth-century altarpiece, is a broad mooning backside, boil-ridden and splayed. A sprig of thorns has been inserted in parody of Christ. On the other panel, a man pulls a grotesquely mocking face. He is sneering at the latest dupe to fall for his booby-trap.

You might think this Flemish diptych was dangerously subversive for its day, sending up religious art to the point of profanity. Yet that most pious of all monarchs, Phillip II of Spain, kept one just like it to fool guests at his palace. This joke-in-a-box is in fact a souvenir of carnival, that pre-Lent festival in which swigging, guzzling, groping and mooning, dressing up as wicked angels and even crowned monarchs were all part of the sanctioned anarchy.

Carnivalesque, the three-venue show that begins its national tour in Brighton, is crammed to bursting-point with images of the carnival. There are fools and hunchbacks, dwarves and cuckolds, women with breasts that reach the floor, men who need a barrow to support their paunch. There is gorging and disgorging, defecation and projectile vomiting, every variety of sudden fluid. There are mad hats and frightening masks, ripped bodices and falling trousers. There is work by some of the great masters of carnival - Tiepolo, Goya, Daumier and Ensor - and, mercifully, there is a magnificent catalogue and captions to help make sense of all this carnival chaos.

This is especially useful for the simple reason that Britain does not do carnivals. Street parades, maybe, but never the unbuttoned catharsis you see in Brueghel's Battle Between Carnival and Lent or Ensor's drawings of the million-headed Brussels mob. Tiepolo's Punchinello roams the crowd in his Klannish clothes; our homicidal Punch stays tidily in his box. We don't dress up like the Spanish demons in Goya or ride donkeys backwards like the Frenchmen in Jacques Callot's etchings. All these festivities continue across the Continent to this day. The nearest we get is the anti-capitalist protester in hobnails and tutu teasing an impassive London copper on May Day.

The absence of the carnivalesque from British life and art is not explained here. The show is inspired by the theories of the Soviet critic Mikhail Bakhtin, who coined the term carnivalesque during Stalin's Purges. He naturally saw the carnival as anti-authoritarian, the victory of laughter in the face of fear. So you get The World Turned Upside Down - images of rabbits shooting hunters, horses riding men, wives beating husbands, bosses enslaved. You get the Grotesque Body - Daumier's Gargantuan Louis Phillippe , swollen by the public purse - and the Comic Mask, in which anyone tyrannised by clerics, dictators or European despots can mock the boss for a single day.

These notions were revived in Sixties Paris, which possibly explains the fortuitous inclusion of Philip Guston's Klansmen from 1968 and Louise Bourgeois's French fetish, a limbless amputee stitched in pink flannel. But Bakhtin's theories were essentially literary; they can't always be made to fit the wilder forms of art.

Guercino, for example, made his name with sublime religious frescoes. But the bizarre watercolour in this show - in which a shocked man encounters a monstrous foot on legs - was clearly painted on some dark day off. Daumier was imprisoned for the self-evident satire of his Gargantuan monarch.

But nobody fully understands the morality of Brueghel's great Land of Cockayne, where work is illegal and fools lie on their backs surrounded by sausage-string fences and custard-pie houses. As for Goya's Caprichos, those black tableaux of blind inhumanity, they were always beyond satire, beyond interpretation.

In a sense, this riveting show is sharply divided between licensed disorder and unfettered art. On the one hand, there are the stock characters, incidents and props of the carnival, coded and repeated in mass-produced prints that can be recognised and chuckled over from one country to the next. Portable jokes, like the Flemish diptych, they exist to remind you of that one-night-only excess.

On the other hand, there is art that follows no conventions and despises all sanction. This is, I think, where the British come in, specifically James Gillray, the English satirist. Gillray's caricatures of Pitt the Younger - as a nightmare dentist ripping out John Bull's mandibles, as the Anti-Midas who turns England's wealth into excrement and spew - are by far the most subversive, anti-authoritarian works in this show.

His brilliant, manic, unleashed draughtsmanship has no need of carnival: it represents in itself the true disorder of the world.

Susan Hiller, the American-born artist, specialises in the disorder of the paranormal world. Her latest work, commissioned by Artangel and installed in a derelict London chapel, is a spectacular congregation of all the first-hand accounts of inexplicable sightings that Hiller has been collecting for many years. You enter through deep shadow to a shifting hum of voices, filling the air like the spirit of the beehive. These are emitting from tiny speakers, suspended from the ceiling in a hanging garden of silver wires. Pressed to your ear, they tell strange stories in many different accents: 'The building just lifted from the ground', 'it had wings like a bat', 'there was a sudden silver light - I know I didn't dream it.'

There is no way that these tales can be disproved. Some witnesses may sound more plausible than others, but you are in your own cloud of unknowing. As the spectral light alters and the chorus fluctuates, the piece feels like a phenomenal visitation in itself. I was listening to an Australian on my speaker when the chapel suddenly fell silent - except for his lone voice, echoing from somewhere far away. I have no idea how this mystery was achieved. I can only say that I didn't dream it.
