But nobody fully understands the morality of Brueghel's great Land of Cockayne, where work is illegal and fools lie on their backs surrounded by sausage-string fences and custard-pie houses. As for Goya's Caprichos, those black tableaux of blind inhumanity, they were always beyond satire, beyond interpretation. In a sense, this riveting show is sharply divided between licensed disorder and unfettered art. On the one hand, there are the stock characters, incidents and props of the carnival, coded and repeated in mass-produced prints that can be recognised and chuckled over from one country to the next. Portable jokes, like the Flemish diptych, they exist to remind you of that one-night-only excess. On the other hand, there is art that follows no conventions and despises all sanction. This is, I think, where the British come in, specifically James Gillray, the English satirist. Gillray's caricatures of Pitt the Younger - as a nightmare dentist ripping out John Bull's mandibles, as the Anti-Midas who turns England's wealth into excrement and spew - are by far the most subversive, anti-authoritarian works in this show. His brilliant, manic, unleashed draughtsmanship has no need of carnival: it represents in itself the true disorder of the world. Susan Hiller, the American-born artist, specialises in the disorder of the paranormal world. Her latest work, commissioned by Artangel and installed in a derelict London chapel, is a spectacular congregation of all the first-hand accounts of inexplicable sightings that Hiller has been collecting for many years. You enter through deep shadow to a shifting hum of voices, filling the air like the spirit of the beehive. These are emitting from tiny speakers, suspended from the ceiling in a hanging garden of silver wires. Pressed to your ear, they tell strange stories in many different accents: 'The building just lifted from the ground', 'it had wings like a bat', 'there was a sudden silver light - I know I didn't dream it.' There is no way that these tales can be disproved. Some witnesses may sound more plausible than others, but you are in your own cloud of unknowing. As the spectral light alters and the chorus fluctuates, the piece feels like a phenomenal visitation in itself. I was listening to an Australian on my speaker when the chapel suddenly fell silent - except for his lone voice, echoing from somewhere far away. I have no idea how this mystery was achieved. I can only say that I didn't dream it.

fields.headline: Spiralling out of control
fields.standfirst: The V&A hoped the Spiral building would repair its reputation. But the Tate has stolen its thunder
fields.trailText: The V&A hoped the Spiral building would repair its reputation. But the Tate has stolen its thunder.
fields.body:
There is one small but highly influential group within the museum establishment that is looking on at the tidal wave of Lottery-funded projects transforming Britain's cultural landscape with nothing short of dismay. It is not the question of the seemliness of non-chronological hangs at the Tate that bothers them. Or the long-term sustainability of the museum of apparently not very popular music in Sheffield. The trustees of the Victoria and Albert would be happy to have built just about anything so long as they could have had it up and running this year. They have had to look on as the Tate has reinvented itself.

While the Tate has picked up huge amounts of Millennium Fund money, attracted a new audience and even charmed the Government into picking up the costs of free admission, the V&A has signally failed to do any of these things. Despite its astonishing treasures, the V&A is still mired in the self-doubt and controversy that has plagued it since it was run by Roy Strong more than a decade ago.

It is now facing yet another financial crisis and, in Alan Borg, it has a director whose authority has been undermined by the failure of the trustees to persuade him into early retirement. Worse, it is continuing to lose visitors - it has even been overtaken by the National Portrait Gallery.

The trustees, led by the well-connected Paula Ridley, and including the developer Peter Rogers, are in no doubt that the V&A needs a fresh approach at the top. Both Ridley, who is a trustee at the Tate, and Rogers, who acted as a construction advisor to Tate Modern in order to get it finished on time, have seen at first hand the impact that a determined director such as Nicholas Serota can make on a museum.

For several months there have been rumours that high-profile figures from outside the museum world have been sounded out on their willingness to take on the directorship. Last month, the V&A publicly admitted that it had started a search for a new director. The trustees had asked Culture Secretary Chris Smith for the money to offer Borg a tempting early retirement package, but were turned down. They decided to renew his contract, but only until his sixtieth birthday at the end of next year.

He went overnight from being a safe pair of hands to the most conspicuous lame duck in British museums. The V&A risks going back into the era of feuding staff and trustees that it had hoped it had finally thrown off. Borg had been brought in as a museum director with an impressive record at the Sainsbury Centre and then at the Imperial War Museum.

He was regarded as credible enough academically to deal with the intellectual snobbery of the world of decorative arts, but also experienced enough to make the V&A popular. Yet here he was on the way out again, just four years later. Press reports about the trustees' failure to get the Department of Culture, Media and Sport to underwrite his pension prompted speculation that it was a deliberate leak, designed to embarrass him into resigning.

It could also be seen as being very unfair to a director who had got two big capital projects under way - the £30 million restructuring of the British Galleries and the eyecatching £80m Spiral building - and secured such notable coups as persuading the troublesome Royal Institute of British Architects to disgorge its spectacular collection of architectural drawings.

The spin from the trustees is that since directors retire at 60, it would be better to appoint Borg's successor sooner rather than later. A new director now would avoid a break in continuity at the top, half way through the construction of the Spiral.

What really worries the trustees is not early retirement, but money. There are serious concerns about the funding of both the major construction projects initiated by Borg. The British Galleries have a budget of £30m, and have had just over £16m from the Heritage Fund. Most of the rest is sponsorship money, which has yet to be raised. If it doesn't materialise, and with the galleries due to open in 2001, time is running out; meeting the shortfall will throw the museum's finances into crisis.

There is also doubt about the funding of the Spiral, and even its purpose. The Millennium Commission turned it down as too nebulously defined to qualify for its help. Borg pressed on regardless, but despite announcing a private donation of £12m last year, the museum is now refusing to be specific either about the exact size and number of donations secured for the project, or to name the donors, even though it says it is confident the Spiral will open in 2005.

But beyond the financial crisis, the V&A has still not managed to address the most fundamental question: what is it for? Is it an institution dedicated to helping industrial manufacturers make better products - as Henry Cole, its progenitor in the wake of the Great Exhibition of 1851, is represented as having seen it, in which case it must continue to adapt, engaging with contemporary design - or is it the greatest collection of decorative art in the world, in which case, the museum's recent interest in collecting twentieth-century design is a distraction.

In the event, the V&A has stumbled on, trying to be all things to all men. It hired architect Michael Hopkins to draw up a master plan to deal with its future growth in the 1980s, when even the roof was leaking. It has now hired another set of consultants, DEGW, best known for having brought the concept of the hot desk to the British office, to tell it how it should deal with the impact of the new British collection and the new Spiral. Given that planning permission has already been granted for the Spiral, it is a case of shutting the stable door far too late.

The Spiral is the product of Borg's belief that he had to seize the chance to build something - anything in fact, so long as it was spectacular - to attract visitors, and to demonstrate that the V&A was still a museum superpower. But quite what it should be used for was another matter. The competition that Daniel Libeskind won in 1998 was intended to come up with a structure that would serve as a new entrance for the whole museum.

But it was only after a year that the museum started to get to grips with exactly what was going to go inside the Spiral. Now they plan a series of galleries dedicated to contemporary design. To help them work out how to go about this, they have commissioned the Guardian 's architecture critic Jonathan Glancey - a sequence of events that inevitably recalls the Millennium Dome's crisis of content. If the idea of the Spiral sounds familiar, it is. The Design Museum has been doing exactly what the Spiral proposes to do for the past 10 years. And even before that, during the Roy Strong years, the Conran Foundation funded the Boilerhouse project at the V&A, a gallery dedicated to contemporary design.

But Strong's jealousy of the Boilerhouse's success - its show on Coca-Cola attracted more visitors than every other gallery in the V&A put together - made for a difficult relationship. So much so that Strong rejected Conran's offer to turn the Boilerhouse into a permanent fixture out of hand. Instead, Conran took his money elsewhere and started the Design Museum at Butler's Wharf.

It was an event that was fatal for the V&A's ambitions to deal with contemporary design. It means that Conran, once a V&A trustee, is implacably opposed to the Spiral. 'For 10 years, we have struggled to do what the Spiral is now proposing to do with the benefit of millions of pounds of tax payers' money, without a penny of public subsidy. We are going to argue forcefully with Chris Smith that the Spiral should not get any public money,' he said. It is not an auspicious start for Borg's successor.

webTitle: All the world's a web - and it's a real tragedy

fields.headline: All the world's a web - and it's a real tragedy
fields.standfirst: Theatre is despised and rejected by the new media, but we need it more than ever
fields.trailText: Theatre is despised and rejected by the new media, but we need it more than ever.
fields.body:
Democracy and theatre were born at the same time in the same place, Athens two-and-a-half millennia ago. It's one of history's most thought-provoking coincidences. Every citizen attended and a prototype of democracy was invented.

Every day a programme of three tragedies tore into the deepest public and private issues of society. This all-day saga under the skies ended with a raucous, irrev erent knees-up, which pilloried gods and leaders, pretensions and beliefs. The questioning spirit of democracy infused the first drama and the first citizens' metropolis in Europe.

Today, the thread connecting theatre and democracy is almost at breaking-point. In a tightly interconnected cyber-world, our electronic Net may deal a fatal blow to theatre and all it implies. The latest digital technology is combining together with neglect, anti-theatrical prejudice and the worship of a shallow 'modernity' to shift people away from the live performance.

Last week, the Arts Council of England published a report, The Next Stage, which recognised the crisis in theatre, accepted that it has been caused by years of underfunding, and asked for £25 million - a rise of more than a third. This does make a change. It shows the Arts Council trying to become, even at the eleventh hour, the artist's friend rather than the tool of government.

Theatre people have seen the crisis coming. Last year, the Theatre Trust, the government watchdog which campaigns to save threatened theatre buildings, sounded the alarm. 'I have a dread,' wrote its director, 'that outside a few major cities we will have seen the slow death of the regional repertory system. Live professional theatre will consist of miked arena opera, two-handers in pubs, American musical imports and pantos with ageing soap stars. The West End will survive, albeit on a restricted and unadventurous scale and classified as a tourist attraction.'

So New Labour's fashionable 'creative industries' hog the spotlight, as canny London producers lure film stars to play the classics, too few regional theatres can afford enough actors to cast a Shakespeare play.

How did things get to this stage? Theatre's traditional opponents have played their part, of course. The controlling puritanism that closed a nation's theatres just a few years after Shakespeare's death underpins the outlook of much of today's political class. Its tidiness is alive and well in the unexceptional digital displays of the Millennium Dome. It is staggering that the great tent meant to house our achievements and aspirations could find no room for live theatre.

The traditional enemies of theatre have been fortified by the populist sneer, which caricatures an entire profession with the unlovely 'luvvies'. Post-modernists write off the whole theatre thing as 'elitist'. Market fundamentalists can't see why all theatre shouldn't be commercial. Decades of putting management and marketing before a democratic justification for theatre have left it bereft of a reply.

To this prejudice must now be added the disdain of the digital world, and global isation's utter lack of interest in the distinctiveness of theatre, which does not sell well across national borders. Hard-core computer 'users' do not easily become that transient community called an audience. If all the world's a web, it becomes harder for its inhabitants to catch the 'form and pressure' of the age which Hamlet exhorted the players to embody.

Two events this month pinpointed the broken contract between stage and citizen, democracy and the values of theatre. In an LSE guest lecture, Benjamin Barber, one of Bill Clinton's more critical advisers, asked 'can democracy survive globalisation?' (and concluded it couldn't). He laid bare the seductive contradictions of the 'global mall' that induces in 'users' a combination of mastery and dependency, which psychologists call infantilism. Globalisation makes us all 'kidults'.

The theatre, conversely, keeps alive our childlike imagination. Two days after Barber's lecture, I watched Tony Harrison's The Mysteries at the National Theatre. The Three Kings came in on camels made of car-tyres, wearing crowns of traffic cones. It was magic - I came away energised and elated.

When I get up from an hour at the keyboard I feel cramped and tired. Theatre may be despised and rejected by the new media, but it still has secret nourishment for us.

 Michael Kustow's theatre@risk is published by Methuen this week

webTitle: It's just one big party. Until the gendarmes show up

fields.headline: It's just one big party. Until the gendarmes show up
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Maybe it was the weather that did for it. The 53rd Cannes Film Festival kicked off not under the piercing blue skies typical of the Riviera in May, but under slate-grey clouds and drenched in drizzle. After a few days the clement weather returned but the slight air of tetchiness and disappointment was harder to dispel.
fields.body:
Maybe it was the weather that did for it. The 53rd Cannes Film Festival kicked off not under the piercing blue skies typical of the Riviera in May, but under slate-grey clouds and drenched in drizzle. After a few days the clement weather returned but the slight air of tetchiness and disappointment was harder to dispel.

It was a mood not relieved by a slate of films generally perceived to be only just north of drab, and a continuing battle between party organisers and the local mayor, who was determined to rain on the parade. Traditionally some of the best and well attended bashes have taken place on the hotel beaches that line the Croisette. But this year Mayor Maurice DeLauney imposed a curfew.

A showdown was inevitable and it arrived with MTV's attempt to ignore the party-pooping politician and dance on. In a stand-off between French local politics and US cultural imperialism the victor was a foregone conclusion, and the gendarmes waded in like angry parents and pulled the plug, leading to scuffles and a general worsening of industry/community relations. It wasn't the Mayor's only unpopular decision. Plans to land a seaplane and stage a Spitfire flypast to promote a forthcoming movie adaptation of Biggles were rejected as 'too noisy' while scantily clad models were barred from parading along the Croisette.

Celebrity turnout was poor, with the Americans still running scared after the risible reception given to Armageddon two years ago. George Clooney, in town to promote the Coen Brothers' Oh Brother Where Art Thou?, was the only really big draw and delighted tourists and locals by signing autographs and having holiday snaps taken.

At the other extreme Tommy Lee Jones chewed up and spat out the journalists unlucky enough to have had to interview him ('That man terrifies me,' whimpered one ashen-faced hack on exiting the star's cabana). Gene Hackman made a fleeting appearance while Gregory Peck arrived with three generations of his family in tow to promote the documentary A Conversation With Gregory Peck.

Uma Thurman, Calista Flockhart and Renee Zellweger also showed up for photocalls. Less impressive was Michael 'Lord Of The Dance' Flatley who announced to whoever would listen to him: 'I may not become a great actor but I've definitely got the makings of a movie star.' Makings, it seems, that include more than a measure of self-confidence.

Brian De Palma did nothing to dispel his famously grumpy reputation at a press conference for the universally panned blockbuster Mission To Mars.

Björk, in town to promote the Lars Von Trier film Dancer In The Dark, allegedly had a spat with her director and failed to turn up at her press conference.

It has also been the first festival to have a distinctly dotcom air, with a plethora of new media firms touting their wares. One of the most prominent, Atomfilms, failed to do itself any favours by hosting a party beset by the unforgivable gaffe of allowing the booze to run out.

It was a slightly downbeat ending to festival director Gilles Jacob's term of office. He becomes president next year, leaving a vacant post already hotly disputed. Whoever finally wins it might want to take the mayor out for an expensive dinner.

webTitle: 'Mom, I blew up the music industry'

fields.headline: 'Mom, I blew up the music industry'
fields.standfirst: Six months ago, Shawn Fanning was just another 19-year-old college kid. Then he invented a piece of software called Napster. Now he's rich, famous, and being sued by his favourite band
fields.trailText: Six months ago, Shawn Fanning was just another 19-year-old college kid. Then he invented a piece of software called Napster. Now he's rich, famous, and being sued by his favourite band.
fields.body:
At 19, Shawn Fanning has a number one haircut, a half-finished degree in computer studies, and is being sued by his favourite band, Metallica. These three facts all contribute to the rather complicated mess Fanning's got himself into, and explain how a nerdy Boston college kid ended up a paper multi-millionaire, an international youth icon, and the centre of a legal storm that will ultimately decide the nature of the music industry's future.

Metallica are suing the company Fanning helped found, Napster Inc, for copyright infringement. This is because of a free piece of software written by Fanning called 'the Napster'. It's simple to download from the Net and makes it easy, for the first time, to get your hands on high-quality copies of chart music for free. Metallica, first among a list of disapproving major artists that includes Elton John, Sean 'Puffy' Combs and Dr Dre, don't like the loss of record sales that this might mean. Conversely, a host of million-selling bands including The Smashing Pumpkins, Hole, The Offspring, Cypress Hill and Limp Bizkit have come out in support of the freedom the Napster grants. A war of words and writs has erupted. And the haircut? Well, that explains how the ridiculous word 'napster' came to be on the lips of media lawyers and music pundits worldwide.

'I was playing basketball with a friend,' begins Fanning, sat on the sunny terrace of an Italian restaurant in the Silicon Valley satellite town of San Mateo. 'We were talking trash back and forth, and at that time my hair was growing out a little bit. He said I had "nappy" hair, because when it grows, it gets all curly. I got really mad at him, so he kept saying it just to piss me off.' Fanning is still sensitive about his hair and takes off his baseball cap to illustrate the next key point. 'Even though I kept my hair very short,' he says, stroking his head as if to remind himself just how much shorter he keeps it now, 'pretty soon it turned into a nickname.'

And so Fanning became the 'Napster'. At first, it was simply the log-on he used when discussing hacking in Internet chat rooms. Now it's in the top 10 most sought-after items on Internet search engines, and a recent survey found that 73 per cent of US students have used it, with more than half using it weekly. What happened between these two events may mark one of the biggest revolutions in music since man first took ecstasy.

What Napster does is find small MP3 files on the Internet. These are copies of digital quality music taken straight from CDs and left online for anyone to download and play on their computer. MP3s have been the bane of music copyrighters for a few years, but they were hard to find, and often didn't work when you got them. Napster has changed all that. It creates a directory of the best MP3s on the Net and leads you straight to them. The Napster has transformed the MP3 from a tech-head pastime into one of the prime social activities of US college life with the potential to explode internationally. And so the music industry has panicked.

Last week a black van arrived at Napster Inc's offices, and dumped 13 boxes of paperwork on its doorstep. These represented the theatrical next stage in a lawsuit from Metallica, who had asked Napster to remove their songs from its directory, saying they were violating the band's copyright. Napster said it would remove the people from the list who were trading the songs, only if Metallica named them individually. So Metallica did just that - and 300,000 names were promptly blacklisted.

'I was defensive of the band when they first filed the suit,' says Fanning. 'I thought perhaps this was industry propaganda and some lawyer capitalising on the controversy - not explaining things to Metallica fully. I got very defensive as I like the music and the band members. Lars Ulrich [drummer and songwriter] has said it's not about money, but control.' Fanning is referring to the fact that many of the songs traded on Napster are demo versions or incomplete songs. Ulrich wants to control who hears what - and when. He says Napster is 'looting our art'.

Napster has several suits against it. One is from the powerful Record Industry Association Of America. In November last year, it announced a suit for 'contributory copyright infringement' because it had noticed that most of the files on Napster were 'purloined'. Dr Dre followed Metallica by handing his list of user names last week to Napster via e-mail. Elton John slammed the lack of 'respect and compensation for creative work' that Napster showed, saying it was 'wrong to promote stealing from artists online'. Sean 'Puffy' Combs said: 'Every artist Napster abuses deserves respect.'

If the RIAA get its way, Napster could be liable for $100,000 damages for each copyright infringement. The total bill could be a sum large enough to bankrupt Bill Gates: Fanning has made powerful enemies. He has his fans, too. 'One of the artists who has publicly come out to support us is Billy Corgan of the Smashing Pumpkins. It's pretty amazing. I'm a big fan and to hear him actually explain how music will evolve online, how this is a good thing for the artist, and present a strong articulate argument - that makes me feel really good,' he says, slurping a Pepsi Max through a straw.

Fanning only got his first computer four years ago. In those years he has had one failed business - an Internet security firm he describes as 'a joke'- and written a piece of software that has catapulted him to the forefront of the intellectual property debate. He now has a small office in San Mateo, where his room - the nerve centre in a firm of 35 - smells of the banana skins that fill the bin and is adorned by a copy of Rolling Stone magazine, propped upright on his desk, with Britney Spears on the cover.

Napster began in 1998 when Fanning was at North West University in Boston. His roommate had an appetite for obscure rap music that he was feed ing with MP3s. Fanning soon picked up on his friend's frustration with MP3s and started work at his uncle's offices on something that might help. With the support of his tutors, he worked obsessively on building the computer code, fearing another company would steal the idea before he had completed it. 'I cut myself off. If I was working on something that took two or three days to implement then I would not sleep for two or three days. I got my energy from the feedback I was getting on chat rooms - and from caffeine.'

The program was released on the Net in January, and Napster soon needed more equipment to meet the demand. Fanning's uncle, John, incorporated the company this month. Since then Fanning has worked flat out. 'I don't have time to party, and if I do I'm afraid I'll lose self-control. Any efforts to establish a relationship with a girl would be pointless as I'm not sleeping much.'

He looks deep into the next glass of Pepsi as he continues coyly. 'It would be nice to have someone to... er, you know... get your mind off of work. But I want to make sure the company is in a great position before I start having fun. It's a huge opportunity because we're really popular in all these schools and it's really tempting to go and party. But I have this fear that if I get caught up it will all fall apart. Maybe I'm overestimating my importance.'

Howard King, lawyer for Metallica and Dr Dre, would not agree. 'This is the fastest-growing site ever,' King says. 'They could raise hundreds of millions of dollars if they decided to offer shares in the company. But the asset of the company is stolen music. There are colleges across the States - where the Napster is particularly popular - whose record stores are going out of business. When we win this case we will put them [Napster] out of business.'

I ask Fanning how he deals with the idea that Napster facilitates the theft of an artist's music. 'I really can't discuss that ,' he says, momentarily distracted by a passing girl. 'It has too many legal implications.' How does he feel about the high stakes of the case? What if he loses? 'It's been a good experience. I've worked as hard as I can, and can't be disappointed. I'm getting burnt out on the whole software development thing. I'm thinking of going back to school. Hanging out, chilling.'

Even if Napster loses, Fanning will have achieved something. 'It's a monumental development,' says Andy Greenwald, online editor of Spin magazine. 'The music industry hyperventilated when home-taping surfaced, but Napster is bigger in its scope. Its very nature - the trading of one song at a time - will place an emphasis on singles. In colleges one song tends to make a hot list, sweep the campus, and then be replaced by another the next week. The most positive thing it that it shows absolute passion in music.' As an LA Times editorial said, Napster is, 'in its purest form, hard-core Sixties: free love, free music'.

Back in Fanning's office, an e-mail has just arrived about a possible front cover of Time magazine. It brings home the scale of what Napster has done and irreversibly will do. And this is something of which Fanning seems both magically and alarmingly unaware.

webTitle: So, Sigmund, why do children suffer?

fields.headline: So, Sigmund, why do children suffer?
fields.standfirst: Freud would have a field day with the new Turn of the Screw
fields.trailText: The Turn of the Screw | Radamisto
fields.body:
The Turn of the Screw New Theatre, Cardiff

Radamisto Grand Theatre, Leeds

Freud is still a writer to be reckoned with. His essay on 'The Uncanny' (1919) deals with man's primitive attitude to death. 'Most likely our fear,' he writes, 'still implies the old belief that the dead man becomes the enemy of his survivor and seeks to carry him off to share his new life with him.' This is as neat a summary as one will find of the anxieties that charge The Turn of the Screw.

In Henry James's novella, a governess struggles to determine whether the children in her care are in the grip of two ghosts - Peter Quint and Miss Jessel - or whether it is she herself who is in their demonic thrall.

James may have written his cryptic tale two decades earlier, but he was fully immersed in the bubbling brew of late nineteenth-century opinion on matters parapsychological out of which Freud would soon emerge. After all, his brother, the philosopher William James, who coined the phrase 'stream of consciousness', argued forcefully for the mutual dependence of the visible and the spiritual world and the powers of the unseen to affect the seen.

Such questions are the crux of The Turn of the Screw . By the time Britten and his librettist, Myfanwy Piper, worked it into an opera in 1954, the tale's ambiguities were now compounded by accretions of a post-Freudian kind, muddied yet further by the composer's own neuroses and his obsessions with haunted isolation and lost innocence.

WNO's penetrating new production by John Crowley, his first in a burgeoning theatrical career, puts such quandaries firmly in perspective. His primary concern is with making good theatre rather than with providing answers to these endlessly fascinating questions. Whereas Deborah Warner's stunning production for the Royal Opera House underlined the sense of collective evil, Crowley's approach is, or gives a clever impression of being, hands-off. Either reading is viable. Britten's miraculous score makes of the strong, slim structure of Piper's text its own elusive play of light and shadow, here wonderfully captured in Paul Pyant's flickeringly atmospheric lighting.

The characters in this strong cast interact with cool austerity and, in the children's case, normal if innocuous mischief. While Warner's governess was hyper-nervy and credibly evil (a memorable Joan Rodgers), Janice Watson here plays her as strikingly impassive, barely smiling at her new charges when she first meets them, her anxieties (mirrored in jittery violin writing) all internalised. Even at the moment of crisis, she retains a vestige of self-control, thus blurring the borders of madness and sanity and giving us the option of believing in her innate goodness.

Crowley and his designer, Rob Howell, whose ingenious movable platform manages to suggest a range of places from tower to lake, have observed Britten's wish that the interludes between scenes should be marked simply by darkness and gauzes. This would have been even more effective were not the ambient light in Cardiff's New Theatre quite so bright.

Nevertheless, this was a gripping evening, with Paul Nilon a mesmerisingly aloof yet full-blooded Quint and Geraldine McGreevy's Miss Jessel disturbingly friendly (and bearing an uncanny resemblance to the governess; is this her future too?). Gregory Monk, aged 12, had the perfect combination of knowing innocence as Miles, with Yvette Bonner a primly charming Flora. WNO's chamber ensemble showed verve and bite under the baton of Carlo Rizzi (whose imminent departure as the company's musical director has recently been announced).

Finally, praise to the compiler of the programme book, always a strong point at WNO, done without fuss. To publish here for the first time the letters of the first Miles, David Hemmings, to Britten was a real coup.

The current craze for Handel operas, redressing two- and-a-half centuries of neglect, has gone too far. I confess to Handel fatigue and now peer gingerly at each new opera schedule to see how many lurk there.

Radamisto, his 1720 opera for London, is a brave choice for any non-specialist opera house. This long, unsmiling work, despite many sizzling numbers, shows the composer at his most solemn. For audiences unused to the noble gestures and high-mindedness of baroque opera seria , it makes a tough evening and one short on jokes.

Moreover, for Handel purists, the clumsy, if well-intentioned attempts of directors to offer a way into this highly stylised art form almost guarantees an air of first-night gloom (not helped on this occasion by several technical mishaps); those keenest to hear it are most visibly and volubly disappointed. Tim Hopkins, though he tried valiantly to create a modern idiom to cope with the difficulties, hadn't entirely found a solution. He is hardly the first. At least the manic activity which has dogged so many recent ENO Handel productions was avoided.

Too much was replaced by not enough. Asia Minor circa AD51, in Charles Edwards's designs, has become a vorticist no-man's-land of aggressive bold lines and sharp angles (with some modish, square-cut costumes).

A room within the set, all wonky lines and false perspective, gave the characters an unfortunate oversized appearance of having fallen down the rabbit hole and eaten Alice's small cake. But the futurist connection was reasonable, and pointed up the ugly violence of the plot, a story taken from Tacitus, whose complexities nearly defy précis but which include the standard ingredients of secret passion, revenge and redemption.

Musical standards were high. Harry Bicket, conducting, drew clean, muscular playing from the English Northern Philharmonia. All the women were good, especially Alice Coote and Emma Bell. Yet, however grand the score - and Handel's invariably are - three-and-a-half hours is too long to watch almost nothing happening.

webTitle: Real women can be cover girls too

fields.headline: Real women can be cover girls too
fields.standfirst: Liz Jones, the editor of Marie Claire, is a former anorexic. Here she argues that women's magazines should be more responsible about the models they use
fields.trailText: Liz Jones, the editor of Marie Claire, is a former anorexic. Here she argues that women's magazines should be more responsible about the models they use.
fields.body:
For a very long time, the fashion industry has been exploiting young girls. As a former anorexic, I couldn't be party to anything that was harmful to vulnerable young girls.

So when I became editor of Marie Claire , I decided to take a serious look at the images of women we see around us - and get people talking about it. My view was that men get lots of different role models in the media, but for women it's mostly models with tiny bodies whose heads look too big.

I also wanted to find out what kind of women our readers wanted in their magazine. So we put out two different covers which are the same in every way - both models are blonde and naked - except that one model is bigger than the other. There's been a huge response and what the letters, faxes and e-mails are saying is, resoundingly, that they don't want to see women who look ill because they're too thin. We won't stop using beautiful women under a certain size - we will just use a greater variety of models. We have also started using black and Asian models, and older women too.

As a young girl, I was addicted to magazines like Marie Claire. My house was full of them, and I knew all the models' names. I was in love with models and wanted to be like them. That was reality for me - as it is for many young girls now. Because of this, I felt unattractive and inadequate. I didn't measure up to them, and I so wanted to. I'm sure it had an effect on my eating. There was also TV: I wanted to be Jaclyn Smith from Charlie's Angels. It's like that with pop stars too these days; they all conform to the same ideal and they're getting so much younger. Think of the pressure that puts on young girls.

Even now, still, if I see Gisele walking down the catwalk when I'm at a fashion show I can still find myself thinking: 'I want to be like that.'

It takes a long time to get over the psychological effects of eating disorders - I still don't let my boyfriend see me without my T-shirt - and I had blackout blinds fitted in my bedroom so that he couldn't see my body too clearly in the daylight.

It's like that with pop stars too these days; they all conform to the same ideal and they're getting so much younger. Think of the pressure that puts on young girls. Even now, still, if I see Gisele walking down the catwalk when I'm at a fashion show I can still find myself thinking: 'I want to be like that.' It takes a long time to get over the psychological effects of eating disorders - I still don't let my boyfriend see me without my T-shirt - and I had blackout blinds fitted in my bedroom so that he couldn't see my body too clearly in the daylight.

fields.standfirst:
Susan Sontag has survived the terrors of Sarajevo, cancer and a horrific car crash to come back with an acclaimed new novel. One of America's intellectual icons, here she talks frankly about her life and work, her radical attitude to her illness - and the virtues of ginger ice cream

fields.body:
Imagine an author embarking on her second major novel, about a Polish actress who emigrates to America. Plot is charted, characters sketched, when the plans for writing are thrown off track. First by war: our writer spends the best part of three years in, or else immersed in the cause of, the besieged Bosnian capital Sarajevo - where you are never out of range, where The End lurks over your shoulder day and night. The war over, she returns to New York and to her book, only to be injured in a car crash, 13 bones fractured. They take months to mend, during which time it is almost impossible to write, but eventually our author resumes work on her book.

Before long, however, doctors diagnose cancer. Unable to write while taking morphine for crippling pain, she is again obliged to shelve the project. Finally, the disease is driven into remission and she returns to writing.

There are many authors who might by now have adapted their subject matter to something more obviously self-centred, but the original themes of this novel, published in the UK next month, remain unchanged. In America - completed in two years but over an eight-year period - is still the book about an emigrant Polish actress called Maryna Zalezowska.

Not only that, of course; it is the story of one rather magnificent woman's waltz with time and place, between her public and private lives, between men - and above all with her adoptive America. It is about her discovery of the country which embraced the author's own family from Poland two generations ago, at a time when, she writes, 'history is roaring by, turning itself into geography; open land as far as the mind can see'. A country where a woman can say: 'I have set my heart against the past. America is good for that.'

Susan Sontag walks the little streets of New York's Chinatown under fire escapes that cascade down the sides of buildings. A warm springtime breeze blows through the badger-like streak of silver hair that makes her so immediately distinctive. Delicacies tumble out of shops on to the sidewalk; Sontag stops and chooses two boxes of duck eggs. This is her favourite quarter of town, which makes subliminal sense: her father, a silk merchant, died while on business in China.

Sontag is excited that a Taiwanese fast-food chain is opening a branch here, selling 'delicious, gummy fruit drinks'. As we walk, she explains why her new book is not about her remarkable decade just past. 'I prefer to live my life,' she says, 'and write about other things. There are writers for whom all experience is material, so that all they really do in the world is write. But there are things I want to do in the world that I can't or don't want to write. I have to be able to stop and pat a child on the head without wondering how it is going to fit into a book.'

Both real-life Sontag and Sontag in books seem to be around every corner. At one point, life had me commuting between Naples and Bosnia; between the Vesuvian city where Sontag set (and I therefore had to read) her first major novel, The Volcano Lover - about Emma Hamilton's affair with Lord Nelson - and Sarajevo, where Sontag was then directing a production of Waiting for Godot under shellfire. Coming to America to set my own heart against the past, I chance upon her or her books with gratifying regularity and almost always by coincidence. And now we're in Chinatown, where she wants to ensure a taste of the best exotic ice cream (her favourite flavour is coconut but the ginger turns out to be even better).

Sontag is ageless in as much as she is a literary grande dame whose work has none the less grown youthful - from the austere asceticism of earlier essays to the often playful sensuality of The Volcano Lover and now In America , whose heroines she both resembles and does not. She is like that Bob Dylan line: 'I was so much older then, I'm younger than that now.' 'Then' was an 'older' past which seemed to bypass childhood and adolescence.

Sontag was born in New York in 1933. She fell in love with Shostakovich, Bartók and the Partisan Review as a teenager in Los Angeles. She went to Chicago University aged 15, 'loved being a student', and after two years married sociology lecturer Philip Rieff who surfaces in the new novel as a character called Casaubon. The two trophies Sontag carried away from the marriage of nine years were, in order of importance, her son David and the distinction of being the only woman in Californian history to refuse alimony. For a while she lived astride Paris and New York, before settling in the latter.

She loves the city she still lives in, and no wonder: her apartment above the meatpacking district has views in every direction of the most audacious urban project mankind has ever undertaken. The interior is lined with what must amount to a mile of books, organised so that Goethe is in the room where she recently installed a piano (having begun lessons at the age of 66); Giotto in the corridor and Umberto Eco next to the kitchen. But, she says, 'the thing that is most American in me' has nothing to do with New York. It is to do with 'a love of self-reinvention, the idea that you can become another person, change your life, be reborn. It's very European to think that you can never escape your past.'

This is over dim sum in a place where they know little or no English but know Susan Sontag as well as she knows their shrimp rolls. There is another American quality, in contrast to Europe, which she describes in her book: 'In America, you are expected to exhibit the confusions of inner vehemence... and have eccentric foibles and extravagant needs which exhibit the force of your will, your appetitiveness, the spread of your self-regard - all excellent things.' In other words, to splurge your complex and lusty private life all over the place.

Sontag does not really think this is all 'excellent', since there is one place her conversation will not go. She and Annie Liebovitz have become a New York institution, usually out in each other's company, and the database files are brimful with attempts by interviewers trying to find out more. We all have to use the same phrase: 'reticent about her private life'. One can infer whatever one wants to, but anyone privy to the truth probably wouldn't write it anyway. There are a variety of celebrated women who command a singular and protective loyalty around them, whose friends are like the military wing of a political organisation - women like Hillary Clinton, Joan Baez and, without doubt, Susan Sontag.

Perhaps logically, then, Sontag once wrote an essay called 'Against Interpretation', as much manifesto for herself as Kantian text. Although a philosopher, she does not like talking in interpretive abstracts about what she calls 'the result of experiences about which I don't think much. I'm interested in the experience, not in any particular moral meaning to experience. I don't worry about life after death, only life before death.' A life for which she has often feared, not least in Bosnia.

'I went to Sarajevo,' she says at lunch, 'initially out of some attachment to Europe. What was happening in Rwanda was far worse than Bosnia, but I found it unbelievable that in modern Europe there could be genocide and death camps 50 years after the end of the Second World War. I went as a self-appointed volunteer to do whatever people wanted me to do. They happened to want me to do theatre. I didn't want to go as a writer or for any reason to do with wickedness or goodness. I'm a very restless person and I have a high tolerance for discomfort. Most people prefer to be comfortable, but I think comfort isolates. It means they're not going to know much about the world are they? And when discomfort or illness or even death happen, they have this idea that it's not fair.'

Like all of us who were in Bosnia, she adds: 'And if you have never seen a war at first hand, then you've missed out on a very important aspect of human experience and existence.' For Sontag, however, war was not the only 'discomfort'.

Cancer still enjoys a primitive, medieval aura in modern society - people talk about the disease as though it were one of the four riders of the Apocalypse rather than something treatable and beatable. So if - as happened to me 18 months ago - doctors find something they do not like the look of, once again one needs to locate Sontag, this time in an essay of 1978 called 'Illness as Metaphor'.

In the seventies, Sontag was diagnosed with breast cancer and, against her doctor's advice, went to France for chemotherapy. It worked; the cancer was beaten back. Sontag, however, was not content to beat just the disease. She went on to rail against a language written by such favourites as Baudelaire (as well as the Nazis) which equates disease with social decay and vice-versa. Sontag's essay liberated 'patients' (she reminds us of the etymological origins of the word) from the stigmas around cancer, and from the idiotic but stubborn notion that 'the cure can be worse than the disease'.

By the time 'Illness as Metaphor' was published, another disease was coming to share with cancer the burden of stigma and melodramatic language, and Sontag wrote a kind of supplement to her cancer essay, a compassionate and passionate document entitled 'Aids and Its Metaphors'. Next time you find someone with either disease, cock your head to one side to inspect the spines of their books and if they do not own these essays, buy them a copy.

Then came Sontag's second, recent, need to defy cancer once again. She recalls it as she does Sarajevo, with her indelible humanism and few judgements to make. 'It was part of the journey. I would never describe cancer as a "learning experience" and I don't know how to use the word "solace". You have to mobilise what resources you have, and you are with other people. You have very intense experiences with people who are ill and around you. In the chemo room at the hospital, it isn't just me - there's someone over there who is vomiting, someone there talking to her husband. It is reality - and you know, it is so easy to shut out reality. I want to take in as much reality as I can.'

In her new novel, Sontag describes Maryna Zalezowska and her husband as 'people of active conscience', which is a good description of her too. For underpinning her world of people is that of politics, in which Sontag is irrevocably involved, be it out of contempt for her mayor, Rudy Giuliani, or in reflection upon the left-wing ideology that propelled her youth.

Earlier this year, cultural New York was captivated by the figure of Dmitri Shostakovich. The Emerson Quartet performed a cycle of string quartets and the Metropolitan Opera staged Lady Macbeth of Mtensk, about lust, murder and the oppression of womanhood. All this meant bumping into Sontag once again. The cycle was for me a culmination of decades of interest in the composer, and at every single performance the audience was spliced by that dash of silver hair, always accompanied by the towering figure of Annie Liebovitz.

Sontag calls Shostakovich 'the real thing, as artist and politically'. Like him and the American Left of her own generation, Sontag felt the presence of Marxism but was appalled by its expressions. She was a vociferous opponent of the Vietnam War and embargo against Cuba, but was later captivated by the spectacle of real revolution - spawned in her family home of Poland - on the streets of our own lifetime which pitched the people not against capitalism but against communism. Eastern Europe's uprising was a very Sontag-ish meeting between personal and political - a political movement, indeed, based upon getting politics out of people's lives.

There was a famous meeting at New York Town Hall in 1992, during the Soviet-backed crackdown on the Solidarnosc movement at which she told a crowd of leftists eager to jump on the Polish union's coat-tails that she thought the pages of the conservative Readers Digest had portrayed communism more accurately than those of the left-wing Nation . She called the Soviet bloc 'fascism with a human face'. Now Sontag says she 'would not use the word "socialism" in any shape or form. In fact I don't really know what it means.' But the wheel has turned and it is time again to worry about capitalism.

'I am astounded and depressed at how the logic of capitalism has become so imperial. There's so little motivating people in America other than making money - I was talking to a friend from Canada who said that her people were not as interested as here in making it, as though that was a problem. I think it is better to try and find other satisfactions... No, I don't think the revolutions in Eastern Europe were motivated by wanting this. They were motivated by a strong idea of bourgeois civil liberties, and power to them!'

Sontag's insatiable interests and infectious enthusiasms seem to know no frontier. Despite her concern over hyper-capitalism, she is enthralled by computers: 'Like it or not, they are here to stay.' And by cyberlife, even cybersex. 'A friend of mine is a heterosexual,' she says, 'has a cyberlife as a gay man, exchanging fantasies with gay men - if that is what they really are! And I wonder what the limits of such relationships are - is it, for instance, permissible to get jealous?'

We're now back at the apartment and her assistants have just set up the software for a new machine. Sontag insists on a CD matinee show - A Bug's Life . She loves the high-definition on screen. 'Have you seen Toy Story 2 ? she asks. 'Oh you should. I went one afternoon, the place full of kids - marvellous movie.' Then we go back to talking about Shostakovich.

webTitle: Who would be in his boots?

fields.headline: Who would be in his boots?
fields.standfirst: Fear, hope, self-loathing... the penalty kick is as near perfect an allegory of the human condition as life can offer. Three decades after a memorable boyhood triumph, one man puts himself on the spot again
fields.trailText: Fear, hope, self-loathing... the penalty kick is as near perfect an allegory of the human condition as life can offer. Three decades after a memorable boyhood triumph, one man puts himself on the spot again
fields.body:
Is th penalty a metaphor for the indecision of modern life or simply an easy way of scoring a goal? I think it's safe to assume that this question was not in the forefront of David Batty's mind when he walked up to take his ill-conceived penalty against Argentina in the 1998 World Cup. Certainly, there was nothing in the stoic demeanour of the Yorkshireman to suggest that he viewed that penalty shoot-out as anything but a penalty shoot-out. Whatever it meant to Batty, it wasn't a workshop on existential doubt.

The obvious answer to why Batty missed is that Carlos Roa, the Argentinian goalkeeper, saved his shot. The man himself, I imagine, would appreciate that sort of blunt logic. To reduce the penalty to this simple exchange, however, is to miss something vital, aside from the goal.

The appeal of the penalty lies ostensibly in its orchestrated suspense. We know something is going to happen but we don't know what it will be. For this reason, some critics have found the penalty shoot-out a contrived drama, an absurd ordeal. One sportswriter compared it to bad art. No doubt there is an element of melodrama in shoot-outs, especially when they are truly gripping, but it is rarely cheap melodrama, if only because failure comes at such a price.

I would go so far as to say that the shoot-out is as near perfect an allegory of the human condition as sport offers. Of course, the field is rich in experiential metaphors, with all the triumphs and disasters, winners and losers, and countless other stupefying clichés that make up the world of competitive games. The beauty of the penalty, though, is that it powerfully represents the fear and the hope, and the regret or relief, that are compressed into the meaningful junctures of life. For a brief period, the game stops and the penalty-taker enters his own chamber of truth, a place where actions have ineluctable consequences. The penalty shoot-out goes even further. In its combination of individual choice and collective responsibility, it attains an almost moral significance.

The metaphysics of the penalty were first explored by Peter Handke. His novel, Die Angst des Tormanns beim Elfmeter or The Goalie's Anxiety at the Penalty Kick, was published in 1970, the year that penalty shoot-outs were introduced to an indifferent world. Fittingly, it was a German film director, Wim Wenders, who took up the idea in his 1971 adaptation of Handke's book. I say fittingly because Wenders's countrymen have excelled at the penalty's physics ever since, with one notable exception. The West German national side lost the final of the 1976 European Nations Cup in a shoot-out. Subsequently, the Germans have won four major shoot-outs, in which, put together, they have missed just one solitary penalty kick.

Footballers have many impressive qualities - bravery, stamina, determination - but decision-making, like verbal eloquence, is seldom one of them. It's simply not something they're used to doing. The choices players make on the pitch - run or mark, shoot or pass, elbow or headbutt - are nothing more than micro-decisions, instant reactions, impulses. Real decisions, big decisions, the kind that demand or, worse, afford time and thought, are something to be taken care of by the manager, or the agent, the adviser or the wife. I mention this with all the humility and sympathy of a man who would rather find out what's on Sky Sports 3 than come to a firm decision about almost anything.

Decision-making, if we are honest, is a mournfully oppressive business. The human spirit may crave freedom, but it recoils from choice. To commit to one option - to live with a certain person rather than another, say, or to go to this New Year's Eve party and not that one - is to confront the irreversibility of time.

In this sense, to make a choice in life is to recognise the inevitability of death. That's why we procrastinate, or attempt to suspend the moment of decision, for as long as we can. And frequently longer if we happen to be male.

'It's very close when you're standing there,' said Bob Wilson, the former Arsenal keeper turned TV pundit who is also the England number one David Seaman's goalkeeping coach. 'If you walk out in the cold light of day in the stadium with no one around and you put the ball on the spot and you stand facing the goal, you seriously think, well, it's impossible to miss.'

My motives for the visit were twofold: I wanted to talk to Bob about penalties, and more than that, I wanted to engage his help in setting up a mini-contest with Seaman, in which I could test my own penalty-taking abilities against arguably the world's best. Bob, to his immense credit, immediately warmed to the idea and promised to sell it to Seaman at their next coaching session.

As agreed, I called Bob a week after my visit.

'No, he can't do it. Insurance.'

'Sorry?'

'What if you were to break his finger?'

Of course.

I later phoned Seaman's business agent, his wife, to see if he'd have a word with me about the art of saving penalties. She told me that he would prefer not to, because at some time in the future he planned to do his own book on penalties. In which case, I feel it is only fair that I take the opportunity right now to state, without bitterness, that I shall not be available to take penalties when he needs someone to test him.

I'd wanted to take on Seaman for obvious reasons: because he was the England goalkeeper in the last two tournaments that ended in shoot-outs and, it appeared, he would maintain that position in the next tournament, Euro 2000. He is also a very fine penalty-saver. But not necessarily the best penalty-saver. Statistically, that award would have to go to Mark Crossley of Nottingham Forest. A 31-year-old goalkeeper who has not benefited from the most consistent good fortune in his career, Crossley has, nevertheless, enjoyed what might seem the luck only to have faced 13 penalties in the top flight - the old First Division, the Premier League and FA Cup. That's almost a 65per cent record, more than double the average of Premiership goalkeepers.

Initially, the word from Forest was that Crossley would talk but he wouldn't stand in goal for me. I then spoke to Crossley. He was open, down-to-earth, interested and helpful. 'Well, if you can come up to the training ground,' he said. 'you can take a few pens with me.'

This is where it all began, in Nottingham. Every schoolboy used to know that Notts County is the world's oldest club, founded in 1862. If you walk for about 10 minutes along the towpath by the River Trent you come to Nottingham Forest's training ground. I didn't take the towpath, a mistake that would cause me severe distress later on. Instead, I crossed the park from the other side and was pleased to see a figure I recognised as Mark Crossley diving about a goal not far from the perimeter fence.

I was about to gesture towards Mark when I suddenly heard a teammate call him 'Norm'. So this wasn't Crossley? Jesus, I thought, they have another keeper who's a dead ringer. How confusing. I tried a couple of waves but received no response. Now I was in something of a quandary. Should I walk over to the other end of the pitch and look for another Crossley? What if there was no other Crossley? The training session was due to end any minute and the original Crossley might have gone by the time I made it back to him. I decided to stick with this Crossley and see what happened. He made a couple of superb saves during a five-a-side game, flying through the air and bending the ball round the post. 'Great save, Norm,' said one of the coaches.

Looking down at the turf, I noted with alarm that it was chewed up and soft from the previous night's rain. I then looked up and noted with even greater alarm that Mark or Norm or whoever he was had gone. The session was over and the players were walking away. I slipped effortlessly and immediately into absolute panic.

'Mark!' I shouted six or seven times, but he couldn't hear me. He was either too far away or not Mark or both. I ran round the top of the perimeter to where I thought the entrance would be. But when I got there, I came up against a barrier of razor wire. That meant I would now have to run around three sides of the vast playing fields, which were about half the size of Nottinghamshire.

The only exercise I had endured for the previous three months was turning on the computer each morning with my middle finger. For some reason, I was also wearing two coats, as well as carrying my kitbag.

What seemed like a month later, I was on the towpath, skidding precariously on my studs. I could see Mark or Norm a couple of hundred yards up ahead. I wanted to shout, but that would have required breath and energy. Instead, I let out a high-pitched whine. Luckily, the guy walking with Mark/Norm must have possessed the hearing of bat, because he drew his companion's attention to the disturbing noise. The goalkeeper looked momentarily baffled. Even now, I dread to imagine what thoughts flickered across his mind as he looked back at this figure with two coats, panting by the side of the river.

Anyhow, he came back and shook my hand. It was Crossley. I learned later that Norm was a nickname given to him years ago by Stuart Pearce on account of a supposed resemblance to Norman Whiteside, the former Manchester United midfielder of celebrated hardness and legendary thirst. The name stuck.

'Right then,' he said. 'Are you ready to do it now?'

What I was ready for was an oxygen tent and a glucose drip.

'Yeah,' I gasped. 'Great.'

We returned to the training field. There was a handful of players collecting balls and messing around. Effectively, the place was empty. But as Gary Lineker once said: 'It's not about the crowd, it's about the technique.'

As I turned to face perhaps the finest penalty-saving goalkeeper in the business, my thoughts were not entirely untroubled by doubt. This was going to be only the second spot kick I had ever taken - the first being some 27 years ago. But I needed to be positive. And, without wishing to boast, there was good cause to be positive. I had scored from that penalty three decades before.

It wasn't just any penalty, either. Television cameras were there to record the event. In the 1972-73 season, I was playing for my class team in what was then known as the fourth year at Rhyl Street primary school in Kentish Town, north London. Actually, every boy in my class played for the team. Selection was based solely on being in my class and not a girl. Our greatest rivals - strictly speaking, our only rivals - were the team from the other class in the fourth year. We played them each morn ing before school and every lunchtime - or 'dinnertime' as we called it then.

The games took place on what was known as a 'bomb debris site' about 100 yards from the school. Unbeknown to us, the wasteland had become the focus of a struggle between an idealistic hippie organisation which wanted to develop a community centre there and, I think, the local council, which owned the site. Anyway, Thames Television became interested and sent along a reporter and cameraman to do a story.

When we arrived at the clearing to resume the daily contest with our implacable opponents, the media were waiting. 'Listen,' said the bloke with the camera, 'don't take any notice of us. Just play your normal game.' Our 'normal game' usually resulted in a score of, say, 13-11 or 18-14. Goals were not a problem. There was no precedent for a nil-nil draw.

But due to our manic need to shine in front of the television camera, the match was goalless with a couple of minutes to go. No one passed the ball and whenever anyone had it everyone tried to tackle him, including his own teammates. Scoring a goal was not the point. Getting into frame was the only concern.

And then somebody clattered into me in the penalty box. I can't remember through what powers of arbitration a penalty was awarded, only that it was.

I wrestled the ball away from the m lée and placed it on the spot , determined to gain what was rightfully mine; I was, after all, the one who had been fouled. My determination was born of the certain knowledge that if I scored, the penalty - the game's only goal - would be shown later that evening on television. On television, where Tottenham Hotspur and Manchester United appeared. On television. In colour.

'Keep your head down,' said a voice inside me. I ran up and cracked the thing as hard as I could. Such was my resolve to obey the injunction that I did not look up in time to be sure if the ball had gone in or not. But my success was confirmed by my classmates shouting and racing after me. I had, of course, already taken off, consumed by the glory of the moment and the adulation of the camera and the instinct to run.

When I got home, I told everyone and we gathered round to watch the report after the six o'clock news. There was an interminable interview with some or other faceless bureaucrat, followed by an even longer one with well-meaning long hair. Cut to a three-second shot of a few indistinguishable kids - but definitely not including me - walking across the tarmac, and then back to the stiff and the freak moaning on.

And that was it. No penalty. No goal. No television fame. At such a tender age, I had experienced the special pressures of the penalty kick and the ruthless demands of television.

Crossley stood in the goal, a forbidding presence, although not one that appeared impassable...

fields.headline: Can I deny her refuge?
fields.trailText: I am a 40-year-old woman and own my own house. Eighteen months ago, I rented a room to a young man. For eight months, he has been seeing a married woman whose husband has a history of violence.
fields.body:
I am a 40-year-old woman and own my own house. Eighteen months ago, I rented a room to a young man. For eight months, he has been seeing a married woman whose husband has a history of violence. She has often taken refuge in my home after being severely beaten by him and I have never objected, although it has made me uncomfortable. Recently, the husband has been making threatening phone calls and has come to the house brandishing a knife, threatening both my lodger and his girlfriend.

My dilemma is that although I feel terrible about the way she is being treated, I do not feel I should be risking my own safety. Am I being selfish or should I insist that the lodger moves out?

C.A. READING

I have a particular sympathy for the conflict between head and heart in the midst of which you find yourself. Your conscience, sense of duty and solidarity, as well as your no doubt vociferous feminist friends, will direct you to continue to provide a sanctuary for this traumatised lady.

By contrast, you will be prey to a more primitive and probably more insistent message, that you, too, are a lone, vulnerable female, that your home should be a safe haven where you can find peace and serenity, and that you do not expect someone else's troubles to be brutally dumped in the middle of it. The territorial instinct in all of us is deep-seated, going back aeons.

This does not mean that it should automatically direct one's behaviour, but it is difficult to resist. The sanctity of a person's home is a basic human right. Your lodger and his girlfriend can lay claim to such a right, but not at your expense.

No doubt the woman has had a rough time, but she also has a responsibility to make a clear choice between the two men, and so minimise the attendant violence. Battered wives receive much sympathy and a high profile nowadays, and I expect you have been pressurised by politically-correct opinion that you should continue to help her. Have you ever noticed that the path of rectitude is one which other people are expected to follow? A theoretical good option which is right when dictated to others, but less clear when it comes home to self?

I am going to seize the courage of my convictions here and assert that if I were in such a position I would ask the lodger politely and very firmly to leave and soon - before any more threats occurred. Anticipate and block any manipulation which might appeal to your 'better nature'. Selfish? Yes, who isn't? But you are certainly less so than the lodger and the aggressive husband and, possibly, even the battered, two-timing wife.

Reader's replies:

It is totally acceptable if your safety is being endangered through no fault of your own, more so within your own home. As a landlady, you are entitled to influence and it is your choice as to how to exercise this power. The marital difficulties of your lodger's partner do not belong in your house, and it is appropriate to ask him to move on if he maintains the current situation.
N.G. of Wiltshire

 I had a relationship with a woman whose husband was violent. I had my own house for her to flee to, but my young son also lived there. Our affair lasted five months. During that time, I was repeatedly threatened by her husband. When I attempted to call the police, my girlfriend begged me not to press charges. She returned to him, he beat her again, she came back to me. By this time, I realised that she actually enjoyed seeing two men fight over her. I ended the relationship. I cannot know what your lodger's girlfriend's agenda is, but if I were you I would seek to remove these people and their unsavoury lives from my home.
R.E. of Frome

Next week's dilemma is from M. C. of London

When I first met and fell in love with my husband, I was 20 and he was 44, married and the father of two grown-up daughters (19 and 21). But we were very much in love and married three years later.

Eleven years on, we have a beautiful nine-year-old son. I still love my husband but we have grown apart, particularly after he had a minor heart attack five years ago. He recovered but it changed him. I feel very attracted to a man I've met at work. He's single, about my age and also attracted to me. I am very tempted to have an affair, even leave my husband and start a new life with my son.

However, I can't forget what my husband gave up for me. His daughters haven't spoken to him since he left their mother for me. We know through others that both girls are married with children, but my husband's attempts at a reconciliation have been rejected.

How can I leave and still live with myself? Sometimes I wonder whether they would acknowledge him again if I was out of the picture. I would welcome your advice.

 Write to Observer Review or e-mail margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on next week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

He's single, about my age and also attracted to me. I am very tempted to have an affair, even leave my husband and start a new life with my son. However, I can't forget what my husband gave up for me. His daughters haven't spoken to him since he left their mother for me. We know through others that both girls are married with children, but my husband's attempts at a reconciliation have been rejected. How can I leave and still live with myself? Sometimes I wonder whether they would acknowledge him again if I was out of the picture. I would welcome your advice.  Write to Observer Review or e-mail margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on next week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

webTitle: Halliwell 1, Adams 0 in screen star race

fields.headline: Halliwell 1, Adams 0 in screen star race
fields.trailText: Harvey Weinstein's powers of persuasion are well documented, but he surpassed himself in luring Daniel Day Lewis back to the screen after a four-year hiatus. The formidable Miramax Studios boss signed Day Lewis after Robert De Niro pulled out of Martin Scorsese's gangster epic Gangs of New York. In hospital for a minor operation, Weinstein wooed the actor by phone from his hospital bed, prompting cynical rumours that he had fallen foul of a phantom illness to secure the sympathy vote. Certainly not, Weinstein said, but added, 'If I had needed to, I would.'

Bjork and the All Saints enjoyed a degree of critical success for their acting efforts in Cannes and they could be followed by various members of the Spice Girls (past and present). Geri Halliwell will star in Therapy, a comedy about a woman who falls in love with her therapist. She described it as 'Working Girl meets Sex in the City meets Alfie'.

Meanwhile, Victoria Adams is still waiting for her screen break after being courted - and rejected - by Hollywood suitors. She admitted having screen tests for leading roles in Tomb Raider and Charlie's Angels but failed to win either part. Elsewhere in Cannes Greg Kinnear revealed an affinity with the media scrum. The former cable television reporter recalled a working visit to the festival which made the hacks chuckle. He said 'I remember the look of fear on Anthony Quinn's face as I lunged in front of him with microphone.'
